begin to emerge.\n\nMost Read from Bloomberg\n\nThe region's heat index values -- a measure of how hot it feels when humidity is factored in -- are forecast to be as high as 106F (41C), the US Actual temperatures wi"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Houston"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}, "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Science/Earth_Sciences/Atmospheric_Sciences", "label": "dmoz/Science/Earth Sciences/Atmospheric Sciences", "wgt": 69}, {"uri": "dmoz/Business/Electronics_and_Electrical/Substation_and_Transmission", "label": "dmoz/Business/Electronics and Electrical/Substation and Transmission", "wgt": 16}, {"uri": "news/Politics", "label": "news/Politics", "wgt": 77}], "articleCounts": {"eng": 131}, "sentiment": -0.2156862745098039}
{"uri": "2024-07-415614622", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "00:42:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T00:42:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T00:32:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9607843160629272, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/beryl-weakens-to-tropical-depression-after-slamming-into-texas-as-category-1-hurricane/article_df161859-2993-57e7-b6c9-14d9faaa16cc.html", "title": "Beryl weakens to tropical depression after slamming into Texas as Category 1 hurricane", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- After Tropical Storm Beryl slammed into Texas early Monday, knocking out power to nearly 3 million homes and businesses and killing several people it moved east and weakened to a tropical depression, the National Hurricane Center said Monday evening. Flooding, rains and tornadoes were possible across portions of eastern Texas, Western Louisiana and Arkansas.\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nHOUSTON (AP) -- Tropical Storm Beryl slammed into Texas on Monday, knocking out power to nearly 3 million homes and businesses and unleashing heavy rains that prompted dozens of high-water rescues. The fast-moving tempest threatened to carve a harsh path over several more states in coming days.\n\nTexas state and local officials warned it could take several days to restore power after Beryl came ashore as a Category 1 hurricane and toppled 10 transmission lines and knocked down trees that took down power lines.\n\nWithin hours, Beryl had weakened into a tropical storm, far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean last weekend. But the winds and rains of the fast-moving storm were still powerful enough to knock down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in water-saturated earth, and strand dozens of cars on flooded roadways.\n\nAs it moved inland, the storm still threatened to spawn tornados.\n\n\"We're not past any difficult conditions,\" said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country, warning it would be a \"multiple day process to get power restored.\"\n\nHouston took a hard hit as CenterPoint Energy reported more than 2 million homes and businesses without power in and around the nation's fourth-largest city. Patrick said the company was bringing in thousands of additional workers to restore power, with top priority for places such as nursing homes and assisted living centers.\n\nAt least two people were killed when trees fell on homes, and the National Hurricane Center said damaging winds and flash flooding would continue as Beryl pushes inland. A third person, a civilian employee of the Houston Police Department, was killed when he was trapped in flood waters under a highway overpass, Houston Mayor John Whitmire said. There were no immediate reports of widespread structural damage, however.\n\nThe loss of power was an all-too familiar experience for Houston: Powerful storms had just ripped through the area in May, killing eight people, leaving nearly 1 million without power and flooding numerous streets.\n\nResidents without power after Beryl were doing their best.\n\n\"We haven't really slept,\" said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in her neighborhood in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio, 67, said she had already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\n\n\"We are struggling to have food and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.\n\nHouston and Harris County officials said power crews would be sent into the area to restore service as quickly as possible, an urgent priority for homes also left without air conditioning in the middle of summer. Temperatures, which had cooled slightly with the storm, were expected to reach back into the 90s as early as Tuesday. The National Weather Service issued a heat advisory that said the area heat index could reach 105 degrees Fahrenheit (41 degrees Celsius).\n\nThe state will be ready to open cooling centers as well as food and water distribution centers, said Nim Kidd, chief of state emergency operations.\n\nBeryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast on Monday, reclosing streets in neighborhoods that had already been washed out by previous storms. Television stations on Monday broadcast the dramatic rescue of a man who had climbed to the roof of his pickup truck after it got trapped in fast-flowing waters. Emergency crews used an extension ladder from a fire truck to drop him a life preserver and a tether before moving him to dry land.\n\nHouston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.\n\n\"First responders are putting their lives at risk. That's what they're trained for. It's working,\" Houston Mayor John Whitmire said.\n\nJavier Mejia was one of about 20 people who gathered near the pickup truck rescue site to take pictures of other submerged vehicles sitting on the flooded highway.\n\n\"If you don't have a way through, you're going to get stuck like that,\" Mejia said.\n\nHaving experienced previous storms in Houston, Mejia stocked up on food and water before Beryl hit, but forgot gas for his portable generator. He planned to spend the day looking for some.\n\n\"I don't want it to go bad,\" he said of the food, adding that if he can't find gas, \"We can just fire up the grill.\"\n\nMany streets and neighborhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents set to work chopping up knocked-down trees and big branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks.\n\nPatrick warned that flooding could last for days as rain continued to fall on already saturated ground.\n\n\"This is not a one-day event,\" he said.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was getting regular updates on the storm after it made landfall, the White House said. The U.S. Coast Guard and FEMA had prepared search and rescue teams, and FEMA collected bottled water, meals, tarps and electric generators in case they are needed.\n\nSeveral companies with refineries or industrial plants in the area reported that the power disruptions necessitated the flaring of gases at the facilities.\n\nMarathon Petroleum Corp. said it conducted a \"safe combustion of excess gases\" at its Galveston Bay Refinery in Texas City, but did not provide information on the amount of gas flared or how long it would continue. Formosa Plastics Corporation and Freeport LNG also reported flaring related to Beryl, according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.\n\nCompanies have 24 hours to share emissions data after the flaring stops, a representative from the TCEQ said in an email.\n\nThe earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, Beryl caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nIn Louisiana, heavy bands of rain were expected all day Monday and \"the risk is going to be for that heavy rainfall and potential for flash flooding,\" National Weather Service meteorologist Donald Jones said in a Monday morning Facebook Live briefing.\n\nThe weather service in Shreveport issued tornado warnings across northwest Louisiana. The agency confirmed on social media that multiple tornados had been spotted in that corner of the state. Information on whether those weather events have caused any significant damage was not immediately available.\n\nBeryl was forecast to bring more strong rain and winds into additional states over the coming days. One of those, Missouri was already dealing with a wet summer. Heavy rains unrelated to the storm prompted several water rescues around the city of Columbia, where rivers and creeks were already high ahead of Beryl's expected arrival on Tuesday.\n\nAssociated Press reporters Jim Vertuno in Austin, Texas; Corey Williams in Detroit; Julie Walker in New York; Melina Walling in Chicago; and Jeff Martin in Atlanta contributed to this report.\n\nMore from this section\n\nProNotary Announces Exciting New Partner Program\n\nKickstarter Fundraising for Jig App: Unique Experiences and Tailored At-Home Services App Project\n\nReconnect with Your Food in Andrea Kristin's Best Selling Book", "source": {"uri": "kulr8.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KULR-8 Local News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@kulr8.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "juan_a_lozano@kulr8.com", "name": "Juan A. 15}, {"uri": "dmoz/Business/Energy/Utilities", "label": "dmoz/Business/Energy/Utilities", "wgt": 16}, {"uri": "dmoz/Science/Earth_Sciences/Atmospheric_Sciences", "label": "dmoz/Science/Earth Sciences/Atmospheric Sciences", "wgt": 24}, {"uri": "dmoz/Home/Emergency_Preparation/Food_and_Water", "label": "dmoz/Home/Emergency Preparation/Food and Water", "wgt": 15}, {"uri": "news/Politics", "label": "news/Politics", "wgt": 65}], "image": "https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/kulr8.com/content/tncms/custom/image/ebec0578-57d0-11ee-978f-b7da313020af.jpg?resize=600%2C315", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9716370", "eventUri": "eng-9716370", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.2549019607843137, "wgt": 245, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-07-415615323", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "00:44:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T00:44:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T00:32:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9529411792755127, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/beryl-weakens-to-tropical-depression-after-slamming-into-texas-as-category-1-hurricane/article_8ae9456b-a942-5aab-9b63-65f659b5b3ad.html", "title": "Beryl weakens to tropical depression after slamming into Texas as Category 1 hurricane", "body": "Buffalo Bayou floods stranding vehicles near Downtown Houston after Beryl came ashore in Texas as a hurricane and dumped heavy rains downtown.\n\nHOUSTON (AP) -- After Tropical Storm Beryl slammed into Texas early Monday, knocking out power to nearly 3 million homes and businesses and killing several people it moved east and weakened to a tropical depression, the National Hurricane Center said Monday evening. Flooding, rains and tornadoes were possible across portions of eastern Texas, Western Louisiana and Arkansas.\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nHOUSTON (AP) -- Tropical Storm Beryl slammed into Texas on Monday, knocking out power to nearly 3 million homes and businesses and unleashing heavy rains that prompted dozens of high-water rescues. The fast-moving tempest threatened to carve a harsh path over several more states in coming days.\n\nTexas state and local officials warned it could take several days to restore power after Beryl came ashore as a Category 1 hurricane and toppled 10 transmission lines and knocked down trees that took down power lines.\n\nWithin hours, Beryl had weakened into a tropical storm, far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean last weekend. But the winds and rains of the fast-moving storm were still powerful enough to knock down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in water-saturated earth, and strand dozens of cars on flooded roadways.\n\nAs it moved inland, the storm still threatened to spawn tornados.\n\n\"We're not past any difficult conditions,\" said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country, warning it would be a \"multiple day process to get power restored.\"\n\nHouston took a hard hit as CenterPoint Energy reported more than 2 million homes and businesses without power in and around the nation's fourth-largest city. Patrick said the company was bringing in thousands of additional workers to restore power, with top priority for places such as nursing homes and assisted living centers.\n\nAt least two people were killed when trees fell on homes, and the National Hurricane Center said damaging winds and flash flooding would continue as Beryl pushes inland. A third person, a civilian employee of the Houston Police Department, was killed when he was trapped in flood waters under a highway overpass, Houston Mayor John Whitmire said. There were no immediate reports of widespread structural damage, however.\n\nThe loss of power was an all-too familiar experience for Houston: Powerful storms had just ripped through the area in May, killing eight people, leaving nearly 1 million without power and flooding numerous streets.\n\nResidents without power after Beryl were doing their best.\n\n\"We haven't really slept,\" said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in her neighborhood in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio, 67, said she had already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\n\n\"We are struggling to have food and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.\n\nHouston and Harris County officials said power crews would be sent into the area to restore service as quickly as possible, an urgent priority for homes also left without air conditioning in the middle of summer. Temperatures, which had cooled slightly with the storm, were expected to reach back into the 90s as early as Tuesday. The National Weather Service issued a heat advisory that said the area heat index could reach 105 degrees Fahrenheit (41 degrees Celsius).\n\nThe state will be ready to open cooling centers as well as food and water distribution centers, said Nim Kidd, chief of state emergency operations.\n\nBeryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast on Monday, reclosing streets in neighborhoods that had already been washed out by previous storms. Television stations on Monday broadcast the dramatic rescue of a man who had climbed to the roof of his pickup truck after it got trapped in fast-flowing waters. Emergency crews used an extension ladder from a fire truck to drop him a life preserver and a tether before moving him to dry land.\n\nHouston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.\n\n\"First responders are putting their lives at risk. That's what they're trained for. It's working,\" Houston Mayor John Whitmire said.\n\nJavier Mejia was one of about 20 people who gathered near the pickup truck rescue site to take pictures of other submerged vehicles sitting on the flooded highway.\n\n\"If you don't have a way through, you're going to get stuck like that,\" Mejia said.\n\nHaving experienced previous storms in Houston, Mejia stocked up on food and water before Beryl hit, but forgot gas for his portable generator. He planned to spend the day looking for some.\n\n\"I don't want it to go bad,\" he said of the food, adding that if he can't find gas, \"We can just fire up the grill.\"\n\nMany streets and neighborhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents set to work chopping up knocked-down trees and big branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks.\n\nPatrick warned that flooding could last for days as rain continued to fall on already saturated ground.\n\n\"This is not a one-day event,\" he said.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was getting regular updates on the storm after it made landfall, the White House said. The U.S. Coast Guard and FEMA had prepared search and rescue teams, and FEMA collected bottled water, meals, tarps and electric generators in case they are needed.\n\nSeveral companies with refineries or industrial plants in the area reported that the power disruptions necessitated the flaring of gases at the facilities.\n\nMarathon Petroleum Corp. said it conducted a \"safe combustion of excess gases\" at its Galveston Bay Refinery in Texas City, but did not provide information on the amount of gas flared or how long it would continue. Formosa Plastics Corporation and Freeport LNG also reported flaring related to Beryl, according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.\n\nCompanies have 24 hours to share emissions data after the flaring stops, a representative from the TCEQ said in an email.\n\nThe earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, Beryl caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nIn Louisiana, heavy bands of rain were expected all day Monday and \"the risk is going to be for that heavy rainfall and potential for flash flooding,\" National Weather Service meteorologist Donald Jones said in a Monday morning Facebook Live briefing.\n\nThe weather service in Shreveport issued tornado warnings across northwest Louisiana. The agency confirmed on social media that multiple tornados had been spotted in that corner of the state. Information on whether those weather events have caused any significant damage was not immediately available.\n\nBeryl was forecast to bring more strong rain and winds into additional states over the coming days. One of those, Missouri was already dealing with a wet summer. Heavy rains unrelated to the storm prompted several water rescues around the city of Columbia, where rivers and creeks were already high ahead of Beryl's expected arrival on Tuesday.\n\nAssociated Press reporters Jim Vertuno in Austin, Texas; Corey Williams in Detroit; Julie Walker in New York; Melina Walling in Chicago; and Jeff Martin in Atlanta contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "register-herald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Beckley Register-Herald"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@register-herald.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "juan_a_lozano@register-herald.com", "name": "Juan A. {"uri": "8216076644", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "01:20:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T01:20:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T01:14:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9490196108818054, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/beryl-weakens-to-tropical-depression-after-slamming-into-texas-as-category-1-hurricane/article_ec4ab4c6-3581-5b73-9e8a-a799e89dc164.html", "title": "Beryl weakens to tropical depression after slamming into Texas as Category 1 hurricane", "body": "A rescue crew prepares in Houston, on Monday, July 8, 2024, after Beryl came ashore in Texas as a hurricane and dumped heavy rains downtown.\n\nHOUSTON (AP) -- After Hurricane Beryl slammed into Texas early Monday, knocking out power to nearly 3 million homes and businesses and killing at least three people it moved east and later weakened to a tropical depression, the National Hurricane Center said Monday evening.\n\nThe fast-moving tempest, which unleashed heavy rains that prompted dozens of high-water rescues, threatened to carve a harsh path over several more states in coming days.\n\nTexas state and local officials warned it could take several days to restore power after Beryl came ashore as a Category 1 hurricane and toppled 10 transmission lines and knocked down trees that took down power lines.\n\nWithin hours, Beryl had weakened into a tropical storm, far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean last weekend. But the winds and rains of the fast-moving storm were still powerful enough to knock down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in water-saturated earth, and strand dozens of cars on flooded roadways.\n\nAs it moved inland, the storm still threatened to spawn tornados.\n\n\"We're not past any difficult conditions,\" said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country, warning it would be a \"multiple day process to get power restored.\"\n\nHouston took a hard hit as CenterPoint Energy reported more than 2 million homes and businesses without power in and around the nation's fourth-largest city. Patrick said the company was bringing in thousands of additional workers to restore power, with top priority for places such as nursing homes and assisted living centers.\n\nAt least two people were killed when trees fell on homes, and the National Hurricane Center said damaging winds and flash flooding would continue as Beryl pushes inland. A third person, a civilian employee of the Houston Police Department, was killed when he was trapped in flood waters under a highway overpass, Houston Mayor John Whitmire said. There were no immediate reports of widespread structural damage, however.\n\nThe loss of power was an all-too familiar experience for Houston: Powerful storms had just ripped through the area in May, killing eight people, leaving nearly 1 million without power and flooding numerous streets.\n\nResidents without power after Beryl were doing their best.\n\n\"We haven't really slept,\" said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in her neighborhood in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio, 67, said she had already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\n\n\"We are struggling to have food and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.\n\nHouston and Harris County officials said power crews would be sent into the area to restore service as quickly as possible, an urgent priority for homes also left without air conditioning in the middle of summer. Temperatures, which had cooled slightly with the storm, were expected to reach back into the 90s as early as Tuesday. The National Weather Service issued a heat advisory that said the area heat index could reach 105 degrees Fahrenheit (41 degrees Celsius).\n\nThe state will be ready to open cooling centers as well as food and water distribution centers, said Nim Kidd, chief of state emergency operations.\n\nBeryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast on Monday, reclosing streets in neighborhoods that had already been washed out by previous storms. Television stations on Monday broadcast the dramatic rescue of a man who had climbed to the roof of his pickup truck after it got trapped in fast-flowing waters. Emergency crews used an extension ladder from a fire truck to drop him a life preserver and a tether before moving him to dry land.\n\nHouston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.\n\n\"First responders are putting their lives at risk. That's what they're trained for. It's working,\" Houston Mayor John Whitmire said.\n\nJavier Mejia was one of about 20 people who gathered near the pickup truck rescue site to take pictures of other submerged vehicles sitting on the flooded highway.\n\n\"If you don't have a way through, you're going to get stuck like that,\" Mejia said.\n\nHaving experienced previous storms in Houston, Mejia stocked up on food and water before Beryl hit, but forgot gas for his portable generator. He planned to spend the day looking for some.\n\n\"I don't want it to go bad,\" he said of the food, adding that if he can't find gas, \"We can just fire up the grill.\"\n\nMany streets and neighborhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents set to work chopping up knocked-down trees and big branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks.\n\nPatrick warned that flooding could last for days as rain continued to fall on already saturated ground.\n\n\"This is not a one-day event,\" he said.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was getting regular updates on the storm after it made landfall, the White House said. The U.S. Coast Guard and FEMA had prepared search and rescue teams, and FEMA collected bottled water, meals, tarps and electric generators in case they are needed.\n\nSeveral companies with refineries or industrial plants in the area reported that the power disruptions necessitated the flaring of gases at the facilities.\n\nMarathon Petroleum Corp. said it conducted a \"safe combustion of excess gases\" at its Galveston Bay Refinery in Texas City, but did not provide information on the amount of gas flared or how long it would continue. Formosa Plastics Corporation and Freeport LNG also reported flaring related to Beryl, according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.\n\nCompanies have 24 hours to share emissions data after the flaring stops, a representative from the TCEQ said in an email.\n\nThe earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, Beryl caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nIn Louisiana, heavy bands of rain were expected all day Monday and \"the risk is going to be for that heavy rainfall and potential for flash flooding,\" National Weather Service meteorologist Donald Jones said in a Monday morning Facebook Live briefing.\n\nThe weather service in Shreveport issued tornado warnings across northwest Louisiana. The agency confirmed on social media that multiple tornados had been spotted in that corner of the state. Information on whether those weather events have caused any significant damage was not immediately available.\n\nBeryl was forecast to bring more strong rain and winds into additional states over the coming days. One of those, Missouri was already dealing with a wet summer. {"uri": "8216107422", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "01:56:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T01:56:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T01:55:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9411764740943909, "url": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/world/hurricane-beryl-weakens-to-tropical-depression-after-slamming-into-texas-as-category-1-hurricane-1.6955042", "title": "Hurricane Beryl weakens to tropical depression after slamming into Texas as Category 1 hurricane", "body": "After Hurricane Beryl slammed into Texas early Monday, knocking out power to nearly three million homes and businesses and killing at least three people it moved east and later weakened to a tropical depression, the National Hurricane Center said Monday evening.\n\nThe fast-moving tempest, which unleashed heavy rains that prompted dozens of high-water rescues, threatened to carve a harsh path over several more states in coming days.\n\nTexas state and local officials warned it could take several days to restore power after Beryl came ashore as a Category 1 hurricane and toppled 10 transmission lines and knocked down trees that took down power lines.\n\nWithin hours, Beryl had weakened into a tropical storm, far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean last weekend. But the winds and rains of the fast-moving storm were still powerful enough to knock down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in water-saturated earth, and strand dozens of cars on flooded roadways.\n\nAs it moved inland, the storm still threatened to spawn tornados.\n\n\"We're not past any difficult conditions,\" said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country, warning it would be a \"multiple day process to get power restored.\"\n\nHouston took a hard hit as CentrePoint Energy reported more than two million homes and businesses without power in and around the nation's fourth-largest city. Patrick said the company was bringing in thousands of additional workers to restore power, with top priority for places such as nursing homes and assisted living centres.\n\nA tree uprooted by the effects of Hurricane Beryl lies in a lawn, Monday, July 8, 2024, in Bay City, Texas. (AP Photo/Eric Gay)\n\nAt least two people were killed when trees fell on homes, and the National Hurricane Centre said damaging winds and flash flooding would continue as Beryl pushes inland. A third person, a civilian employee of the Houston Police Department, was killed when he was trapped in flood waters under a highway overpass, Houston Mayor John Whitmire said. There were no immediate reports of widespread structural damage, however.\n\nThe loss of power was an all-too familiar experience for Houston: Powerful storms had just ripped through the area in May, killing eight people, leaving nearly 1 million without power and flooding numerous streets.\n\nResidents without power after Beryl were doing their best.\n\n\"We haven't really slept,\" said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in her neighborhood in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio, 67, said she had already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\n\n\"We are struggling to have food and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.\n\nHouston and Harris County officials said power crews would be sent into the area to restore service as quickly as possible, an urgent priority for homes also left without air conditioning in the middle of summer. Temperatures, which had cooled slightly with the storm, were expected to reach back into the 90s as early as Tuesday. The National Weather Service issued a heat advisory that said the area heat index could reach 105 degrees Fahrenheit (41 degrees Celsius).\n\nThe state will be ready to open cooling centres as well as food and water distribution centres, said Nim Kidd, chief of state emergency operations.\n\nBeryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast on Monday, reclosing streets in neighborhoods that had already been washed out by previous storms. Television stations on Monday broadcast the dramatic rescue of a man who had climbed to the roof of his pickup truck after it got trapped in fast-flowing waters. Emergency crews used an extension ladder from a fire truck to drop him a life preserver and a tether before moving him to dry land.\n\nHouston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.\n\n\"First responders are putting their lives at risk. That's what they're trained for. It's working,\" Houston Mayor John Whitmire said.\n\nJavier Mejia was one of about 20 people who gathered near the pickup truck rescue site to take pictures of other submerged vehicles sitting on the flooded highway.\n\n\"If you don't have a way through, you're going to get stuck like that,\" Mejia said.\n\nHaving experienced previous storms in Houston, Mejia stocked up on food and water before Beryl hit, but forgot gas for his portable generator. He planned to spend the day looking for some.\n\n\"I don't want it to go bad,\" he said of the food, adding that if he can't find gas, \"We can just fire up the grill.\"\n\nClyde George, left, and his son Chris George board up their home ahead of the arrival of Tropical Storm Beryl on Sunday, July 7, 2024, in Port O'Connor, Texas. (Jon Shapley/Houston Chronicle via AP)\n\nMany streets and neighborhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents set to work chopping up knocked-down trees and big branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks.\n\nPatrick warned that flooding could last for days as rain continued to fall on already saturated ground.\n\n\"This is not a one-day event,\" he said.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was getting regular updates on the storm after it made landfall, the White House said. The U.S. Coast Guard and FEMA had prepared search and rescue teams, and FEMA collected bottled water, meals, tarps and electric generators in case they are needed.\n\nSeveral companies with refineries or industrial plants in the area reported that the power disruptions necessitated the flaring of gases at the facilities.\n\nMarathon Petroleum Corp. said it conducted a \"safe combustion of excess gases\" at its Galveston Bay Refinery in Texas City, but did not provide information on the amount of gas flared or how long it would continue. Formosa Plastics Corporation and Freeport LNG also reported flaring related to Beryl, according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.\n\nCompanies have 24 hours to share emissions data after the flaring stops, a representative from the TCEQ said in an email.\n\nThe earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, Beryl caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over US$6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nIn Louisiana, heavy bands of rain were expected all day Monday and \"the risk is going to be for that heavy rainfall and potential for flash flooding,\" National Weather Service meteorologist Donald Jones said in a Monday morning Facebook Live briefing.\n\nThe weather service in Shreveport issued tornado warnings across northwest Louisiana. The agency confirmed on social media that multiple tornados had been spotted in that corner of the state. Information on whether those weather events have caused any significant damage was not immediately available.\n\nBeryl was forecast to bring more strong rain and winds into additional states over the coming days. One of those, Missouri was already dealing with a wet summer. Heavy rains unrelated to the storm prompted several water rescues around the city of Columbia, where rivers and creeks were already high ahead of Beryl's expected arrival on Tuesday.", "source": {"uri": "2024-07-415687075", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "03:21:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T03:21:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-08T21:15:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9372549057006836, "url": "https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2024/jul/8/beryl-weakens-to-tropical-depression-after-slammin/", "title": "Beryl weakens to tropical depression after slamming into Texas as Category 1 hurricane", "body": "HOUSTON -- After Hurricane Beryl slammed into Texas early Monday, knocking out power to nearly 3 million homes and businesses, unleashing heavy rain and killing at least three people it moved east and later weakened to a tropical depression, the National Hurricane Center said Monday evening. The fast-moving tempest threatened to carve a harsh path over several more states in coming days.\n\nTexas state and local officials warned it could take several days to restore power after Beryl came ashore as a Category 1 hurricane and toppled 10 transmission lines and knocked down trees that took down power lines.\n\nBeryl later weakened into a tropical storm and then a tropical depression, far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean last weekend. But the winds and rains of the fast-moving storm were still powerful enough to knock down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in water-saturated earth, and strand dozens of cars on flooded roadways.\n\nAs it moved inland, the storm threatened to spawn tornadoes and the National Weather Service confirmed on social media that tornadoes had been spotted in northeastern Louisiana. Bossier Sheriff Julian Whittington said in a Facebook post that a woman was killed in the Benton area when a tree fell on her home.\n\n\"We're not past any difficult conditions,\" said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country, warning it would be a \"multiple day process to get power restored.\"\n\nHouston took a hard hit as CenterPoint Energy reported more than 2 million homes and businesses without power in and around the nation's fourth-largest city. Patrick said the company was bringing in thousands of additional workers to restore power, with top priority for places such as nursing homes and assisted living centers.\n\nAt least two people were killed when trees fell on homes, and the National Hurricane Center said damaging winds and flash flooding would continue as Beryl pushes inland. A third person, a civilian employee of the Houston Police Department, was killed when he was trapped in flood waters under a highway overpass, Houston Mayor John Whitmire said. There were no immediate reports of widespread structural damage, however.\n\nThe loss of power was an all-too familiar experience for Houston: Powerful storms had just ripped through the area in May, killing eight people, leaving nearly 1 million without power and flooding numerous streets.\n\nResidents without power after Beryl were doing their best.\n\n\"We haven't really slept,\" said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in her neighborhood in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio, 67, said she had already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\n\n\"We are struggling to have food and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.\n\nHouston and Harris County officials said power crews would be sent into the area to restore service as quickly as possible, an urgent priority for homes also left without air conditioning in the middle of summer. Temperatures, which had cooled slightly with the storm, were expected to reach back into the 90s as early as Tuesday. The National Weather Service issued a heat advisory that said the area heat index could reach 105 degrees Fahrenheit (41 degrees Celsius).\n\nThe state will be ready to open cooling centers as well as food and water distribution centers, said Nim Kidd, chief of state emergency operations.\n\nBeryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast on Monday, reclosing streets in neighborhoods that had already been washed out by previous storms. Television stations on Monday broadcast the dramatic rescue of a man who had climbed to the roof of his pickup truck after it got trapped in fast-flowing waters. Emergency crews used an extension ladder from a fire truck to drop him a life preserver and a tether before moving him to dry land.\n\nHouston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.\n\n\"First responders are putting their lives at risk. That's what they're trained for. It's working,\" Houston Mayor John Whitmire said.\n\nJavier Mejia was one of about 20 people who gathered near the pickup truck rescue site to take pictures of other submerged vehicles sitting on the flooded highway.\n\n\"If you don't have a way through, you're going to get stuck like that,\" Mejia said.\n\nHaving experienced previous storms in Houston, Mejia stocked up on food and water before Beryl hit, but forgot gas for his portable generator. He planned to spend the day looking for some.\n\n\"I don't want it to go bad,\" he said of the food, adding that if he can't find gas, \"We can just fire up the grill.\"\n\nMany streets and neighborhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents set to work chopping up knocked-down trees and big branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks.\n\nPatrick warned that flooding could last for days as rain continued to fall on already saturated ground.\n\n\"This is not a one-day event,\" he said.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was getting regular updates on the storm after it made landfall, the White House said. The U.S. Coast Guard and FEMA had prepared search and rescue teams, and FEMA collected bottled water, meals, tarps and electric generators in case they are needed.\n\nSeveral companies with refineries or industrial plants in the area reported that the power disruptions necessitated the flaring of gases at the facilities.\n\nMarathon Petroleum Corp. said it conducted a \"safe combustion of excess gases\" at its Galveston Bay Refinery in Texas City, but did not provide information on the amount of gas flared or how long it would continue. Formosa Plastics Corporation and Freeport LNG also reported flaring related to Beryl, according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.\n\nCompanies have 24 hours to share emissions data after the flaring stops, a representative from the TCEQ said in an email.\n\nThe earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, Beryl caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nIn Louisiana, heavy bands of rain were expected all day Monday and \"the risk is going to be for that heavy rainfall and potential for flash flooding,\" National Weather Service meteorologist Donald Jones said in a Monday morning Facebook Live briefing.\n\nThe weather service in Shreveport issued tornado warnings across northwest Louisiana. The agency confirmed on social media that multiple tornadoes had been spotted in that corner of the state. Information on whether those weather events have caused any significant damage was not immediately available.\n\nBeryl was forecast to bring more strong rain and winds into additional states over the coming days. One of those, Missouri was already dealing with a wet summer. Heavy rains unrelated to the storm prompted several water rescues around the city of Columbia, where rivers and creeks were already high ahead of Beryl's expected arrival on Tuesday.\n\n___", "source": {"uri": "washingtontimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Washington Times"}, "authors": [{"uri": "juan_a_lozano@washingtontimes.com", "name": "Juan A. {"uri": "8216061924", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "00:58:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T00:58:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T00:54:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9372549057006836, "url": "https://www.idahostatejournal.com/news/national/beryl-weakens-to-tropical-depression-after-slamming-into-texas-as-category-1-hurricane/article_958f026c-7f48-5d53-8bab-2929364c424d.html", "title": "Beryl weakens to tropical depression after slamming into Texas as Category 1 hurricane", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- After Hurricane Beryl slammed into Texas early Monday, knocking out power to nearly 3 million homes and businesses and killing at least three people it moved east and later weakened to a tropical depression, the National Hurricane Center said Monday evening.\n\nThe fast-moving tempest, which unleashed heavy rains that prompted dozens of high-water rescues, threatened to carve a harsh path over several more states in coming days.\n\nTexas state and local officials warned it could take several days to restore power after Beryl came ashore as a Category 1 hurricane and toppled 10 transmission lines and knocked down trees that took down power lines.\n\nWithin hours, Beryl had weakened into a tropical storm, far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean last weekend. But the winds and rains of the fast-moving storm were still powerful enough to knock down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in water-saturated earth, and strand dozens of cars on flooded roadways.\n\nAs it moved inland, the storm still threatened to spawn tornados.\n\n\"We're not past any difficult conditions,\" said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country, warning it would be a \"multiple day process to get power restored.\"\n\nHouston took a hard hit as CenterPoint Energy reported more than 2 million homes and businesses without power in and around the nation's fourth-largest city. Patrick said the company was bringing in thousands of additional workers to restore power, with top priority for places such as nursing homes and assisted living centers.\n\nAt least two people were killed when trees fell on homes, and the National Hurricane Center said damaging winds and flash flooding would continue as Beryl pushes inland. A third person, a civilian employee of the Houston Police Department, was killed when he was trapped in flood waters under a highway overpass, Houston Mayor John Whitmire said. There were no immediate reports of widespread structural damage, however.\n\nThe loss of power was an all-too familiar experience for Houston: Powerful storms had just ripped through the area in May, killing eight people, leaving nearly 1 million without power and flooding numerous streets.\n\nResidents without power after Beryl were doing their best.\n\n\"We haven't really slept,\" said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in her neighborhood in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio, 67, said she had already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\n\n\"We are struggling to have food and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.\n\nHouston and Harris County officials said power crews would be sent into the area to restore service as quickly as possible, an urgent priority for homes also left without air conditioning in the middle of summer. Temperatures, which had cooled slightly with the storm, were expected to reach back into the 90s as early as Tuesday. The National Weather Service issued a heat advisory that said the area heat index could reach 105 degrees Fahrenheit (41 degrees Celsius).\n\nThe state will be ready to open cooling centers as well as food and water distribution centers, said Nim Kidd, chief of state emergency operations.\n\nBeryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast on Monday, reclosing streets in neighborhoods that had already been washed out by previous storms. Television stations on Monday broadcast the dramatic rescue of a man who had climbed to the roof of his pickup truck after it got trapped in fast-flowing waters. Emergency crews used an extension ladder from a fire truck to drop him a life preserver and a tether before moving him to dry land.\n\nHouston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.\n\n\"First responders are putting their lives at risk. That's what they're trained for. It's working,\" Houston Mayor John Whitmire said.\n\nJavier Mejia was one of about 20 people who gathered near the pickup truck rescue site to take pictures of other submerged vehicles sitting on the flooded highway.\n\n\"If you don't have a way through, you're going to get stuck like that,\" Mejia said.\n\nHaving experienced previous storms in Houston, Mejia stocked up on food and water before Beryl hit, but forgot gas for his portable generator. He planned to spend the day looking for some.\n\n\"I don't want it to go bad,\" he said of the food, adding that if he can't find gas, \"We can just fire up the grill.\"\n\nMany streets and neighborhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents set to work chopping up knocked-down trees and big branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks.\n\nPatrick warned that flooding could last for days as rain continued to fall on already saturated ground.\n\n\"This is not a one-day event,\" he said.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was getting regular updates on the storm after it made landfall, the White House said. The U.S. Coast Guard and FEMA had prepared search and rescue teams, and FEMA collected bottled water, meals, tarps and electric generators in case they are needed.\n\nSeveral companies with refineries or industrial plants in the area reported that the power disruptions necessitated the flaring of gases at the facilities.\n\nMarathon Petroleum Corp. said it conducted a \"safe combustion of excess gases\" at its Galveston Bay Refinery in Texas City, but did not provide information on the amount of gas flared or how long it would continue. Formosa Plastics Corporation and Freeport LNG also reported flaring related to Beryl, according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.\n\nCompanies have 24 hours to share emissions data after the flaring stops, a representative from the TCEQ said in an email.\n\nThe earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, Beryl caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nIn Louisiana, heavy bands of rain were expected all day Monday and \"the risk is going to be for that heavy rainfall and potential for flash flooding,\" National Weather Service meteorologist Donald Jones said in a Monday morning Facebook Live briefing.\n\nThe weather service in Shreveport issued tornado warnings across northwest Louisiana. The agency confirmed on social media that multiple tornados had been spotted in that corner of the state. Information on whether those weather events have caused any significant damage was not immediately available.\n\nBeryl was forecast to bring more strong rain and winds into additional states over the coming days. One of those, Missouri was already dealing with a wet summer. Heavy rains unrelated to the storm prompted several water rescues around the city of Columbia, where rivers and creeks were already high ahead of Beryl's expected arrival on Tuesday.\n\nAssociated Press reporters Jim Vertuno in Austin, Texas; Corey Williams in Detroit; Julie Walker in New York; Melina Walling in Chicago; and Jeff Martin in Atlanta contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "idahostatejournal.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Idaho State Journal"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@idahostatejournal.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": true}, {"uri": "juan_a_lozano@idahostatejournal.com", "name": "Juan A. Lozano", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "mark_vancleave@idahostatejournal.com", "name": "Mark Vancleave", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electric_power_transmission", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Electric power transmission"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tropical_cyclone", "dmoz/Science/Earth_Sciences/Atmospheric_Sciences", "label": "dmoz/Science/Earth Sciences/Atmospheric Sciences", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Politics", "label": "news/Politics", "wgt": 85}], "image": "https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/idahostatejournal.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/3/e1/3e1ce53d-dd7b-5316-892c-330e3015687b/668b21654c449.image.jpg?crop=1763%2C926%2C0%2C124&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9716370", "eventUri": "eng-9716370", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Houston"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.192156862745098, "wgt": 239, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-07-415570608", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-08", "time": "22:57:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-08T22:57:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-08T22:27:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9333333373069763, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/texas-officials-say-restoring-electricity-will-take-days-after-beryl-knocked-out-power-to-millions/article_df161859-2993-57e7-b6c9-14d9faaa16cc.html", "title": "Texas officials say restoring electricity will take days after Beryl knocked out power to millions", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- Texas officials say restoring electricity will take days after Beryl came ashore Monday as a Category 1 hurricane and knocked out power to nearly 3 million homes and businesses.\n\nTexas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country, said CenterPoint Energy was bringing in thousands of additional workers to help get the lights turned back on quicker. He said the storm toppled 10 transmission lines and that many of the outages were caused by fallen trees.\n\nBeryl sped across the Texas coast on Monday, unleashing heavy rains that prompted dozens of high-water rescues. The fast-moving tempest threatened to carve a harsh path over several more states in coming days. At least three people were killed as Beryl moved through Texas.\n\nWithin hours after Beryl swept ashore as a Category 1 hurricane, it had weakened into a tropical storm, far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean last weekend.\n\nBut the winds and rains of the fast-moving storm were still powerful enough to knock down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in water-saturated earth and to strand dozens of cars on flooded roadways.\n\nAt least two people were killed when trees fell on homes, and the National Hurricane Center said damaging winds and flash flooding would continue as Beryl pushes inland. A third person, a civilian employee of the Houston Police Department, was killed when he was trapped in flood waters under a highway overpass, Houston Mayor John Whitmire said. There were no immediate reports of widespread structural damage, however.\n\nMore than 2.2 million homes and businesses were without power around Houston, the nation's fourth-largest city, after Beryl blew through, according to the CenterPoint Energy utility. For many, it was an all-too-familiar experience: Powerful storms had just ripped through the area in May, killing eight people, leaving nearly 1 million without power and flooding numerous streets.\n\nResidents without power after Beryl were doing their best.\n\n\"We haven't really slept,\" said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in her neighborhood in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio, 67, said she had already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\n\n\"We are struggling to have food and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.\n\nHouston and Harris County officials said power crews would be sent into the area to restore service as quickly as possible, an urgent priority for homes also left without air conditioning in the middle of summer. Temperatures, which had cooled slightly with the storm, were expected to reach back into the 90s as early as Tuesday.\n\n\"While these efforts are full steam ahead, we want residents to know and prepare for a possible multi-day power outage,\" Galveston city officials said on Facebook. \"The estimated timeline is anywhere from 72 hours to two weeks in parts of the island.\"\n\nBeryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast on Monday, reclosing streets in neighborhoods that had already been washed out by previous storms. Television stations on Monday broadcast the dramatic rescue of a man who had climbed to the roof of his pickup truck after it got trapped in fast-flowing waters. Emergency crews used an extension ladder from a fire truck to drop him a life preserver and a tether before moving him to dry land.\n\nHouston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.\n\n\"First responders are putting their lives at risk. That's what they're trained for. It's working,\" Houston Mayor John Whitmire said.\n\nJavier Mejia was one of about 20 people who gathered near the pickup truck rescue site to take pictures of other submerged vehicles sitting on the flooded highway.\n\n\"If you don't have a way through, you're going to get stuck like that,\" Mejia said.\n\nHaving experienced previous storms in Houston, Mejia stocked up on food and water before Beryl hit, but forgot gas for his portable generator. He planned to spend the day looking for some.\n\n\"I don't want it to go bad,\" he said of the food, adding that if he can't find gas, \"We can just fire up the grill.\"\n\nMany streets and neighborhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents set to work chopping up knocked-down trees and big branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks.\n\nTwo people were killed after trees fell on their houses: a man in the Houston suburb of Humble and a woman in Harris County, authorities said. Hundreds of trees fell in the county, crushing vehicles and damaging homes, said Precinct 4 County Constable Mark Herman.\n\nPatrick warned that flooding could last for days as rain continued to fall on already saturated ground.\n\n\"This is not a one-day event,\" he said.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was getting regular updates on the storm after it made landfall, the White House said. The U.S. Coast Guard and FEMA had prepared search and rescue teams, and FEMA collected bottled water, meals, tarps and electric generators in case they are needed.\n\nSeveral companies with refineries or industrial plants in the area reported that the power disruptions necessitated the flaring of gases at the facilities.\n\nMarathon Petroleum Corp. said it conducted a \"safe combustion of excess gases\" at its Galveston Bay Refinery in Texas City, but did not provide information on the amount of gas flared or how long it would continue. Formosa Plastics Corporation and Freeport LNG also reported flaring related to Beryl, according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.\n\nCompanies have 24 hours to share emissions data after the flaring stops, a representative from the TCEQ said in an email.\n\nThe earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, Beryl caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. The storm ripped off doors, windows and roofs with devastating winds and storm surge fueled by the Atlantic's record warmth.\n\nThree times during the week, Beryl gained 35 mph (56 kph) in wind speed in 24 hours or less, the official weather service definition of rapid intensification.\n\nBeryl's explosive growth into an unprecedented early whopper of a storm indicates the hot water of the Atlantic and Caribbean and what the Atlantic hurricane belt can expect for the rest of the storm season, experts said. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nIn Louisiana, heavy bands of rain were expected all day Monday and \"the risk is going to be for that heavy rainfall and potential for flash flooding,\" National Weather Service meteorologist Donald Jones said in a Monday morning Facebook Live briefing.\n\nMeteorologists in Louisiana are watching for lingering rainbands, which could drop copious amounts of rain wherever they materialize, as well as \"quick, spin-up tornadoes,\" said Donald Jones, a National Weather Service meteorologist in Lake Charles, Louisiana.\n\n\"It's just a matter of exactly where that's going to be,\" Jones said. \"That's very difficult to predict more than maybe an hour or so in advance.\"\n\nBeryl was forecast to bring more strong rain and winds into additional states over the coming days. One of those, Missouri was already dealing with a wet summer. Heavy rains unrelated to the storm prompted several water rescues around the city of Columbia, where rivers and creeks were already high ahead of Beryl's expected arrival on Tuesday.\n\nAssociated Press reporters Jim Vertuno in Austin, Texas; Corey Williams in Detroit; Julie Walker in New York; Melina Walling in Chicago; and Jeff Martin in Atlanta contributed to this report.\n\nMore from this section\n\nKickstarter Fundraising for Jig App: Unique Experiences and Tailored At-Home Services App Project\n\nProNotary Announces Exciting New Partner Program\n\nMocPOGO Pokemon GO Hacks Updated: Fixes Failed to Detect Location Error 12", "source": {"uri": "kulr8.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KULR-8 Local News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@kulr8.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "juan_a_lozano@kulr8.com", "name": "Juan A. {"uri": "2024-07-415848713", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "07:06:08", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T07:06:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-08T09:31:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9254902005195618, "url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/world/article-hurricane-beryl-makes-landfall-on-texas-coast/", "title": "Beryl weakens to tropical depression after slamming into Texas as Category 1 hurricane", "body": "After Hurricane Beryl slammed into Texas early Monday, knocking out power to nearly three million homes and businesses and killing at least three people it moved east and later weakened to a tropical depression, the National Hurricane Center said Monday evening.\n\nThe fast-moving tempest, which unleashed heavy rains that prompted dozens of high-water rescues, threatened to carve a harsh path over several more states in coming days.\n\nTexas state and local officials warned it could take several days to restore power after Beryl came ashore as a Category 1 hurricane and toppled 10 transmission lines and knocked down trees that took down power lines.\n\nWithin hours, Beryl had weakened into a tropical storm, far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean last weekend. But the winds and rains of the fast-moving storm were still powerful enough to knock down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in water-saturated earth, and strand dozens of cars on flooded roadways.\n\nAs it moved inland, the storm still threatened to spawn tornadoes.\n\n\"We're not past any difficult conditions,\" said Texas Lieutenant Governor Dan Patrick, who is acting governor while Governor Greg Abbott is out of the country, warning it would be a \"multiple day process to get power restored.\"\n\nHouston took a hard hit as CenterPoint Energy reported more than two million homes and businesses without power in and around the nation's fourth-largest city. Mr. Patrick said the company was bringing in thousands of additional workers to restore power, with top priority for places such as nursing homes and assisted living centres.\n\nAt least two people were killed when trees fell on homes, and the National Hurricane Center said damaging winds and flash flooding would continue as Beryl pushes inland. A third person, a civilian employee of the Houston Police Department, was killed when he was trapped in flood waters under a highway overpass, Houston Mayor John Whitmire said. There were no immediate reports of widespread structural damage, however.\n\nThe loss of power was an all-too familiar experience for Houston: Powerful storms had just ripped through the area in May, killing eight people, leaving nearly one million without power and flooding numerous streets.\n\nResidents without power after Beryl were doing their best.\n\n\"We haven't really slept,\" said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in her neighbourhood in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio, 67, said she had already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\n\n\"We are struggling to have food and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.\n\nHouston and Harris County officials said power crews would be sent into the area to restore service as quickly as possible, an urgent priority for homes also left without air conditioning in the middle of summer. Temperatures, which had cooled slightly with the storm, were expected to reach back into the 90s as early as Tuesday. The National Weather Service issued a heat advisory that said the area heat index could reach 41 degrees Celsius.\n\nThe state will be ready to open cooling centres as well as food and water distribution centres, said Nim Kidd, chief of state emergency operations.\n\nBeryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast on Monday, reclosing streets in neighbourhoods that had already been washed out by previous storms. Television stations on Monday broadcast the dramatic rescue of a man who had climbed to the roof of his pickup truck after it got trapped in fast-flowing waters. Emergency crews used an extension ladder from a fire truck to drop him a life preserver and a tether before moving him to dry land.\n\nHouston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in flood waters.\n\n\"First responders are putting their lives at risk. That's what they're trained for. It's working,\" Houston Mayor John Whitmire said.\n\nJavier Mejia was one of about 20 people who gathered near the pickup truck rescue site to take pictures of other submerged vehicles sitting on the flooded highway.\n\n\"If you don't have a way through, you're going to get stuck like that,\" Mr. Mejia said.\n\nHaving experienced previous storms in Houston, Mr. Mejia stocked up on food and water before Beryl hit, but forgot gas for his portable generator. He planned to spend the day looking for some.\n\n\"I don't want it to go bad,\" he said of the food, adding that if he can't find gas, \"We can just fire up the grill.\"\n\nMany streets and neighbourhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents set to work chopping up knocked-down trees and big branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks.\n\nMr. Patrick warned that flooding could last for days as rain continued to fall on already saturated ground.\n\n\"This is not a one-day event,\" he said.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was getting regular updates on the storm after it made landfall, the White House said. The U.S. Coast Guard and FEMA had prepared search and rescue teams, and FEMA collected bottled water, meals, tarps and electric generators in case they are needed.\n\nSeveral companies with refineries or industrial plants in the area reported that the power disruptions necessitated the flaring of gases at the facilities.\n\nMarathon Petroleum Corp. said it conducted a \"safe combustion of excess gases\" at its Galveston Bay Refinery in Texas City, but did not provide information on the amount of gas flared or how long it would continue. Formosa Plastics Corporation and Freeport LNG also reported flaring related to Beryl, according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.\n\nCompanies have 24 hours to share emissions data after the flaring stops, a representative from the TCEQ said in an e-mail.\n\nThe earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, Beryl caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4-million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nIn Louisiana, heavy bands of rain were expected all day Monday and \"the risk is going to be for that heavy rainfall and potential for flash flooding,\" National Weather Service meteorologist Donald Jones said in a Monday morning Facebook Live briefing.\n\nThe weather service in Shreveport issued tornado warnings across northwest Louisiana. The agency confirmed on social media that multiple tornadoes had been spotted in that corner of the state. Information on whether those weather events have caused any significant damage was not immediately available.\n\nBeryl was forecast to bring more strong rain and winds into additional states over the coming days. One of those, Missouri was already dealing with a wet summer. Heavy rains unrelated to the storm prompted several water rescues around the city of Columbia, where rivers and creeks were already high ahead of Beryl's expected arrival on Tuesday.", "source": {"uri": "theglobeandmail.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Globe and Mail"}, "authors": [{"uri": "juan_a_lozano@theglobeandmail.com", "name": "Juan A. {"uri": "2024-07-415636706", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "01:34:22", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T01:34:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T01:15:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9254902005195618, "url": "https://www.kadn.com/weather/hurricane/beryl-responsible-for-3-deaths-in-texas-1-in-louisiana/article_e77cc214-bdca-5f3a-9965-5b7431ab16ea.html", "title": "Beryl responsible for 3 deaths in Texas, 1 in Louisiana", "body": "Hurricane Beryl devastated parts of the Texas coast when it made landfall. Drone footage shows the widespread destruction in the Sargent Beach area. (CREDIT: CNN)\n\nHOUSTON (AP) -- After Hurricane Beryl slammed into Texas early Monday, knocking out power to nearly 3 million homes and businesses, unleashing heavy rain, and killing at least four people, it moved east and later weakened to a tropical depression, according to officials. The fast-moving tempest threatened to carve a harsh path over several more states in coming days.\n\nTexas state and local officials warned it could take several days to restore power after Beryl came ashore as a Category 1 hurricane and toppled 10 transmission lines and knocked down trees that took down power lines.\n\nBeryl later weakened into a tropical storm and then a tropical depression, far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean last weekend. But the winds and rains of the fast-moving storm were still powerful enough to knock down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in water-saturated earth, and strand dozens of cars on flooded roadways.\n\nAs it moved inland, the storm threatened to spawn tornadoes and the National Weather Service confirmed on social media that tornadoes had been spotted in northeastern Louisiana. Bossier Sheriff Julian Whittington said in a Facebook post that a woman was killed in the Benton area when a tree fell on her home. The Louisiana Department of Health later confirmed the death in Bossier Parish.\n\n\"We're not past any difficult conditions,\" said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country, warning it would be a \"multiple day process to get power restored.\"\n\nHouston took a hard hit as CenterPoint Energy reported more than 2 million homes and businesses without power in and around the nation's fourth-largest city. Patrick said the company was bringing in thousands of additional workers to restore power, with top priority for places such as nursing homes and assisted living centers.\n\nAt least two people were killed when trees fell on homes, and the National Hurricane Center said damaging winds and flash flooding would continue as Beryl pushes inland. A third person, a civilian employee of the Houston Police Department, was killed when he was trapped in flood waters under a highway overpass, Houston Mayor John Whitmire said. There were no immediate reports of widespread structural damage, however.\n\nThe loss of power was an all-too familiar experience for Houston: Powerful storms had just ripped through the area in May, killing eight people, leaving nearly 1 million without power and flooding numerous streets.\n\nResidents without power after Beryl were doing their best.\n\n\"We haven't really slept,\" said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in her neighborhood in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio, 67, said she had already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\n\n\"We are struggling to have food and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.\n\nHouston and Harris County officials said power crews would be sent into the area to restore service as quickly as possible, an urgent priority for homes also left without air conditioning in the middle of summer. Temperatures, which had cooled slightly with the storm, were expected to reach back into the 90s as early as Tuesday. The National Weather Service issued a heat advisory that said the area heat index could reach 105 degrees Fahrenheit (41 degrees Celsius).\n\nThe state will be ready to open cooling centers as well as food and water distribution centers, said Nim Kidd, chief of state emergency operations.\n\nBeryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast on Monday, reclosing streets in neighborhoods that had already been washed out by previous storms. Television stations on Monday broadcast the dramatic rescue of a man who had climbed to the roof of his pickup truck after it got trapped in fast-flowing waters. Emergency crews used an extension ladder from a fire truck to drop him a life preserver and a tether before moving him to dry land.\n\nHouston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.\n\n\"First responders are putting their lives at risk. That's what they're trained for. It's working,\" Houston Mayor John Whitmire said.\n\nJavier Mejia was one of about 20 people who gathered near the pickup truck rescue site to take pictures of other submerged vehicles sitting on the flooded highway.\n\n\"If you don't have a way through, you're going to get stuck like that,\" Mejia said.\n\nHaving experienced previous storms in Houston, Mejia stocked up on food and water before Beryl hit, but forgot gas for his portable generator. He planned to spend the day looking for some.\n\n\"I don't want it to go bad,\" he said of the food, adding that if he can't find gas, \"We can just fire up the grill.\"\n\nMany streets and neighborhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents set to work chopping up knocked-down trees and big branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks.\n\nPatrick warned that flooding could last for days as rain continued to fall on already saturated ground.\n\n\"This is not a one-day event,\" he said.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was getting regular updates on the storm after it made landfall, the White House said. The U.S. Coast Guard and FEMA had prepared search and rescue teams, and FEMA collected bottled water, meals, tarps and electric generators in case they are needed.\n\nSeveral companies with refineries or industrial plants in the area reported that the power disruptions necessitated the flaring of gases at the facilities.\n\nMarathon Petroleum Corp. said it conducted a \"safe combustion of excess gases\" at its Galveston Bay Refinery in Texas City, but did not provide information on the amount of gas flared or how long it would continue. Formosa Plastics Corporation and Freeport LNG also reported flaring related to Beryl, according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.\n\nCompanies have 24 hours to share emissions data after the flaring stops, a representative from the TCEQ said in an email.\n\nThe earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, Beryl caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nIn Louisiana, heavy bands of rain were expected all day Monday and \"the risk is going to be for that heavy rainfall and potential for flash flooding,\" National Weather Service meteorologist Donald Jones said in a Monday morning Facebook Live briefing.\n\nThe weather service in Shreveport issued tornado warnings across northwest Louisiana. The agency confirmed on social media that multiple tornadoes had been spotted in that corner of the state. Information on whether those weather events have caused any significant damage was not immediately available.\n\nBeryl was forecast to bring more strong rain and winds into additional states over the coming days. One of those, Missouri was already dealing with a wet summer. Heavy rains unrelated to the storm prompted several water rescues around the city of Columbia, where rivers and creeks were already high ahead of Beryl's expected arrival on Tuesday.\n\nAssociated Press reporters Jim Vertuno in Austin, Texas; Corey Williams in Detroit; Julie Walker in New York; Melina Walling in Chicago; and Jeff Martin in Atlanta contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "kadn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KADN News 15"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@kadn.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "mark_vancleave@kadn.com", "name": "Mark Vancleave", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "juan_a_lozano@kadn.com", "name": "Juan A.
