{"uri": "2024-07-415629664", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "01:17:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T01:17:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-08T21:14:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9254902005195618, "url": "https://www.politico.com/news/2024/07/08/beryl-weakens-after-knocking-out-power-to-millions-in-texas-00166961", "title": "Beryl weakens after knocking out power to millions in Texas", "body": "Texas state and local officials warned it could take several days to restore power after Beryl came ashore as a Category 1 hurricane and toppled 10 transmission lines and knocked down trees that took down power lines.\n\nWithin hours, Beryl had weakened into a tropical storm, far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean last weekend. But the winds and rains of the fast-moving storm were still powerful enough to knock down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in water-saturated earth, and strand dozens of cars on flooded roadways.\n\nAs it moved inland, the storm still threatened to spawn tornadoes.\n\n\"We're not past any difficult conditions,\" said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country, warning it would be a \"multiple day process to get power restored.\"\n\nHouston took a hard hit as CenterPoint Energy reported more than 2 million homes and businesses without power in and around the nation's fourth-largest city. Patrick said the company was bringing in thousands of additional workers to restore power, with top priority for places such as nursing homes and assisted living centers.\n\nAt least two people were killed when trees fell on homes, and the National Hurricane Center said damaging winds and flash flooding would continue as Beryl pushes inland. A third person, a civilian employee of the Houston Police Department, was killed when he was trapped in flood waters under a highway overpass, Houston Mayor John Whitmire said. There were no immediate reports of widespread structural damage, however.\n\nThe loss of power was an all-too-familiar experience for Houston: Powerful storms had just ripped through the area in May, killing eight people, leaving nearly 1 million without power and flooding numerous streets.\n\nResidents without power after Beryl were doing their best.\n\n\"We haven't really slept,\" said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in her neighborhood in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio, 67, said she had already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\n\n\"We are struggling to have food and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.\n\nHouston and Harris County officials said power crews would be sent into the area to restore service as quickly as possible, an urgent priority for homes also left without air conditioning in the middle of summer. Temperatures, which had cooled slightly with the storm, were expected to reach back into the 90s as early as Tuesday. The National Weather Service issued a heat advisory that said the area heat index could reach 105 degrees Fahrenheit (41 degrees Celsius).\n\nThe state will be ready to open cooling centers as well as food and water distribution centers, said Nim Kidd, chief of state emergency operations.\n\nBeryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast on Monday, reclosing streets in neighborhoods that had already been washed out by previous storms. Television stations on Monday broadcast the dramatic rescue of a man who had climbed to the roof of his pickup truck after it got trapped in fast-flowing waters. Emergency crews used an extension ladder from a fire truck to drop him a life preserver and a tether before moving him to dry land.\n\nHouston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.\n\n\"First responders are putting their lives at risk. That's what they're trained for. It's working,\" Houston Mayor John Whitmire said.\n\nJavier Mejia was one of about 20 people who gathered near the pickup truck rescue site to take pictures of other submerged vehicles sitting on the flooded highway.\n\n\"If you don't have a way through, you're going to get stuck like that,\" Mejia said.\n\nHaving experienced previous storms in Houston, Mejia stocked up on food and water before Beryl hit, but forgot gas for his portable generator. He planned to spend the day looking for some.\n\n\"I don't want it to go bad,\" he said of the food, adding that if he can't find gas, \"We can just fire up the grill.\"\n\nMany streets and neighborhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents set to work chopping up knocked-down trees and big branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks.\n\nPatrick warned that flooding could last for days as rain continued to fall on already saturated ground.\n\n\"This is not a one-day event,\" he said.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was getting regular updates on the storm after it made landfall, the White House said. The U.S. Coast Guard and FEMA had prepared search and rescue teams, and FEMA collected bottled water, meals, tarps and electric generators in case they are needed.\n\nSeveral companies with refineries or industrial plants in the area reported that the power disruptions necessitated the flaring of gases at the facilities.\n\nMarathon Petroleum Corp. said it conducted a \"safe combustion of excess gases\" at its Galveston Bay Refinery in Texas City, but did not provide information on the amount of gas flared or how long it would continue. Formosa Plastics Corporation and Freeport LNG also reported flaring related to Beryl, according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.\n\nCompanies have 24 hours to share emissions data after the flaring stops, a representative from the TCEQ said in an email.\n\nThe earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, Beryl caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nIn Louisiana, heavy bands of rain were expected all day Monday and \"the risk is going to be for that heavy rainfall and potential for flash flooding,\" National Weather Service meteorologist Donald Jones said in a Monday morning Facebook Live briefing.\n\nThe weather service in Shreveport issued tornado warnings across northwest Louisiana. The agency confirmed on social media that multiple tornadoes had been spotted in that corner of the state. Information on whether those weather events have caused any significant damage was not immediately available.\n\nBeryl was forecast to bring more strong rain and winds into additional states over the coming days. One of those, Missouri was already dealing with a wet summer. Heavy rains unrelated to the storm prompted several water rescues around the city of Columbia, where rivers and creeks were already high ahead of Beryl's expected arrival on Tuesday.", "source": {"uri": "2024-07-415560312", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-08", "time": "22:32:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-08T22:32:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-08T22:19:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9254902005195618, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/texas-officials-say-restoring-electricity-will-take-days-after-beryl-knocked-out-power-to-millions/article_8ae9456b-a942-5aab-9b63-65f659b5b3ad.html", "title": "Texas officials say restoring electricity will take days after Beryl knocked out power to millions", "body": "City of Galveston workers clear debris from Beryl from the West End of the seawall in Galveston, Texas, on Monday, July 8, 2024. Tropical Storm Beryl was unleashing heavy rains and powerful winds along the Texas coast, knocking out power to more than 2 million homes and businesses and flooding streets with fast-rising waters.\n\nHOUSTON (AP) -- Texas officials say restoring electricity will take days after Beryl came ashore Monday as a Category 1 hurricane and knocked out power to nearly 3 million homes and businesses.\n\nTexas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick said CenterPoint Energy was bringing in thousands of additional workers to help get the lights turned back on quicker. He said the storm toppled 10 transmission lines and that many of the outages were caused by fallen trees.\n\nThe fast-moving tempest threatened to carve a harsh path over several more states in coming days. At least three people were killed as Beryl moved through Texas.\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nHOUSTON (AP) -- Tropical Storm Beryl sped across the Texas coast on Monday, leaving more than 2 million people and businesses without power in the Houston area and unleashing heavy rains that prompted dozens of high-water rescues. The fast-moving tempest threatened to carve a harsh path over several more states in coming days.\n\nWithin hours after Beryl swept ashore as a Category 1 hurricane, it had weakened into a tropical storm, far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean last weekend.\n\nBut the winds and rains of the fast-moving storm were still powerful enough to knock down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in water-saturated earth and to strand dozens of cars on flooded roadways.\n\nAt least two people were killed when trees fell on homes, and the National Hurricane Center said damaging winds and flash flooding would continue as Beryl pushes inland. A third person, a civilian employee of the Houston Police Department, was killed when he was trapped in flood waters under a highway overpass, Houston Mayor John Whitmire said. There were no immediate reports of widespread structural damage, however.\n\nMore than 2.2 million homes and businesses were without power around Houston, the nation's fourth-largest city, after Beryl blew through, according to the CenterPoint Energy utility. For many, it was an all-too-familiar experience: Powerful storms had just ripped through the area in May, killing eight people, leaving nearly 1 million without power and flooding numerous streets.\n\nResidents without power after Beryl were doing their best.\n\n\"We haven't really slept,\" said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in her neighborhood in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio, 67, said already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\n\n\"We are struggling to have food and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.\n\nHouston and Harris County officials said power crews would be sent into the area to restore service as quickly as possible, an urgent priority for homes also left without air conditioning in the middle of summer. Temperatures, which had cooled slightly with the storm, were expected to reach back into the 90s as early as Tuesday.\n\n\"While these efforts are full steam ahead, we want residents to know and prepare for a possible multi-day power outage,\" Galveston city officials said on Facebook. \"The estimated timeline is anywhere from 72 hours to two weeks in parts of the island.\"\n\nBeryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast on Monday, reclosing streets in neighborhoods that had already been washed out by previous storms. Television stations on Monday broadcast the dramatic rescue of a man who had climbed to the roof of his pickup truck after it got trapped in fast-flowing waters. Emergency crews used an extension ladder from a fire truck to drop him a life preserver and a tether before moving him to dry land.\n\nHouston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.\n\n\"First responders are putting their lives at risk. That's what they're trained for. It's working,\" Houston Mayor John Whitmire said.\n\nJavier Mejia was one of about 20 people who gathered near the pickup truck rescue site to take pictures of other submerged vehicles sitting on the flooded highway.\n\n\"If you don't have a way through, you're going to get stuck like that,\" Mejia said.\n\nHaving experienced previous storms in Houston, Mejia stocked up on food and water before Beryl hit, but forgot gas for his portable generator. He planned to spend the day looking for some.\n\n\"I don't want it to go bad,\" he said of the food, adding that if he can't find gas, \"We can just fire up the grill.\"\n\nMany streets and neighborhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents set to work chopping up knocked-down trees and big branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks.\n\nTwo people were killed after trees fell on their houses: a man in the Houston suburb of Humble and a woman in Harris County, authorities said. Hundreds of trees fell in the county, crushing vehicles and damaging homes, said Precinct 4 County Constable Mark Herman.\n\nTexas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country, warned that flooding could last for days as rain continued to fall on already saturated ground.\n\n\"This is not a one-day event,\" he said.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was getting regular updates on the storm after it made landfall, the White House said. The U.S. Coast Guard and FEMA had prepared search and rescue teams, and FEMA collected bottled water, meals, tarps and electric generators in case they are needed.\n\nSeveral companies with refineries or industrial plants in the area reported that the power disruptions necessitated the flaring of gases at the facilities.\n\nMarathon Petroleum Corp. said it conducted a \"safe combustion of excess gases\" at its Galveston Bay Refinery in Texas City, but did not provide information on the amount of gas flared or how long it would continue. Formosa Plastics Corporation and Freeport LNG also reported flaring related to Beryl, according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.\n\nCompanies have 24 hours to share emissions data after the flaring stops, a representative from the TCEQ said in an email.\n\nThe earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, Beryl caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. The storm ripped off doors, windows and roofs with devastating winds and storm surge fueled by the Atlantic's record warmth.\n\nThree times during the week, Beryl gained 35 mph (56 kph) in wind speed in 24 hours or less, the official weather service definition of rapid intensification.\n\nBeryl's explosive growth into an unprecedented early whopper of a storm indicates the hot water of the Atlantic and Caribbean and what the Atlantic hurricane belt can expect for the rest of the storm season, experts said. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nIn Louisiana, heavy bands of rain were expected all day Monday and \"the risk is going to be for that heavy rainfall and potential for flash flooding,\" National Weather Service meteorologist Donald Jones said in a Monday morning Facebook Live briefing.\n\nMeteorologists in Louisiana are watching for lingering rainbands, which could drop copious amounts of rain wherever they materialize, as well as \"quick, spin-up tornadoes,\" said Donald Jones, a National Weather Service meteorologist in Lake Charles, Louisiana.\n\n\"It's just a matter of exactly where that's going to be,\" Jones said. \"That's very difficult to predict more than maybe an hour or so in advance.\"\n\nBeryl was forecast to bring more strong rain and winds into additional states over the coming days. One of those, Missouri was already dealing with a wet summer. Heavy rains unrelated to the storm prompted several water rescues around the city of Columbia, where rivers and creeks were already high ahead of Beryl's expected arrival on Tuesday.\n\nAssociated Press reporters Jim Vertuno in Austin, Texas; Corey Williams in Detroit; Julie Walker in New York; Melina Walling in Chicago; and Jeff Martin in Atlanta contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "register-herald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Beckley Register-Herald"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@register-herald.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "juan_a_lozano@register-herald.com", "name": "Juan A. {"uri": "8216785887", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "10:57:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T10:57:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T10:57:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9176470637321472, "url": "https://www.news-journal.com/news/texas-grapples-with-power-outages-flooding-after-beryls-landfall/article_8af1f542-3d7c-11ef-9305-3f7cb1bf45af.html", "title": "Texas grapples with power outages, flooding after Beryl's landfall", "body": "HOUSTON -- Texas officials say restoring electricity will take days after Tropical Storm Beryl came ashore Monday as a Category 1 hurricane and knocked out power to nearly 3 million homes and businesses.\n\nTexas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country, said CenterPoint Energy was bringing in thousands of additional workers to help get the lights turned back on quicker. He said the storm toppled 10 transmission lines and that many of the outages were caused by fallen trees.\n\nBeryl sped across the Texas coast on Monday, unleashing heavy rains that prompted dozens of high-water rescues. The fast-moving tempest threatened to carve a harsh path over several more states in coming days. At least three people were killed as Beryl moved through Texas.\n\nWithin hours after Beryl swept ashore as a Category 1 hurricane, it had weakened into a tropical storm, far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean last weekend.\n\nBut the winds and rains of the fast-moving storm were still powerful enough to knock down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in water-saturated earth and to strand dozens of cars on flooded roadways.\n\nAt least two people were killed when trees fell on homes, and the National Hurricane Center said damaging winds and flash flooding would continue as Beryl pushes inland. A third person, a civilian employee of the Houston Police Department, was killed when he was trapped in flood waters under a highway overpass, Houston Mayor John Whitmire said. There were no immediate reports of widespread structural damage, however.\n\nMore than 2.2 million homes and businesses were without power around Houston, the nation's fourth-largest city, after Beryl blew through, according to the CenterPoint Energy utility. For many, it was an all-too-familiar experience: Powerful storms had just ripped through the area in May, killing eight people, leaving nearly 1 million without power and flooding numerous streets.\n\nResidents without power after Beryl were doing their best.\n\n\"We haven't really slept,\" said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in her neighborhood in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio, 67, said she had already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\n\n\"We are struggling to have food and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.\n\nHouston and Harris County officials said power crews would be sent into the area to restore service as quickly as possible, an urgent priority for homes also left without air conditioning in the middle of summer. Temperatures, which had cooled slightly with the storm, were expected to reach back into the 90s as early as Tuesday.\n\n\"While these efforts are full steam ahead, we want residents to know and prepare for a possible multi-day power outage,\" Galveston city officials said on Facebook. \"The estimated timeline is anywhere from 72 hours to two weeks in parts of the island.\"\n\nBeryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast on Monday, reclosing streets in neighborhoods that had already been washed out by previous storms. Television stations on Monday broadcast the dramatic rescue of a man who had climbed to the roof of his pickup truck after it got trapped in fast-flowing waters. Emergency crews used an extension ladder from a fire truck to drop him a life preserver and a tether before moving him to dry land.\n\nHouston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.\n\n\"First responders are putting their lives at risk. That's what they're trained for. It's working,\" Houston Mayor John Whitmire said.\n\nJavier Mejia was one of about 20 people who gathered near the pickup truck rescue site to take pictures of other submerged vehicles sitting on the flooded highway.\n\n\"If you don't have a way through, you're going to get stuck like that,\" Mejia said.\n\nSign Up for Newsletters Email* Select Newsletters to Sign Up For News Updates Breaking News Sports Digest Obituaries and Death Notices Submit\n\nHaving experienced previous storms in Houston, Mejia stocked up on food and water before Beryl hit, but forgot gas for his portable generator. He planned to spend the day looking for some.\n\n\"I don't want it to go bad,\" he said of the food, adding that if he can't find gas, \"We can just fire up the grill.\"\n\nMany streets and neighborhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents set to work chopping up knocked-down trees and big branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks.\n\nTwo people were killed after trees fell on their houses: a man in the Houston suburb of Humble and a woman in Harris County, authorities said. Hundreds of trees fell in the county, crushing vehicles and damaging homes, said Precinct 4 County Constable Mark Herman.\n\nPatrick warned that flooding could last for days as rain continued to fall on already saturated ground.\n\n\"This is not a one-day event,\" he said.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was getting regular updates on the storm after it made landfall, the White House said. The U.S. Coast Guard and FEMA had prepared search and rescue teams, and FEMA collected bottled water, meals, tarps and electric generators in case they are needed.\n\nSeveral companies with refineries or industrial plants in the area reported that the power disruptions necessitated the flaring of gases at the facilities.\n\nMarathon Petroleum Corp. said it conducted a \"safe combustion of excess gases\" at its Galveston Bay Refinery in Texas City, but did not provide information on the amount of gas flared or how long it would continue. Formosa Plastics Corporation and Freeport LNG also reported flaring related to Beryl, according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.\n\nCompanies have 24 hours to share emissions data after the flaring stops, a representative from the TCEQ said in an email.\n\nThe earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, Beryl caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. The storm ripped off doors, windows and roofs with devastating winds and storm surge fueled by the Atlantic's record warmth.\n\nThree times during the week, Beryl gained 35 mph in wind speed in 24 hours or less, the official weather service definition of rapid intensification.\n\nBeryl's explosive growth into an unprecedented early whopper of a storm indicates the hot water of the Atlantic and Caribbean and what the Atlantic hurricane belt can expect for the rest of the storm season, experts said. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nIn Louisiana, heavy bands of rain were expected all day Monday and \"the risk is going to be for that heavy rainfall and potential for flash flooding,\" National Weather Service meteorologist Donald Jones said in a Monday morning Facebook Live briefing.\n\nMeteorologists in Louisiana are watching for lingering rainbands, which could drop copious amounts of rain wherever they materialize, as well as \"quick, spin-up tornadoes,\" said Donald Jones, a National Weather Service meteorologist in Lake Charles, Louisiana.\n\n\"It's just a matter of exactly where that's going to be,\" Jones said. \"That's very difficult to predict more than maybe an hour or so in advance.\"\n\nBeryl was forecast to bring more strong rain and winds into additional states over the coming days. One of those, Missouri was already dealing with a wet summer. Heavy rains unrelated to the storm prompted several water rescues around the city of Columbia, where rivers and creeks were already high ahead of Beryl's expected arrival on Tuesday.", "source": "https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/news-journal.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/a/ef/aefe7216-3d7d-11ef-bf6c-633a45100ced/668c6f3cc1bf6.image.jpg?crop=1662%2C873%2C0%2C187&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize", {"uri": "8216044290", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "00:32:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T00:32:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T00:27:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9137254953384399, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/texas-officials-say-restoring-electricity-will-take-days-after-beryl-knocked-out-power-to-millions/article_ec4ab4c6-3581-5b73-9e8a-a799e89dc164.html", "title": "Texas officials say restoring electricity will take days after Beryl knocked out power to millions", "body": "Buffalo Bayou floods stranding vehicles near Downtown Houston after Beryl came ashore in Texas as a hurricane and dumped heavy rains downtown.\n\nHOUSTON (AP) -- Tropical Storm Beryl slammed into Texas on Monday, knocking out power to nearly 3 million homes and businesses and unleashing heavy rains that prompted dozens of high-water rescues. The fast-moving tempest threatened to carve a harsh path over several more states in coming days.\n\nTexas state and local officials warned it could take several days to restore power after Beryl came ashore as a Category 1 hurricane and toppled 10 transmission lines and knocked down trees that took down power lines.\n\nWithin hours, Beryl had weakened into a tropical storm, far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean last weekend. But the winds and rains of the fast-moving storm were still powerful enough to knock down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in water-saturated earth, and strand dozens of cars on flooded roadways.\n\nAs it moved inland, the storm still threatened to spawn tornados.\n\n\"We're not past any difficult conditions,\" said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country, warning it would be a \"multiple day process to get power restored.\"\n\nHouston took a hard hit as CenterPoint Energy reported more than 2 million homes and businesses without power in and around the nation's fourth-largest city. Patrick said the company was bringing in thousands of additional workers to restore power, with top priority for places such as nursing homes and assisted living centers.\n\nAt least two people were killed when trees fell on homes, and the National Hurricane Center said damaging winds and flash flooding would continue as Beryl pushes inland. A third person, a civilian employee of the Houston Police Department, was killed when he was trapped in flood waters under a highway overpass, Houston Mayor John Whitmire said. There were no immediate reports of widespread structural damage, however.\n\nThe loss of power was an all-too familiar experience for Houston: Powerful storms had just ripped through the area in May, killing eight people, leaving nearly 1 million without power and flooding numerous streets.\n\nResidents without power after Beryl were doing their best.\n\n\"We haven't really slept,\" said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in her neighborhood in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio, 67, said she had already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\n\n\"We are struggling to have food and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.\n\nHouston and Harris County officials said power crews would be sent into the area to restore service as quickly as possible, an urgent priority for homes also left without air conditioning in the middle of summer. Temperatures, which had cooled slightly with the storm, were expected to reach back into the 90s as early as Tuesday. The National Weather Service issued a heat advisory that said the area heat index could reach 105 degrees Fahrenheit (41 degrees Celsius).\n\nThe state will be ready to open cooling centers as well as food and water distribution centers, said Nim Kidd, chief of state emergency operations.\n\nBeryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast on Monday, reclosing streets in neighborhoods that had already been washed out by previous storms. Television stations on Monday broadcast the dramatic rescue of a man who had climbed to the roof of his pickup truck after it got trapped in fast-flowing waters. Emergency crews used an extension ladder from a fire truck to drop him a life preserver and a tether before moving him to dry land.\n\nHouston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.\n\n\"First responders are putting their lives at risk. That's what they're trained for. It's working,\" Houston Mayor John Whitmire said.\n\nJavier Mejia was one of about 20 people who gathered near the pickup truck rescue site to take pictures of other submerged vehicles sitting on the flooded highway.\n\n\"If you don't have a way through, you're going to get stuck like that,\" Mejia said.\n\nHaving experienced previous storms in Houston, Mejia stocked up on food and water before Beryl hit, but forgot gas for his portable generator. He planned to spend the day looking for some.\n\n\"I don't want it to go bad,\" he said of the food, adding that if he can't find gas, \"We can just fire up the grill.\"\n\nMany streets and neighborhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents set to work chopping up knocked-down trees and big branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks.\n\nPatrick warned that flooding could last for days as rain continued to fall on already saturated ground.\n\n\"This is not a one-day event,\" he said.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was getting regular updates on the storm after it made landfall, the White House said. The U.S. Coast Guard and FEMA had prepared search and rescue teams, and FEMA collected bottled water, meals, tarps and electric generators in case they are needed.\n\nSeveral companies with refineries or industrial plants in the area reported that the power disruptions necessitated the flaring of gases at the facilities.\n\nMarathon Petroleum Corp. said it conducted a \"safe combustion of excess gases\" at its Galveston Bay Refinery in Texas City, but did not provide information on the amount of gas flared or how long it would continue. Formosa Plastics Corporation and Freeport LNG also reported flaring related to Beryl, according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.\n\nCompanies have 24 hours to share emissions data after the flaring stops, a representative from the TCEQ said in an email.\n\nThe earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, Beryl caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. The storm ripped off doors, windows and roofs with devastating winds and storm surge fueled by the Atlantic's record warmth.\n\nThree times during the week, Beryl gained 35 mph (56 kph) in wind speed in 24 hours or less, the official weather service definition of rapid intensification.\n\nBeryl's explosive growth into an unprecedented early whopper of a storm indicates the hot water of the Atlantic and Caribbean and what the Atlantic hurricane belt can expect for the rest of the storm season, experts said. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nIn Louisiana, heavy bands of rain were expected all day Monday and \"the risk is going to be for that heavy rainfall and potential for flash flooding,\" National Weather Service meteorologist Donald Jones said in a Monday morning Facebook Live briefing.\n\nThe weather service in Shreveport issued tornado warnings across northwest Louisiana. The agency confirmed on social media that multiple tornados had been spotted in that corner of the state. Information on whether those weather events have caused any significant damage was not immediately available.\n\nBeryl was forecast to bring more strong rain and winds into additional states over the coming days. One of those, Missouri was already dealing with a wet summer. Heavy rains unrelated to the storm prompted several water rescues around the city of Columbia, where rivers and creeks were already high ahead of Beryl's expected arrival on Tuesday.\n\nAssociated Press reporters Jim Vertuno in Austin, Texas; Corey Williams in Detroit; Julie Walker in New York; Melina Walling in Chicago; and Jeff Martin in Atlanta contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "eagletribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Eagle-Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@eagletribune.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "juan_a_lozano@eagletribune.com", "name": "Juan A. {"uri": "8216057344", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "00:47:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T00:47:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T00:46:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9137254953384399, "url": "https://medicinehatnews.com/news/world-news/2024/07/08/beryl-weakens-to-tropical-depression-after-slamming-into-texas-as-category-1-hurricane/", "title": "Beryl weakens to tropical depression after slamming into Texas as Category 1 hurricane - Medicine Hat News", "body": "By Mark Vancleave And Juan A. Lozano, The Associated Press on July 8, 2024.\n\nLeo Cardin walks past a Confederate Artillery Battery display as he watches storm clouds roll in ahead of Beryl, Sunday, July 7, 2024, in Port Lavaca, Texas. (AP Photo/Eric Gay)HOUSTON (AP) - After Tropical Storm Beryl slammed into Texas early Monday, knocking out power to nearly 3 million homes and businesses and killing several people it moved east and weakened to a tropical depression, the National Hurricane Center said Monday evening. Flooding, rains and tornadoes were possible across portions of eastern Texas, Western Louisiana and Arkansas. THIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below. HOUSTON (AP) - Tropical Storm Beryl slammed into Texas on Monday, knocking out power to nearly 3 million homes and businesses and unleashing heavy rains that prompted dozens of high-water rescues. The fast-moving tempest threatened to carve a harsh path over several more states in coming days. Texas state and local officials warned it could take several days to restore power after Beryl came ashore as a Category 1 hurricane and toppled 10 transmission lines and knocked down trees that took down power lines. Within hours, Beryl had weakened into a tropical storm, far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean last weekend. But the winds and rains of the fast-moving storm were still powerful enough to knock down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in water-saturated earth, and strand dozens of cars on flooded roadways. As it moved inland, the storm still threatened to spawn tornados. \"We're not past any difficult conditions,\"\u009d said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country, warning it would be a \"\u009dmultiple day process to get power restored.\"\u009d Houston took a hard hit as CenterPoint Energy reported more than 2 million homes and businesses without power in and around the nation's fourth-largest city. Patrick said the company was bringing in thousands of additional workers to restore power, with top priority for places such as nursing homes and assisted living centers. At least two people were killed when trees fell on homes, and the National Hurricane Center said damaging winds and flash flooding would continue as Beryl pushes inland. A third person, a civilian employee of the Houston Police Department, was killed when he was trapped in flood waters under a highway overpass, Houston Mayor John Whitmire said. There were no immediate reports of widespread structural damage, however. The loss of power was an all-too familiar experience for Houston: Powerful storms had just ripped through the area in May, killing eight people, leaving nearly 1 million without power and flooding numerous streets. Residents without power after Beryl were doing their best. \"We haven't really slept,\"\u009d said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in her neighborhood in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio, 67, said she had already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled. \"We are struggling to have food and losing that food would be difficult,\"\u009d she said. Houston and Harris County officials said power crews would be sent into the area to restore service as quickly as possible, an urgent priority for homes also left without air conditioning in the middle of summer. Temperatures, which had cooled slightly with the storm, were expected to reach back into the 90s as early as Tuesday. The National Weather Service issued a heat advisory that said the area heat index could reach 105 degrees Fahrenheit (41 degrees Celsius). The state will be ready to open cooling centers as well as food and water distribution centers, said Nim Kidd, chief of state emergency operations. Beryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast on Monday, reclosing streets in neighborhoods that had already been washed out by previous storms. Television stations on Monday broadcast the dramatic rescue of a man who had climbed to the roof of his pickup truck after it got trapped in fast-flowing waters. Emergency crews used an extension ladder from a fire truck to drop him a life preserver and a tether before moving him to dry land. Houston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters. \"First responders are putting their lives at risk. That's what they're trained for. It's working,\"\u009d Houston Mayor John Whitmire said. Javier Mejia was one of about 20 people who gathered near the pickup truck rescue site to take pictures of other submerged vehicles sitting on the flooded highway. \"If you don't have a way through, you're going to get stuck like that,\"\u009d Mejia said. Having experienced previous storms in Houston, Mejia stocked up on food and water before Beryl hit, but forgot gas for his portable generator. He planned to spend the day looking for some. \"I don't want it to go bad,\" he said of the food, adding that if he can't find gas, \"We can just fire up the grill.\"\u009d Many streets and neighborhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents set to work chopping up knocked-down trees and big branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks. Patrick warned that flooding could last for days as rain continued to fall on already saturated ground. \"This is not a one-day event,\"\u009d he said. President Joe Biden was getting regular updates on the storm after it made landfall, the White House said. The U.S. Coast Guard and FEMA had prepared search and rescue teams, and FEMA collected bottled water, meals, tarps and electric generators in case they are needed. Several companies with refineries or industrial plants in the area reported that the power disruptions necessitated the flaring of gases at the facilities. Marathon Petroleum Corp. said it conducted a \"safe combustion of excess gases\"\u009d at its Galveston Bay Refinery in Texas City, but did not provide information on the amount of gas flared or how long it would continue. Formosa Plastics Corporation and Freeport LNG also reported flaring related to Beryl, according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality. Companies have 24 hours to share emissions data after the flaring stops, a representative from the TCEQ said in an email. The earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, Beryl caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure. In Louisiana, heavy bands of rain were expected all day Monday and \"the risk is going to be for that heavy rainfall and potential for flash flooding,\"\u009d National Weather Service meteorologist Donald Jones said in a Monday morning Facebook Live briefing. The weather service in Shreveport issued tornado warnings across northwest Louisiana. The agency confirmed on social media that multiple tornados had been spotted in that corner of the state. Information on whether those weather events have caused any significant damage was not immediately available. Beryl was forecast to bring more strong rain and winds into additional states over the coming days. One of those, Missouri was already dealing with a wet summer. Heavy rains unrelated to the storm prompted several water rescues around the city of Columbia, where rivers and creeks were already high ahead of Beryl's expected arrival on Tuesday. ___ Associated Press reporters Jim Vertuno in Austin, Texas; Corey Williams in Detroit; Julie Walker in New York; Melina Walling in Chicago; and Jeff Martin in Atlanta contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8216600142", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "09:04:04", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T09:04:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T09:03:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9137254953384399, "url": "https://www.nwaonline.com/news/2024/jul/09/millions-without-power-after-beryl-slams-texas/", "title": "Millions without power after Beryl slams Texas", "body": "HOUSTON -- After Hurricane Beryl slammed into Texas early Monday, knocking out power to nearly 3 million homes and businesses, unleashing heavy rain and killing at least three people, it moved east and later weakened to a tropical depression, the National Hurricane Center said Monday evening. The fast-moving tempest threatened to carve a harsh path over several more states in coming days.\n\nTexas state and local officials warned that it could take several days to restore power after Beryl came ashore as a Category 1 hurricane and toppled 10 transmission lines and knocked down trees that took down power lines.\n\nBeryl later weakened into a tropical storm and then a tropical depression, far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean last weekend. But the winds and rains of the fast-moving storm were still powerful enough to knock down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in water-saturated earth, and strand dozens of cars on flooded roadways.\n\nAs it moved inland, the storm threatened to spawn tornadoes and the National Weather Service confirmed on social media that tornadoes had been spotted in northeastern Louisiana. Bossier Sheriff Julian Whittington said in a Facebook post that a woman was killed in the Benton area when a tree fell on her home.\n\n\"We're not past any difficult conditions,\" said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country, warning that it would be a \"multiple-day process to get power restored.\"\n\nHouston took a hard hit as CenterPoint Energy reported more than 2 million homes and businesses without power in and around the nation's fourth-largest city. Patrick said the company was bringing in thousands of additional workers to restore power, with top priority for places such as nursing homes and assisted living centers.\n\nAt least two people were killed when trees fell on homes, and the National Hurricane Center said damaging winds and flash flooding would continue as Beryl pushes inland. A third person, a civilian employee of the Houston Police Department, was killed when he was trapped in flood waters under a highway overpass, Houston Mayor John Whitmire said. There were no immediate reports of widespread structural damage, however.\n\nPhoto GalleryBeryl causes damage in Texas\n\nThe loss of power was an all-too-familiar experience for Houston: Powerful storms had just ripped through the area in May, killing eight people, leaving nearly 1 million without power and flooding numerous streets.\n\nResidents without power after Beryl were doing their best.\n\n\"We haven't really slept,\" said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in her neighborhood in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio, 67, said she had already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\n\n\"We are struggling to have food and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.\n\nHouston and Harris County officials said power crews would be sent into the area to restore service as quickly as possible, an urgent priority for homes also left without air conditioning in the middle of summer. Temperatures, which had lowered slightly with the storm, were expected to climb back into the 90s as early as Tuesday. The National Weather Service issued a heat advisory that said the area heat index could reach 105 degrees Fahrenheit.\n\nThe state will be ready to open cooling centers as well as food and water distribution centers, said Nim Kidd, chief of state emergency operations.\n\nBeryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast Monday, reclosing streets in neighborhoods that had already been washed out by previous storms. Television stations on Monday broadcast the dramatic rescue of a man who had climbed to the roof of his pickup after it got trapped in fast-flowing waters. Emergency crews used an extension ladder from a fire truck to drop him a life preserver and a tether before moving him to dry land.\n\nHouston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.\n\nMany streets and neighborhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents set to work chopping up knocked-down trees and big branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks.\n\nPatrick warned that flooding could last for days as rain continued to fall on already saturated ground.\n\n\"This is not a one-day event,\" he said.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was getting regular updates on the storm after it made landfall, the White House said. The U.S. Coast Guard and the Federal Emergency Management Agency had prepared search-and-rescue teams and collected bottled water, meals, tarps and electric generators in case they are needed.\n\nSeveral companies with refineries or industrial plants in the area reported that the power disruptions necessitated the flaring of gases at the facilities.\n\nMarathon Petroleum Corp. said it conducted a \"safe combustion of excess gases\" at its Galveston Bay Refinery in Texas City, but did not provide information on the amount of gas flared or how long it would continue. Formosa Plastics Corporation and Freeport LNG also reported flaring related to Beryl, according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.\n\nCompanies have 24 hours to share emissions data after the flaring stops, a representative from the TCEQ said in an email.\n\nThe earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, Beryl caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas.\n\nBeryl was forecast to bring more strong rain and winds into additional states over the coming days.\n\nInformation for this article was contributed by Jim Vertuno, Corey Williams, Julie Walker, Melina Walling and Jeff Martin of The Associated Press.\n\nHook Jefferson assesses damages after a tree fell on his neighbor's home after Hurricane Beryl hit the Texas coast, Monday, July 8, 2024, in Bay City, Texas. (AP Photo/Eric Gay)\n\nA man looks out a patio at The Oceanfront Loft Apartments in Galveston, Texas, after the patio was damaged from Tropical Storm Beryl on Monday, July 8, 2024. (Elizabeth Conley/Houston Chronicle via AP)\n\nLouise Cohen, right, and Zilfa Ruhen help clear neighborhood drains after Beryl made landfall early morning Monday, July 8, 2024, in Houston. The National Hurricane Center said damaging winds and flash flooding will continue as Beryl continues pushing inland. (Ishika Samant/Houston Chronicle via AP)\n\nAnthony Le, left, and his father Phuong Le help pull a car stuck in the mud after Beryl made landfall early morning Monday, July 8, 2024, in Houston. The National Hurricane Center said damaging winds and flash flooding will continue as Beryl continues pushing inland. (Ishika Samant/Houston Chronicle via AP)\n\nA horse runs through a flooded field after Beryl moved through the area, Monday, July 8, 2024, in Matagorda, Texas. Tropical Storm Beryl unleashed heavy rains and powerful winds along the Texas coast on Monday, knocking out power to homes and businesses and flooding streets with fast-rising waters as first responders raced to rescue stranded residents. (AP Photo/Eric Gay)\n\nDesi Littleton assesses damages after a tree fell on his home after Hurricane Beryl hit the Texas coast, Monday, July 8, 2024, in Bay City, Texas. (AP Photo/Eric Gay)\n\nA tattered flag tips in the wind after Beryl moved through the area, Monday, July 8, 2024, in Matagorda, Texas. The National Hurricane Center said damaging winds and flash flooding will continue as Beryl continues pushing inland. (AP Photo/Eric Gay)\n\nAndrew Parada, an employee at Residence Inn mops up the floor as water keeps leaking in during Tropical Storm Beryl wanes on Monday, July 8, 2024, Galveston, Texas. (Elizabeth Conley/Houston Chronicle via AP)\n\nCity of Galveston workers clear debris from Beryl from the West End of the seawall in Galveston, Texas, on Monday, July 8, 2024. Tropical Storm Beryl was unleashing heavy rains and powerful winds along the Texas coast, knocking out power to more than 2 million homes and businesses and flooding streets with fast-rising waters. {"uri": "2024-07-415530669", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-08", "time": "21:30:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-08T21:30:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-08T21:19:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9058823585510254, "url": "https://www.timesdaily.com/ap/national/tropical-storm-beryl-topples-trees-floods-highways-and-leaves-more-than-2m-without-power-in/article_50f816ac-1652-591f-b859-7e52ce5db46b.html", "title": "Tropical Storm Beryl topples trees, floods highways and leaves more than 2M without power in Texas", "body": "City of Galveston workers clear debris from Beryl from the West End of the seawall in Galveston, Texas, on Monday, July 8, 2024. Tropical Storm Beryl was unleashing heavy rains and powerful winds along the Texas coast, knocking out power to more than 2 million homes and businesses and flooding streets with fast-rising waters.\n\nHOUSTON (AP) -- Tropical Storm Beryl sped across the Texas coast on Monday, leaving more than 2 million people and businesses without power in the Houston area and unleashing heavy rains that prompted dozens of high-water rescues. The fast-moving tempest threatened to carve a harsh path over several more states in coming days.", "source": {"uri": "timesdaily.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "TimesDaily"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@timesdaily.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": true}, {"uri": "juan_a_lozano@timesdaily.com", "name": "Juan A. {"uri": "8216794198", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "11:02:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T11:02:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T11:02:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "url": "https://www.nbcdfw.com/news/local/texas-news/some-power-restored-in-houston-after-hurricane-beryl-while-storm-spawns-tornadoes-as-it-moves-east/3586907/", "title": "Some power restored in Houston after Hurricane Beryl, millions still without electricity on Tuesday", "body": "Seven people have died in Texas since the storm came ashore early Monday.\n\nPower started to come back for some of the millions of homes and businesses left in the dark when Hurricane Beryl slammed into the Houston area, while the weakened storm moved east, spawning suspected tornadoes and causing more damage.\n\nBeryl was blamed for killing several people in Texas on Monday and at least one person in Louisiana, officials said.\n\nAfter a peak Monday of more than 2.7 million customers around Houston without power, the numbers improved to more than 2.4 million homes and businesses lacking electricity by Monday night, according to PowerOutage.us. The lack of cooling to people's homes, downed power lines and non-functioning traffic lights led officials to ask residents to stay home if possible.\n\n\"Houstonians need to know we're working around the clock so you will be safe,\" Houston Mayor John Whitmire said Monday at a media briefing, urging residents to also know the dangers of high water, to stay hydrated and to check on their neighbors.\n\nBeryl later Monday weakened into a tropical depression with maximum wind speeds of about 35 mph (56 kph). The storm still packed a punch, and the National Weather Service confirmed on social media Monday evening that tornadoes had been spotted in northeastern Louisiana. Bossier Sheriff Julian Whittington said in a Facebook post that a woman was killed in the Benton area when a tree fell on her home.\n\nTracking Beryl -- see the latest storm path and radar images here\n\nDozens of tornado warnings were issued in Louisiana and Arkansas on Monday evening and they continued into the night.\n\nWhile weakened, Beryl threatened to unleash harsh weather over several more states in coming days.\n\nTexas state and local officials warned it could take several days to fully restore power after Beryl came ashore as a Category 1 hurricane and toppled 10 transmission lines and knocked down trees that took down power lines.\n\nBeryl on Tuesday was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean last weekend. But its winds and rains were still powerful enough to knock down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in water-saturated earth, and strand dozens of cars on flooded roadways.\n\n\"We're not past any difficult conditions,\" said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country.\n\nPatrick said CenterPoint Energy was bringing thousands of additional workers to restore power, with top priorities including nursing homes and assisted living centers.\n\nAt least two people were killed when trees fell on homes in Texas, and a third person, a civilian employee of the Houston Police Department, was killed when he was trapped in flood waters under a highway overpass, Whitmire said.\n\nThe loss of power was an all-too familiar experience for Houston: Powerful storms had just ripped through the area in May, killing eight people, leaving nearly 1 million without power and flooding numerous streets.\n\nResidents without power after Beryl were doing their best.\n\n\"We haven't really slept,\" said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in her neighborhood in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio said she had already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\n\n\"We are struggling to have food and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.\n\nPower crews were working to restore service as quickly as possible, an urgent priority for homes also left without air conditioning in the middle of summer. Temperatures in the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) were expected Tuesday. The National Weather Service issued a heat advisory that said the area heat index could reach 105 F (40.5 C).\n\nThe state was opening cooling centers as well as food and water distribution centers, said Nim Kidd, chief of state emergency operations.\n\nBeryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast on Monday, reclosing streets in neighborhoods that had already been washed out by previous storms. Television stations on Monday broadcast the dramatic rescue of a man who had climbed to the roof of his pickup truck after it got trapped in fast-flowing waters. Emergency crews used an extension ladder from a fire truck to drop him a life preserver and a tether before moving him to dry land.\n\nHouston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.\n\nMany streets and neighborhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents chopped up knocked-down trees and branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks.\n\nPatrick warned that flooding could last for days as rain continued to fall on already saturated ground.\n\n\"This is not a one-day event,\" he said.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was getting regular updates on the storm after it made landfall and called the Houston mayor on Monday, the White House said. He told the mayor his administration will make sure Texans have the resources they need to get through the storm and recovery.\n\nSeveral companies with refineries or industrial plants in the area reported that the power disruptions necessitated the flaring of gases at the facilities.\n\nMarathon Petroleum Corp. said it conducted a \"safe combustion of excess gases\" at its Galveston Bay Refinery in Texas City, but did not provide information on the amount of gas flared or how long it would continue. Formosa Plastics Corporation and Freeport LNG also reported flaring related to Beryl, according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.\n\nCompanies have 24 hours to share emissions data after the flaring stops, a representative from the TCEQ said in an email.\n\nThe earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, Beryl caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nBeryl was forecast to bring more strong rain and winds into additional states over the coming days. One of those, Missouri was already dealing with a wet summer. Heavy rains unrelated to the storm prompted several water rescues around the city of Columbia, where rivers and creeks were already high ahead of Beryl's expected arrival on Tuesday.", "source": {"uri": "2024-07-415728814", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "04:29:28", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T04:29:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T04:04:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "url": "https://www.wboc.com/news/national/some-power-restored-in-houston-after-hurricane-beryl-while-storm-spawns-tornadoes-as-it-moves/article_1ef298a3-6ad1-57ae-b359-bdbdd51238ce.html", "title": "Some power restored in Houston after Hurricane Beryl, while storm spawns tornadoes as it moves east", "body": "Buffalo Bayou floods stranding vehicles near Downtown Houston after Beryl came ashore in Texas as a hurricane and dumped heavy rains downtown.\n\nHOUSTON (AP) -- Power started to come back for some of the millions of homes and businesses left in the dark when Hurricane Beryl slammed into the Houston area, while the weakened storm moved east, spawning suspected tornadoes and causing more damage.\n\nBeryl was blamed for killing several people in Texas on Monday and at least one person in Louisiana, officials said.\n\nAfter a peak Monday of more than 2.7 million customers around Houston without power, the numbers improved to more than 2.4 million homes and businesses lacking electricity by Monday night, according to PowerOutage.us. The lack of cooling to people's homes, downed power lines and non-functioning traffic lights led officials to ask residents to stay home if possible.\n\n\"Houstonians need to know we're working around the clock so you will be safe,\" Houston Mayor John Whitmire said Monday at a media briefing, urging residents to also know the dangers of high water, to stay hydrated and to check on their neighbors.\n\nBeryl later Monday weakened into a tropical depression with maximum wind speeds of about 35 mph (56 kph). The storm still packed a punch, and the National Weather Service confirmed on social media Monday evening that tornadoes had been spotted in northeastern Louisiana. Bossier Sheriff Julian Whittington said in a Facebook post that a woman was killed in the Benton area when a tree fell on her home.\n\nDozens of tornado warnings were issued in Louisiana and Arkansas on Monday evening and they continued into the night.\n\nWhile weakened, Beryl threatened to unleash harsh weather over several more states in coming days.\n\nTexas state and local officials warned it could take several days to fully restore power after Beryl came ashore as a Category 1 hurricane and toppled 10 transmission lines and knocked down trees that took down power lines.\n\nBeryl on Tuesday was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean last weekend. But its winds and rains were still powerful enough to knock down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in water-saturated earth, and strand dozens of cars on flooded roadways.\n\n\"We're not past any difficult conditions,\" said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country.\n\nPatrick said CenterPoint Energy was bringing thousands of additional workers to restore power, with top priorities including nursing homes and assisted living centers.\n\nAt least two people were killed when trees fell on homes in Texas, and a third person, a civilian employee of the Houston Police Department, was killed when he was trapped in flood waters under a highway overpass, Whitmire said.\n\nThe loss of power was an all-too familiar experience for Houston: Powerful storms had just ripped through the area in May, killing eight people, leaving nearly 1 million without power and flooding numerous streets.\n\nResidents without power after Beryl were doing their best.\n\n\"We haven't really slept,\" said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in her neighborhood in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio said she had already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\n\n\"We are struggling to have food and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.\n\nPower crews were working to restore service as quickly as possible, an urgent priority for homes also left without air conditioning in the middle of summer. Temperatures in the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) were expected Tuesday. The National Weather Service issued a heat advisory that said the area heat index could reach 105 F (40.5 C).\n\nThe state was opening cooling centers as well as food and water distribution centers, said Nim Kidd, chief of state emergency operations.\n\nBeryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast on Monday, reclosing streets in neighborhoods that had already been washed out by previous storms. Television stations on Monday broadcast the dramatic rescue of a man who had climbed to the roof of his pickup truck after it got trapped in fast-flowing waters. Emergency crews used an extension ladder from a fire truck to drop him a life preserver and a tether before moving him to dry land.\n\nHouston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.\n\nMany streets and neighborhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents chopped up knocked-down trees and branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks.\n\nPatrick warned that flooding could last for days as rain continued to fall on already saturated ground.\n\n\"This is not a one-day event,\" he said.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was getting regular updates on the storm after it made landfall and called the Houston mayor on Monday, the White House said. He told the mayor his administration will make sure Texans have the resources they need to get through the storm and recovery.\n\nSeveral companies with refineries or industrial plants in the area reported that the power disruptions necessitated the flaring of gases at the facilities.\n\nMarathon Petroleum Corp. said it conducted a \"safe combustion of excess gases\" at its Galveston Bay Refinery in Texas City, but did not provide information on the amount of gas flared or how long it would continue. Formosa Plastics Corporation and Freeport LNG also reported flaring related to Beryl, according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.\n\nCompanies have 24 hours to share emissions data after the flaring stops, a representative from the TCEQ said in an email.\n\nThe earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, Beryl caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nBeryl was forecast to bring more strong rain and winds into additional states over the coming days. One of those, Missouri was already dealing with a wet summer. Heavy rains unrelated to the storm prompted several water rescues around the city of Columbia, where rivers and creeks were already high ahead of Beryl's expected arrival on Tuesday.\n\nAssociated Press reporters Jim Vertuno in Austin, Texas; Corey Williams in Detroit; Julie Walker in New York; Melina Walling in Chicago; Jeff Martin in Atlanta; and Sara Cline in Baton Rouge, Louisiana, contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "wboc.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WBOC TV-16"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@wboc.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "juan_a_lozano@wboc.com", "name": "Juan A. {"uri": "8216011453", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-08", "time": "23:41:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-08T23:41:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-08T23:40:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "url": "https://abc7amarillo.com/news/local/hurricane-beryl-causes-widespread-power-outages-and-flooding-in-texas-killing-one", "title": "Tropical storm Beryl ravages Texas, leaves 2 dead and millions without power", "body": "NOTE - The original title of this article has been shortened from \"Texas officials say restoring electricity will take days after Beryl knocked out power to millions.\"\n\nHOUSTON (AP) -- Texas officials say restoring electricity will take days after Beryl came ashore Monday as a Category 1 hurricane and knocked out power to nearly 3 million homes and businesses.\n\nTexas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country, said CenterPoint Energy was bringing in thousands of additional workers to help get the lights turned back on quicker. He said the storm toppled 10 transmission lines and that many of the outages were caused by fallen trees.\n\nBeryl sped across the Texas coast on Monday, unleashing heavy rains that prompted dozens of high-water rescues. The fast-moving tempest threatened to carve a harsh path over several more states in coming days. At least three people were killed as Beryl moved through Texas.\n\nWithin hours after Beryl swept ashore as a Category 1 hurricane, it had weakened into a tropical storm, far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean last weekend.\n\nBut the winds and rains of the fast-moving storm were still powerful enough to knock down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in water-saturated earth and to strand dozens of cars on flooded roadways.\n\nAt least two people were killed when trees fell on homes, and the National Hurricane Center said damaging winds and flash flooding would continue as Beryl pushes inland. A third person, a civilian employee of the Houston Police Department, was killed when he was trapped in flood waters under a highway overpass, Houston Mayor John Whitmire said. There were no immediate reports of widespread structural damage, however.\n\nMore than 2.2 million homes and businesses were without power around Houston, the nation's fourth-largest city, after Beryl blew through, according to the CenterPoint Energy utility. For many, it was an all-too-familiar experience: Powerful storms had just ripped through the area in May, killing eight people, leaving nearly 1 million without power and flooding numerous streets.\n\nResidents without power after Beryl were doing their best.\n\n\"We haven't really slept,\" said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in her neighborhood in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio, 67, said she had already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\n\n\"We are struggling to have food and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.\n\nTornadoes and flash flooding were also possible in eastern Texas, Louisiana, and Arkansas, the hurricane center said.\n\nIn the Texas coastal city of Freeport, Patti Richardson said she was riding out the the storm in her 123-year-old house.\n\n\"We are sitting in the middle of it. It sounds like we are in a train station, it's that loud and has been about four hours. We're just hoping everything holds together,\" Richardson said. \"You can feel the house shaking. ... It's freaky.\"\n\nMore than 1,000 flights have been canceled at Houston's two airports, according to tracking data from FlightAware.\n\nHouston and Harris County officials said power crews would be sent into the area to restore service as quickly as possible, an urgent priority for homes also left without air conditioning in the middle of summer. Temperatures, which had cooled slightly with the storm, were expected to reach back into the 90s as early as Tuesday.\n\n\"While these efforts are full steam ahead, we want residents to know and prepare for a possible multi-day power outage,\" Galveston city officials said on Facebook. \"The estimated timeline is anywhere from 72 hours to two weeks in parts of the island.\"\n\nBeryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast on Monday, reclosing streets in neighborhoods that had already been washed out by previous storms. Television stations on Monday broadcast the dramatic rescue of a man who had climbed to the roof of his pickup truck after it got trapped in fast-flowing waters. Emergency crews used an extension ladder from a fire truck to drop him a life preserver and a tether before moving him to dry land.\n\nHouston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.\n\n\"First responders are putting their lives at risk. That's what they're trained for. It's working,\" Houston Mayor John Whitmire said.\n\nJavier Mejia was one of about 20 people who gathered near the pickup truck rescue site to take pictures of other submerged vehicles sitting on the flooded highway.\n\n\"If you don't have a way through, you're going to get stuck like that,\" Mejia said.\n\nHaving experienced previous storms in Houston, Mejia stocked up on food and water before Beryl hit, but forgot gas for his portable generator. He planned to spend the day looking for some.\n\n\"I don't want it to go bad,\" he said of the food, adding that if he can't find gas, \"We can just fire up the grill.\"\n\nMany streets and neighborhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents set to work chopping up knocked-down trees and big branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks.\n\nTwo people were killed after trees fell on their houses: a man in the Houston suburb of Humble and a woman in Harris County, authorities said. Hundreds of trees fell in the county, crushing vehicles and damaging homes, said Precinct 4 County Constable Mark Herman.\n\nPatrick warned that flooding could last for days as rain continued to fall on already saturated ground.\n\n\"This is not a one-day event,\" he said.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was getting regular updates on the storm after it made landfall, the White House said. The U.S. Coast Guard and FEMA had prepared search and rescue teams, and FEMA collected bottled water, meals, tarps and electric generators in case they are needed.\n\nSeveral companies with refineries or industrial plants in the area reported that the power disruptions necessitated the flaring of gases at the facilities.\n\nMarathon Petroleum Corp. said it conducted a \"safe combustion of excess gases\" at its Galveston Bay Refinery in Texas City, but did not provide information on the amount of gas flared or how long it would continue. Formosa Plastics Corporation and Freeport LNG also reported flaring related to Beryl, according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.\n\nCompanies have 24 hours to share emissions data after the flaring stops, a representative from the TCEQ said in an email.\n\nThe earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, Beryl caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. The storm ripped off doors, windows and roofs with devastating winds and storm surge fueled by the Atlantic's record warmth.\n\nThree times during the week, Beryl gained 35 mph (56 kph) in wind speed in 24 hours or less, the official weather service definition of rapid intensification.\n\nBeryl's explosive growth into an unprecedented early whopper of a storm indicates the hot water of the Atlantic and Caribbean and what the Atlantic hurricane belt can expect for the rest of the storm season, experts said. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nIn Louisiana, heavy bands of rain were expected all day Monday and \"the risk is going to be for that heavy rainfall and potential for flash flooding,\" National Weather Service meteorologist Donald Jones said in a Monday morning Facebook Live briefing.\n\nMeteorologists in Louisiana are watching for lingering rainbands, which could drop copious amounts of rain wherever they materialize, as well as \"quick, spin-up tornadoes,\" said Donald Jones, a National Weather Service meteorologist in Lake Charles, Louisiana.\n\n\"It's just a matter of exactly where that's going to be,\" Jones said. \"That's very difficult to predict more than maybe an hour or so in advance.\"\n\nBeryl was forecast to bring more strong rain and winds into additional states over the coming days. One of those, Missouri was already dealing with a wet summer. Heavy rains unrelated to the storm prompted several water rescues around the city of Columbia, where rivers and creeks were already high ahead of Beryl's expected arrival on Tuesday.\n\n__", "source":
