{"uri": "2024-07-415759587", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "05:16:28", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T05:16:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T00:04:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/texas/articles/2024-07-09/some-power-restored-in-houston-after-hurricane-beryl-while-storm-spawns-tornadoes-as-it-moves-east", "title": "Some Power Restored in Houston After Hurricane Beryl, While Storm Spawns Tornadoes as It Moves East", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- Power started to come back for some of the millions of homes and businesses left in the dark when Hurricane Beryl slammed into the Houston area, while the weakened storm moved east, spawning suspected tornadoes and causing more damage.\n\nBeryl was blamed for killing several people in Texas on Monday and at least one person in Louisiana, officials said.\n\nAfter a peak Monday of more than 2.7 million customers around Houston without power, the numbers improved to more than 2.4 million homes and businesses lacking electricity by Monday night, according to PowerOutage.us. The lack of cooling to people's homes, downed power lines and non-functioning traffic lights led officials to ask residents to stay home if possible.\n\n\"Houstonians need to know we're working around the clock so you will be safe,\" Houston Mayor John Whitmire said Monday at a media briefing, urging residents to also know the dangers of high water, to stay hydrated and to check on their neighbors.\n\nBeryl later Monday weakened into a tropical depression with maximum wind speeds of about 35 mph (56 kph). The storm still packed a punch, and the National Weather Service confirmed on social media Monday evening that tornadoes had been spotted in northeastern Louisiana. Bossier Sheriff Julian Whittington said in a Facebook post that a woman was killed in the Benton area when a tree fell on her home.\n\nDozens of tornado warnings were issued in Louisiana and Arkansas on Monday evening and they continued into the night.\n\nWhile weakened, Beryl threatened to unleash harsh weather over several more states in coming days.\n\nTexas state and local officials warned it could take several days to fully restore power after Beryl came ashore as a Category 1 hurricane and toppled 10 transmission lines and knocked down trees that took down power lines.\n\nBeryl on Tuesday was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean last weekend. But its winds and rains were still powerful enough to knock down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in water-saturated earth, and strand dozens of cars on flooded roadways.\n\n\"We're not past any difficult conditions,\" said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country.\n\nPatrick said CenterPoint Energy was bringing thousands of additional workers to restore power, with top priorities including nursing homes and assisted living centers.\n\nAt least two people were killed when trees fell on homes in Texas, and a third person, a civilian employee of the Houston Police Department, was killed when he was trapped in flood waters under a highway overpass, Whitmire said.\n\nThe loss of power was an all-too familiar experience for Houston: Powerful storms had just ripped through the area in May, killing eight people, leaving nearly 1 million without power and flooding numerous streets.\n\nResidents without power after Beryl were doing their best.\n\n\"We haven't really slept,\" said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in her neighborhood in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio said she had already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\n\n\"We are struggling to have food and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.\n\nPower crews were working to restore service as quickly as possible, an urgent priority for homes also left without air conditioning in the middle of summer. Temperatures in the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) were expected Tuesday. The National Weather Service issued a heat advisory that said the area heat index could reach 105 F (40.5 C).\n\nThe state was opening cooling centers as well as food and water distribution centers, said Nim Kidd, chief of state emergency operations.\n\nBeryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast on Monday, reclosing streets in neighborhoods that had already been washed out by previous storms. Television stations on Monday broadcast the dramatic rescue of a man who had climbed to the roof of his pickup truck after it got trapped in fast-flowing waters. Emergency crews used an extension ladder from a fire truck to drop him a life preserver and a tether before moving him to dry land.\n\nHouston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.\n\nMany streets and neighborhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents chopped up knocked-down trees and branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks.\n\nPatrick warned that flooding could last for days as rain continued to fall on already saturated ground.\n\n\"This is not a one-day event,\" he said.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was getting regular updates on the storm after it made landfall and called the Houston mayor on Monday, the White House said. He told the mayor his administration will make sure Texans have the resources they need to get through the storm and recovery.\n\nSeveral companies with refineries or industrial plants in the area reported that the power disruptions necessitated the flaring of gases at the facilities.\n\nMarathon Petroleum Corp. said it conducted a \"safe combustion of excess gases\" at its Galveston Bay Refinery in Texas City, but did not provide information on the amount of gas flared or how long it would continue. Formosa Plastics Corporation and Freeport LNG also reported flaring related to Beryl, according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.\n\nCompanies have 24 hours to share emissions data after the flaring stops, a representative from the TCEQ said in an email.\n\nThe earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, Beryl caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nBeryl was forecast to bring more strong rain and winds into additional states over the coming days. One of those, Missouri was already dealing with a wet summer. Heavy rains unrelated to the storm prompted several water rescues around the city of Columbia, where rivers and creeks were already high ahead of Beryl's expected arrival on Tuesday.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press reporters Jim Vertuno in Austin, Texas; Corey Williams in Detroit; Julie Walker in New York; Melina Walling in Chicago; Jeff Martin in Atlanta; and Sara Cline in Baton Rouge, Louisiana, contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8216073359", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "01:10:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T01:10:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T01:10:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/world-news-beryl-weakens-to-tropical-depression-after-slamming-into-texas-as-category-1-hurricane-6096200.html", "title": "World News | Beryl Weakens to Tropical Depression After Slamming into Texas as Category-1 Hurricane | LatestLY", "body": "Houston, Jul 9 (AP) After tropical storm Beryl slammed into Texas early on Monday, knocking out power to nearly three million homes and businesses and killing several people, it moved east and weakened to a tropical depression, the National Hurricane Centre said on Monday evening. Flooding, rains and tornadoes were possible across portions of eastern Texas, Western Louisiana and Arkansas.\n\nBeryl slammed into Texas on Monday, knocking out power to nearly three million (30 lakh) homes and businesses and unleashing heavy rains that prompted dozens of high-water rescues. The fast-moving tempest threatened to carve a harsh path over several more states in coming days.\n\nAlso Read | US Presidential Elections 2024: Joe Biden Tells Democrats in Congress He Will Not Drop out in Race Against Donald Trump After Debate Debacle.\n\nTexas state and local officials warned it could take several days to restore power after Beryl came ashore as a Category-1 hurricane and toppled 10 transmission lines and knocked down trees that took down power lines.\n\nWithin hours, Beryl had weakened into a tropical storm, far less powerful than the Category-5 behemoth that tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean last weekend. But the winds and rains of the fast-moving storm were still powerful enough to knock down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in water-saturated earth, and strand dozens of cars on flooded roadways.\n\nAlso Read | Layoffs 2024: US-Based Westgate Resorts Announced To Lay Off 357 Workers To Streamline Operations.\n\nAs it moved inland, the storm still threatened to spawn tornados.\n\n\"We are not past any difficult conditions,\" said Texas Lieutenant Governor Dan Patrick, who is the acting governor while Governor Greg Abbott is out of the country, warning it would be a \"multiple-day process to get power restored\".\n\nHouston took a hard hit as CenterPoint Energy reported more than two million (20 lakh) homes and businesses without power in and around the nation's fourth-largest city. Patrick said the company was bringing in thousands of additional workers to restore power, with top priority for places such as nursing homes and assisted living centres.\n\nAt least two people were killed when trees fell on homes, and the National Hurricane Centre said damaging winds and flash flooding would continue as Beryl pushes inland. A third person, a civilian employee of the Houston Police Department, was killed when he was trapped in flood waters under a highway overpass, Houston Mayor John Whitmire said. There were no immediate reports of widespread structural damage, however.\n\nThe loss of power was an all-too familiar experience for Houston -- powerful storms had just ripped through the area in May, killing eight people, leaving nearly one million (10 lakh) without power and flooding numerous streets.\n\nResidents without power after Beryl were doing their best.\n\n\"We have not really slept,\" said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in her neighbourhood in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio, 67, said she had already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\n\n\"We are struggling to have food and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.\n\nHouston and Harris County officials said power crews would be sent into the area to restore service as quickly as possible, an urgent priority for homes also left without air conditioning in the middle of summer. Temperatures, which had cooled slightly with the storm, were expected to reach back into the 90s as early as on Tuesday. The National Weather Service issued a heat advisory that said the area heat index could reach 105 degrees Fahrenheit (41 degrees Celsius).\n\nThe state will be ready to open cooling centres as well as food and water distribution centres, said Nim Kidd, chief of state emergency operations.\n\nBeryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast on Monday, reclosing streets in neighbourhoods that had already been washed out by previous storms. Television stations on Monday broadcast the dramatic rescue of a man who had climbed to the roof of his pickup truck after it got trapped in fast-flowing waters. Emergency crews used an extension ladder from a fire truck to drop him a life preserver and a tether before moving him to dry land.\n\nHouston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.\n\n\"First responders are putting their lives at risk. That is what they are trained for. It is working,\" Houston Mayor John Whitmire said.\n\nJavier Mejia was one of about 20 people who gathered near the pickup truck rescue site to take pictures of other submerged vehicles sitting on the flooded highway.\n\n\"If you do not have a way through, you are going to get stuck like that,\" Mejia said.\n\nHaving experienced previous storms in Houston, Mejia stocked up on food and water before Beryl hit, but forgot gas for his portable generator. He planned to spend the day looking for some.\n\n\"I do not want it to go bad,\" he said of the food, adding that if he cannot find gas, \"We can just fire up the grill.\"\n\nMany streets and neighbourhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air on Monday afternoon as residents set to work chopping up knocked-down trees and big branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks.\n\nPatrick warned that flooding could last for days as rain continued to fall on already saturated ground.\n\n\"This is not a one-day event,\" he said.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was getting regular updates on the storm after it made landfall, the White House said. {"uri": "2024-07-416055511", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "10:11:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T10:11:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T10:10:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://www.wmtw.com/article/beryl-damage-power-outages-texas/61541579", "title": "Some power restored in Houston after Hurricane Beryl, while storm spawns tornadoes as it moves east", "body": "Power started to come back for some of the millions of homes and businesses left in the dark when Hurricane Beryl slammed into the Houston area, while the weakened storm moved east, spawning suspected tornadoes and causing more damage.Beryl was blamed for killing several people in Texas on Monday and at least one person in Louisiana, officials said.After a peak Monday of more than 2.7 million customers around Houston without power, the numbers improved to more than 2.4 million homes and businesses lacking electricity by Monday night, according to PowerOutage.us. The lack of cooling to people's homes, downed power lines and non-functioning traffic lights led officials to ask residents to stay home if possible.\"Houstonians need to know we're working around the clock so you will be safe,\" Houston Mayor John Whitmire said Monday at a media briefing, urging residents to also know the dangers of high water, to stay hydrated and to check on their neighbors.Beryl later Monday weakened into a tropical depression with maximum wind speeds of about 35 mph. The storm still packed a punch, and the National Weather Service confirmed on social media Monday evening that tornadoes had been spotted in northeastern Louisiana. Bossier Sheriff Julian Whittington said in a Facebook post that a woman was killed in the Benton area when a tree fell on her home.Dozens of tornado warnings were issued in Louisiana and Arkansas on Monday evening and they continued into the night.While weakened, Beryl threatened to unleash harsh weather over several more states in coming days.Texas state and local officials warned it could take several days to fully restore power after Beryl came ashore as a Category 1 hurricane and toppled 10 transmission lines and knocked down trees that took down power lines.Beryl on Tuesday was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean last weekend. But its winds and rains were still powerful enough to knock down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in water-saturated earth, and strand dozens of cars on flooded roadways.\"We're not past any difficult conditions,\" said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country.Patrick said CenterPoint Energy was bringing thousands of additional workers to restore power, with top priorities including nursing homes and assisted living centers.At least two people were killed when trees fell on homes in Texas, and a third person, a civilian employee of the Houston Police Department, was killed when he was trapped in flood waters under a highway overpass, Whitmire said.The loss of power was an all-too familiar experience for Houston: Powerful storms had just ripped through the area in May, killing eight people, leaving nearly 1 million without power and flooding numerous streets.Residents without power after Beryl were doing their best.\"We haven't really slept,\" said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in her neighborhood in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio said she had already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\"We are struggling to have food and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.Power crews were working to restore service as quickly as possible, an urgent priority for homes also left without air conditioning in the middle of summer. Temperatures in the 90s were expected Tuesday. The National Weather Service issued a heat advisory that said the area heat index could reach 105 F.The state was opening cooling centers as well as food and water distribution centers, said Nim Kidd, chief of state emergency operations.Beryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast on Monday, reclosing streets in neighborhoods that had already been washed out by previous storms. Television stations on Monday broadcast the dramatic rescue of a man who had climbed to the roof of his pickup truck after it got trapped in fast-flowing waters. Emergency crews used an extension ladder from a fire truck to drop him a life preserver and a tether before moving him to dry land.Houston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.Many streets and neighborhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents chopped up knocked-down trees and branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks.Patrick warned that flooding could last for days as rain continued to fall on already saturated ground.\"This is not a one-day event,\" he said.President Joe Biden was getting regular updates on the storm after it made landfall and called the Houston mayor on Monday, the White House said. He told the mayor his administration will make sure Texans have the resources they need to get through the storm and recovery.Several companies with refineries or industrial plants in the area reported that the power disruptions necessitated the flaring of gases at the facilities.Marathon Petroleum Corp. said it conducted a \"safe combustion of excess gases\" at its Galveston Bay Refinery in Texas City, but did not provide information on the amount of gas flared or how long it would continue. Formosa Plastics Corporation and Freeport LNG also reported flaring related to Beryl, according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.Companies have 24 hours to share emissions data after the flaring stops, a representative from the TCEQ said in an email.The earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, Beryl caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.Beryl was forecast to bring more strong rain and winds into additional states over the coming days. One of those, Missouri was already dealing with a wet summer. Heavy rains unrelated to the storm prompted several water rescues around the city of Columbia, where rivers and creeks were already high ahead of Beryl's expected arrival on Tuesday.___Associated Press reporters Jim Vertuno in Austin, Texas; Corey Williams in Detroit; Julie Walker in New York; Melina Walling in Chicago; Jeff Martin in Atlanta; and Sara Cline in Baton Rouge, Louisiana, contributed to this report.\n\nPower started to come back for some of the millions of homes and businesses left in the dark when Hurricane Beryl slammed into the Houston area, while the weakened storm moved east, spawning suspected tornadoes and causing more damage.\n\nBeryl was blamed for killing several people in Texas on Monday and at least one person in Louisiana, officials said.\n\nAfter a peak Monday of more than 2.7 million customers around Houston without power, the numbers improved to more than 2.4 million homes and businesses lacking electricity by Monday night, according to PowerOutage.us. The lack of cooling to people's homes, downed power lines and non-functioning traffic lights led officials to ask residents to stay home if possible.\n\n\"Houstonians need to know we're working around the clock so you will be safe,\" Houston Mayor John Whitmire said Monday at a media briefing, urging residents to also know the dangers of high water, to stay hydrated and to check on their neighbors.\n\nBeryl later Monday weakened into a tropical depression with maximum wind speeds of about 35 mph. The storm still packed a punch, and the National Weather Service confirmed on social media Monday evening that tornadoes had been spotted in northeastern Louisiana. Bossier Sheriff Julian Whittington said in a Facebook post that a woman was killed in the Benton area when a tree fell on her home.\n\nDozens of tornado warnings were issued in Louisiana and Arkansas on Monday evening and they continued into the night.\n\nWhile weakened, Beryl threatened to unleash harsh weather over several more states in coming days.\n\nTexas state and local officials warned it could take several days to fully restore power after Beryl came ashore as a Category 1 hurricane and toppled 10 transmission lines and knocked down trees that took down power lines.\n\nBeryl on Tuesday was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean last weekend. But its winds and rains were still powerful enough to knock down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in water-saturated earth, and strand dozens of cars on flooded roadways.\n\n\"We're not past any difficult conditions,\" said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country.\n\nPatrick said CenterPoint Energy was bringing thousands of additional workers to restore power, with top priorities including nursing homes and assisted living centers.\n\nAt least two people were killed when trees fell on homes in Texas, and a third person, a civilian employee of the Houston Police Department, was killed when he was trapped in flood waters under a highway overpass, Whitmire said.\n\nThe loss of power was an all-too familiar experience for Houston: Powerful storms had just ripped through the area in May, killing eight people, leaving nearly 1 million without power and flooding numerous streets.\n\nResidents without power after Beryl were doing their best.\n\n\"We haven't really slept,\" said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in her neighborhood in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio said she had already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\n\n\"We are struggling to have food and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.\n\nPower crews were working to restore service as quickly as possible, an urgent priority for homes also left without air conditioning in the middle of summer. Temperatures in the 90s were expected Tuesday. The National Weather Service issued a heat advisory that said the area heat index could reach 105 F.\n\nThe state was opening cooling centers as well as food and water distribution centers, said Nim Kidd, chief of state emergency operations.\n\nBeryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast on Monday, reclosing streets in neighborhoods that had already been washed out by previous storms. Television stations on Monday broadcast the dramatic rescue of a man who had climbed to the roof of his pickup truck after it got trapped in fast-flowing waters. Emergency crews used an extension ladder from a fire truck to drop him a life preserver and a tether before moving him to dry land.\n\nHouston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.\n\nMany streets and neighborhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents chopped up knocked-down trees and branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks.\n\nPatrick warned that flooding could last for days as rain continued to fall on already saturated ground.\n\n\"This is not a one-day event,\" he said.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was getting regular updates on the storm after it made landfall and called the Houston mayor on Monday, the White House said. He told the mayor his administration will make sure Texans have the resources they need to get through the storm and recovery.\n\nSeveral companies with refineries or industrial plants in the area reported that the power disruptions necessitated the flaring of gases at the facilities.\n\nMarathon Petroleum Corp. said it conducted a \"safe combustion of excess gases\" at its Galveston Bay Refinery in Texas City, but did not provide information on the amount of gas flared or how long it would continue. Formosa Plastics Corporation and Freeport LNG also reported flaring related to Beryl, according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.\n\nCompanies have 24 hours to share emissions data after the flaring stops, a representative from the TCEQ said in an email.\n\nThe earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, Beryl caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nBeryl was forecast to bring more strong rain and winds into additional states over the coming days. One of those, Missouri was already dealing with a wet summer. Heavy rains unrelated to the storm prompted several water rescues around the city of Columbia, where rivers and creeks were already high ahead of Beryl's expected arrival on Tuesday.\n\n___", {"uri": "8216018031", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-08", "time": "23:50:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-08T23:50:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-08T23:50:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://www.pressherald.com/2024/07/08/texas-officials-say-restoring-electricity-will-take-days-after-beryl-knocked-out-power-to-millions/", "title": "Texas officials say restoring electricity will take days after Beryl knocked out power to millions", "body": "Power lines downed by the effects of Hurricane Beryl block a highway near Palacios, Texas, on Monday. Beryl was downgraded to a tropical storm after sweeping into Texas.\n\nHOUSTON -- Tropical Storm Beryl slammed into Texas on Monday, knocking out power to nearly 3 million homes and businesses and unleashing heavy rains that prompted dozens of high-water rescues. The fast-moving tempest threatened to carve a harsh path over several more states in coming days.\n\nTexas state and local officials warned it could take several days to restore power after Beryl came ashore as a Category 1 hurricane and toppled 10 transmission lines and knocked down trees that took down power lines.\n\nWithin hours, Beryl had weakened into a tropical storm, far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean last weekend. But the winds and rains of the fast-moving storm were still powerful enough to knock down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in water-saturated earth, and strand dozens of cars on flooded roadways.\n\nAs it moved inland, the storm still threatened to spawn tornados.\n\n\"We're not past any difficult conditions,\" said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country, warning it would be a \"multiple-day process to get power restored.\"\n\nHouston took a hard hit: CenterPoint Energy reported more than 2 million homes and businesses without power in and around the nation's fourth-largest city. Patrick said the company was bringing in thousands of additional workers to restore power, with top priority for places such as nursing homes and assisted living centers.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nAt least two people were killed when trees fell on homes, and the National Hurricane Center said damaging winds and flash flooding would continue as Beryl pushes inland. A third person, a civilian employee of the Houston Police Department, was killed when he was trapped in floodwaters under a highway overpass, Houston Mayor John Whitmire said. There were no immediate reports of widespread structural damage, however.\n\nA tree uprooted by the effects of Hurricane Beryl lies on a lawn Monday in Bay City, Texas. Eric Gay/Associated Press\n\nThe loss of power was an all-too familiar experience for Houston: Powerful storms just ripped through the area in May, killing eight people, leaving nearly 1 million without power and flooding numerous streets.\n\nResidents without power after Beryl were doing their best.\n\n\"We haven't really slept,\" said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in her neighborhood in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio, 67, said she had already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\n\n\"We are struggling to have food, and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.\n\nHouston and Harris County officials said power crews would be sent into the area to restore service as quickly as possible, an urgent priority for homes also left without air conditioning in the middle of summer. Temperatures, which cooled slightly with the storm, were expected to reach back into the 90s as early as Tuesday. The National Weather Service issued a heat advisory, saying the area heat index could reach 105 degrees Fahrenheit.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe state will be ready to open cooling centers as well as food and water distribution centers, said Nim Kidd, chief of state emergency operations.\n\nBeryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast Monday, again closing streets in neighborhoods that had already been washed out by previous storms.\n\nTelevision stations broadcast the dramatic rescue of a man who had climbed to the roof of his pickup truck after it got trapped in fast-flowing waters. Emergency crews used an extension ladder from a fire truck to drop him a life preserver and a tether before moving him to dry land.\n\nHouston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.\n\n\"First responders are putting their lives at risk. That's what they're trained for. It's working,\" Houston Mayor John Whitmire said.\n\nJavier Mejia was one of about 20 people who gathered near the pickup truck rescue site to take pictures of other submerged vehicles sitting on the flooded highway.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"If you don't have a way through, you're going to get stuck like that,\" Mejia said.\n\nHaving experienced previous storms in Houston, Mejia stocked up on food and water before Beryl hit, but he forgot gas for his portable generator. He planned to spend the day looking for some.\n\n\"I don't want it to go bad,\" he said of the food, adding that if he can't find gas, \"We can just fire up the grill.\"\n\nMany streets and neighborhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents set to work chopping up knocked-down trees and big branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks.\n\nPatrick warned that flooding could last for days as rain continued to fall on already saturated ground.\n\n\"This is not a one-day event,\" the lieutenant governor said.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nPresident Biden was getting regular updates on the storm after it made landfall, the White House said. The U.S. Coast Guard and FEMA had prepared search and rescue teams, and FEMA collected bottled water, meals, tarps and electric generators in case they are needed.\n\nSeveral companies with refineries or industrial plants in the area reported that the power disruptions necessitated the flaring of gases at the facilities.\n\nMarathon Petroleum Corp. said it conducted a \"safe combustion of excess gases\" at its Galveston Bay Refinery in Texas City, but it did not provide information on the amount of gas flared or how long it would continue. Formosa Plastics Corporation and Freeport LNG also reported flaring related to Beryl, according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.\n\nCompanies have 24 hours to share emissions data after the flaring stops, a representative from the TCEQ said in an email.\n\nThe earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, Beryl caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. The storm ripped off doors, windows and roofs with devastating winds and storm surge fueled by the Atlantic's record warmth.\n\nThree times during the week, Beryl gained 35 mph in wind speed in 24 hours or less - the official weather service definition of rapid intensification.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nBeryl's explosive growth into an unprecedented early whopper of a storm indicates the hot water of the Atlantic and Caribbean and what the Atlantic hurricane belt can expect for the rest of the storm season, experts said. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nIn Louisiana, heavy bands of rain were expected all day Monday, and \"the risk is going to be for that heavy rainfall and potential for flash flooding,\" National Weather Service meteorologist Donald Jones said in a Monday morning Facebook Live briefing.\n\nThe weather service in Shreveport issued tornado warnings across northwest Louisiana. The agency confirmed on social media that multiple tornadoes had been spotted in that corner of the state. Information on whether those weather events have caused any significant damage was not immediately available.\n\nBeryl was forecast to bring more strong rain and winds into additional states over the coming days. One of those, Missouri, was already dealing with a wet summer. Heavy rains unrelated to the storm prompted several water rescues around the city of Columbia, where rivers and creeks were already high ahead of Beryl's expected arrival Tuesday.\n\nAssociated Press reporters Jim Vertuno in Austin, Texas; Corey Williams in Detroit; Julie Walker in New York; Melina Walling in Chicago; and Jeff Martin in Atlanta contributed to this report.\n\nCopy the Story Link "https://www.pressherald.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/4/2024/07/Texas_Tropical_Weather_33762-1720459814.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9716370", "eventUri": "eng-9716370", "location": {"uri": "2024-07-415725032", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "04:24:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T04:24:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T04:04:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://www.aol.com/news/power-restored-houston-hurricane-beryl-040418103.html", "title": "Some power restored in Houston after Hurricane Beryl, while storm spawns tornadoes as it moves east", "body": "Some power restored in Houston after Hurricane Beryl, while storm spawns tornadoes as it moves east\n\nMARK VANCLEAVE and JUAN A. LOZANO\n\nJuly 9, 2024 at 6:04 AM\n\nHOUSTON (AP) -- Power started to come back for some of the millions of homes and businesses left in the dark when Hurricane Beryl slammed into the Houston area, while the weakened storm moved east, spawning suspected tornadoes and causing more damage.\n\nBeryl was blamed for killing several people in Texas on Monday and at least one person in Louisiana, officials said.\n\nAfter a peak Monday of more than 2.7 million customers around Houston without power, the numbers improved to more than 2.4 million homes and businesses lacking electricity by Monday night, according to PowerOutage.us. The lack of cooling to people's homes, downed power lines and non-functioning traffic lights led officials to ask residents to stay home if possible.\n\n\"Houstonians need to know we're working around the clock so you will be safe,\" Houston Mayor John Whitmire said Monday at a media briefing, urging residents to also know the dangers of high water, to stay hydrated and to check on their neighbors.\n\nBeryl later Monday weakened into a tropical depression with maximum wind speeds of about 35 mph (56 kph). The storm still packed a punch, and the National Weather Service confirmed on social media Monday evening that tornadoes had been spotted in northeastern Louisiana. Bossier Sheriff Julian Whittington said in a Facebook post that a woman was killed in the Benton area when a tree fell on her home.\n\nDozens of tornado warnings were issued in Louisiana and Arkansas on Monday evening and they continued into the night.\n\nWhile weakened, Beryl threatened to unleash harsh weather over several more states in coming days.\n\nTexas state and local officials warned it could take several days to fully restore power after Beryl came ashore as a Category 1 hurricane and toppled 10 transmission lines and knocked down trees that took down power lines.\n\nBeryl on Tuesday was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean last weekend. But its winds and rains were still powerful enough to knock down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in water-saturated earth, and strand dozens of cars on flooded roadways.\n\n\"We're not past any difficult conditions,\" said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country.\n\nPatrick said CenterPoint Energy was bringing thousands of additional workers to restore power, with top priorities including nursing homes and assisted living centers.\n\nAt least two people were killed when trees fell on homes in Texas, and a third person, a civilian employee of the Houston Police Department, was killed when he was trapped in flood waters under a highway overpass, Whitmire said.\n\nThe loss of power was an all-too familiar experience for Houston: Powerful storms had just ripped through the area in May, killing eight people, leaving nearly 1 million without power and flooding numerous streets.\n\nResidents without power after Beryl were doing their best.\n\n\"We haven't really slept,\" said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in her neighborhood in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio said she had already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\n\n\"We are struggling to have food and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.\n\nPower crews were working to restore service as quickly as possible, an urgent priority for homes also left without air conditioning in the middle of summer. Temperatures in the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) were expected Tuesday. The National Weather Service issued a heat advisory that said the area heat index could reach 105 F (40.5 C).\n\nThe state was opening cooling centers as well as food and water distribution centers, said Nim Kidd, chief of state emergency operations.\n\nBeryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast on Monday, reclosing streets in neighborhoods that had already been washed out by previous storms. Television stations on Monday broadcast the dramatic rescue of a man who had climbed to the roof of his pickup truck after it got trapped in fast-flowing waters. Emergency crews used an extension ladder from a fire truck to drop him a life preserver and a tether before moving him to dry land.\n\nHouston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.\n\nMany streets and neighborhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents chopped up knocked-down trees and branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks.\n\nPatrick warned that flooding could last for days as rain continued to fall on already saturated ground.\n\n\"This is not a one-day event,\" he said.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was getting regular updates on the storm after it made landfall and called the Houston mayor on Monday, the White House said. He told the mayor his administration will make sure Texans have the resources they need to get through the storm and recovery.\n\nSeveral companies with refineries or industrial plants in the area reported that the power disruptions necessitated the flaring of gases at the facilities.\n\nMarathon Petroleum Corp. said it conducted a \"safe combustion of excess gases\" at its Galveston Bay Refinery in Texas City, but did not provide information on the amount of gas flared or how long it would continue. Formosa Plastics Corporation and Freeport LNG also reported flaring related to Beryl, according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.\n\nCompanies have 24 hours to share emissions data after the flaring stops, a representative from the TCEQ said in an email.\n\nThe earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, Beryl caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nBeryl was forecast to bring more strong rain and winds into additional states over the coming days. One of those, Missouri was already dealing with a wet summer. Heavy rains unrelated to the storm prompted several water rescues around the city of Columbia, where rivers and creeks were already high ahead of Beryl's expected arrival on Tuesday.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press reporters Jim Vertuno in Austin, Texas; Corey Williams in Detroit; Julie Walker in New York; Melina Walling in Chicago; Jeff Martin in Atlanta; and Sara Cline in Baton Rouge, Louisiana, contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "aol.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Aol"}, "authors": [{"uri": "juan_a_lozano@aol.com", "name": "Juan A. {"uri": "2024-07-416314042", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "13:52:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T13:52:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T13:03:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://internewscast.com/local-news/beryl-leaves-hot-misery-still-a-threat-as-storm-moves-inland-in-the-us/", "title": "Beryl Leaves Hot Misery, Still a Threat as Storm Moves Inland in the US - Internewscast Journal", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- Many of the millions left without power when Hurricane Beryl crashed into the Houston area, killing several people and unleashing flooding, now face days without power and air conditioning as dangerous heat threatens the region Tuesday.\n\nA heat advisory was in effect through Wednesday in parts of Texas, with temperatures in the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) and heat index values up to 105 degrees (40.5 Celsius) expected Tuesday. The widespread loss of power -- and therefore air conditioning -- could make for dangerous conditions, the National Weather Service said.\n\nMore than 2.3 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday morning, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. The lack of cooling to people's homes, downed power lines and nonfunctioning traffic lights led officials to ask residents to stay home if possible.\n\n\"Houstonians need to know we're working around the clock so you will be safe,\" Houston Mayor John Whitmire said Monday at a media briefing, urging residents to also know the dangers of high water, to stay hydrated and to check on their neighbors.\n\nBeryl was blamed for killing several people in Texas and at least one in Louisiana, officials said.\n\nThe storm weakened into a tropical depression after making landfall, and by Tuesday morning its center was over southwestern Arkansas, moving northeast with maximum sustained wind speeds near 30 mph (48 kph), the weather service said. Its strength wasn't expected to change much in the next day or two.\n\nBeryl still threatened to unleash more harsh weather over several other states in coming days. It is expected to bring heavy rainfall and possible flash flooding from the lower and mid-Mississippi Valley to the Great Lakes on Tuesday into Wednesday, the weather service said.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana and Michigan, and tornadoes were possible through the early morning across parts of the mid-South. A few tornadoes were possible from midday to the early evening in Missouri, Tennessee, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana, and Ohio, according to the weather service.\n\nThe weather service confirmed on social media Monday evening that tornadoes had been spotted in northeastern Louisiana. Bossier Sheriff Julian Whittington said in a Facebook post that a woman was killed in the Benton area when a tree fell on her home.\n\nTexas state and local officials warned it could take several days to fully restore power after Beryl came ashore as a Category 1 hurricane, toppled 10 transmission lines and knocked down trees that took down power lines.\n\nBeryl on Tuesday was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that earlier tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean. But its winds and rains still knocked down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in water-saturated earth, and strand dozens of cars on flooded roads.\n\n\"We're not past any difficult conditions,\" said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country.\n\nPatrick said CenterPoint Energy was bringing thousands of additional workers to restore power, with top priorities including nursing homes and assisted living centers. CenterPoint said in an update Monday evening that it expected to restore power to 1 million customers by the end of Wednesday.\n\nAt least two people were killed when trees fell on homes in Texas, and a third person, a civilian employee of the Houston Police Department, was killed when he was trapped in floodwaters under a highway overpass, Whitmire said.\n\nThe loss of power was an all-too familiar experience for Houston. Powerful storms ripped through the area in May, killing eight people, leaving nearly 1 million without power and flooding streets.\n\nResidents without power after Beryl were doing their best.\n\n\"We haven't really slept,\" said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in her neighborhood in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio said she had already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\n\n\"We are struggling to have food, and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.\n\nThe state was opening cooling centers, as well as food and water distribution centers, said Nim Kidd, chief of state emergency operations.\n\nBeryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast Monday, closing streets that had already been washed out by previous storms. Houston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.\n\nMany streets and neighborhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents chopped up knocked-down trees and branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was getting regular updates on the storm and called the Houston mayor Monday, the White House said. He told the mayor his administration will make sure Texans have resources.\n\nSeveral companies with refineries or industrial plants reported the power disruptions required the flaring of gases.\n\nThe earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, Beryl caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8216060454", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "00:53:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T00:53:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T00:52:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/ap/national/texas-officials-say-restoring-electricity-will-take-days-after-beryl-knocked-out-power-to-millions/article_6ef0d5db-2097-51b7-b5fd-ea21897810e1.html", "title": "Texas officials say restoring electricity will take days after Beryl knocked out power to millions", "body": "BY MARK VANCLEAVE and JUAN A. LOZANO\n\nHOUSTON -- Tropical Storm Beryl slammed into Texas on Monday, knocking out power to nearly 3 million homes and businesses and unleashing heavy rains that prompted dozens of high-water rescues. The fast-moving tempest threatened to carve a harsh path over several more states in coming days.\n\nTexas state and local officials warned it could take several days to restore power after Beryl came ashore as a Category 1 hurricane and toppled 10 transmission lines and knocked down trees that took down power lines.\n\nWithin hours, Beryl had weakened into a tropical storm, far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean last weekend. But the winds and rains of the fast-moving storm were still powerful enough to knock down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in water-saturated earth, and strand dozens of cars on flooded roadways.\n\nAs it moved inland, the storm still threatened to spawn tornados.\n\n\"We're not past any difficult conditions,\" said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country, warning it would be a \"multiple day process to get power restored.\"\n\nHouston took a hard hit as CenterPoint Energy reported more than 2 million homes and businesses without power in and around the nation's fourth-largest city. Patrick said the company was bringing in thousands of additional workers to restore power, with top priority for places such as nursing homes and assisted living centers.\n\nAt least two people were killed when trees fell on homes, and the National Hurricane Center said damaging winds and flash flooding would continue as Beryl pushes inland. A third person, a civilian employee of the Houston Police Department, was killed when he was trapped in flood waters under a highway overpass, Houston Mayor John Whitmire said. There were no immediate reports of widespread structural damage, however.\n\nThe loss of power was an all-too familiar experience for Houston: Powerful storms had just ripped through the area in May, killing eight people, leaving nearly 1 million without power and flooding numerous streets.\n\nResidents without power after Beryl were doing their best.\n\n\"We haven't really slept,\" said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in her neighborhood in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio, 67, said she had already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\n\n\"We are struggling to have food and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.\n\nHouston and Harris County officials said power crews would be sent into the area to restore service as quickly as possible, an urgent priority for homes also left without air conditioning in the middle of summer. Temperatures, which had cooled slightly with the storm, were expected to reach back into the 90s as early as Tuesday. The National Weather Service issued a heat advisory that said the area heat index could reach 105 degrees Fahrenheit.\n\nThe state will be ready to open cooling centers as well as food and water distribution centers, said Nim Kidd, chief of state emergency operations.\n\nBeryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast on Monday, reclosing streets in neighborhoods that had already been washed out by previous storms. Television stations on Monday broadcast the dramatic rescue of a man who had climbed to the roof of his pickup truck after it got trapped in fast-flowing waters. Emergency crews used an extension ladder from a fire truck to drop him a life preserver and a tether before moving him to dry land.\n\nHouston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.\n\n\"First responders are putting their lives at risk. That's what they're trained for. It's working,\" Houston Mayor John Whitmire said.\n\nToday's Top Headlines\n\nStory continues below\n\nA good neighbor's bad decision. Summerville man dies after placing firework atop his head. SC restaurateurs charged with bilking federal pandemic loan programs out of $591K Bankrupt apparel maker spun out of SC textile mill owner sizes up its options Clemson women's lacrosse nabs nation's No. 1 recruit -- with an assist from Dabo Swinney The Charleston Place to undergo a $150M total makeover What is SC's largest city? The answer is more complicated than you might think. Why are some of Charleston's roads so bad? Blame centuries of land 'reclamation.' Another Charleston hotel picked to join historic lodging group Charleston's Sweet Grass Vodka abruptly closed. Actor Jeremy Renner and investors lost big. Column: Canada's immigration crisis\n\nJavier Mejia was one of about 20 people who gathered near the pickup truck rescue site to take pictures of other submerged vehicles sitting on the flooded highway.\n\n\"If you don't have a way through, you're going to get stuck like that,\" Mejia said.\n\nHaving experienced previous storms in Houston, Mejia stocked up on food and water before Beryl hit, but forgot gas for his portable generator. He planned to spend the day looking for some.\n\n\"I don't want it to go bad,\" he said of the food, adding that if he can't find gas, \"We can just fire up the grill.\"\n\nMany streets and neighborhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents set to work chopping up knocked-down trees and big branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks.\n\nPatrick warned that flooding could last for days as rain continued to fall on already saturated ground.\n\n\"This is not a one-day event,\" he said.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was getting regular updates on the storm after it made landfall, the White House said. The U.S. Coast Guard and FEMA had prepared search and rescue teams, and FEMA collected bottled water, meals, tarps and electric generators in case they are needed.\n\nSeveral companies with refineries or industrial plants in the area reported that the power disruptions necessitated the flaring of gases at the facilities.\n\nMarathon Petroleum Corp. said it conducted a \"safe combustion of excess gases\" at its Galveston Bay Refinery in Texas City, but did not provide information on the amount of gas flared or how long it would continue. Formosa Plastics Corporation and Freeport LNG also reported flaring related to Beryl, according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.\n\nCompanies have 24 hours to share emissions data after the flaring stops, a representative from the TCEQ said in an email.\n\nThe earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, Beryl caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. The storm ripped off doors, windows and roofs with devastating winds and storm surge fueled by the Atlantic's record warmth.\n\nThree times during the week, Beryl gained 35 mph (56 kph) in wind speed in 24 hours or less, the official weather service definition of rapid intensification.\n\nBeryl's explosive growth into an unprecedented early whopper of a storm indicates the hot water of the Atlantic and Caribbean and what the Atlantic hurricane belt can expect for the rest of the storm season, experts said. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nIn Louisiana, heavy bands of rain were expected all day Monday and \"the risk is going to be for that heavy rainfall and potential for flash flooding,\" National Weather Service meteorologist Donald Jones said in a Monday morning Facebook Live briefing.\n\nThe weather service in Shreveport issued tornado warnings across northwest Louisiana. The agency confirmed on social media that multiple tornados had been spotted in that corner of the state. Information on whether those weather events have caused any significant damage was not immediately available.\n\nBeryl was forecast to bring more strong rain and winds into additional states over the coming days. One of those, Missouri was already dealing with a wet summer. Heavy rains unrelated to the storm prompted several water rescues around the city of Columbia, where rivers and creeks were already high ahead of Beryl's expected arrival on Tuesday.", "source": {"uri": "8216237427", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "04:27:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T04:27:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T04:27:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/07/09/nation/some-power-restored-houston-after-hurricane-beryl-while-storm-spawns-tornadoes-it-moves-east/", "title": "Some power restored in Houston after Hurricane Beryl, while storm spawns tornadoes as it moves east - The Boston Globe", "body": "\"Houstonians need to know we're working around the clock so you will be safe,\" Houston Mayor John Whitmire said Monday at a media briefing, urging residents to also know the dangers of high water, to stay hydrated and to check on their neighbors.\n\nBeryl later Monday weakened into a tropical depression with maximum wind speeds of about 35 mph (56 kph). The storm still packed a punch, and the National Weather Service confirmed on social media Monday evening that tornadoes had been spotted in northeastern Louisiana. Bossier Sheriff Julian Whittington said in a Facebook post that a woman was killed in the Benton area when a tree fell on her home.\n\nDozens of tornado warnings were issued in Louisiana and Arkansas on Monday evening and they continued into the night.\n\nWhile weakened, Beryl threatened to unleash harsh weather over several more states in coming days.\n\nTexas state and local officials warned it could take several days to fully restore power after Beryl came ashore as a Category 1 hurricane and toppled 10 transmission lines and knocked down trees that took down power lines.\n\nBeryl on Tuesday was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean last weekend. But its winds and rains were still powerful enough to knock down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in water-saturated earth, and strand dozens of cars on flooded roadways.\n\n\"We're not past any difficult conditions,\" said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country.\n\nPatrick said CenterPoint Energy was bringing thousands of additional workers to restore power, with top priorities including nursing homes and assisted living centers.\n\nAt least two people were killed when trees fell on homes in Texas, and a third person, a civilian employee of the Houston Police Department, was killed when he was trapped in flood waters under a highway overpass, Whitmire said.\n\nThe loss of power was an all-too familiar experience for Houston: Powerful storms had just ripped through the area in May, killing eight people, leaving nearly 1 million without power and flooding numerous streets.\n\nResidents without power after Beryl were doing their best.\n\n\"We haven't really slept,\" said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in her neighborhood in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio said she had already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\n\n\"We are struggling to have food and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.\n\nPower crews were working to restore service as quickly as possible, an urgent priority for homes also left without air conditioning in the middle of summer. Temperatures in the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) were expected Tuesday. The National Weather Service issued a heat advisory that said the area heat index could reach 105 F (40.5 C).\n\nThe state was opening cooling centers as well as food and water distribution centers, said Nim Kidd, chief of state emergency operations.\n\nBeryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast on Monday, reclosing streets in neighborhoods that had already been washed out by previous storms. Television stations on Monday broadcast the dramatic rescue of a man who had climbed to the roof of his pickup truck after it got trapped in fast-flowing waters. Emergency crews used an extension ladder from a fire truck to drop him a life preserver and a tether before moving him to dry land.\n\nHouston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.\n\nMany streets and neighborhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents chopped up knocked-down trees and branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks.\n\nPatrick warned that flooding could last for days as rain continued to fall on already saturated ground.\n\n\"This is not a one-day event,\" he said.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was getting regular updates on the storm after it made landfall and called the Houston mayor on Monday, the White House said. He told the mayor his administration will make sure Texans have the resources they need to get through the storm and recovery.\n\nSeveral companies with refineries or industrial plants in the area reported that the power disruptions necessitated the flaring of gases at the facilities.\n\nMarathon Petroleum Corp. said it conducted a \"safe combustion of excess gases\" at its Galveston Bay Refinery in Texas City, but did not provide information on the amount of gas flared or how long it would continue. Formosa Plastics Corporation and Freeport LNG also reported flaring related to Beryl, according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.\n\nCompanies have 24 hours to share emissions data after the flaring stops, a representative from the TCEQ said in an email.\n\nThe earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, Beryl caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nBeryl was forecast to bring more strong rain and winds into additional states over the coming days. One of those, Missouri was already dealing with a wet summer. Heavy rains unrelated to the storm prompted several water rescues around the city of Columbia, where rivers and creeks were already high ahead of Beryl's expected arrival on Tuesday.", "source": {"uri": "2024-07-416258826", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "13:04:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T13:04:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T06:45:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2024/jul/9/some-power-back-on-in-houston-after-hurricane-bery/", "title": "Some power restored in Houston after Hurricane Beryl while storm spawns tornadoes as it moves east", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- Power started to come back for some of the millions of homes and businesses left in the dark when Hurricane Beryl slammed into the Houston area, while the weakened storm moved east, spawning suspected tornadoes and causing more damage.\n\nBeryl was blamed for killing several people in Texas on Monday and at least one person in Louisiana, officials said.\n\nAfter a peak Monday of more than 2.7 million customers around Houston without power, the numbers improved to more than 2.3 million homes and businesses lacking electricity by Tuesday morning, according to PowerOutage.us. The lack of cooling to people's homes, downed power lines and non-functioning traffic lights led officials to ask residents to stay home if possible.\n\n\"Houstonians need to know we're working around the clock so you will be safe,\" Houston Mayor John Whitmire said Monday at a media briefing, urging residents to also know the dangers of high water, to stay hydrated and to check on their neighbors.\n\nBeryl later Monday weakened into a tropical depression and by Tuesday morning the weather service said it was about 95 miles (155 kilometers) north of Shreveport, Louisiana, moving northeast with maximum sustained wind speeds near 30 mph (48 kph). Its strength wasn't expected to change much in the next day or two.\n\nWhile weakened, Beryl threatened to unleash more harsh weather over several other states in coming days. The storm was expected to bring heavy rainfall and possible flash flooding from the lower and mid-Mississippi Valley to the Great Lakes on Tuesday into Wednesday, the weather service said.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana and Michigan and tornadoes were possible through the early morning across parts of the Mid-South. A few tornadoes were possible from midday to the early evening in Missouri, Tennessee, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana, and Ohio, according to the weather service.\n\nThe storm still packed a punch, and the weather service confirmed on social media Monday evening that tornadoes had been spotted in northeastern Louisiana. Bossier Sheriff Julian Whittington said in a Facebook post that a woman was killed in the Benton area when a tree fell on her home.\n\nDozens of tornado warnings were issued in Louisiana and Arkansas on Monday evening.\n\nTexas state and local officials warned it could take several days to fully restore power after Beryl came ashore as a Category 1 hurricane, toppled 10 transmission lines and knocked down trees that took down power lines.\n\nBeryl on Tuesday was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that earlier tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean. But its winds and rains still knocked down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in water-saturated earth, and strand dozens of cars on flooded roadways.\n\n\"We're not past any difficult conditions,\" said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country.\n\nPatrick said CenterPoint Energy was bringing thousands of additional workers to restore power, with top priorities including nursing homes and assisted living centers.\n\nAt least two people were killed when trees fell on homes in Texas, and a third person, a civilian employee of the Houston Police Department, was killed when he was trapped in floodwaters under a highway overpass, Whitmire said.\n\nThe loss of power was an all-too familiar experience for Houston: Powerful storms had just ripped through the area in May, killing eight people, leaving nearly 1 million without power and flooding numerous streets.\n\nResidents without power after Beryl were doing their best.\n\n\"We haven't really slept,\" said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in her neighborhood in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio said she had already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\n\n\"We are struggling to have food and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.\n\nPower crews were working to restore service as quickly as possible, an urgent priority for homes also left without air conditioning in the middle of summer. Temperatures in the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) were expected Tuesday. The National Weather Service issued a heat advisory that said the area heat index could reach 105 degrees (40.5 C).\n\nThe state was opening cooling centers as well as food and water distribution centers, said Nim Kidd, chief of state emergency operations.\n\nBeryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast on Monday, reclosing streets in neighborhoods that had already been washed out by previous storms. Houston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.\n\nMany streets and neighborhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents chopped up knocked-down trees and branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks.\n\nPatrick warned that flooding could last for days as rain continued to fall on already saturated ground.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was getting regular updates on the storm and called the Houston mayor on Monday, the White House said. He told the mayor his administration will make sure Texans have the resources they need to get through the storm and recovery.\n\nSeveral companies with refineries or industrial plants in the area reported that the power disruptions necessitated the flaring of gases at the facilities.\n\nThe earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, Beryl caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\n___", "source": {"uri": "washingtontimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Washington Times"}, "authors": [{"uri": "juan_a_lozano@washingtontimes.com", "name": "Juan A. "https://twt-thumbs.washtimes.com/media/image/2024/07/08/APTOPIX_Texas_Tropical_Weather_05030_c0-101-5395-3246_s1770x1032.jpg?027a21724c69e856032beae04878a096c87f04b4", "originalArticle": null,
