{"uri": "8216221439", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "04:16:22", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T04:16:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T04:12:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13614439/Some-power-restored-Houston-Hurricane-Beryl-storm-spawns-tornadoes-moves-east.html", "title": "Some power restored in Houston after Hurricane Beryl, while storm...", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) - Power started to come back for some of the millions of homes and businesses left in the dark when Hurricane Beryl slammed into the Houston area, while the weakened storm moved east, spawning suspected tornadoes and causing more damage.\n\nBeryl was blamed for killing several people in Texas on Monday and at least one person in Louisiana, officials said.\n\nAfter a peak Monday of more than 2.7 million customers around Houston without power, the numbers improved to more than 2.4 million homes and businesses lacking electricity by Monday night, according to PowerOutage.us. The lack of cooling to people\u00b4s homes, downed power lines and non-functioning traffic lights led officials to ask residents to stay home if possible.\n\n\"Houstonians need to know we\u00b4re working around the clock so you will be safe,\" Houston Mayor John Whitmire said Monday at a media briefing, urging residents to also know the dangers of high water, to stay hydrated and to check on their neighbors.\n\nBeryl later Monday weakened into a tropical depression with maximum wind speeds of about 35 mph (56 kph). The storm still packed a punch, and the National Weather Service confirmed on social media Monday evening that tornadoes had been spotted in northeastern Louisiana. Bossier Sheriff Julian Whittington said in a Facebook post that a woman was killed in the Benton area when a tree fell on her home.\n\nDozens of tornado warnings were issued in Louisiana and Arkansas on Monday evening and they continued into the night.\n\nAn upended tree rests on Bethel Church after Hurricane Beryl moved through the area, Monday, July 8, 2024, in Van Vleck, Texas. (AP Photo/Eric Gay)\n\nWhile weakened, Beryl threatened to unleash harsh weather over several more states in coming days.\n\nTexas state and local officials warned it could take several days to fully restore power after Beryl came ashore as a Category 1 hurricane and toppled 10 transmission lines and knocked down trees that took down power lines.\n\nBeryl on Tuesday was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean last weekend. But its winds and rains were still powerful enough to knock down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in water-saturated earth, and strand dozens of cars on flooded roadways.\n\n\"We\u00b4re not past any difficult conditions,\" said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country.\n\nPatrick said CenterPoint Energy was bringing thousands of additional workers to restore power, with top priorities including nursing homes and assisted living centers.\n\nAt least two people were killed when trees fell on homes in Texas, and a third person, a civilian employee of the Houston Police Department, was killed when he was trapped in flood waters under a highway overpass, Whitmire said.\n\nThe loss of power was an all-too familiar experience for Houston: Powerful storms had just ripped through the area in May, killing eight people, leaving nearly 1 million without power and flooding numerous streets.\n\nResidents without power after Beryl were doing their best.\n\n\"We haven\u00b4t really slept,\" said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in her neighborhood in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio said she had already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\n\n\"We are struggling to have food and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.\n\nPower crews were working to restore service as quickly as possible, an urgent priority for homes also left without air conditioning in the middle of summer. Temperatures in the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) were expected Tuesday. The National Weather Service issued a heat advisory that said the area heat index could reach 105 F (40.5 C).\n\nThe state was opening cooling centers as well as food and water distribution centers, said Nim Kidd, chief of state emergency operations.\n\nBeryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast on Monday, reclosing streets in neighborhoods that had already been washed out by previous storms. Television stations on Monday broadcast the dramatic rescue of a man who had climbed to the roof of his pickup truck after it got trapped in fast-flowing waters. Emergency crews used an extension ladder from a fire truck to drop him a life preserver and a tether before moving him to dry land.\n\nHouston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.\n\nMany streets and neighborhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents chopped up knocked-down trees and branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks.\n\nPatrick warned that flooding could last for days as rain continued to fall on already saturated ground.\n\n\"This is not a one-day event,\" he said.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was getting regular updates on the storm after it made landfall and called the Houston mayor on Monday, the White House said. He told the mayor his administration will make sure Texans have the resources they need to get through the storm and recovery.\n\nSeveral companies with refineries or industrial plants in the area reported that the power disruptions necessitated the flaring of gases at the facilities.\n\nMarathon Petroleum Corp. said it conducted a \"safe combustion of excess gases\" at its Galveston Bay Refinery in Texas City, but did not provide information on the amount of gas flared or how long it would continue. Formosa Plastics Corporation and Freeport LNG also reported flaring related to Beryl, according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.\n\nCompanies have 24 hours to share emissions data after the flaring stops, a representative from the TCEQ said in an email.\n\nThe earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, Beryl caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nBeryl was forecast to bring more strong rain and winds into additional states over the coming days. One of those, Missouri was already dealing with a wet summer. Heavy rains unrelated to the storm prompted several water rescues around the city of Columbia, where rivers and creeks were already high ahead of Beryl's expected arrival on Tuesday.\n\nAssociated Press reporters Jim Vertuno in Austin, Texas; Corey Williams in Detroit; Julie Walker in New York; Melina Walling in Chicago; Jeff Martin in Atlanta; and Sara Cline in Baton Rouge, Louisiana, contributed to this report.\n\nJackie Jecmenek, right, talks with city worker Bobby Head as she stands in front of her neighbor's home after Beryl passed, Monday, July 8, 2024, in Bay City, Texas. (AP Photo/Eric Gay)\n\nAnn McCauley examines the damage at Bethel Church after Hurricane Beryl moved through the area, Monday, July 8, 2024, in Van Vleck, Texas. (AP Photo/Eric Gay)\n\nCORRECTION CORRECTS NAME Haley Loredo with her brother, Elmer Alvarado, wipes away tears outside her home in the 17400 block of Rustic Canyon Trail where her mother-in-law, Maria Loredo, 74, died after a tree fell on her second story bedroom during Hurricane Beryl, Monday, July 8, 2024, in Houston. (Melissa Phillip/Houston Chronicle via AP)\n\nCORRECTION CORRECTS NAME People gather outside a home in the 17400 block of Rustic Canyon Trail where Maria Loredo, 74, died after a tree fell on her second story bedroom during Hurricane Beryl Monday, July 8, 2024, in Houston (Melissa Phillip/Houston Chronicle via AP)\n\nBeach goers try to keep their balance as wind gusts continue as Tropical Storm Beryl wanes on Monday, July 8, 2024, Galveston, Texas. (Elizabeth Conley/Houston Chronicle via AP)\n\nA vehicle is stranded in high waters on a flooded highway in Houston, on Monday, July 8, 2024, after Beryl came ashore in Texas as a hurricane and dumped heavy rains along the coast. (AP Photo/Juan A. Lozano)\n\nHook Jefferson assesses damages after a tree fell on his neighbor's home after Hurricane Beryl hit the Texas coast, Monday, July 8, 2024, in Bay City, Texas. (AP Photo/Eric Gay)\n\nWilliam Ruiz uses a tow strap and his pick-up truck to remove a downed tree branch from the middle of the street in his neighborhood during a lull as the eye of hurrican Beryl passes through Monday, July 8, 2024, in Rosenberg, Texas. (AP Photo/Michael Wyke)\n\nResident Isabel Perez rakes up downed tree branches from the street outside of her home during a lull in the wind and rain as Tropical Storm Beryl passes Monday, July 8, 2024, in Rosenburg, Texas. Hurricane Beryl has been downgraded to a tropical storm after sweeping into Texas as a Category 1 storm with heavy rains and powerful winds. (AP Photo/Michael Wyke)\n\nCORRECTION CORRECTS NAME People gather outside a home in the 17400 block of Rustic Canyon Trail where Maria Loredo, 74, died after a tree fell on her second story bedroom during Hurricane Beryl Monday, July 8, 2024, in Houston. Tropical Storm Beryl unleashed heavy rains and powerful winds along the Texas coast on Monday, knocking out power to homes and businesses and flooding streets with fast-rising waters as first responders raced to rescue stranded residents. The National Hurricane Center said damaging winds and flash flooding will continue as Beryl continues pushing inland. (AP Photo/Eric Gay)\n\nAndrew Parada, an employee at Residence Inn mops up the floor as water keeps leaking in during Tropical Storm Beryl wanes on Monday, July 8, 2024, Galveston, Texas. (Elizabeth Conley/Houston Chronicle via AP)\n\nCity of Galveston workers clear debris from Beryl from the West End of the seawall in Galveston, Texas, on Monday, July 8, 2024. Tropical Storm Beryl was unleashing heavy rains and powerful winds along the Texas coast, knocking out power to more than 2 million homes and businesses and flooding streets with fast-rising waters. (Jennifer Reynolds/The Galveston County Daily News via AP)\n\nA rescue crew prepares in Houston, on Monday, July 8, 2024, after Beryl came ashore in Texas as a hurricane and dumped heavy rains downtown. {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Associated_Press", "type": "org", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Associated Press"}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Science/Earth_Sciences/Atmospheric_Sciences", "label": "dmoz/Science/Earth Sciences/Atmospheric Sciences", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Business", "label": "news/Business", "wgt": 87}], "image": "https://i.dailymail.co.uk/1s/2024/07/09/05/wire-87097415-1720498169-793_636x382.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9716370", "eventUri": "eng-9716370", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Houston"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.403921568627451, "wgt": 217, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8216003731", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-08", "time": "23:30:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-08T23:30:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-08T23:30:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://wsvn.com/news/us-world/texas-officials-say-restoring-electricity-will-take-days-after-beryl-knocked-out-power-to-millions/", "title": "Texas officials say restoring electricity will take days after Beryl knocked out power to millions - WSVN 7News | Miami News, Weather, Sports | Fort Lauderdale", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- Tropical Storm Beryl slammed into Texas on Monday, knocking out power to nearly 3 million homes and businesses and unleashing heavy rains that prompted dozens of high-water rescues. The fast-moving tempest threatened to carve a harsh path over several more states in coming days.\n\nTexas state and local officials warned it could take several days to restore power after Beryl came ashore as a Category 1 hurricane and toppled 10 transmission lines and knocked down trees that took down power lines.\n\nWithin hours, Beryl had weakened into a tropical storm, far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean last weekend. But the winds and rains of the fast-moving storm were still powerful enough to knock down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in water-saturated earth, and strand dozens of cars on flooded roadways.\n\nAs it moved inland, the storm still threatened to spawn tornados.\n\n\"We're not past any difficult conditions,\" said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country, warning it would be a \"multiple day process to get power restored.\"\n\nHouston took a hard hit as CenterPoint Energy reported more than 2 million homes and businesses without power in and around the nation's fourth-largest city. Patrick said the company was bringing in thousands of additional workers to restore power, with top priority for places such as nursing homes and assisted living centers.\n\nAt least two people were killed when trees fell on homes, and the National Hurricane Center said damaging winds and flash flooding would continue as Beryl pushes inland. A third person, a civilian employee of the Houston Police Department, was killed when he was trapped in flood waters under a highway overpass, Houston Mayor John Whitmire said. There were no immediate reports of widespread structural damage, however.\n\nThe loss of power was an all-too familiar experience for Houston: Powerful storms had just ripped through the area in May, killing eight people, leaving nearly 1 million without power and flooding numerous streets.\n\nResidents without power after Beryl were doing their best.\n\n\"We haven't really slept,\" said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in her neighborhood in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio, 67, said she had already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\n\n\"We are struggling to have food and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.\n\nHouston and Harris County officials said power crews would be sent into the area to restore service as quickly as possible, an urgent priority for homes also left without air conditioning in the middle of summer. Temperatures, which had cooled slightly with the storm, were expected to reach back into the 90s as early as Tuesday. The National Weather Service issued a heat advisory that said the area heat index could reach 105 degrees Fahrenheit (41 degrees Celsius).\n\nThe state will be ready to open cooling centers as well as food and water distribution centers, said Nim Kidd, chief of state emergency operations.\n\nBeryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast on Monday, reclosing streets in neighborhoods that had already been washed out by previous storms. Television stations on Monday broadcast the dramatic rescue of a man who had climbed to the roof of his pickup truck after it got trapped in fast-flowing waters. Emergency crews used an extension ladder from a fire truck to drop him a life preserver and a tether before moving him to dry land.\n\nHouston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.\n\n\"First responders are putting their lives at risk. That's what they're trained for. It's working,\" Houston Mayor John Whitmire said.\n\nJavier Mejia was one of about 20 people who gathered near the pickup truck rescue site to take pictures of other submerged vehicles sitting on the flooded highway.\n\n\"If you don't have a way through, you're going to get stuck like that,\" Mejia said.\n\nHaving experienced previous storms in Houston, Mejia stocked up on food and water before Beryl hit, but forgot gas for his portable generator. He planned to spend the day looking for some.\n\n\"I don't want it to go bad,\" he said of the food, adding that if he can't find gas, \"We can just fire up the grill.\"\n\nMany streets and neighborhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents set to work chopping up knocked-down trees and big branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks.\n\nPatrick warned that flooding could last for days as rain continued to fall on already saturated ground.\n\n\"This is not a one-day event,\" he said.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was getting regular updates on the storm after it made landfall, the White House said. The U.S. Coast Guard and FEMA had prepared search and rescue teams, and FEMA collected bottled water, meals, tarps and electric generators in case they are needed.\n\nSeveral companies with refineries or industrial plants in the area reported that the power disruptions necessitated the flaring of gases at the facilities.\n\nMarathon Petroleum Corp. said it conducted a \"safe combustion of excess gases\" at its Galveston Bay Refinery in Texas City, but did not provide information on the amount of gas flared or how long it would continue. Formosa Plastics Corporation and Freeport LNG also reported flaring related to Beryl, according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.\n\nCompanies have 24 hours to share emissions data after the flaring stops, a representative from the TCEQ said in an email.\n\nThe earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, Beryl caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. The storm ripped off doors, windows and roofs with devastating winds and storm surge fueled by the Atlantic's record warmth.\n\nThree times during the week, Beryl gained 35 mph (56 kph) in wind speed in 24 hours or less, the official weather service definition of rapid intensification.\n\nBeryl's explosive growth into an unprecedented early whopper of a storm indicates the hot water of the Atlantic and Caribbean and what the Atlantic hurricane belt can expect for the rest of the storm season, experts said. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nIn Louisiana, heavy bands of rain were expected all day Monday and \"the risk is going to be for that heavy rainfall and potential for flash flooding,\" National Weather Service meteorologist Donald Jones said in a Monday morning Facebook Live briefing.\n\nThe weather service in Shreveport issued tornado warnings across northwest Louisiana. The agency confirmed on social media that multiple tornados had been spotted in that corner of the state. Information on whether those weather events have caused any significant damage was not immediately available.\n\nBeryl was forecast to bring more strong rain and winds into additional states over the coming days. One of those, Missouri was already dealing with a wet summer. Heavy rains unrelated to the storm prompted several water rescues around the city of Columbia, where rivers and creeks were already high ahead of Beryl's expected arrival on Tuesday.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.\n\nJoin our Newsletter for the latest news right to your inbox Email address Submit", "source": {"uri": "wsvn.com", {"uri": "8216055756", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "00:45:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T00:45:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T00:45:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/news/world/united-states/beryl-weakens-to-tropical-depression-after-slamming-into-texas-as-category-1-hurricane/article_0cda9a1d-6aab-54be-b689-e0675b202a01.html", "title": "Beryl weakens to tropical depression after slamming into Texas as Category 1 hurricane", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- After Tropical Storm Beryl slammed into Texas early Monday, knocking out power to nearly 3 million homes and businesses and killing several people it moved east and weakened to a tropical depression, the National Hurricane Center said Monday evening. Flooding, rains and tornadoes were possible across portions of eastern Texas, Western Louisiana and Arkansas.\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nHOUSTON (AP) -- Tropical Storm Beryl slammed into Texas on Monday, knocking out power to nearly 3 million homes and businesses and unleashing heavy rains that prompted dozens of high-water rescues. The fast-moving tempest threatened to carve a harsh path over several more states in coming days.\n\nTexas state and local officials warned it could take several days to restore power after Beryl came ashore as a Category 1 hurricane and toppled 10 transmission lines and knocked down trees that took down power lines.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nWithin hours, Beryl had weakened into a tropical storm, far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean last weekend. But the winds and rains of the fast-moving storm were still powerful enough to knock down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in water-saturated earth, and strand dozens of cars on flooded roadways.\n\nAs it moved inland, the storm still threatened to spawn tornados.\n\n\"We're not past any difficult conditions,\" said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country, warning it would be a \"multiple day process to get power restored.\"\n\nHouston took a hard hit as CenterPoint Energy reported more than 2 million homes and businesses without power in and around the nation's fourth-largest city. Patrick said the company was bringing in thousands of additional workers to restore power, with top priority for places such as nursing homes and assisted living centers.\n\nAt least two people were killed when trees fell on homes, and the National Hurricane Center said damaging winds and flash flooding would continue as Beryl pushes inland. A third person, a civilian employee of the Houston Police Department, was killed when he was trapped in flood waters under a highway overpass, Houston Mayor John Whitmire said. There were no immediate reports of widespread structural damage, however.\n\nThe loss of power was an all-too familiar experience for Houston: Powerful storms had just ripped through the area in May, killing eight people, leaving nearly 1 million without power and flooding numerous streets.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nResidents without power after Beryl were doing their best.\n\n\"We haven't really slept,\" said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in her neighborhood in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio, 67, said she had already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\n\n\"We are struggling to have food and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.\n\nHouston and Harris County officials said power crews would be sent into the area to restore service as quickly as possible, an urgent priority for homes also left without air conditioning in the middle of summer. Temperatures, which had cooled slightly with the storm, were expected to reach back into the 90s as early as Tuesday. The National Weather Service issued a heat advisory that said the area heat index could reach 105 degrees Fahrenheit (41 degrees Celsius).\n\nThe state will be ready to open cooling centers as well as food and water distribution centers, said Nim Kidd, chief of state emergency operations.\n\nBeryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast on Monday, reclosing streets in neighborhoods that had already been washed out by previous storms. Television stations on Monday broadcast the dramatic rescue of a man who had climbed to the roof of his pickup truck after it got trapped in fast-flowing waters. Emergency crews used an extension ladder from a fire truck to drop him a life preserver and a tether before moving him to dry land.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nHouston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.\n\n\"First responders are putting their lives at risk. That's what they're trained for. It's working,\" Houston Mayor John Whitmire said.\n\nJavier Mejia was one of about 20 people who gathered near the pickup truck rescue site to take pictures of other submerged vehicles sitting on the flooded highway.\n\n\"If you don't have a way through, you're going to get stuck like that,\" Mejia said.\n\nHaving experienced previous storms in Houston, Mejia stocked up on food and water before Beryl hit, but forgot gas for his portable generator. He planned to spend the day looking for some.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"I don't want it to go bad,\" he said of the food, adding that if he can't find gas, \"We can just fire up the grill.\"\n\nMany streets and neighborhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents set to work chopping up knocked-down trees and big branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks.\n\nPatrick warned that flooding could last for days as rain continued to fall on already saturated ground.\n\n\"This is not a one-day event,\" he said.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was getting regular updates on the storm after it made landfall, the White House said. The U.S. Coast Guard and FEMA had prepared search and rescue teams, and FEMA collected bottled water, meals, tarps and electric generators in case they are needed.\n\nSeveral companies with refineries or industrial plants in the area reported that the power disruptions necessitated the flaring of gases at the facilities.\n\nMarathon Petroleum Corp. said it conducted a \"safe combustion of excess gases\" at its Galveston Bay Refinery in Texas City, but did not provide information on the amount of gas flared or how long it would continue. Formosa Plastics Corporation and Freeport LNG also reported flaring related to Beryl, according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.\n\nCompanies have 24 hours to share emissions data after the flaring stops, a representative from the TCEQ said in an email.\n\nThe earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, Beryl caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nIn Louisiana, heavy bands of rain were expected all day Monday and \"the risk is going to be for that heavy rainfall and potential for flash flooding,\" National Weather Service meteorologist Donald Jones said in a Monday morning Facebook Live briefing.\n\nThe weather service in Shreveport issued tornado warnings across northwest Louisiana. The agency confirmed on social media that multiple tornados had been spotted in that corner of the state. Information on whether those weather events have caused any significant damage was not immediately available.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nBeryl was forecast to bring more strong rain and winds into additional states over the coming days. One of those, Missouri was already dealing with a wet summer. Heavy rains unrelated to the storm prompted several water rescues around the city of Columbia, where rivers and creeks were already high ahead of Beryl's expected arrival on Tuesday.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press reporters Jim Vertuno in Austin, Texas; Corey Williams in Detroit; Julie Walker in New York; Melina Walling in Chicago; and Jeff Martin in Atlanta contributed to {"uri": "8215911844", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-08", "time": "21:26:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-08T21:26:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-08T21:25:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.abqjournal.com/news/national/tropical-storm-beryl-topples-trees-floods-highways-and-leaves-more-than-2m-without-power-in/article_8c7d5f8f-ef43-570a-ab49-d69bd690f64d.html", "title": "Tropical Storm Beryl topples trees, floods highways and leaves more than 2M without power in Texas", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- Tropical Storm Beryl sped across the Texas coast on Monday, leaving more than 2 million people and businesses without power in the Houston area and unleashing heavy rains that prompted dozens of high-water rescues. {"uri": "8217038434", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "13:32:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T13:32:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T13:32:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.huffpost.com/entry/beryl-tropical-weather_n_668d376de4b0a62057b8532c", "title": "Beryl Leaves Hot Misery In Its Wake As It Churns Into U.S. Interior", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- Many of the millions left without power when Hurricane Beryl crashed into the Houston area, killing several people and unleashing flooding, now face days without air conditioning as dangerous heat threatens the region Tuesday.\n\nA heat advisory was in effect through Wednesday in parts of Texas, with temperatures in the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) and heat index values up to 105 degrees (40.5 Celsius) expected Tuesday. The widespread loss of power -- and therefore air conditioning -- could make for dangerous conditions, the National Weather Service said.\n\nMore than 2.3 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday morning, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\n\"Houstonians need to know we're working around the clock so you will be safe,\" Houston Mayor John Whitmire said Monday, urging residents to also know the dangers of high water, to stay hydrated and to check on their neighbors.\n\nBeryl was blamed for killing several people in Texas and at least one in Louisiana, officials said.\n\nThe storm weakened into a tropical depression after making landfall, and by Tuesday morning its center was over southwestern Arkansas, moving northeast with maximum sustained wind speeds near 30 mph (48 kph), the weather service said. Its strength wasn't expected to change much in the next day or two.\n\nBeryl still threatened to unleash more harsh weather over several other states in coming days. It is expected to bring heavy rainfall and possible flash flooding from the lower and mid-Mississippi Valley to the Great Lakes on Tuesday into Wednesday, the weather service said.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana and Michigan, and tornadoes were possible through the early morning across parts of the mid-South. A few tornadoes were possible from midday to the early evening in Missouri, Tennessee, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana, and Ohio, according to the weather service.\n\nThe weather service confirmed on social media Monday evening that tornadoes had been spotted in northeastern Louisiana. Bossier Sheriff Julian Whittington said in a Facebook post that a woman was killed in the Benton area when a tree fell on her home.\n\nTexas state and local officials warned it could take several days to fully restore power after Beryl came ashore as a Category 1 hurricane, toppled 10 transmission lines and knocked down trees that took down power lines.\n\nBeryl on Tuesday was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that earlier tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean. But its winds and rains still knocked down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in water-saturated earth, and strand dozens of cars on flooded roads.\n\n\"We're not past any difficult conditions,\" said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country.\n\nPatrick said CenterPoint Energy was bringing thousands of additional workers to restore power, with top priorities including nursing homes and assisted living centers. CenterPoint said in an update Monday evening that it expected to restore power to 1 million customers by the end of Wednesday.\n\nAt least two people were killed when trees fell on homes in Texas, and a third person, a civilian employee of the Houston Police Department, was killed when he was trapped in floodwaters under a highway overpass, Whitmire said.\n\nThe loss of power was an all-too familiar experience for Houston. Powerful storms ripped through the area in May, killing eight people, leaving nearly 1 million without power and flooding streets.\n\nResidents without power after Beryl were doing their best.\n\n\"We haven't really slept,\" said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in her neighborhood in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio said she had already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\n\n\"We are struggling to have food, and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.\n\nThe state was opening cooling centers, as well as food and water distribution centers, said Nim Kidd, chief of state emergency operations.\n\nBeryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast Monday, closing streets that had already been washed out by previous storms. Houston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.\n\nMany streets and neighborhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents chopped up knocked-down trees and branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was getting regular updates on the storm and called the Houston mayor Monday, the White House said. He told the mayor his administration will make sure Texans have resources.\n\nSeveral companies with refineries or industrial plants reported the power disruptions required the flaring of gases.\n\nThe earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, Beryl caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\n___", "source": {"uri": "8217255193", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "15:45:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T15:45:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T15:44:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.lakecowichangazette.com/world-news/beryl-leaves-hot-misery-in-its-wake-as-it-churns-over-us-interior-7432926", "title": "Beryl leaves hot misery in its wake as it churns over US interior", "body": "Heat and humidity after flooding, devastation in hurricane's Texas landfall\n\nMany of the millions left without power when Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas, killing several people and unleashing flooding, now face days without air conditioning as dangerous heat threatens the region Tuesday.\n\nA heat advisory was in effect through Wednesday in the Houston area and beyond, with temperatures expected to soar into the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) and humidity that could make it feel as hot as 105 degrees (40.5 Celsius). The widespread loss of power, and therefore air conditioning, could make for dangerous conditions, the National Weather Service said.\n\nMore than 2.3 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday morning, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\n\"Houstonians need to know we're working around the clock so you will be safe,\" Houston Mayor John Whitmire said Monday, urging residents to also know the dangers of high water, to stay hydrated and to check on their neighbors.\n\nBeryl has been blamed for at least seven deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas, officials said.\n\nThe storm weakened after making landfall, and by Tuesday morning it was a tropical depression centered over southwestern Arkansas, moving northeast with maximum sustained winds near 30 mph (48 kph), the weather service said. Its strength wasn't expected to change much in the next day or two.\n\nThe storm is forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flash flooding from the lower and mid-Mississippi Valley to the Great Lakes into Wednesday, the weather service said.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana and Michigan. A few tornadoes were possible in Missouri, Tennessee, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana and Ohio, forecasters said.\n\nBeryl came ashore in Texas as a Category 1 hurricane, far less powerful than the behemoth that tore a deadly path through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean. But its winds and rains still knocked down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in saturated earth and stranded dozens of cars on flooded roads.\n\nIt could take days to fully return power in Texas after Beryl toppled 10 transmission lines. Top priorities for power restoration include nursing homes and assisted living centers, said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting as governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country.\n\nPowerful storms in the area in May killed eight people, left nearly 1 million without power and flooded streets. Residents now without power after Beryl were doing their best.\n\n\"We haven't really slept,\" said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio said she had already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\n\n\"We are struggling to have food, and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.\n\nThe state was opening cooling centers, as well as food and water distribution centers, said Nim Kidd, chief of state emergency operations.\n\nBeryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast Monday, closing streets that had already been washed out by previous storms. Houston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.\n\nMany streets and neighborhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents chopped up knocked-down trees and branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks. Several companies with refineries or industrial plants reported the power disruptions required the flaring of gases.\n\nThe earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, Beryl caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nREAD ALSO: Hurricane {"uri": "2024-07-416306053", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "13:43:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T13:43:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T13:08:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://whnt.com/news/national/ap-us-news/ap-some-power-restored-in-houston-after-hurricane-beryl-while-storm-spawns-tornadoes-as-it-moves-east/", "title": "Beryl leaves hot misery in its wake as the still-dangerous storm churns into the US interior", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- Many of the millions left without power when Hurricane Beryl crashed into the Houston area, killing several people and unleashing flooding, now face days without air conditioning as dangerous heat threatens the region Tuesday.\n\nA heat advisory was in effect through Wednesday in parts of Texas, with temperatures in the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) and heat index values up to 105 degrees (40.5 Celsius) expected Tuesday. The widespread loss of power -- and therefore air conditioning -- could make for dangerous conditions, the National Weather Service said.\n\nMore than 2.3 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday morning, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\n\"Houstonians need to know we're working around the clock so you will be safe,\" Houston Mayor John Whitmire said Monday, urging residents to also know the dangers of high water, to stay hydrated, and to check on their neighbors.\n\nBeryl was blamed for killing several people in Texas and at least one in Louisiana, officials said.\n\nThe storm weakened into a tropical depression after making landfall, and by Tuesday morning its center was over southwestern Arkansas, moving northeast with maximum sustained wind speeds near 30 mph (48 kph), the weather service said. Its strength wasn't expected to change much in the next day or two.\n\nBeryl still threatened to unleash more harsh weather over several other states in the coming days. It is expected to bring heavy rainfall and possible flash flooding from the lower and mid-Mississippi Valley to the Great Lakes on Tuesday into Wednesday, the weather service said.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana, and Michigan, and tornadoes were possible through the early morning across parts of the mid-South. A few tornadoes were possible from midday to the early evening in Missouri, Tennessee, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana, and Ohio, according to the weather service.\n\nThe weather service confirmed on social media Monday evening that tornadoes had been spotted in northeastern Louisiana. Bossier Sheriff Julian Whittington said in a Facebook post that a woman was killed in the Benton area when a tree fell on her home.\n\nTexas state and local officials warned it could take several days to fully restore power after Beryl came ashore as a Category 1 hurricane, toppled 10 transmission lines, and knocked down trees that took down power lines.\n\nBeryl on Tuesday was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that earlier tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean. But its winds and rains still knocked down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in water-saturated earth, and stranded dozens of cars on flooded roads.\n\n\"We're not past any difficult conditions,\" said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country.\n\nPatrick said CenterPoint Energy was bringing thousands of additional workers to restore power, with top priorities including nursing homes and assisted living centers. CenterPoint said in an update Monday evening that it expected to restore power to 1 million customers by the end of Wednesday.\n\nAt least two people were killed when trees fell on homes in Texas, and a third person, a civilian employee of the Houston Police Department, was killed when he was trapped in floodwaters under a highway overpass, Whitmire said.\n\nThe loss of power was an all-too-familiar experience for Houston. Powerful storms ripped through the area in May, killing eight people, leaving nearly 1 million without power, and flooding streets.\n\nResidents without power after Beryl were doing their best.\n\n\"We haven't really slept,\" said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in her neighborhood in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio said she had already been without power for several hours and worried that the food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\n\n\"We are struggling to have food, and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.\n\nThe state was opening cooling centers, as well as food and water distribution centers, said Nim Kidd, chief of state emergency operations.\n\nBeryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast Monday, closing streets that had already been washed out by previous storms. Houston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.\n\nMany streets and neighborhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents chopped up knocked-down trees and branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was getting regular updates on the storm and called the Houston mayor Monday, the White House said. He told the mayor his administration would make sure Texans have resources.\n\nSeveral companies with refineries or industrial plants reported that power disruptions required the flaring of gases.\n\nThe earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, Beryl caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\n___\n\nContributing to this report were Associated Press reporters Jim Vertuno in Austin, Texas; Corey Williams in Detroit; Julie Walker in New York; Melina Walling in Chicago; Jeff Martin in Atlanta; and Sara Cline in {"uri": "8217326924", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "16:34:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T16:34:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T16:34:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://wsvn.com/news/us-world/beryl-leaves-hot-misery-in-its-wake-as-the-still-dangerous-storm-churns-over-the-us-interior/", "title": "Beryl leaves hot misery in its wake as the still-dangerous storm churns over the US interior - WSVN 7News | Miami News, Weather, Sports | Fort Lauderdale", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- Many of the millions left without power when Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas, killing several people and unleashing flooding, now face days without air conditioning as dangerous heat threatens the region Tuesday.\n\nA heat advisory was in effect through Wednesday in the Houston area and beyond, with temperatures expected to soar into the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) and humidity that could make it feel as hot as 105 degrees (40.5 Celsius). The widespread loss of power, and therefore air conditioning, could make for dangerous conditions, the National Weather Service said.\n\nMore than 2.3 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday morning, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\n\"Houstonians need to know we're working around the clock so you will be safe,\" Houston Mayor John Whitmire said Monday, urging residents to also know the dangers of high water, to stay hydrated and to check on their neighbors.\n\nBeryl has been blamed for at least seven deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas, officials said.\n\nThe storm weakened after making landfall, and late Tuesday morning it was a post-tropical cyclone centered over northeastern Arkansas, moving northeast with maximum sustained winds near 30 mph (48 kph), the weather service said. Its strength wasn't expected to change much in the next two days.\n\nThe storm is forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flash flooding from the lower and mid-Mississippi Valley to the Great Lakes into Wednesday, the weather service said.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana and Michigan. A few tornadoes were possible in Missouri, Tennessee, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana and Ohio, forecasters said.\n\nBeryl came ashore in Texas as a Category 1 hurricane, far less powerful than the behemoth that tore a deadly path through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean. But its winds and rains still knocked down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in saturated earth and stranded dozens of cars on flooded roads.\n\nIt could take days to fully return power in Texas after Beryl toppled 10 transmission lines. Top priorities for power restoration include nursing homes and assisted living centers, said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting as governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country.\n\nPowerful storms in the area in May killed eight people, left nearly 1 million without power and flooded streets. Residents now without power after Beryl were doing their best.\n\n\"We haven't really slept,\" said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio said she had already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\n\n\"We are struggling to have food, and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.\n\nThe state was opening cooling centers, as well as food and water distribution centers, said Nim Kidd, chief of state emergency operations.\n\nBeryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast Monday, closing streets that had already been washed out by previous storms. Houston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.\n\nMany streets and neighborhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents chopped up knocked-down trees and branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks. Several companies with refineries or industrial plants reported the power disruptions required the flaring of gases.\n\nThe earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, Beryl caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8217238445", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "15:34:22", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T15:34:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T15:34:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.adn.com/nation-world/2024/07/09/hurricane-beryl-leaves-hot-misery-in-its-wake-as-the-still-dangerous-storm-churns-through-the-us-interior/", "title": "Hurricane Beryl leaves hot misery in its wake as the still-dangerous storm churns through the US interior", "body": "HOUSTON -- Many of the millions left without power when Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas, killing several people and unleashing flooding, now face days without air conditioning as dangerous heat threatens the region Tuesday.\n\nA heat advisory was in effect through Wednesday in the Houston area and beyond, with temperatures expected to soar into the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) and humidity that could make it feel as hot as 105 degrees (40.5 Celsius). The widespread loss of power, and therefore air conditioning, could make for dangerous conditions, the National Weather Service said.\n\nMore than 2.3 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday morning, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\n\"Houstonians need to know we're working around the clock so you will be safe,\" Houston Mayor John Whitmire said Monday, urging residents to also know the dangers of high water, to stay hydrated and to check on their neighbors.\n\nBeryl has been blamed for at least seven deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas, officials said.\n\nThe storm weakened after making landfall, and late Tuesday morning it was a post-tropical cyclone centered over northeastern Arkansas, moving northeast with maximum sustained winds near 30 mph (48 kph), the weather service said. Its strength wasn't expected to change much in the next two days.\n\nThe storm is forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flash flooding from the lower and mid-Mississippi Valley to the Great Lakes into Wednesday, the weather service said.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana and Michigan. A few tornadoes were possible in Missouri, Tennessee, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana and Ohio, forecasters said.\n\nBeryl came ashore in Texas as a Category 1 hurricane, far less powerful than the behemoth that tore a deadly path through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean. But its winds and rains still knocked down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in saturated earth and stranded dozens of cars on flooded roads.\n\nIt could take days to fully return power in Texas after Beryl toppled 10 transmission lines. Top priorities for power restoration include nursing homes and assisted living centers, said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting as governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country.\n\nPowerful storms in the area in May killed eight people, left nearly 1 million without power and flooded streets. Residents now without power after Beryl were doing their best.\n\n\"We haven't really slept,\" said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio said she had already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\n\n\"We are struggling to have food, and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.\n\nThe state was opening cooling centers, as well as food and water distribution centers, said Nim Kidd, chief of state emergency operations.\n\nBeryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast Monday, closing streets that had already been washed out by previous storms. Houston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.\n\nMany streets and neighborhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents chopped up knocked-down trees and branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks. {"uri": "2024-07-416244755", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "12:51:29", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T12:51:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T12:37:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/beryl-leaves-hot-misery-in-its-wake-as-the-still-dangerous-storm-churns-into-the/article_3827e47c-07fe-561b-a512-333651a2f548.html", "title": "Beryl leaves hot misery in its wake as the still-dangerous storm churns into the US interior", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- Many of the millions left without power when Hurricane Beryl crashed into the Houston area, killing several people and unleashing flooding, now face days without power and air conditioning as dangerous heat threatens the region Tuesday.\n\nA heat advisory was in effect through Wednesday in parts of Texas, with temperatures in the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) and heat index values up to 105 degrees (40.5 Celsius) expected Tuesday. The widespread loss of power -- and therefore air conditioning -- could make for dangerous conditions, the National Weather Service said.\n\nMore than 2.3 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday morning, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. The lack of cooling to people's homes, downed power lines and nonfunctioning traffic lights led officials to ask residents to stay home if possible.\n\n\"Houstonians need to know we're working around the clock so you will be safe,\" Houston Mayor John Whitmire said Monday at a media briefing, urging residents to also know the dangers of high water, to stay hydrated and to check on their neighbors.\n\nBeryl was blamed for killing several people in Texas and at least one in Louisiana, officials said.\n\nThe storm weakened into a tropical depression after making landfall, and by Tuesday morning its center was over southwestern Arkansas, moving northeast with maximum sustained wind speeds near 30 mph (48 kph), the weather service said. Its strength wasn't expected to change much in the next day or two.\n\nBeryl still threatened to unleash more harsh weather over several other states in coming days. It is expected to bring heavy rainfall and possible flash flooding from the lower and mid-Mississippi Valley to the Great Lakes on Tuesday into Wednesday, the weather service said.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana and Michigan, and tornadoes were possible through the early morning across parts of the mid-South. A few tornadoes were possible from midday to the early evening in Missouri, Tennessee, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana, and Ohio, according to the weather service.\n\nThe weather service confirmed on social media Monday evening that tornadoes had been spotted in northeastern Louisiana. Bossier Sheriff Julian Whittington said in a Facebook post that a woman was killed in the Benton area when a tree fell on her home.\n\nTexas state and local officials warned it could take several days to fully restore power after Beryl came ashore as a Category 1 hurricane, toppled 10 transmission lines and knocked down trees that took down power lines.\n\nBeryl on Tuesday was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that earlier tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean. But its winds and rains still knocked down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in water-saturated earth, and strand dozens of cars on flooded roads.\n\n\"We're not past any difficult conditions,\" said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country.\n\nPatrick said CenterPoint Energy was bringing thousands of additional workers to restore power, with top priorities including nursing homes and assisted living centers. CenterPoint said in an update Monday evening that it expected to restore power to 1 million customers by the end of Wednesday.\n\nAt least two people were killed when trees fell on homes in Texas, and a third person, a civilian employee of the Houston Police Department, was killed when he was trapped in floodwaters under a highway overpass, Whitmire said.\n\nThe loss of power was an all-too familiar experience for Houston. Powerful storms ripped through the area in May, killing eight people, leaving nearly 1 million without power and flooding streets.\n\nResidents without power after Beryl were doing their best.\n\n\"We haven't really slept,\" said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in her neighborhood in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio said she had already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\n\n\"We are struggling to have food, and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.\n\nThe state was opening cooling centers, as well as food and water distribution centers, said Nim Kidd, chief of state emergency operations.\n\nBeryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast Monday, closing streets that had already been washed out by previous storms. Houston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.\n\nMany streets and neighborhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents chopped up knocked-down trees and branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was getting regular updates on the storm and called the Houston mayor Monday, the White House said. He told the mayor his administration will make sure Texans have resources.\n\nSeveral companies with refineries or industrial plants reported the power disruptions required the flaring of gases.\n\nThe earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, Beryl caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. {"uri": "2024-07-416371744", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "14:42:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T14:42:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T04:04:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.orlandosentinel.com/2024/07/09/beryl-leaves-hot-misery-in-its-wake-as-the-still-dangerous-storm-churns-over-the-us-interior/", "title": "Beryl leaves hot misery in its wake as the still-dangerous storm churns over the US interior", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- Many of the millions left without power when Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas, killing several people and unleashing flooding, now face days without air conditioning as dangerous heat threatens the region Tuesday.\n\nA heat advisory was in effect through Wednesday in the Houston area and beyond, with temperatures expected to soar into the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) and humidity that could make it feel as hot as 105 degrees (40.5 Celsius). The widespread loss of power, and therefore air conditioning, could make for dangerous conditions, the National Weather Service said.\n\nMore than 2.3 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday morning, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\n\"Houstonians need to know we're working around the clock so you will be safe,\" Houston Mayor John Whitmire said Monday, urging residents to also know the dangers of high water, to stay hydrated and to check on their neighbors.\n\nBeryl has been blamed for at least seven deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas, officials said.\n\nThe storm weakened after making landfall, and by Tuesday morning it was a tropical depression centered over southwestern Arkansas, moving northeast with maximum sustained winds near 30 mph (48 kph), the weather service said. Its strength wasn't expected to change much in the next day or two.\n\nThe storm is forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flash flooding from the lower and mid-Mississippi Valley to the Great Lakes into Wednesday, the weather service said.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana and Michigan. A few tornadoes were possible in Missouri, Tennessee, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana and Ohio, forecasters said.\n\nBeryl came ashore in Texas as a Category 1 hurricane, far less powerful than the behemoth that tore a deadly path through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean. But its winds and rains still knocked down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in saturated earth and stranded dozens of cars on flooded roads.\n\nIt could take days to fully return power in Texas after Beryl toppled 10 transmission lines. Top priorities for power restoration include nursing homes and assisted living centers, said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting as governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country.\n\nPowerful storms in the area in May killed eight people, left nearly 1 million without power and flooded streets. Residents now without power after Beryl were doing their best.\n\n\"We haven't really slept,\" said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio said she had already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\n\n\"We are struggling to have food, and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.\n\nThe state was opening cooling centers, as well as food and water distribution centers, said Nim Kidd, chief of state emergency operations.\n\nBeryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast Monday, closing streets that had already been washed out by previous storms. Houston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.\n\nMany streets and neighborhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents chopped up knocked-down trees and branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks. Several companies with refineries or industrial plants reported the power disruptions required the flaring of gases.\n\nThe earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, Beryl caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\n___\n\nContributing {"uri": "2024-07-415547864", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-08", "time": "22:04:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-08T22:04:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-08T21:19:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/tropical-storm-beryl-topples-trees-floods-highways-and-leaves-more-than-2m-without-power-in/article_df161859-2993-57e7-b6c9-14d9faaa16cc.html", "title": "Tropical Storm Beryl topples trees, floods highways and leaves more than 2M without power in Texas", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- Tropical Storm Beryl sped across the Texas coast on Monday, leaving more than 2 million people and businesses without power in the Houston area and unleashing heavy rains that prompted dozens of high-water rescues. The fast-moving tempest threatened to carve a harsh path over several more states in coming days.\n\nWithin hours after Beryl swept ashore as a Category 1 hurricane, it had weakened into a tropical storm, far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean last weekend.\n\nBut the winds and rains of the fast-moving storm were still powerful enough to knock down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in water-saturated earth and to strand dozens of cars on flooded roadways.\n\nAt least two people were killed when trees fell on homes, and the National Hurricane Center said damaging winds and flash flooding would continue as Beryl pushes inland. There were no immediate reports of widespread structural damage, however.\n\nMore than 2.2 million homes and businesses were without power around Houston, the nation's fourth-largest city, after Beryl blew through, according to the CenterPoint Energy utility. For many, it was an all-too-familiar experience: Powerful storms had just ripped through the area in May, killing eight people, leaving nearly 1 million without power and flooding numerous streets.\n\nResidents without power after Beryl were doing their best.\n\n\"We haven't really slept,\" said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in her neighborhood in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio, 67, said already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\n\n\"We are struggling to have food and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.\n\nHouston and Harris County officials said power crews would be sent into the area to restore service as quickly as possible, an urgent priority for homes also left without air conditioning in the middle of summer. Temperatures, which had cooled slightly with the storm, were expected to reach back into the 90s as early as Tuesday.\n\n\"While these efforts are full steam ahead, we want residents to know and prepare for a possible multi-day power outage,\" Galveston city officials said on Facebook. \"The estimated timeline is anywhere from 72 hours to two weeks in parts of the island.\"\n\nBeryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast on Monday, reclosing streets in neighborhoods that had already been washed out by previous storms. Television stations on Monday broadcast the dramatic rescue of a man who had climbed to the roof of his pickup truck after it got trapped in fast-flowing waters. Emergency crews used an extension ladder from a fire truck to drop him a life preserver and a tether before moving him to dry land.\n\nHouston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.\n\n\"First responders are putting their lives at risk. That's what they're trained for. It's working,\" Houston Mayor John Whitmire said.\n\nJavier Mejia was one of about 20 people who gathered near the pickup truck rescue site to take pictures of other submerged vehicles sitting on the flooded highway.\n\n\"If you don't have a way through, you're going to get stuck like that,\" Mejia said.\n\nHaving experienced previous storms in Houston, Mejia stocked up on food and water before Beryl hit, but forgot gas for his portable generator. He planned to spend the day looking for some.\n\n\"I don't want it to go bad,\" he said of the food, adding that if he can't find gas, \"We can just fire up the grill.\"\n\nMany streets and neighborhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents set to work chopping up knocked-down trees and big branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks.\n\nTwo people were killed after trees fell on their houses: a man in the Houston suburb of Humble and a woman in Harris County, authorities said. Hundreds of trees fell in the county, crushing vehicles and damaging homes, said Precinct 4 County Constable Mark Herman.\n\nTexas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country, warned that flooding could last for days as rain continued to fall on already saturated ground.\n\n\"This is not a one-day event,\" he said.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was getting regular updates on the storm after it made landfall, the White House said. The U.S. Coast Guard and FEMA had prepared search and rescue teams, and FEMA collected bottled water, meals, tarps and electric generators in case they are needed.\n\nSeveral companies with refineries or industrial plants in the area reported that the power disruptions necessitated the flaring of gases at the facilities.\n\nMarathon Petroleum Corp. said it conducted a \"safe combustion of excess gases\" at its Galveston Bay Refinery in Texas City, but did not provide information on the amount of gas flared or how long it would continue. Formosa Plastics Corporation and Freeport LNG also reported flaring related to Beryl, according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.\n\nCompanies have 24 hours to share emissions data after the flaring stops, a representative from the TCEQ said in an email.\n\nThe earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, Beryl caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. The storm ripped off doors, windows and roofs with devastating winds and storm surge fueled by the Atlantic's record warmth.\n\nThree times during the week, Beryl gained 35 mph (56 kph) in wind speed in 24 hours or less, the official weather service definition of rapid intensification.\n\nBeryl's explosive growth into an unprecedented early whopper of a storm indicates the hot water of the Atlantic and Caribbean and what the Atlantic hurricane belt can expect for the rest of the storm season, experts said. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nIn Louisiana, heavy bands of rain were expected all day Monday and \"the risk is going to be for that heavy rainfall and potential for flash flooding,\" National Weather Service meteorologist Donald Jones said in a Monday morning Facebook Live briefing.\n\nMeteorologists in Louisiana are watching for lingering rainbands, which could drop copious amounts of rain wherever they materialize, as well as \"quick, spin-up tornadoes,\" said Donald Jones, a National Weather Service meteorologist in Lake Charles, Louisiana.\n\n\"It's just a matter of exactly where that's going to be,\" Jones said. \"That's very difficult to predict more than maybe an hour or so in advance.\"\n\nBeryl was forecast to bring more strong rain and winds into additional states over the coming days. One of those, Missouri was already dealing with a wet summer. Heavy rains unrelated to the storm prompted several water rescues around the city of Columbia, where rivers and creeks were already high ahead of Beryl's expected arrival on Tuesday.\n\nAssociated Press reporters Jim Vertuno in Austin, Texas; Corey Williams in Detroit; Julie Walker in New York; Melina Walling in Chicago; and Jeff Martin in Atlanta contributed to this report.\n\nMore from this section\n\nReconnect with Your Food in Andrea Kristin's Best Selling Book\n\nMocPOGO Pokemon GO Hacks Updated: Fixes Failed to Detect Location Error 12\n\nProNotary Announces Exciting New Partner Program", "source": {"uri": "kulr8.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KULR-8 Local News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@kulr8.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "juan_a_lozano@kulr8.com", "name": "Juan A.
