{"uri": "8216705176", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "10:07:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T10:07:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T10:07:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13614897/hurricane-beryl-hospitals-clinics-close-houston.html", "title": "Hurricane Beryl kills eight: Killer storm leaves 3M without power", "body": "Several hospitals have been forced to close and cancel patients appointments after Hurricane Beryl ripped through southeast Texas, causing widespread power outages and leaving at least eight people dead.\n\nThe super storm brought howling winds and torrential rain on Monday, flooding highways, closing oil ports, canceling more than 1,300 flights and knocking out power at more than 2.7 million houses and businesses.\n\nSome hospitals in the Houston suffered damage during the storm and have been forced to close their doors Tuesday to non-emergency appointments. At least one is operating on generator power.\n\nBeryl hit land as a Category 1 hurricane, strengthening from a tropical storm over the Gulf of Mexico. It later weakened into a tropical depression with maximum wind speeds of about 35mph.\n\nThe storm, which was expected to rapidly weaken as it moved inland, swept a destructive path through Jamaica, Grenada, and St. Vincent and the Grenadines last week. It killed at least 11 in Mexico and the Caribbean and before reaching Texas.\n\nMike Isbell (C) climbs a ladder to look at the remains of his home which was destroyed in Surfside Beach, Texas, on July 8, 2024, after Hurricane Beryl made landfall.\n\nA resident walks past debris in the aftermath of Hurricane Beryl in Surfside Beach, Texas, U.S., July 8, 2024\n\nBeryl was blamed for killing several people in Texas on Monday and at least one person in Louisiana, officials said.\n\nAfter a peak Monday of more than 2.7million customers around Houston without power, the numbers improved to more than 2.4million homes and businesses lacking electricity by Monday night, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nSeveral hospitals and health clinics throughout the Greater Houston area were forced to hunker down during the storm, impacting their services.\n\nMost hospitals have remained open and are providing emergency medical assistance, The Houston Business Journal reported.\n\nHowever, some have closed outpatient services, specialty facilities, health centers, and same-day clinics. Patients whose appointments have been canceled will be rescheduled.\n\nSt. Luke's Health system's Brazosport Hospital, located in Lake Jackson, was among the facilities damaged during the storm. It is currently operating on generator power and accepted new emergency patients.\n\nOfficials told the newspaper that no staff or patients were injured, however some people receiving treatment had to be relocated in the facility.\n\nMD Anderson Cancer Center has closed its facility for all appointments except for emergency procedures at its Texas Medical Center campus.\n\nBeryl is forecast to bring more strong rain and winds across the US over the coming days\n\nA home is severely damaged after Hurricane Beryl swept through the area on July 08, 2024 in Freeport, Texas\n\nDebris and flood waters from Hurricane Beryl cover the main roadway in Surfside Beach, Texas, U.S., July 8, 2024\n\nThe lack of cooling to people's homes, downed power lines and non-functioning traffic lights led officials to ask residents to stay home if possible.\n\n'Houstonians need to know we're working around the clock so you will be safe,' Houston Mayor John Whitmire said Monday at a media briefing, urging residents to also know the dangers of high water, to stay hydrated and to check on their neighbors.\n\nDespite weakening to a tropical depression, Beryl still packed a punch, with the National Weather Service confirming that tornadoes had been spotted in northeastern Louisiana.\n\nBossier Sheriff Julian Whittington said in a Facebook post that a woman was killed in the Benton area when a tree fell on her home.\n\nDozens of tornado warnings were issued in Louisiana and Arkansas on Monday evening and they continued into the night.\n\nWhile weakened, Beryl threatened to unleash harsh weather over several more states in coming days.\n\nTexas state and local officials warned it could take several days to fully restore power after Beryl came ashore as a Category 1 hurricane and toppled 10 transmission lines and knocked down trees that took down power lines.\n\nBeryl on Tuesday was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean last weekend. But its winds and rains were still powerful enough to knock down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in water-saturated earth, and strand dozens of cars on flooded roadways.\n\n'We're not past any difficult conditions,' said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country.\n\nPatrick said CenterPoint Energy was bringing thousands of additional workers to restore power, with top priorities including nursing homes and assisted living centers.\n\nAt least two people were killed when trees fell on homes in Texas, and a third person, a civilian employee of the Houston Police Department, was killed when he was trapped in flood waters under a highway overpass, Whitmire said.\n\nThe loss of power was an all-too familiar experience for Houston: Powerful storms had just ripped through the area in May, killing eight people, leaving nearly 1 million without power and flooding numerous streets.\n\nResidents without power after Beryl were doing their best.\n\n'We haven't really slept,' said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in her neighborhood in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio said she had already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\n\n'We are struggling to have food and losing that food would be difficult,' she said.\n\nA man navigates flood waters following heavy rain from Hurricane Beryl in Houston, Texas, USA, 08 July 2024\n\nJackie Jecmenek, right, talks with city worker Bobby Head as she stands in front of her neighbor's home after Beryl passed, Monday, July 8, 2024, in Bay City, Texas. (AP Photo/Eric Gay)\n\nAnn McCauley examines the damage at Bethel Church after Hurricane Beryl moved through the area, Monday, July 8, 2024, in Van Vleck, Texas. (AP Photo/Eric Gay)\n\nPeople gather outside a home in the 17400 block of Rustic Canyon Trail where Maria Loredo, 74, died after a tree fell on her second story bedroom during Hurricane Beryl Monday, July 8, 2024, in Houston (Melissa Phillip/Houston Chronicle via AP)\n\nPower crews were working to restore service as quickly as possible, an urgent priority for homes also left without air conditioning in the middle of summer.\n\nTemperatures in the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) were expected Tuesday. The National Weather Service issued a heat advisory that said the area heat index could reach 105 F (40.5 C).\n\nThe state was opening cooling centers as well as food and water distribution centers, said Nim Kidd, chief of state emergency operations.\n\nBeryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast on Monday, reclosing streets in neighborhoods that had already been washed out by previous storms.\n\nTelevision stations on Monday broadcast the dramatic rescue of a man who had climbed to the roof of his pickup truck after it got trapped in fast-flowing waters.\n\nEmergency crews used an extension ladder from a fire truck to drop him a life preserver and a tether before moving him to dry land.\n\nHouston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.\n\nMany streets and neighborhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris.\n\nThe buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents chopped up knocked-down trees and branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks.\n\nPatrick warned that flooding could last for days as rain continued to fall on already saturated ground.\n\n'This is not a one-day event,' he said.\n\nBeach goers try to keep their balance as wind gusts continue as Tropical Storm Beryl wanes on Monday, July 8, 2024, Galveston, Texas. (Elizabeth Conley/Houston Chronicle via AP)\n\nA vehicle is stranded in high waters on a flooded highway in Houston, on Monday, July 8, 2024, after Beryl came ashore in Texas as a hurricane and dumped heavy rains along the coast. (AP Photo/Juan A. Lozano)\n\nHook Jefferson assesses damages after a tree fell on his neighbor's home after Hurricane Beryl hit the Texas coast, Monday, July 8, 2024, in Bay City, Texas. (AP Photo/Eric Gay)\n\nWilliam Ruiz uses a tow strap and his pick-up truck to remove a downed tree branch from the middle of the street in his neighborhood during a lull as the eye of hurrican Beryl passes through Monday, July 8, 2024, in Rosenberg, Texas. (AP Photo/Michael Wyke)\n\nResident Isabel Perez rakes up downed tree branches from the street outside of her home during a lull in the wind and rain as Tropical Storm Beryl passes Monday, July 8, 2024, in Rosenburg, Texas. Hurricane Beryl has been downgraded to a tropical storm after sweeping into Texas as a Category 1 storm with heavy rains and powerful winds. (AP Photo/Michael Wyke)\n\nPresident Joe Biden was getting regular updates on the storm after it made landfall and called the Houston mayor on Monday, the White House said.\n\nHe told the mayor his administration will make sure Texans have the resources they need to get through the storm and recovery.\n\nSeveral companies with refineries or industrial plants in the area reported that the power disruptions necessitated the flaring of gases at the facilities.\n\nMarathon Petroleum Corp. said it conducted a 'safe combustion of excess gases' at its Galveston Bay Refinery in Texas City, but did not provide information on the amount of gas flared or how long it would continue.\n\nFormosa Plastics Corporation and Freeport LNG also reported flaring related to Beryl, according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.\n\nCompanies have 24 hours to share emissions data after the flaring stops, a representative from the TCEQ said in an email.\n\nThe earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, Berylcaused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas.\n\nCORRECTION CORRECTS NAME People gather outside a home in the 17400 block of Rustic Canyon Trail where Maria Loredo, 74, died after a tree fell on her second story bedroom during Hurricane Beryl Monday, July 8, 2024, in Houston. There were no immediate reports of widespread structural damage, however.\n\nMore than 2.2 million homes and businesses were without power around Houston, the nation's fourth-largest city, after Beryl blew through, according to the CenterPoint Energy utility. {"uri": "8217846888", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "01:38:19", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T01:38:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T01:37:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://wsvn.com/news/us-world/frustrations-mount-in-the-houston-heat-after-beryl-moves-on-and-leaves-millions-without-power/", "title": "Frustrations mount in the Houston heat after Beryl moves on and leaves millions without power - WSVN 7News | Miami News, Weather, Sports | Fort Lauderdale", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- The return of soaring heat in Houston on Tuesday deepened the misery for millions of people still without power after Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas and left residents in search of places to cool off and fuel up as the extended outages strained one of the nation's largest cities.\n\nFrustration mounted that Houston appeared to buckle under a storm less powerful than previous ones. State officials faced questions over whether Houston's power utility had sufficiently prepared, including one who said he would withhold judgement until after the lights are back on.\n\nHospitals also started to feel the pinch: Nearly 36 hours after Beryl made landfall, Texas' lieutenant governor said a sports and event complex would be used to temporarily hold up to 250 patients who are awaiting discharge but cannot be released to homes with no power.\n\nPeople coped as best they could.\n\n\"We can handle it, but not the kids,\" said Walter Perez, 49, as he arrived early Tuesday at celebrity pastor Joel Osteen's megachurch in Houston, which served as a cooling center and distributed 40-bottle packs of water.\n\nPerez said his family -- including his wife, a 3-year-old son, a 3-week-old daughter and his father-in-law -- retreated from their apartment after a night he described as \"bad, bad, bad, bad.\"\n\nHighs in the Houston on Tuesday climbed back into the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) and humidity that could make it feel even hotter. The National Weather Service described the conditions as potentially dangerous given the lack of power and air conditioning.\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas -- and at least 11 in the Caribbean.\n\nNearly 2 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. For many, it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nFood spoiled in listless refrigerators in neighborhoods that pined for air conditioning. Long lines of cars and people queued up at any fast food restaurant, food truck or gas station that had power and was open.\n\nPatrons lined up on one block to eat at KFC, Jack in the Box or Denny's -- or just to get a few minutes in some cooler air. Dwight Yell, 54, had power at his house but took a disabled neighbor, who did not, to Denny's for some food.\n\nHe complained that city and state officials did not alert residents well enough to a storm initially projected to land much farther down the coast: \"They didn't give us enough warning, where maybe we could go get gas or prepare to go out of town if the lights go out.\"\n\nRobin Taylor, who got takeout from Denny's, was getting tired of the same old struggle. She has been living a hotel since her home was damaged by the storms in May. When Beryl hit, her hotel room flooded.\n\nShe was angry that Houston didn't appear prepared to handle the Category 1 storm after it had weathered much stronger ones in the past.\n\n\"No WiFi, no power, and it's hot outside. That's dangerous for people. That's really the big issue,\" Taylor said. \"People will die in this heat in their homes.\"\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, emphasized that restoring power was the top priority. CenterPoint Energy in Houston has said it aims to restore power to 1 million customers by the end of Wednesday.\n\nBut for others, getting the lights back could take several more days or longer. Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is serving as acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is oveseas, said nursing homes and assisted living centers were the highest priority. Sixteen hospitals were running on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nPatrick urged utilities to restore power quickly and said he would evaluate later whether they did enough before the storm.\n\nAn executive for CenterPoint Energy, which covers much of the Houston area, defended the utility's preparation and response.\n\n\"From my perspective to have a storm pass at 3 p.m. in the afternoon, have those crews come in in the late evening, and have everything ready by 5 a.m. to go out and get out and start the workforce is rather impressive because we're talking about thousands of crews,\" Brad Tutunjian, vice president of regulatory policy with CenterPoint Energy, said at a media briefing on Tuesday .\n\nKyuta Allen brought her family to a Houston community center to cool down and use the internet for work and the night classes she takes online.\n\n\"During the day you can have the doors open but at night you've got to board up and lock up - lock yourself like into a sauna,\" she said.\n\nLouisiana Gov. Jeff Landry issued a state of emergency Tuesday afternoon for part of that state after trees were knocked down, homes were damaged and thousands lost power.\n\nWhen Beryl made landfall, it was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean.\n\nBeryl was the earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 in the Atlantic. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "2024-07-415534728", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-08", "time": "21:38:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-08T21:38:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-08T21:19:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/tropical-storm-beryl-topples-trees-floods-highways-and-leaves-more-than-2m-without-power-in/article_8ae9456b-a942-5aab-9b63-65f659b5b3ad.html", "title": "Tropical Storm Beryl topples trees, floods highways and leaves more than 2M without power in Texas", "body": "City of Galveston workers clear debris from Beryl from the West End of the seawall in Galveston, Texas, on Monday, July 8, 2024. Tropical Storm Beryl was unleashing heavy rains and powerful winds along the Texas coast, knocking out power to more than 2 million homes and businesses and flooding streets with fast-rising waters.\n\nHOUSTON (AP) -- Tropical Storm Beryl sped across the Texas coast on Monday, leaving more than 2 million people and businesses without power in the Houston area and unleashing heavy rains that prompted dozens of high-water rescues. The fast-moving tempest threatened to carve a harsh path over several more states in coming days.\n\nWithin hours after Beryl swept ashore as a Category 1 hurricane, it had weakened into a tropical storm, far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean last weekend.\n\nBut the winds and rains of the fast-moving storm were still powerful enough to knock down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in water-saturated earth and to strand dozens of cars on flooded roadways.\n\nAt least two people were killed when trees fell on homes, and the National Hurricane Center said damaging winds and flash flooding would continue as Beryl pushes inland. There were no immediate reports of widespread structural damage, however.\n\nMore than 2.2 million homes and businesses were without power around Houston, the nation's fourth-largest city, after Beryl blew through, according to the CenterPoint Energy utility. For many, it was an all-too-familiar experience: Powerful storms had just ripped through the area in May, killing eight people, leaving nearly 1 million without power and flooding numerous streets.\n\nResidents without power after Beryl were doing their best.\n\n\"We haven't really slept,\" said Eva Costancio as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in her neighborhood in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. Costancio, 67, said already been without power for several hours and worried that food in her refrigerator would be spoiled.\n\n\"We are struggling to have food and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.\n\nHouston and Harris County officials said power crews would be sent into the area to restore service as quickly as possible, an urgent priority for homes also left without air conditioning in the middle of summer. Temperatures, which had cooled slightly with the storm, were expected to reach back into the 90s as early as Tuesday.\n\n\"While these efforts are full steam ahead, we want residents to know and prepare for a possible multi-day power outage,\" Galveston city officials said on Facebook. \"The estimated timeline is anywhere from 72 hours to two weeks in parts of the island.\"\n\nBeryl's rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast on Monday, reclosing streets in neighborhoods that had already been washed out by previous storms. Television stations on Monday broadcast the dramatic rescue of a man who had climbed to the roof of his pickup truck after it got trapped in fast-flowing waters. Emergency crews used an extension ladder from a fire truck to drop him a life preserver and a tether before moving him to dry land.\n\nHouston officials reported at least 25 water rescues by Monday afternoon, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.\n\n\"First responders are putting their lives at risk. That's what they're trained for. It's working,\" Houston Mayor John Whitmire said.\n\nJavier Mejia was one of about 20 people who gathered near the pickup truck rescue site to take pictures of other submerged vehicles sitting on the flooded highway.\n\n\"If you don't have a way through, you're going to get stuck like that,\" Mejia said.\n\nHaving experienced previous storms in Houston, Mejia stocked up on food and water before Beryl hit, but forgot gas for his portable generator. He planned to spend the day looking for some.\n\n\"I don't want it to go bad,\" he said of the food, adding that if he can't find gas, \"We can just fire up the grill.\"\n\nMany streets and neighborhoods throughout Houston were littered with fallen branches and other debris. The buzz of chainsaws filled the air Monday afternoon as residents set to work chopping up knocked-down trees and big branches that had blocked streets and sidewalks.\n\nTwo people were killed after trees fell on their houses: a man in the Houston suburb of Humble and a woman in Harris County, authorities said. Hundreds of trees fell in the county, crushing vehicles and damaging homes, said Precinct 4 County Constable Mark Herman.\n\nTexas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country, warned that flooding could last for days as rain continued to fall on already saturated ground.\n\n\"This is not a one-day event,\" he said.\n\nPresident Joe Biden was getting regular updates on the storm after it made landfall, the White House said. The U.S. Coast Guard and FEMA had prepared search and rescue teams, and FEMA collected bottled water, meals, tarps and electric generators in case they are needed.\n\nSeveral companies with refineries or industrial plants in the area reported that the power disruptions necessitated the flaring of gases at the facilities.\n\nMarathon Petroleum Corp. said it conducted a \"safe combustion of excess gases\" at its Galveston Bay Refinery in Texas City, but did not provide information on the amount of gas flared or how long it would continue. Formosa Plastics Corporation and Freeport LNG also reported flaring related to Beryl, according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.\n\nCompanies have 24 hours to share emissions data after the flaring stops, a representative from the TCEQ said in an email.\n\nThe earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, Beryl caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. The storm ripped off doors, windows and roofs with devastating winds and storm surge fueled by the Atlantic's record warmth.\n\nThree times during the week, Beryl gained 35 mph (56 kph) in wind speed in 24 hours or less, the official weather service definition of rapid intensification.\n\nBeryl's explosive growth into an unprecedented early whopper of a storm indicates the hot water of the Atlantic and Caribbean and what the Atlantic hurricane belt can expect for the rest of the storm season, experts said. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nIn Louisiana, heavy bands of rain were expected all day Monday and \"the risk is going to be for that heavy rainfall and potential for flash flooding,\" National Weather Service meteorologist Donald Jones said in a Monday morning Facebook Live briefing.\n\nMeteorologists in Louisiana are watching for lingering rainbands, which could drop copious amounts of rain wherever they materialize, as well as \"quick, spin-up tornadoes,\" said Donald Jones, a National Weather Service meteorologist in Lake Charles, Louisiana.\n\n\"It's just a matter of exactly where that's going to be,\" Jones said. \"That's very difficult to predict more than maybe an hour or so in advance.\"\n\nBeryl was forecast to bring more strong rain and winds into additional states over the coming days. One of those, Missouri was already dealing with a wet summer. Heavy rains unrelated to the storm prompted several water rescues around the city of Columbia, where rivers and creeks were already high ahead of Beryl's expected arrival on Tuesday.\n\nAssociated Press reporters Jim Vertuno in Austin, Texas; Corey Williams in Detroit; Julie Walker in New York; Melina Walling in Chicago; and Jeff Martin in Atlanta contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "register-herald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Beckley Register-Herald"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@register-herald.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "juan_a_lozano@register-herald.com", "name": "Juan A. "dmoz/Business/Energy/Utilities", "label": "dmoz/Business/Energy/Utilities", "wgt": 15}, {"uri": "dmoz/Science/Earth_Sciences/Atmospheric_Sciences", "label": "dmoz/Science/Earth Sciences/Atmospheric "https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/register-herald.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/8/22/822c3297-ef45-51f5-9ede-e7e0aae8d716/668b3588b89d6.image.jpg?crop=1676%2C880%2C0%2C178&resize=1200%2C630&order=crop%2Cresize", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9716370", "eventUri": "eng-9716370", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.04313725490196085, "wgt": 179, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-07-416662101", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "20:07:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T20:07:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T19:35:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/frustrations-mount-in-the-houston-heat-after-beryl-moves-on-and-leaves-millions-without-power/article_3827e47c-07fe-561b-a512-333651a2f548.html", "title": "Frustrations mount in the Houston heat after Beryl moves on and leaves millions without power", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- Many of the millions left without power after Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas, killing several people and unleashing flooding, sweltered and grumbled Tuesday as the storm deprived much of the nation's fourth-largest city of air conditioning, food and water in sweltering heat and humidity.\n\nA heat advisory took effect through Wednesday in the Houston area and beyond, with temperatures expected to soar into the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) and humidity that could make it feel as hot as 105 degrees (40.5 Celsius).\n\n\"We can handle it, but not the kids,\" said Walter Perez, 49, as he arrived early Tuesday at celebrity pastor Joel Osteen's megachurch in Houston, which served as a cooling center and distributed 40-bottle packs of water to cars that drove up.\n\nPerez said he, his wife, their 3-year-old son and 3-week-old daughter, and his father-in-law retreated from their apartment after a night he described as \"bad, bad, bad, bad.\"\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas -- and at least 11 in the Caribbean. At midday Tuesday, it was a post-tropical cyclone centered over Arkansas and was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flooding to a swath extending to the Great Lakes and Canada.\n\nMore than 2 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. For many, it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nFood spoiled in listless refrigerators in neighborhoods that pined for air conditioning. Long lines of cars and people queued up at any fast food restaurant, food truck or gas station that had power and was open. And frustration mounted that Houston appeared to buckle under a storm not as powerful as previous ones.\n\nPatrons lined up on one block to eat at KFC, Jack in the Box or Denny's -- or just to get a few minutes in some cooler air. Dwight Yell, 54, had power at his house but took a disabled neighbor, who did not, to Denny's for some food.\n\nHe complained that city and state officials did not alert residents well enough to a storm initially projected to land much farther down the coast: \"They didn't give us enough warning, where maybe we could go get gas or prepare to go out of town if the lights go out.\"\n\nRobin Taylor, who got takeout from Denny's, was getting tired of the same old struggle. She has been living a hotel since her home was damaged by the storms in May. When Beryl hit, her hotel room flooded.\n\nShe was angry that Houston didn't appear prepared to handle the Category 1 storm after it had weathered much stronger ones in the past.\n\n\"No WiFi, no power, and it's hot outside. That's dangerous for people. That's really the big issue,\" Taylor said. \"People will die in this heat in their homes.\"\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, said at a news conference with other officials that restoring power is the No. 1 priority. And in Washington, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said President Joe Biden approved a major disaster declaration. Emergency crews hope to have power restored to an additional 1 million people by the end of the day, she said.\n\nIt could take days to fully return power in Texas after Beryl toppled 10 transmission lines. Top priorities for power restoration include nursing homes and assisted living centers, said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting as governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country. Sixteen hospitals were running on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nPatrick urged utilities to restore power \"as quickly as they can.\"\n\nBeryl's strength at midday Tuesday -- with sustained winds near 30 mph (48 kph) -- wasn't expected to change much in the next two days. It was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flash flooding from the lower and mid-Mississippi Valley to the Great Lakes into Wednesday, the National Weather Service said.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana and Michigan. A few tornadoes were possible in Missouri, Tennessee, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana and Ohio, forecasters said.\n\nWhen Beryl made landfall, it was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean. But its winds and rains still knocked down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in saturated earth and stranded dozens of cars on flooded roads.\n\nBeryl was the earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 in the Atlantic. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nContributing to this report were Associated Press journalists Jim Vertuno in Austin, Texas; Sara Cline in Baton Rouge, Louisiana; Jeff Martin in Atlanta; and Sarah Brumfield in Silver Spring, Maryland.", "source": {"uri": "register-herald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Beckley Register-Herald"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@register-herald.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "juan_a_lozano@register-herald.com", "name": "Juan A. {"uri": "8217747493", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "23:22:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T23:22:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T23:21:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://newsadvance.com/news/nation-world/weather/frustrations-mount-in-the-houston-heat-after-beryl-moves-on-and-leaves-millions-without-power/article_cebd4609-8e5e-583e-bb59-709369b9cfdd.html", "title": "Frustrations mount in the Houston heat after Beryl moves on and leaves millions without power", "body": "HOUSTON -- Many of the millions left without power after Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas sweltered and grumbled Tuesday as the storm gutted access to air conditioning, food and water while smothering heat and humidity draped over the nation's fourth-largest city.\n\nFrustration mounted that Houston appeared to buckle under a storm not as powerful as previous ones. State officials were questioned whether utilities were prepared in advance, and at least one said they would withhold judgement until after the lights were turned back on.\n\nA heat advisory took effect through Wednesday in the Houston area and beyond, with temperatures expected to soar into the 90s and humidity that could make it feel as hot as 105 degrees. The National Weather Service described the conditions as potentially dangerous given the lack of power and air conditioning.\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths and at least 11 in the Caribbean. At midday Tuesday, it was a post-tropical cyclone centered over Arkansas and was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flooding to a swath extending to the Great Lakes and Canada.\n\nMore than 2 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday, down from a peak of more than 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. For many, it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nFood spoiled in powerless refrigerators in neighborhoods that pined for air conditioning. Long lines of cars and people queued up at any fast food restaurant, food truck or gas station that had power and was open.\n\nPatrons lined up on one block to eat at KFC, Jack in the Box or Denny's -- or just to get a few minutes in some cooler air.\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, said at a news conference with other officials that restoring power is the No. 1 priority. In Washington, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said President Joe Biden approved a major disaster declaration.\n\nEmergency crews hoped to have power restored to an additional 1 million people by the end of the day, she said.\n\nIt could take days to fully return power in Texas after Beryl toppled 10 transmission lines. Top priorities for power restoration include nursing homes and assisted living centers, said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting as governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country. Sixteen hospitals were on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nPatrick said he would evaluate later whether utilities had taken proper steps before the storm to mount a swift response.\n\nCenterPoint Energy, which covers much of the Houston area, said it would bring in about 12,000 workers from around the region to help restore power. A company spokesperson said those workers weren't staged in the Houston area before the storm hit, noting that forecasts initially predicted it would go much further south.\n\nKyuta Allen brought her family to a Houston community center to cool down and use the internet for work and the night classes she takes online.\n\n\"You can't really get a lot of stuff done when you are hot,\" she said, adding it is also hard to sleep in the heat.\n\n\"During the day you can have the doors open but at night you've got to board up and lock up -- lock yourself like into a sauna,\" she said.\n\nLesley Briones, a Harris County commissioner, who visited a community center, said she's been told of people waiting hours to get gas.\n\n\"It's catastrophic when you lose everything in your fridge and you are living check to check,\" Briones said.\n\nBeryl's strength at midday Tuesday -- with sustained winds near 30 mph -- wasn't expected to change much in the next two days. It was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flash flooding from the lower and mid-Mississippi Valley to the Great Lakes into Wednesday, the National Weather Service said.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana and Michigan. A few tornadoes were possible in Missouri, Tennessee, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana and Ohio, forecasters said.\n\nLouisiana Gov. Jeff Landry issued a state of emergency Tuesday afternoon for part of that state after trees were knocked down, homes were damaged and thousands lost power.\n\nWhen Beryl made landfall, it was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean. But its winds and rains still knocked down hundreds of trees that already teetered in saturated earth and stranded dozens of cars on flooded roads.\n\nBeryl was the earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 in the Atlantic. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed more than $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nLocal Weather\n\nGet the daily forecast and severe weather alerts in your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.", "source": {"uri": "newsadvance.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NewsAdvance.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": "juan_a_lozano@newsadvance.com", "name": "Juan A. {"uri": "8216345119", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "06:07:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T06:07:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T06:06:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.independent.ie/news/two-dead-as-beryl-hits-texas-with-power-cuts-and-flooding/a1570232748.html", "title": "Two dead as Beryl hits Texas with power cuts and flooding", "body": "Tropical Storm Beryl unleashed heavy rain and powerful winds along the \u00adTexas coast yesterday, knocking out power to more than two million homes and businesses and flooding streets with fast-\u00adrising waters as emergency \u00adservices raced to rescue stranded residents.\n\nBeryl had already cut a deadly path through parts of Mexico and the \u00adCaribbean before making a turn, sweeping ashore as a category one hurricane in Texas early yesterday, then later weakening to a tropical storm.\n\nAt least two people were killed. The US National Hurricane Centre said damaging winds and flash flooding will continue as Beryl continues pushing inland.\n\nMore than two million homes and businesses in the Houston area were without electricity, CenterPoint Energy officials said. Texas lieutenant governor Dan Patrick, who is acting governor while Greg Abbott is out of the country, said crews could not get out to restore it until the wind dies down.\n\nResidents without power were doing their best.\n\n\"We haven't really slept,\" Eva \u00adCostancio said as she gazed at a large tree that had fallen across electric lines in her neighbourhood in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg.\n\nMs Costancio (67) said she had been without power for about four hours yesterday and worried that food in her \u00adrefrigerator would be spoiled. \"We are struggling to have food and losing that food would be difficult,\" she said.\n\nHigh waters quickly closed streets. In flood-weary Houston, where previous storms had already washed out neighbourhoods, television stations broadcast the dramatic rescue of a man who had climbed to the roof of his pickup truck after it got trapped in fast-flowing waters. Emergency crews used an extension ladder from a fire truck to drop him a life preserver and a tether before moving him to dry land.\n\nHouston officials said they had performed at least 15 high-water rescues and more were ongoing. \"First responders are putting their lives at risk. That's what they're trained for. It's working,\" Houston mayor John Whitmire said.\n\nHouston was under a flash-flood warning for most of the morning as heavy rain continued to soak the city. Flood warnings also were in effect across a wide stretch of the Texas coast, where a powerful storm surge pushed water ashore, and further inland as heavy rain continued to fall.\n\nRosenberg police also noted that one of their high-water vehicles was hit by a falling tree while returning from a rescue.\n\nTwo people were killed after trees fell on their houses: a man in the Houston suburb of Humble and a woman in \u00adHarris County, authorities said. Hundreds of trees fell in the county, crushing vehicles and damaging homes, said a police spokesman.\n\nMr Patrick warned flooding could last for days as the storm continues to dump rain on to already saturated ground. \"This is not a one-day event,\" he said.\n\nBeryl and the widespread power outages were just the latest weather problems for Houston, where nearly one million people lost power when deadly storms ripped through the area in May, killed eight people and brought much of the city to a standstill.", "source": {"uri": "independent.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": "Irish Independent"}, {"uri": "8217748913", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "23:24:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T23:24:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T23:23:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.wistv.com/2024/07/09/some-power-restored-houston-after-hurricane-beryl-while-storm-spawns-tornadoes-it-moves-east/", "title": "Frustrations mount in the Houston heat after Beryl moves on and leaves millions without power", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- Many of the millions left without power after Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas sweltered and grumbled Tuesday as the storm gutted access to air conditioning, food and water, and smothering heat and humidity draped over the nation's fourth-largest city.\n\nFrustration mounted that Houston appeared to buckle under a storm not as powerful as previous ones. State officials were questioned whether utilities were prepared in advance, and at least one said they would withhold judgement until after the lights were turned back on.\n\n\"We can handle it, but not the kids,\" said Walter Perez, 49, as he arrived early Tuesday at celebrity pastor Joel Osteen's megachurch in Houston, which served as a cooling center and distributed 40-bottle packs of water to cars that drove up.\n\nPerez said he, his wife, their 3-year-old son and 3-week-old daughter, and his father-in-law retreated from their apartment after a night he described as \"bad, bad, bad, bad.\"\n\nA heat advisory took effect through Wednesday in the Houston area and beyond, with temperatures expected to soar into the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) and humidity that could make it feel as hot as 105 degrees (40.5 Celsius). The National Weather Service described the conditions as potentially dangerous given the lack of power and air conditioning.\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas -- and at least 11 in the Caribbean. At midday Tuesday, it was a post-tropical cyclone centered over Arkansas and was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flooding to a swath extending to the Great Lakes and Canada.\n\nNearly 2 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. For many, it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nHospitals were having a crowding problem because they haven't been able to release patients who can't return to homes with no power, said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting as governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country. A large sports and events complex will be used to temporarily hold up to 250 patients who are released from hospitals.\n\nFood spoiled in listless refrigerators in neighborhoods that pined for air conditioning. Long lines of cars and people queued up at any fast food restaurant, food truck or gas station that had power and was open.\n\nPatrons lined up on one block to eat at KFC, Jack in the Box or Denny's -- or just to get a few minutes in some cooler air. Dwight Yell, 54, had power at his house but took a disabled neighbor, who did not, to Denny's for some food.\n\nHe complained that city and state officials did not alert residents well enough to a storm initially projected to land much farther down the coast: \"They didn't give us enough warning, where maybe we could go get gas or prepare to go out of town if the lights go out.\"\n\nRobin Taylor, who got takeout from Denny's, was getting tired of the same old struggle. She has been living a hotel since her home was damaged by the storms in May. When Beryl hit, her hotel room flooded.\n\nShe was angry that Houston didn't appear prepared to handle the Category 1 storm after it had weathered much stronger ones in the past.\n\n\"No WiFi, no power, and it's hot outside. That's dangerous for people. That's really the big issue,\" Taylor said. \"People will die in this heat in their homes.\"\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, said at a news conference with other officials that restoring power is the No. 1 priority. And in Washington, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said President Joe Biden approved a major disaster declaration. Emergency crews hope to have power restored to an additional 1 million people by the end of the day, she said.\n\nIt could take days to fully return power in Texas after Beryl toppled 10 transmission lines. Top priorities for power restoration include nursing homes and assisted living centers, said Patrick. Sixteen hospitals were running on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nPatrick urged utilities to restore power \"as quickly as they can.\" Patrick said he would evaluate later whether utilities had taken proper steps before the storm to mount a swift response.\n\nCenterPoint Energy, which covers much of the Houston area, said it was bringing in about 12,000 workers from around the region to help restore power. A company spokesperson said those workers weren't staged in the Houston area before the storm hit, noting that forecasts initially predicted it would go much further south.\n\nKyuta Allen brought her family to a Houston community center to cool down and use the internet for work and the night classes she takes online.\n\n\"You can't really get a lot of stuff done when you are hot,\" she said, adding it is also hard to sleep in the heat.\n\n\"During the day you can have the doors open but at night you've got to board up and lock up - lock yourself like into a sauna,\" she said.\n\nLesley Briones, a Harris County commissioner, who visited a community center, said she's been told of people waiting hours to get gas.\n\n\"It's catastrophic when you lose everything in your fridge and you are living check to check,\" Briones said.\n\nBeryl's strength at midday Tuesday -- with sustained winds near 30 mph (48 kph) -- wasn't expected to change much in the next two days. It was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flash flooding from the lower and mid-Mississippi Valley to the Great Lakes into Wednesday, the National Weather Service said.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana and Michigan. A few tornadoes were possible in Missouri, Tennessee, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana and Ohio, forecasters said.\n\nLouisiana Gov. Jeff Landry issued a state of emergency Tuesday afternoon for part of that state after trees were knocked down, homes were damaged and thousands lost power.\n\nWhen Beryl made landfall, it was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean. But its winds and rains still knocked down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in saturated earth and stranded dozens of cars on flooded roads.\n\nBeryl was the earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 in the Atlantic. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\n___\n\nContributing to this report were Associated Press journalists Jim Vertuno in Austin, Texas; Sara Cline in Baton Rouge, Louisiana; Jeff Martin in Atlanta; and Sarah Brumfield in Silver Spring, Maryland.", "source": "https://gray-wistv-prod.cdn.arcpublishing.com/resizer/v2/IPXY7VV22AMM44TEYZMU6SO5WA.jpg?auth=f3b89e2238bdfa423afd3616e518a21bd19ef3c84192e6a58582876767a8dd09&width=1200&height=600&smart=true", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9716370", "eventUri": "eng-9716370", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Houston"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.3098039215686275, "wgt": 177, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8217676150", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "21:58:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T21:58:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T21:58:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://gorgenewscenter.com/2024/07/09/frustrations-mount-in-the-houston-heat-after-beryl-moves-on-and-leaves-millions-without-power/", "title": "Frustrations mount in the Houston heat after Beryl moves on and leaves millions without power", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- Many of the millions left without power after Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas sweltered and grumbled Tuesday as the storm gutted access to air conditioning, food and water, and smothering heat and humidity draped over the nation's fourth-largest city.\n\nFrustration mounted that Houston appeared to buckle under a storm not as powerful as previous ones. State officials were questioned whether utilities were prepared in advance, and at least one said they would withhold judgement until after the lights were turned back on.\n\n\"We can handle it, but not the kids,\" said Walter Perez, 49, as he arrived early Tuesday at celebrity pastor Joel Osteen's megachurch in Houston, which served as a cooling center and distributed 40-bottle packs of water to cars that drove up.\n\nPerez said he, his wife, their 3-year-old son and 3-week-old daughter, and his father-in-law retreated from their apartment after a night he described as \"bad, bad, bad, bad.\"\n\nA heat advisory took effect through Wednesday in the Houston area and beyond, with temperatures expected to soar into the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) and humidity that could make it feel as hot as 105 degrees (40.5 Celsius). The National Weather Service described the conditions as potentially dangerous given the lack of power and air conditioning.\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas -- and at least 11 in the Caribbean. At midday Tuesday, it was a post-tropical cyclone centered over Arkansas and was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flooding to a swath extending to the Great Lakes and Canada.\n\nMore than 2 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. For many, it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nFood spoiled in listless refrigerators in neighborhoods that pined for air conditioning. Long lines of cars and people queued up at any fast food restaurant, food truck or gas station that had power and was open.\n\nPatrons lined up on one block to eat at KFC, Jack in the Box or Denny's -- or just to get a few minutes in some cooler air. Dwight Yell, 54, had power at his house but took a disabled neighbor, who did not, to Denny's for some food.\n\nHe complained that city and state officials did not alert residents well enough to a storm initially projected to land much farther down the coast: \"They didn't give us enough warning, where maybe we could go get gas or prepare to go out of town if the lights go out.\"\n\nRobin Taylor, who got takeout from Denny's, was getting tired of the same old struggle. She has been living a hotel since her home was damaged by the storms in May. When Beryl hit, her hotel room flooded.\n\nShe was angry that Houston didn't appear prepared to handle the Category 1 storm after it had weathered much stronger ones in the past.\n\n\"No WiFi, no power, and it's hot outside. That's dangerous for people. That's really the big issue,\" Taylor said. \"People will die in this heat in their homes.\"\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, said at a news conference with other officials that restoring power is the No. 1 priority. And in Washington, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said President Joe Biden approved a major disaster declaration. Emergency crews hope to have power restored to an additional 1 million people by the end of the day, she said.\n\nIt could take days to fully return power in Texas after Beryl toppled 10 transmission lines. Top priorities for power restoration include nursing homes and assisted living centers, said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting as governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country. Sixteen hospitals were running on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nPatrick urged utilities to restore power \"as quickly as they can.\" Patrick said he would evaluate later whether utilities had taken proper steps before the storm to mount a swift response.\n\nCenterPoint Energy, which covers much of the Houston area, said it was bringing in about 12,000 workers from around the region to help restore power. A company spokesperson said those workers weren't staged in the Houston area before the storm hit, noting that forecasts initially predicted it would go much further south.\n\nKyuta Allen brought her family to a Houston community center to cool down and use the internet for work and the night classes she takes online.\n\n\"You can't really get a lot of stuff done when you are hot,\" she said, adding it is also hard to sleep in the heat.\n\n\"During the day you can have the doors open but at night you've got to board up and lock up - lock yourself like into a sauna,\" she said.\n\nLesley Briones, a Harris County commissioner, who visited a community center, said she's been told of people waiting hours to get gas.\n\n\"It's catastrophic when you lose everything in your fridge and you are living check to check,\" Briones said.\n\nBeryl's strength at midday Tuesday -- with sustained winds near 30 mph (48 kph) -- wasn't expected to change much in the next two days. It was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flash flooding from the lower and mid-Mississippi Valley to the Great Lakes into Wednesday, the National Weather Service said.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana and Michigan. A few tornadoes were possible in Missouri, Tennessee, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana and Ohio, forecasters said.\n\nLouisiana Gov. Jeff Landry issued a state of emergency Tuesday afternoon for part of that state after trees were knocked down, homes were damaged and thousands lost power.\n\nWhen Beryl made landfall, it was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean. But its winds and rains still knocked down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in saturated earth and stranded dozens of cars on flooded roads.\n\nBeryl was the earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 in the Atlantic. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-416660826", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "20:05:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T20:05:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T19:35:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/frustrations-mount-in-the-houston-heat-after-beryl-moves-on-and-leaves-millions-without-power/article_1b1062d0-bf4d-57ff-bc86-ca5ed03adfed.html", "title": "Frustrations mount in the Houston heat after Beryl moves on and leaves millions without power", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- Many of the millions left without power after Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas, killing several people and unleashing flooding, sweltered and grumbled Tuesday as the storm deprived much of the nation's fourth-largest city of air conditioning, food and water in sweltering heat and humidity.\n\nA heat advisory took effect through Wednesday in the Houston area and beyond, with temperatures expected to soar into the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) and humidity that could make it feel as hot as 105 degrees (40.5 Celsius).\n\n\"We can handle it, but not the kids,\" said Walter Perez, 49, as he arrived early Tuesday at celebrity pastor Joel Osteen's megachurch in Houston, which served as a cooling center and distributed 40-bottle packs of water to cars that drove up.\n\nPerez said he, his wife, their 3-year-old son and 3-week-old daughter, and his father-in-law retreated from their apartment after a night he described as \"bad, bad, bad, bad.\"\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas -- and at least 11 in the Caribbean. At midday Tuesday, it was a post-tropical cyclone centered over Arkansas and was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flooding to a swath extending to the Great Lakes and Canada.\n\nMore than 2 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. For many, it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nFood spoiled in listless refrigerators in neighborhoods that pined for air conditioning. Long lines of cars and people queued up at any fast food restaurant, food truck or gas station that had power and was open. And frustration mounted that Houston appeared to buckle under a storm not as powerful as previous ones.\n\nPatrons lined up on one block to eat at KFC, Jack in the Box or Denny's -- or just to get a few minutes in some cooler air. Dwight Yell, 54, had power at his house but took a disabled neighbor, who did not, to Denny's for some food.\n\nHe complained that city and state officials did not alert residents well enough to a storm initially projected to land much farther down the coast: \"They didn't give us enough warning, where maybe we could go get gas or prepare to go out of town if the lights go out.\"\n\nRobin Taylor, who got takeout from Denny's, was getting tired of the same old struggle. She has been living a hotel since her home was damaged by the storms in May. When Beryl hit, her hotel room flooded.\n\nShe was angry that Houston didn't appear prepared to handle the Category 1 storm after it had weathered much stronger ones in the past.\n\n\"No WiFi, no power, and it's hot outside. That's dangerous for people. That's really the big issue,\" Taylor said. \"People will die in this heat in their homes.\"\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, said at a news conference with other officials that restoring power is the No. 1 priority. And in Washington, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said President Joe Biden approved a major disaster declaration. Emergency crews hope to have power restored to an additional 1 million people by the end of the day, she said.\n\nIt could take days to fully return power in Texas after Beryl toppled 10 transmission lines. Top priorities for power restoration include nursing homes and assisted living centers, said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting as governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country. Sixteen hospitals were running on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nPatrick urged utilities to restore power \"as quickly as they can.\"\n\nBeryl's strength at midday Tuesday -- with sustained winds near 30 mph (48 kph) -- wasn't expected to change much in the next two days. It was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flash flooding from the lower and mid-Mississippi Valley to the Great Lakes into Wednesday, the National Weather Service said.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana and Michigan. A few tornadoes were possible in Missouri, Tennessee, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana and Ohio, forecasters said.\n\nWhen Beryl made landfall, it was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean. But its winds and rains still knocked down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in saturated earth and stranded dozens of cars on flooded roads.\n\nBeryl was the earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 in the Atlantic. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nContributing to this report were Associated Press journalists Jim Vertuno in Austin, Texas; Sara Cline in Baton Rouge, Louisiana; Jeff Martin in Atlanta; and Sarah Brumfield in Silver Spring, Maryland.\n\nMore from this section\n\n[Not Banned] Failed to Detect Location 12 Error Fixed by iToolab AnyGo Pok\u00e9mon GO Spoofing App\n\nInformative Research Adds Brandon Hall as New EVP of Operations\n\nReconnect with Your Food in Andrea Kristin's Best Selling Book", "source": {"uri": "kulr8.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KULR-8 Local News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@kulr8.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "juan_a_lozano@kulr8.com", "name": "Juan A. {"uri": "8218743579", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:01:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:01:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:00:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.theepochtimes.com/us/houston-residents-left-sweltering-after-beryl-with-over-1-7-million-still-lacking-power-5683475", "title": "Houston Residents Left Sweltering After Beryl With Over 1.7 Million Still Lacking Power", "body": "HOUSTON -- The return of searing heat in the Houston area has deepened the misery for people still without power after Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas and left residents in search of places to cool off and fuel up as the extended outages strained one of the nation's largest cities.\n\nMore than 1.7 million homes and businesses still lacked electricity Wednesday morning, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. As frustration mounted, state officials faced questions over whether the power utility that covers much of the area had sufficiently prepared.\n\nNearly 36 hours after Beryl made landfall, Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick said that a sports and event complex would be used to temporarily hold up to 250 hospital patients who are awaiting discharge but cannot be released to homes with no power.\n\nPeople were coping as best they could.\n\n\"We can handle it, but not the kids,\" Walter Perez said as he arrived at celebrity pastor Joel Osteen's megachurch in Houston, which served as a cooling center and distributed 40-bottle packs of water.\n\nMr. Perez said his wife, 3-year-old son, 3-week-old daughter, and his father-in-law retreated from their apartment after a night he described as \"bad, bad, bad, bad.\"\n\nAn executive for CenterPoint Energy, which covers much of the Houston area, defended the utility's preparation and response.\n\n\"From my perspective to have a storm pass at 3 p.m. in the afternoon, have those crews come in in the late evening, and have everything ready by 5 a.m. to go out and get out and start the workforce is rather impressive because we're talking about thousands of crews,\" Brad Tutunjian, vice president of regulatory policy with CenterPoint Energy, said at a media briefing.\n\nHighs in the Houston area on Tuesday climbed back into the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) with humidity that made it feel even hotter. Similar heat and humidity was expected Wednesday. The National Weather Service described the conditions as potentially dangerous given the lack of power and air conditioning.\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas -- and at least 11 in the Caribbean.\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, emphasized that restoring power was the top priority.\n\nMr. Patrick, who is serving as acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is overseas, said nursing homes and assisted living centers were the highest priority. Sixteen hospitals were running on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nFor many in the Houston area it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nPatrons on Tuesday lined up on one block to eat at KFC, Jack in the Box, or Denny's. Dwight Yell took a disabled neighbor who did not have power to Denny's for some food.\n\nHe complained that city and state officials did not alert residents well enough to a storm initially projected to land much farther down the coast: \"They didn't give us enough warning, where maybe we could go get gas or prepare to go out of town if the lights go out.\"\n\nRobin Taylor, who got takeout from Denny's, has been living a hotel since her home was damaged by the storms in May. When Beryl hit, her hotel room flooded.\n\n\"No WiFi, no power, and it's hot outside,\" Mr. Taylor said. \"People will die in this heat in their homes.\"\n\nKyuta Allen brought her family to a Houston community center to cool down and use the internet.\n\n\"During the day you can have the doors open but at night you've got to board up and lock up -- lock yourself like into a sauna,\" she said.", {"uri": "8217954905", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "03:52:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T03:52:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T03:51:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.dallasnews.com/news/texas/2024/07/09/when-will-power-return-in-houston-frustration-rises-with-temperature/", "title": "When will power return in Houston: Frustration rises with temperature", "body": "HOUSTON -- The return of soaring heat in Houston on Tuesday deepened the misery for millions of people still without power after Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas and left residents in search of places to cool off and fuel up as the extended outages strained one of the nation's largest cities.\n\nFrustration mounted that Houston appeared to buckle under a storm less powerful than previous ones. State officials faced questions over whether Houston's power utility had sufficiently prepared, including one who said he would withhold judgement until after the lights are back on.\n\nAdvertisementAdvertisement\n\nHospitals also started to feel the pinch: Nearly 36 hours after Beryl made landfall, Texas' lieutenant governor said a sports and event complex would be used to temporarily hold up to 250 patients who are awaiting discharge but cannot be released to homes with no power.\n\nBreaking News\n\nGet the latest breaking news from North Texas and beyond.\n\nSIGN UP\n\nOr with:\n\nGoogleFacebook\n\nBy signing up you agree to our Terms of Service and Privacy Policy\n\nPeople coped as best they could.\n\n\"We can handle it, but not the kids,\" said Walter Perez, 49, as he arrived early Tuesday at celebrity pastor Joel Osteen's megachurch in Houston, which served as a cooling center and distributed 40-bottle packs of water.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nPerez said his family -- including his wife, a 3-year-old son, a 3-week-old daughter and his father-in-law -- retreated from their apartment after a night he described as \"bad, bad, bad, bad.\"\n\nHighs in the Houston on Tuesday climbed back into the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) and humidity that could make it feel even hotter. The National Weather Service described the conditions as potentially dangerous given the lack of power and air conditioning.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas -- and at least 11 in the Caribbean.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nNearly 2 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. For many, it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nFood spoiled in listless refrigerators in neighborhoods that pined for air conditioning. Long lines of cars and people queued up at any fast food restaurant, food truck or gas station that had power and was open.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nPatrons lined up on one block to eat at KFC, Jack in the Box or Denny's -- or just to get a few minutes in some cooler air. Dwight Yell, 54, had power at his house but took a disabled neighbor, who did not, to Denny's for some food.\n\nHe complained that city and state officials did not alert residents well enough to a storm initially projected to land much farther down the coast: \"They didn't give us enough warning, where maybe we could go get gas or prepare to go out of town if the lights go out.\"\n\nRobin Taylor, who got takeout from Denny's, was getting tired of the same old struggle. She has been living a hotel since her home was damaged by the storms in May. When Beryl hit, her hotel room flooded.\n\nShe was angry that Houston didn't appear prepared to handle the Category 1 storm after it had weathered much stronger ones in the past.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"No WiFi, no power, and it's hot outside. That's dangerous for people. That's really the big issue,\" Taylor said. \"People will die in this heat in their homes.\"\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, emphasized that restoring power was the top priority. CenterPoint Energy in Houston has said it aims to restore power to 1 million customers by the end of Wednesday.\n\nBut for others, getting the lights back could take several more days or longer. Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is serving as acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is oveseas, said nursing homes and assisted living centers were the highest priority. Sixteen hospitals were running on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nPatrick urged utilities to restore power quickly and said he would evaluate later whether they did enough before the storm.\n\nAn executive for CenterPoint Energy, which covers much of the Houston area, defended the utility's preparation and response.\n\n\"From my perspective to have a storm pass at 3 p.m. in the afternoon, have those crews come in in the late evening, and have everything ready by 5 a.m. to go out and get out and start the workforce is rather impressive because we're talking about thousands of crews,\" Brad Tutunjian, vice president of regulatory policy with CenterPoint Energy, said at a media briefing on Tuesday .\n\nAdvertisement\n\nKyuta Allen brought her family to a Houston community center to cool down and use the internet for work and the night classes she takes online.\n\n\"During the day you can have the doors open but at night you've got to board up and lock up - lock yourself like into a sauna,\" she said.\n\nLouisiana Gov. Jeff Landry issued a state of emergency Tuesday afternoon for part of that state after trees were knocked down, homes were damaged and thousands lost power.\n\nWhen Beryl made landfall, it was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nBeryl was the earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 in the Atlantic. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nBy JUAN A. State officials faced questions over whether the power utility that covers much of the area had sufficiently prepared.\n\nTexas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick said that a sports and event complex would be used to temporarily hold up to 250 hospital patients who are awaiting discharge but cannot be released to homes with no power.\n\nBeryl, which made landfall in Texas early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas -- and at least 11 in the Caribbean. It weakened as it moved deeper into the U.S. and early Wednesday was a post-tropical cyclone centered over northeastern Indiana.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, New York, Vermont, New Hampshire and Maine. The storm spawned suspected tornadoes in parts of Indiana and Kentucky.\n\nIn the Houston area, Beryl compounded and repeated the misery of May, when storms killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power.\n\nHigh temperatures Tuesday climbed into the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) with humidity that made it feel even hotter. Similar heat and humidity were expected Wednesday. The National Weather Service described the conditions as potentially dangerous, given the lack of power and air conditioning.\n\nPeople coped as best they could. Kyuta Allen took her family to a Houston community center to cool down and use the internet.\n\n\"During the day you can have the doors open, but at night you've got to board up and lock up -- lock yourself like into a sauna,\" she said.\n\nAn executive for CenterPoint Energy, which covers much of the Houston area, defended the utility's preparation and response.\n\n\"From my perspective, to have a storm pass at 3 p.m. in the afternoon, have those crews come in in the late evening, and have everything ready by 5 a.m. to go out and get out and start the workforce is rather impressive, because we're talking about thousands of crews,\" said Brad Tutunjian, vice president of regulatory policy.\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, stressed that restoring power was the top priority.\n\nPatrick, who is acting as governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is overseas, said nursing homes and assisted living centers were the highest priority.
