{"uri": "2024-07-417372659", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "11:46:04", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T11:46:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T07:40:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://wjla.com/news/nation-world/houston-heat-rises-as-17-million-remain-powerless-after-hurricane-beryl-electricity-hospital-patients-lt-gov-dan-patrick-gov-greg-abbott-centerpoint-energy-humidity-death-toll-louisiana-caribbean", "title": "Houston heat rises as 1.7 million remain powerless after Hurricane Beryl", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- The return of searing heat in the Houston area has deepened the misery for people still without power after Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas and left residents in search of places to cool off and fuel up as the extended outages strained one of the nation's largest cities.\n\nMore than 1.7 million homes and businesses still lacked electricity Tuesday night, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. As frustration mounted, state officials faced questions over whether the power utility that covers much of the area had sufficiently prepared.\n\nNearly 36 hours after Beryl made landfall, Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick said that a sports and event complex would be used to temporarily hold up to 250 hospital patients who are awaiting discharge but cannot be released to homes with no power.\n\nPeople were coping as best they could.\n\n\"We can handle it, but not the kids,\" Walter Perez said as he arrived at celebrity pastor Joel Osteen's megachurch in Houston, which served as a cooling center and distributed 40-bottle packs of water.\n\nPerez said his wife, 3-year-old son, 3-week-old daughter and his father-in-law retreated from their apartment after a night he described as \"bad, bad, bad, bad.\"\n\nAn executive for CenterPoint Energy, which covers much of the Houston area, defended the utility's preparation and response.\n\n\"From my perspective to have a storm pass at 3 p.m. in the afternoon, have those crews come in in the late evening, and have everything ready by 5 a.m. to go out and get out and start the workforce is rather impressive because we're talking about thousands of crews,\" Brad Tutunjian, vice president of regulatory policy with CenterPoint Energy, said at a media briefing.\n\nHighs in the Houston area on Tuesday climbed back into the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) with humidity that made it feel even hotter. Similar heat and humidity was expected Wednesday. The National Weather Service described the conditions as potentially dangerous given the lack of power and air conditioning.\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas -- and at least 11 in the Caribbean.\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, emphasized that restoring power was the top priority.\n\nPatrick, who is serving as acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is overseas, said nursing homes and assisted living centers were the highest priority. Sixteen hospitals were running on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nFor many in the Houston area it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nPatrons on Tuesday lined up on one block to eat at KFC, Jack in the Box or Denny's. Dwight Yell took a disabled neighbor who did not have power to Denny's for some food.\n\nHe complained that city and state officials did not alert residents well enough to a storm initially projected to land much farther down the coast: \"They didn't give us enough warning, where maybe we could go get gas or prepare to go out of town if the lights go out.\"\n\nRobin Taylor, who got takeout from Denny's, has been living a hotel since her home was damaged by the storms in May. When Beryl hit, her hotel room flooded.\n\n\"No WiFi, no power, and it's hot outside,\" Taylor said. \"People will die in this heat in their homes.\"\n\nKyuta Allen brought her family to a Houston community center to cool down and use the internet.\n\n\"During the day you can have the doors open but at night you've got to board up and lock up -- lock yourself like into a sauna,\" she said.", "eventUri": "eng-9716370", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.1529411764705882, "wgt": 171, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8217680009", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "22:02:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T22:02:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T22:02:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.mercurynews.com/2024/07/09/millions-without-power-in-houston-after-beryl-batters-texas/", "title": "Millions without power in Houston after Beryl batters Texas", "body": "\"No WiFi, no power, and it's hot outside. That's dangerous for people.\"\n\nBy Juan A. Lozano and Mark Vancleave | Associated Press\n\nHOUSTON (AP) -- Many of the millions left without power after Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas sweltered and grumbled Tuesday as the storm gutted access to air conditioning, food and water, and smothering heat and humidity draped over the nation's fourth-largest city.\n\nFrustration mounted that Houston appeared to buckle under a storm not as powerful as previous ones. State officials were questioned whether utilities were prepared in advance, and at least one said they would withhold judgement until after the lights were turned back on.\n\n\"We can handle it, but not the kids,\" said Walter Perez, 49, as he arrived early Tuesday at celebrity pastor Joel Osteen's megachurch in Houston, which served as a cooling center and distributed 40-bottle packs of water to cars that drove up.\n\nPerez said he, his wife, their 3-year-old son and 3-week-old daughter, and his father-in-law retreated from their apartment after a night he described as \"bad, bad, bad, bad.\"\n\nA heat advisory took effect through Wednesday in the Houston area and beyond, with temperatures expected to soar into the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) and humidity that could make it feel as hot as 105 degrees (40.5 Celsius). The National Weather Service described the conditions as potentially dangerous given the lack of power and air conditioning.\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas -- and at least 11 in the Caribbean. At midday Tuesday, it was a post-tropical cyclone centered over Arkansas and was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flooding to a swath extending to the Great Lakes and Canada.\n\nMore than 2 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. For many, it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nFood spoiled in listless refrigerators in neighborhoods that pined for air conditioning. Long lines of cars and people queued up at any fast food restaurant, food truck or gas station that had power and was open.\n\nPatrons lined up on one block to eat at KFC, Jack in the Box or Denny's -- or just to get a few minutes in some cooler air. Dwight Yell, 54, had power at his house but took a disabled neighbor, who did not, to Denny's for some food.\n\nHe complained that city and state officials did not alert residents well enough to a storm initially projected to land much farther down the coast: \"They didn't give us enough warning, where maybe we could go get gas or prepare to go out of town if the lights go out.\"\n\nRobin Taylor, who got takeout from Denny's, was getting tired of the same old struggle. She has been living a hotel since her home was damaged by the storms in May. When Beryl hit, her hotel room flooded.\n\nShe was angry that Houston didn't appear prepared to handle the Category 1 storm after it had weathered much stronger ones in the past.\n\n\"No WiFi, no power, and it's hot outside. That's dangerous for people. That's really the big issue,\" Taylor said. \"People will die in this heat in their homes.\"\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, said at a news conference with other officials that restoring power is the No. 1 priority. And in Washington, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said President Joe Biden approved a major disaster declaration. Emergency crews hope to have power restored to an additional 1 million people by the end of the day, she said.\n\nIt could take days to fully return power in Texas after Beryl toppled 10 transmission lines. Top priorities for power restoration include nursing homes and assisted living centers, said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting as governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country. Sixteen hospitals were running on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nPatrick urged utilities to restore power \"as quickly as they can.\" Patrick said he would evaluate later whether utilities had taken proper steps before the storm to mount a swift response.\n\nCenterPoint Energy, which covers much of the Houston area, said it was bringing in about 12,000 workers from around the region to help restore power. A company spokesperson said those workers weren't staged in the Houston area before the storm hit, noting that forecasts initially predicted it would go much further south.\n\nKyuta Allen brought her family to a Houston community center to cool down and use the internet for work and the night classes she takes online.\n\n\"You can't really get a lot of stuff done when you are hot,\" she said, adding it is also hard to sleep in the heat.\n\n\"During the day you can have the doors open but at night you've got to board up and lock up - lock yourself like into a sauna,\" she said.\n\nLesley Briones, a Harris County commissioner, who visited a community center, said she's been told of people waiting hours to get gas.\n\n\"It's catastrophic when you lose everything in your fridge and you are living check to check,\" Briones said.\n\nBeryl's strength at midday Tuesday -- with sustained winds near 30 mph (48 kph) -- wasn't expected to change much in the next two days. It was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flash flooding from the lower and mid-Mississippi Valley to the Great Lakes into Wednesday, the National Weather Service said.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana and Michigan. A few tornadoes were possible in Missouri, Tennessee, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana and Ohio, forecasters said.\n\nLouisiana Gov. Jeff Landry issued a state of emergency Tuesday afternoon for part of that state after trees were knocked down, homes were damaged and thousands lost power.\n\nWhen Beryl made landfall, it was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean. But its winds and rains still knocked down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in saturated earth and stranded dozens of cars on flooded roads.\n\nBeryl was the earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 in the Atlantic. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-417481830", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:19:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:19:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:06:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.thenationalherald.com/houston-residents-left-sweltering-after-beryl-with-over-1-7-million-still-lacking-power/", "title": "Houston Residents Left Sweltering after Beryl with over 1.7 Million Still Lacking Power", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- The return of searing heat in the Houston area has deepened the misery for people still without power after Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas and left residents in search of places to cool off and fuel up as the extended outages strained one of the nation's largest cities.\n\nMore than 1.7 million homes and businesses still lacked electricity Wednesday morning, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. As frustration mounted, state officials faced questions over whether the power utility that covers much of the area had sufficiently prepared.\n\nNearly 36 hours after Beryl made landfall, Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick said that a sports and event complex would be used to temporarily hold up to 250 hospital patients who are awaiting discharge but cannot be released to homes with no power.\n\nPeople were coping as best they could.\n\n\"We can handle it, but not the kids,\" Walter Perez said as he arrived at celebrity pastor Joel Osteen's megachurch in Houston, which served as a cooling center and distributed 40-bottle packs of water.\n\nPerez said his wife, 3-year-old son, 3-week-old daughter and his father-in-law retreated from their apartment after a night he described as \"bad, bad, bad, bad.\"\n\nAn executive for CenterPoint Energy, which covers much of the Houston area, defended the utility's preparation and response.\n\n\"From my perspective to have a storm pass at 3 p.m. in the afternoon, have those crews come in in the late evening, and have everything ready by 5 a.m. to go out and get out and start the workforce is rather impressive because we're talking about thousands of crews,\" Brad Tutunjian, vice president of regulatory policy with CenterPoint Energy, said at a media briefing.\n\nHighs in the Houston area on Tuesday climbed back into the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) with humidity that made it feel even hotter. Similar heat and humidity was expected Wednesday. The National Weather Service described the conditions as potentially dangerous given the lack of power and air conditioning.\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas -- and at least 11 in the Caribbean.\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, emphasized that restoring power was the top priority.\n\nPatrick, who is serving as acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is overseas, said nursing homes and assisted living centers were the highest priority. Sixteen hospitals were running on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nFor many in the Houston area it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nPatrons on Tuesday lined up on one block to eat at KFC, Jack in the Box or Denny's. Dwight Yell took a disabled neighbor who did not have power to Denny's for some food.\n\nHe complained that city and state officials did not alert residents well enough to a storm initially projected to land much farther down the coast: \"They didn't give us enough warning, where maybe we could go get gas or prepare to go out of town if the lights go out.\"\n\nRobin Taylor, who got takeout from Denny's, has been living a hotel since her home was damaged by the storms in May. When Beryl hit, her hotel room flooded.\n\n\"No WiFi, no power, and it's hot outside,\" Taylor said. \"People will die in this heat in their homes.\"\n\nKyuta Allen brought her family to a Houston community center to cool down and use the internet.\n\n\"During the day you can have the doors open but at night you've got to board up and lock up -- lock yourself like into a sauna,\" she said.\n\n___\n\nBy JUAN A. {"uri": "8217765340", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "23:46:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T23:46:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T23:46:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://heraldcourier.com/news/nation-world/weather/frustrations-mount-in-the-houston-heat-after-beryl-moves-on-and-leaves-millions-without-power/article_28df8e1d-f6ca-52fe-8ecc-3383e9ef0e8e.html", "title": "Frustrations mount in the Houston heat after Beryl moves on and leaves millions without power", "body": "HOUSTON -- Many of the millions left without power after Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas sweltered and grumbled Tuesday as the storm gutted access to air conditioning, food and water while smothering heat and humidity draped over the nation's fourth-largest city.\n\nFrustration mounted that Houston appeared to buckle under a storm not as powerful as previous ones. State officials were questioned whether utilities were prepared in advance, and at least one said they would withhold judgement until after the lights were turned back on.\n\nA heat advisory took effect through Wednesday in the Houston area and beyond, with temperatures expected to soar into the 90s and humidity that could make it feel as hot as 105 degrees. The National Weather Service described the conditions as potentially dangerous given the lack of power and air conditioning.\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths and at least 11 in the Caribbean. At midday Tuesday, it was a post-tropical cyclone centered over Arkansas and was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flooding to a swath extending to the Great Lakes and Canada.\n\nPeople are also reading... TVA announces changes at South Holston, Boone properties LITTLE LEAGUE: Good day for local teams in state softball tournament McNew living her dream as a large truck mechanic 'Vampire' series gives Sam Reid plenty to bite into Marion drive in entrance design sparks controversy, extra look by officials PREP FOOTBALL: Shane Wicks gets first head-coaching opportunity at Honaker White to fill board vacancy; Guffy selected new chair EO prepares for grand opening of new facility PREP FOOTBALL: Honaker hires Wicks LITTLE LEAGUE: State tournaments set across region and state Parades, music, fireworks on tap for Independence Day Dip Dog remains as popular as ever PREP FOOTBALL: The VHSL master schedule was released on Thursday. Here are some games with intriguing storylines PREP FOOTBALL: Chris Long says Heath Miller is right man for job at St. Anne's-Belfield Scientists say they've confirmed a slowdown in Earth's inner core rotation. Now what?\n\nMore than 2 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday, down from a peak of more than 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. For many, it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nFood spoiled in powerless refrigerators in neighborhoods that pined for air conditioning. Long lines of cars and people queued up at any fast food restaurant, food truck or gas station that had power and was open.\n\nPatrons lined up on one block to eat at KFC, Jack in the Box or Denny's -- or just to get a few minutes in some cooler air.\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, said at a news conference with other officials that restoring power is the No. 1 priority. In Washington, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said President Joe Biden approved a major disaster declaration.\n\nEmergency crews hoped to have power restored to an additional 1 million people by the end of the day, she said.\n\nIt could take days to fully return power in Texas after Beryl toppled 10 transmission lines. Top priorities for power restoration include nursing homes and assisted living centers, said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting as governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country. Sixteen hospitals were on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nPatrick said he would evaluate later whether utilities had taken proper steps before the storm to mount a swift response.\n\nCenterPoint Energy, which covers much of the Houston area, said it would bring in about 12,000 workers from around the region to help restore power. A company spokesperson said those workers weren't staged in the Houston area before the storm hit, noting that forecasts initially predicted it would go much further south.\n\nKyuta Allen brought her family to a Houston community center to cool down and use the internet for work and the night classes she takes online.\n\n\"You can't really get a lot of stuff done when you are hot,\" she said, adding it is also hard to sleep in the heat.\n\n\"During the day you can have the doors open but at night you've got to board up and lock up -- lock yourself like into a sauna,\" she said.\n\nLesley Briones, a Harris County commissioner, who visited a community center, said she's been told of people waiting hours to get gas.\n\n\"It's catastrophic when you lose everything in your fridge and you are living check to check,\" Briones said.\n\nBeryl's strength at midday Tuesday -- with sustained winds near 30 mph -- wasn't expected to change much in the next two days. It was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flash flooding from the lower and mid-Mississippi Valley to the Great Lakes into Wednesday, the National Weather Service said.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana and Michigan. A few tornadoes were possible in Missouri, Tennessee, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana and Ohio, forecasters said.\n\nLouisiana Gov. Jeff Landry issued a state of emergency Tuesday afternoon for part of that state after trees were knocked down, homes were damaged and thousands lost power.\n\nWhen Beryl made landfall, it was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean. But its winds and rains still knocked down hundreds of trees that already teetered in saturated earth and stranded dozens of cars on flooded roads.\n\nBeryl was the earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 in the Atlantic. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed more than $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nFrom the Caribbean to Texas, Hurricane Beryl leaves a trail of destruction Local Weather\n\nGet the daily forecast and severe weather alerts in your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.", "source": {"uri": "heraldcourier.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "HeraldCourier.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": "juan_a_lozano@heraldcourier.com", "name": "Juan A. {"uri": "8218683739", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "12:22:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T12:22:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T12:21:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/world/article-houston-residents-left-sweltering-after-hurricane-beryl-with-over-17/", "title": "Houston residents left sweltering after Hurricane Beryl with over 1.7 million still lacking power", "body": "The return of searing heat in the Houston area has deepened the misery for people still without power after Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas and left residents in search of places to cool off and fuel up as the extended outages strained one of the nation's largest cities.\n\nMore than 1.7 million homes and businesses still lacked electricity Wednesday morning, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. As frustration mounted, state officials faced questions over whether the power utility that covers much of the area had sufficiently prepared.\n\nNearly 36 hours after Beryl made landfall, Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick said that a sports and event complex would be used to temporarily hold up to 250 hospital patients who are awaiting discharge but cannot be released to homes with no power.\n\nPeople were coping as best they could.\n\n\"We can handle it, but not the kids,\" Walter Perez said as he arrived at celebrity pastor Joel Osteen's megachurch in Houston, which served as a cooling centre and distributed 40-bottle packs of water.\n\nPerez said his wife, 3-year-old son, 3-week-old daughter and his father-in-law retreated from their apartment after a night he described as \"bad, bad, bad, bad.\"\n\nAn executive for CenterPoint Energy, which covers much of the Houston area, defended the utility's preparation and response.\n\n\"From my perspective to have a storm pass at 3 p.m. in the afternoon, have those crews come in in the late evening, and have everything ready by 5 a.m. to go out and get out and start the workforce is rather impressive because we're talking about thousands of crews,\" Brad Tutunjian, vice president of regulatory policy with CenterPoint Energy, said at a media briefing.\n\nHighs in the Houston area on Tuesday climbed back into the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) with humidity that made it feel even hotter. Similar heat and humidity was expected Wednesday. The National Weather Service described the conditions as potentially dangerous given the lack of power and air conditioning.\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths - one in Louisiana and six in Texas - and at least 11 in the Caribbean.\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, emphasized that restoring power was the top priority.\n\nPatrick, who is serving as acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is overseas, said nursing homes and assisted living centres were the highest priority. Sixteen hospitals were running on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nFor many in the Houston area it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nPatrons on Tuesday lined up on one block to eat at KFC, Jack in the Box or Denny's. Dwight Yell took a disabled neighbour who did not have power to Denny's for some food.\n\nHe complained that city and state officials did not alert residents well enough to a storm initially projected to land much farther down the coast: \"They didn't give us enough warning, where maybe we could go get gas or prepare to go out of town if the lights go out.\"\n\nRobin Taylor, who got takeout from Denny's, has been living a hotel since her home was damaged by the storms in May. When Beryl hit, her hotel room flooded.\n\n\"No WiFi, no power, and it's hot outside,\" Taylor said. \"People will die in this heat in their homes.\"\n\nKyuta Allen brought her family to a Houston community centre to cool down and use the internet.\n\n\"During the day you can have the doors open but at night you've got to board up and lock up - lock yourself like into a sauna,\" she said.", {"uri": "8217695919", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "22:22:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T22:22:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T22:20:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/07/09/nation/frustrations-mount-houston-heat-after-beryl-moves-leaves-millions-without-power/", "title": "Frustrations mount in the Houston heat after Beryl moves on and leaves millions without power - The Boston Globe", "body": "\"We can handle it, but not the kids,\" said Walter Perez, 49, as he arrived early Tuesday at celebrity pastor Joel Osteen's megachurch in Houston, which served as a cooling center and distributed 40-bottle packs of water to cars that drove up.\n\nPerez said he, his wife, their 3-year-old son and 3-week-old daughter, and his father-in-law retreated from their apartment after a night he described as \"bad, bad, bad, bad.\"\n\nA heat advisory took effect through Wednesday in the Houston area and beyond, with temperatures expected to soar into the 90s and humidity that could make it feel as hot as 105 degrees. The National Weather Service described the conditions as potentially dangerous given the lack of power and air conditioning.\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven US deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas -- and at least 11 in the Caribbean. At midday Tuesday, it was a post-tropical cyclone centered over Arkansas and was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flooding to a swath extending to the Great Lakes and Canada.\n\nMore than 2 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. For many, it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nFood spoiled in listless refrigerators. Long lines of cars and people queued up at any fast food restaurant, food truck, or gas station that had power and was open.\n\nPatrons lined up on one block to eat at KFC, Jack in the Box, or Denny's -- or just to get a few minutes in some cooler air. Dwight Yell, 54, had power at his house but took a disabled neighbor, who did not, to Denny's for some food.\n\nHe complained that city and state officials did not alert residents well enough to a storm initially projected to land much farther down the coast: \"They didn't give us enough warning, where maybe we could go get gas or prepare to go out of town if the lights go out.\"\n\nRobin Taylor, who got takeout from Denny's, was getting tired of the same old struggle. She has been living in a hotel since her home was damaged by the storms in May. When Beryl hit, her hotel room flooded.\n\nShe was angry that Houston didn't appear prepared to handle the Category 1 storm after it had weathered much stronger ones in the past.\n\n\"No Wi-Fi, no power, and it's hot outside. That's dangerous for people. That's really the big issue,\" Taylor said. \"People will die in this heat in their homes.\"\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, said at a news conference with other officials that restoring power is the number one priority. And in Washington, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said President Biden approved a major disaster declaration. Emergency crews hope to have power restored to an additional 1 million people by the end of the day, she said.\n\nIt could take days to fully return power in Texas after Beryl toppled 10 transmission lines. Top priorities for power restoration include nursing homes and assisted living centers, said Texas Lieutenant Governor Dan Patrick, who is acting as governor while Governor Greg Abbott is out of the country. Sixteen hospitals were running on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nPatrick urged utilities to restore power \"as quickly as they can.\" Patrick said he would evaluate later whether utilities had taken proper steps before the storm to mount a swift response.\n\nCenterPoint Energy, which covers much of the Houston area, said it was bringing in about 12,000 workers from around the region to help restore power. A company spokesperson said those workers weren't staged in the Houston area before the storm hit, noting that forecasts initially predicted it would go much farther south.\n\nLesley Briones, a Harris County commissioner, who visited a community center, said she's been told of people waiting hours to get gas.\n\n\"It's catastrophic when you lose everything in your fridge and you are living check to check,\" Briones said.\n\nBeryl's strength at midday Tuesday -- with sustained winds near 30 miles per hour -- wasn't expected to change much in the next two days. It was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flash flooding from the lower and mid-Mississippi Valley to the Great Lakes into Wednesday, the National Weather Service said.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana, and Michigan. A few tornadoes were possible in Missouri, Tennessee, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana, and Ohio, forecasters said.\n\nLouisiana Governor Jeff Landry issued a state of emergency Tuesday afternoon for part of that state after trees were knocked down, homes were damaged, and thousands lost power.\n\nWhen Beryl made landfall, it was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean. But its winds and rains still knocked down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in saturated earth and stranded dozens of cars on flooded roads.", "source": {"uri": "bostonglobe.com", {"uri": "2024-07-416931706", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "04:37:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T04:37:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T00:16:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/texas/articles/2024-07-10/houston-residents-left-sweltering-after-beryl-with-over-1-7-million-still-lacking-power", "title": "Houston Residents Left Sweltering After Beryl With Over 1.7 Million Still Lacking Power", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- The return of soaring heat in Houston has deepened the misery for people still without power after Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas and left residents in search of places to cool off and fuel up as the extended outages strained one of the nation's largest cities.\n\nFrustration mounted that Houston appeared to buckle under a storm less powerful than previous ones and state officials faced questions over whether the power utility that covers much of the area had sufficiently prepared.\n\nNearly 36 hours after Beryl made landfall, Texas' lieutenant governor said Tuesday that a sports and event complex would be used to temporarily hold up to 250 hospital patients who are awaiting discharge but cannot be released to homes with no power.\n\nPeople were coping as best they could.\n\n\"We can handle it, but not the kids,\" Walter Perez said as he arrived Tuesday at celebrity pastor Joel Osteen's megachurch in Houston, which served as a cooling center and distributed 40-bottle packs of water.\n\nPerez said his wife, 3-year-old son, 3-week-old daughter and his father-in-law retreated from their apartment after a night he described as \"bad, bad, bad, bad.\"\n\nHighs in the Houston area on Tuesday climbed back into the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) with humidity that made it feel even hotter. Similar heat and humidity was expected on Wednesday. The National Weather Service described the conditions as potentially dangerous given the lack of power and air conditioning.\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas -- and at least 11 in the Caribbean.\n\nMore than 1.7 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday night, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. For many, it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nPatrons on Tuesday lined up on one block to eat at KFC, Jack in the Box or Denny's. Dwight Yell took a disabled neighbor who did not have power to Denny's for some food.\n\nHe complained that city and state officials did not alert residents well enough to a storm initially projected to land much farther down the coast: \"They didn't give us enough warning, where maybe we could go get gas or prepare to go out of town if the lights go out.\"\n\nRobin Taylor, who got takeout from Denny's, has been living a hotel since her home was damaged by storms that hit the city in May. When Beryl hit, her hotel room flooded.\n\n\"No WiFi, no power, and it's hot outside,\" Taylor said. \"People will die in this heat in their homes.\"\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, emphasized that restoring power was the top priority. CenterPoint Energy in Houston has said it aims to restore power to 1 million customers by the end of Wednesday.\n\nTexas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is serving as acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is overseas, said nursing homes and assisted living centers were the highest priority. Sixteen hospitals were running on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nAn executive for CenterPoint Energy, which covers much of the Houston area, defended the utility's preparation and response.\n\n\"From my perspective to have a storm pass at 3 p.m. in the afternoon, have those crews come in in the late evening, and have everything ready by 5 a.m. to go out and get out and start the workforce is rather impressive because we're talking about thousands of crews,\" Brad Tutunjian, vice president of regulatory policy with CenterPoint Energy, said at a media briefing on Tuesday.\n\nKyuta Allen brought her family to a Houston community center to cool down and use the internet.\n\n\"During the day you can have the doors open but at night you've got to board up and lock up - lock yourself like into a sauna,\" she said.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press journalists Jim Vertuno in Austin, Texas; Sara Cline in Baton Rouge, Louisiana; Jeff Martin in Atlanta; and Sarah Brumfield in Silver Spring, Maryland, congtributed.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8217525633", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "19:23:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T19:23:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T19:23:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://wsvn.com/news/us-world/beryl-leaves-hot-misery-in-the-houston-area-it-still-threatens-flooding-on-its-path-northward/", "title": "Beryl leaves hot misery in the Houston area. It still threatens flooding on its path northward - WSVN 7News | Miami News, Weather, Sports | Fort Lauderdale", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- Many of the millions left without power after Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas, killing several people and unleashing flooding, sweltered and fretted Tuesday as the storm deprived them of air conditioning, food and water in dangerous heat.\n\nA heat advisory took effect through Wednesday in the Houston area and beyond, with temperatures expected to soar into the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) and humidity that could make it feel as hot as 105 degrees (40.5 Celsius).\n\n\"We can handle it, but not the kids,\" said Walter Perez, 49, as he arrived early Tuesday at celebrity pastor Joel Osteen's megachurch in Houston, which served as a cooling center and distributed 40-bottle packs of water to cars that drove up.\n\nPerez said he, his wife, their 3-year-old son and 3-week-old daughter, and his father-in-law retreated from their apartment after a night he described as \"bad, bad, bad, bad.\"\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas -- and at least 11 in the Caribbean. At midday Tuesday, it was a post-tropical cyclone centered over Arkansas and was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flooding to a swath extending to the Great Lakes and Canada.\n\nMore than 2.1 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. For many, it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, said at a news conference with other officials that restoring power is the No. 1 priority. And in Washington, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said President Joe Biden approved a major disaster declaration. Emergency crews hope to have power restored to another 1 million people by the end of the day, she said.\n\nFood spoiled in listless refrigerators in neighborhoods that pined for air conditioning. Long lines of cars and people queued up at any fast food restaurant, food truck or gas station that had power and was open.\n\nDamonte Oliver, 32, visited Osteen's Lakewood Church with his girlfriend and her mother. Their apartment had lost power for days after the May storm.\n\n\"I know they are trying to do their best to get everything back on. It's just a waiting game on how long it's going to take,\" he said before walking to a convenience store to buy cigarettes.\n\n\"I've got to calm down a little bit myself,\" Oliver said.\n\nIt could take days to fully return power in Texas after Beryl toppled 10 transmission lines. Top priorities for power restoration include nursing homes and assisted living centers, said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting as governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country. Sixteen hospitals were running on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nBeryl's strength at midday Tuesday -- with sustained winds near 30 mph (48 kph) -- wasn't expected to change much in the next two days. It was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flash flooding from the lower and mid-Mississippi Valley to the Great Lakes into Wednesday, the National Weather Service said.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana and Michigan. A few tornadoes were possible in Missouri, Tennessee, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana and Ohio, forecasters said.\n\nWhen Beryl made landfall, it was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean. But its winds and rains still knocked down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in saturated earth and stranded dozens of cars on flooded roads.\n\nBeryl was the earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 in the Atlantic. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8216937927", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "12:30:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T12:30:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T12:29:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/article/2024/jul/09/tropical-storm-beryl-texas-death-toll", "title": "Weakened Tropical Storm Beryl moves east after at least seven killed in Texas", "body": "More than 2.3m homes still without power as storm weakens to tropical depression threatening flash flooding\n\nPower started to come back for some of the millions of homes and businesses left in the dark when Hurricane Beryl slammed into the Houston area, while the storm - which killed several people before weakening - moved east, spawning suspected tornadoes and causing more damage.\n\nBeryl was blamed for the deaths of at least seven people in the Houston area on Monday, officials said. Three of those people were killed by fallen trees, one died in a fire, two drowned, and a civilian police department employee died after being trapped in high water while driving to work.\n\nOne person died in north-west Louisiana during the storm when a tree fell on a home, according to authorities.\n\nAfter a peak Monday of more than 2.7 million customers around Houston without power, the numbers improved with more than 2.3m homes and businesses lacking electricity by Tuesday morning, according to PowerOutage.us. The lack of cooling to people's homes, downed power lines and non-functioning traffic lights led officials to ask residents to stay home if possible.\n\n\"Houstonians need to know we're working around the clock so you will be safe,\" the mayor, John Whitmire, said on Monday at a media briefing, urging residents to also know the dangers of high water, to stay hydrated and to check on their neighbors.\n\nBeryl later on Monday weakened into a tropical depression and by Tuesday morning the National Weather Service (NWS) said it was about 95 miles (155km) north of Shreveport, Louisiana, moving north-east with maximum sustained wind speeds near 30mph (48km/h). Its strength was not expected to change much in the next day or two.\n\nWhile weakened, Beryl threatened to unleash more harsh weather over several other states in coming days. The storm was expected to bring heavy rainfall and possible flash flooding from the lower and mid-Mississippi Valley to the Great Lakes on Tuesday into Wednesday, the NWS said.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana and Michigan, and tornadoes were possible through the early morning across parts of the mid-south. A few tornadoes were possible from midday to the early evening in Missouri, Tennessee, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana and Ohio, according to the NWS.\n\nThe storm still packed a punch, and the NWS confirmed on social media on Monday evening that tornadoes had been spotted in north-eastern Louisiana. The Bossier sheriff, Julian Whittington, said in a Facebook post that a woman was killed in the Benton area when a tree fell on her home.\n\nDozens of tornado warnings were issued in Louisiana and Arkansas on Monday evening.\n\nTexas state and local officials warned it could take several days to fully restore power after Beryl came ashore as a category 1 hurricane, toppled 10 transmission lines and knocked down trees that took down power lines.\n\nBeryl on Tuesday was far less powerful than the category 5 behemoth - the earliest on record in the Atlantic basin - that previously tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean.\n\nBut its winds and rains still knocked down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in water-saturated earth, and stranded dozens of cars on flooded roadways.\n\nThe loss of power was an all-too familiar experience for Houston: powerful storms had just ripped through the area in May, killing eight people, leaving nearly 1 million without power and flooding numerous streets.\n\nPower crews were working to restore service as quickly as possible, an urgent priority for homes also left without air conditioning in the middle of summer. Temperatures in the 90s Fahrenheit (above 32.2C) were expected on Tuesday. The NWS issued a heat advisory that said the area heat index could reach 105F (40.5C).\n\nThe state was opening cooling centers as well as food and water distribution centers, said Nim Kidd, chief of state emergency operations.\n\nBeryl was supercharged by extremely hot ocean temperatures resulting from the burning of fossil, according to experts. Its rains pounded Houston and other areas of the coast on Monday, reclosing streets in neighborhoods that had already been washed out by previous storms. {"uri": "8218397301", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "09:28:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T09:28:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T09:28:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://wsvn.com/news/us-world/houston-residents-left-sweltering-after-beryl-with-over-1-7-million-still-lacking-power/", "title": "Houston residents left sweltering after Beryl with over 1.7 million still lacking power - WSVN 7News | Miami News, Weather, Sports | Fort Lauderdale", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- The return of searing heat in the Houston area has deepened the misery for people still without power after Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas and left residents in search of places to cool off and fuel up as the extended outages strained one of the nation's largest cities.\n\nMore than 1.7 million homes and businesses still lacked electricity Tuesday night, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. As frustration mounted, state officials faced questions over whether the power utility that covers much of the area had sufficiently prepared.\n\nNearly 36 hours after Beryl made landfall, Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick said that a sports and event complex would be used to temporarily hold up to 250 hospital patients who are awaiting discharge but cannot be released to homes with no power.\n\nPeople were coping as best they could.\n\n\"We can handle it, but not the kids,\" Walter Perez said as he arrived at celebrity pastor Joel Osteen's megachurch in Houston, which served as a cooling center and distributed 40-bottle packs of water.\n\nPerez said his wife, 3-year-old son, 3-week-old daughter and his father-in-law retreated from their apartment after a night he described as \"bad, bad, bad, bad.\"\n\nAn executive for CenterPoint Energy, which covers much of the Houston area, defended the utility's preparation and response.\n\n\"From my perspective to have a storm pass at 3 p.m. in the afternoon, have those crews come in in the late evening, and have everything ready by 5 a.m. to go out and get out and start the workforce is rather impressive because we're talking about thousands of crews,\" Brad Tutunjian, vice president of regulatory policy with CenterPoint Energy, said at a media briefing.\n\nHighs in the Houston area on Tuesday climbed back into the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) with humidity that made it feel even hotter. Similar heat and humidity was expected Wednesday. The National Weather Service described the conditions as potentially dangerous given the lack of power and air conditioning.\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas -- and at least 11 in the Caribbean.\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, emphasized that restoring power was the top priority.\n\nPatrick, who is serving as acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is overseas, said nursing homes and assisted living centers were the highest priority. Sixteen hospitals were running on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nFor many in the Houston area it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nPatrons on Tuesday lined up on one block to eat at KFC, Jack in the Box or Denny's. Dwight Yell took a disabled neighbor who did not have power to Denny's for some food.\n\nHe complained that city and state officials did not alert residents well enough to a storm initially projected to land much farther down the coast: \"They didn't give us enough warning, where maybe we could go get gas or prepare to go out of town if the lights go out.\"\n\nRobin Taylor, who got takeout from Denny's, has been living a hotel since her home was damaged by the storms in May. When Beryl hit, her hotel room flooded.\n\n\"No WiFi, no power, and it's hot outside,\" Taylor said. \"People will die in this heat in their homes.\"\n\nKyuta Allen brought her family to a Houston community center to cool down and use the internet.\n\n\"During the day you can have the doors open but at night you've got to board up and lock up -- lock yourself like into a sauna,\" she said.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8218008510", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "04:44:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T04:44:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T04:43:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://www.newsday.com/news/nation/houston-power-outages-beryl-r56195", "title": "Houston residents left sweltering after Beryl with over 1.7 million still lacking power", "body": "HOUSTON -- The return of soaring heat in Houston has deepened the misery for people still without power after Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas and left residents in search of places to cool off and fuel up as the extended outages strained one of the nation's largest cities.\n\nFrustration mounted that Houston appeared to buckle under a storm less powerful than previous ones and state officials faced questions over whether the power utility that covers much of the area had sufficiently prepared.\n\nNearly 36 hours after Beryl made landfall, Texas' lieutenant governor said Tuesday that a sports and event complex would be used to temporarily hold up to 250 hospital patients who are awaiting discharge but cannot be released to homes with no power.\n\nPeople were coping as best they could.\n\n\"We can handle it, but not the kids,\" Walter Perez said as he arrived Tuesday at celebrity pastor Joel Osteen's megachurch in Houston, which served as a cooling center and distributed 40-bottle packs of water.\n\nPerez said his wife, 3-year-old son, 3-week-old daughter and his father-in-law retreated from their apartment after a night he described as \"bad, bad, bad, bad.\"\n\nHighs in the Houston area on Tuesday climbed back into the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) with humidity that made it feel even hotter. Similar heat and humidity was expected on Wednesday. The National Weather Service described the conditions as potentially dangerous given the lack of power and air conditioning.\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas -- and at least 11 in the Caribbean.\n\nMore than 1.7 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday night, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. For many, it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nPatrons on Tuesday lined up on one block to eat at KFC, Jack in the Box or Denny's. Dwight Yell took a disabled neighbor who did not have power to Denny's for some food.\n\nHe complained that city and state officials did not alert residents well enough to a storm initially projected to land much farther down the coast: \"They didn't give us enough warning, where maybe we could go get gas or prepare to go out of town if the lights go out.\"\n\nRobin Taylor, who got takeout from Denny's, has been living a hotel since her home was damaged by storms that hit the city in May. When Beryl hit, her hotel room flooded.\n\n\"No WiFi, no power, and it's hot outside,\" Taylor said. \"People will die in this heat in their homes.\"\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, emphasized that restoring power was the top priority. CenterPoint Energy in Houston has said it aims to restore power to 1 million customers by the end of Wednesday.\n\nTexas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is serving as acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is overseas, said nursing homes and assisted living centers were the highest priority. Sixteen hospitals were running on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nAn executive for CenterPoint Energy, which covers much of the Houston area, defended the utility's preparation and response.\n\n\"From my perspective to have a storm pass at 3 p.m. in the afternoon, have those crews come in in the late evening, and have everything ready by 5 a.m. to go out and get out and start the workforce is rather impressive because we're talking about thousands of crews,\" Brad Tutunjian, vice president of regulatory policy with CenterPoint Energy, said at a media briefing on Tuesday.\n\nKyuta Allen brought her family to a Houston community center to cool down and use the internet.\n\n\"During the day you can have the doors open but at night {"uri": "8219361270", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "20:47:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T20:47:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T20:47:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://ktar.com/story/5579753/millions-still-have-no-power-days-after-beryl-struck-texas-heres-why-and-the-rush-to-fix-it/", "title": "Millions still have no power days after Beryl struck Texas. Here's why, and the rush to fix it", "body": "DALLAS (AP) -- It could take days or longer to fully restore power to the Houston area after Hurricane Beryl slammed into Texas, leaving millions of residents in the dark and without air conditioning in searing summer heat.\n\nThe slow pace of restoring power in America's fourth-largest city has put CenterPoint Energy, Houston's utility provider, under mounting scrutiny over whether it was sufficiently prepared before the storm and was working fast enough to get the lights back on.\n\nSome Houston residents -- who are all too familiar with enduring natural disasters -- have also questioned why one of the largest cities on the Gulf Coast appeared to wilt under Beryl and was unable to better withstand a Category 1 hurricane.\n\nBeryl was no longer a Category 5 behemoth by the time it reached the U.S. before sunrise Monday. It made landfall as a weakened hurricane with sustained winds of 80 mph (128 kpm) after having already torn a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean.\n\nIn the Houston area, Beryl toppled transmission lines, uprooted trees and snapped branches that crashed onto power lines. By Wedesday afternoon -- nearly 60 hours after landfall -- about 1.3 million homes and businesses were still without power Wednesday, according to CenterPoint Energy. The utility said it had restored electricity to nearly 1 million customers who lost power during Beryl.\n\nTypically sweltering summer heat along the Texas coast has added to the urgency of restoring power. Temperatures on Wednesday were back above 90 degrees (above 32.2 Celsius), prompting the city to open cooling centers for residents without air conditioning.\n\nCenterPoint Energy has defended its preparation for the storm and said that it had brought in nearly 12,000 additional workers from outside Houston since landfall to expedite power restoration.\n\nUnder sometimes sharp questioning Wednesday from Houston city councilmembers about the utiltity's handling of the storm, Brad Tutunjian, vice president for regulatory policy for CenterPoint Energy, said it wouldn't have been safe to pre-position outside crews to \"ride out\" the storm.\n\nHe said the extensive damage to trees and power poles has hampered the ability to restore power quickly.\n\n\"That's where all the time comes in to do the restoration work,\" he said.\n\nRural communities in Beryl's path are also struggling to get power restored quickly. In coastal Matagorda County, where Beryl made landfall, officials said it may take up to two weeks to get the electricity back on for around 2,500 customers in the hard-hit community of Sargent, where homes were destroyed and badly damaged.\n\nBeryl is just the latest natural disaster to wreak havoc on the power grid in the Houston area. In May, a powerful storm that ripped through the area with high winds left nearly 1 million people without power.\n\nHouston was also hit hard in 2021 when Texas' power grid failed during a deadly winter storm that brought plunging temperatures, snow and ice. Millions of Texans lost power during that storm and were left to ride it out in frigid homes, or flee.\n\nIn 2008, Hurricane Ike made landfall on Galveston Island as a Category 2 hurricane with 110-mph (177-kph) sustained winds, bringing flooding and wind damage to the Houston area. After that storm, about 2.2 million CenterPoint customers were without power, according to the Harris County Flood Control District, which said that 75% of the power was restored by day 10.\n\nTexas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick has been the face of the state's response while Gov. Greg Abbott is on an economic development visit to Asia, where he's traveling to Taiwan, South Korea and Japan.\n\nAbbott left Texas on Friday with a delegation that included other lawmakers, state officials and civic leaders. On Tuesday, Abbott posted on social media that he has remained in contact with emergency management officials and Patrick, who is the acting governor while Abbott is traveling.\n\n\"We'll remain engaged until every Texan recovers,\" he wrote.\n\nRepublican Sen. Ted Cruz of Texas was criticized in 2021 for traveling to Cancun while his state suffered through a deadly freeze. This week, Cruz has traveled along the coast visiting hard-hit communities alongside state officials. On Tuesday, Cruz said he was sleeping on a friend's couch after his own home in Houston lost power.", "source": {"uri": "ktar.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KTAR News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@ktar.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": true}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Landfall", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Landfall"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CenterPoint_Energy", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "CenterPoint Energy"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greater_Houston", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Greater Houston"}, "location": null}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tropical_cyclone", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Tropical cyclone"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Texas", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Texas"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Texas"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Houston", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Houston"}, {"uri": "2024-07-417046919", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "07:02:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T07:02:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T04:16:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://tribtown.com/2024/07/10/houston-residents-left-sweltering-after-beryl-with-over-1-7-million-still-lacking-power/", "title": "Houston residents left sweltering after Beryl with over 1.7 million still lacking power", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- The return of searing heat in the Houston area has deepened the misery for people still without power after Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas and left residents in search of places to cool off and fuel up as the extended outages strained one of the nation's largest cities.\n\nMore than 1.7 million homes and businesses still lacked electricity Tuesday night, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. As frustration mounted, state officials faced questions over whether the power utility that covers much of the area had sufficiently prepared.\n\nNearly 36 hours after Beryl made landfall, Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick said that a sports and event complex would be used to temporarily hold up to 250 hospital patients who are awaiting discharge but cannot be released to homes with no power.\n\nPeople were coping as best they could.\n\n\"We can handle it, but not the kids,\" Walter Perez said as he arrived at celebrity pastor Joel Osteen's megachurch in Houston, which served as a cooling center and distributed 40-bottle packs of water.\n\nPerez said his wife, 3-year-old son, 3-week-old daughter and his father-in-law retreated from their apartment after a night he described as \"bad, bad, bad, bad.\"\n\nAn executive for CenterPoint Energy, which covers much of the Houston area, defended the utility's preparation and response.\n\n\"From my perspective to have a storm pass at 3 p.m. in the afternoon, have those crews come in in the late evening, and have everything ready by 5 a.m. to go out and get out and start the workforce is rather impressive because we're talking about thousands of crews,\" Brad Tutunjian, vice president of regulatory policy with CenterPoint Energy, said at a media briefing.\n\nHighs in the Houston area on Tuesday climbed back into the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) with humidity that made it feel even hotter. Similar heat and humidity was expected Wednesday. The National Weather Service described the conditions as potentially dangerous given the lack of power and air conditioning.\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas -- and at least 11 in the Caribbean.\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, emphasized that restoring power was the top priority.\n\nPatrick, who is serving as acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is overseas, said nursing homes and assisted living centers were the highest priority. Sixteen hospitals were running on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nFor many in the Houston area it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nPatrons on Tuesday lined up on one block to eat at KFC, Jack in the Box or Denny's. Dwight Yell took a disabled neighbor who did not have power to Denny's for some food.\n\nHe complained that city and state officials did not alert residents well enough to a storm initially projected to land much farther down the coast: \"They didn't give us enough warning, where maybe we could go get gas or prepare to go out of town if the lights go out.\"\n\nRobin Taylor, who got takeout from Denny's, has been living a hotel since her home was damaged by the storms in May. When Beryl hit, her hotel room flooded.\n\n\"No WiFi, no power, and it's hot outside,\" Taylor said. \"People will die in this heat in their homes.\"\n\nKyuta Allen brought her family to a Houston community center to cool down and use the internet.\n\n\"During the day you can have the doors open but at night you've got to board up and lock up -- lock yourself like into a sauna,\" she said.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press journalists Jim Vertuno in Austin, Texas; Sara Cline in Baton Rouge, Louisiana; Jeff Martin in Atlanta; and Sarah Brumfield in Silver Spring, Maryland, contributed.", {"uri": "8217765285", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "23:46:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T23:46:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T23:46:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://siouxcityjournal.com/news/nation-world/weather/frustrations-mount-in-the-houston-heat-after-beryl-moves-on-and-leaves-millions-without-power/article_16e9a803-5ed9-5c8c-848d-b1dde5418caa.html", "title": "Frustrations mount in the Houston heat after Beryl moves on and leaves millions without power", "body": "HOUSTON -- Many of the millions left without power after Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas sweltered and grumbled Tuesday as the storm gutted access to air conditioning, food and water while smothering heat and humidity draped over the nation's fourth-largest city.\n\nFrustration mounted that Houston appeared to buckle under a storm not as powerful as previous ones. State officials were questioned whether utilities were prepared in advance, and at least one said they would withhold judgement until after the lights were turned back on.\n\nA heat advisory took effect through Wednesday in the Houston area and beyond, with temperatures expected to soar into the 90s and humidity that could make it feel as hot as 105 degrees. The National Weather Service described the conditions as potentially dangerous given the lack of power and air conditioning.\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths and at least 11 in the Caribbean. At midday Tuesday, it was a post-tropical cyclone centered over Arkansas and was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flooding to a swath extending to the Great Lakes and Canada.\n\nPeople are also reading... Where to go for firework displays in Siouxland Panel looks to release more water from Okoboji lakes without hurting flood-stricken Spencer, Cherokee Belly up to the bar-cade: Warp Zone brings bar and arcade combo to downtown Sioux City McCook Lake Association president: 'There's really no compensation' for flood losses Saturday in the Park continues to bring in big name acts without charging admission Marriage licenses for Woodbury County for July 8, 2024 McCook Lake residents seek answers for flood recovery REVIEW: Bleachers teach plenty at Saturday in the Park 1 killed, 1 hurt in crash near Lake Park North Sioux City updates residents on flood recovery Iowa legislator J.D. Scholten earns win in last-minute start for Sioux City Explorers Ex-Plymouth County deputy to plead guilty of stealing drugs Issues continue to plague Woodbury County jail project, sheriff shares concerns Body of missing 17-year-old who jumped into Platte River to save girl found, authorities say Saturday in the Park 2024 kicks-off with high spirits\n\nMore than 2 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday, down from a peak of more than 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. For many, it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nFood spoiled in powerless refrigerators in neighborhoods that pined for air conditioning. Long lines of cars and people queued up at any fast food restaurant, food truck or gas station that had power and was open.\n\nPatrons lined up on one block to eat at KFC, Jack in the Box or Denny's -- or just to get a few minutes in some cooler air.\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, said at a news conference with other officials that restoring power is the No. 1 priority. In Washington, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said President Joe Biden approved a major disaster declaration.\n\nEmergency crews hoped to have power restored to an additional 1 million people by the end of the day, she said.\n\nIt could take days to fully return power in Texas after Beryl toppled 10 transmission lines. Top priorities for power restoration include nursing homes and assisted living centers, said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting as governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country. Sixteen hospitals were on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nPatrick said he would evaluate later whether utilities had taken proper steps before the storm to mount a swift response.\n\nCenterPoint Energy, which covers much of the Houston area, said it would bring in about 12,000 workers from around the region to help restore power. A company spokesperson said those workers weren't staged in the Houston area before the storm hit, noting that forecasts initially predicted it would go much further south.\n\nKyuta Allen brought her family to a Houston community center to cool down and use the internet for work and the night classes she takes online.\n\n\"You can't really get a lot of stuff done when you are hot,\" she said, adding it is also hard to sleep in the heat.\n\n\"During the day you can have the doors open but at night you've got to board up and lock up -- lock yourself like into a sauna,\" she said.\n\nLesley Briones, a Harris County commissioner, who visited a community center, said she's been told of people waiting hours to get gas.\n\n\"It's catastrophic when you lose everything in your fridge and you are living check to check,\" Briones said.\n\nBeryl's strength at midday Tuesday -- with sustained winds near 30 mph -- wasn't expected to change much in the next two days. It was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flash flooding from the lower and mid-Mississippi Valley to the Great Lakes into Wednesday, the National Weather Service said.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana and Michigan. A few tornadoes were possible in Missouri, Tennessee, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana and Ohio, forecasters said.\n\nLouisiana Gov. Jeff Landry issued a state of emergency Tuesday afternoon for part of that state after trees were knocked down, homes were damaged and thousands lost power.\n\nWhen Beryl made landfall, it was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean. But its winds and rains still knocked down hundreds of trees that already teetered in saturated earth and stranded dozens of cars on flooded roads.\n\nBeryl was the earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 in the Atlantic. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed more than $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nFrom the Caribbean to Texas, Hurricane Beryl leaves a trail of destruction 0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nLocal Weather\n\nGet the daily forecast and severe weather alerts in your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.", "source": {"uri": "siouxcityjournal.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Sioux City Journal"}, "authors": [{"uri": "juan_a_lozano@siouxcityjournal.com", "name": "Juan A. {"uri": "8217171846", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "14:48:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T14:48:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T14:48:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://jamaica-gleaner.com/article/world-news/20240709/beryl-leaves-hot-misery-its-wake-still-dangerous-storm-churns-over-us", "title": "Beryl leaves hot misery in its wake as the still-dangerous storm churns over the US interior", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- Many of the millions left without power when Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas, killing several people and unleashing flooding, now face days without air conditioning as dangerous heat threatens the region Tuesday.\n\nA heat advisory was in effect through Wednesday in the Houston area and beyond, with temperatures expected to soar into the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) and humidity that could make it feel as hot as 105 degrees (40.5 Celsius). The widespread loss of power, and therefore air conditioning, could make for dangerous conditions, the National Weather Service said.\n\nMore than 2.3 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday morning, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\n\"Houstonians need to know we're working around the clock so you will be safe,\" Houston Mayor John Whitmire said Monday, urging residents to also know the dangers of high water, to stay hydrated and to check on their neighbours.\n\nBeryl has been blamed for at least seven deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas, officials said.\n\nThe storm weakened after making landfall, and by Tuesday morning it was a tropical depression centred over southwestern Arkansas, moving northeast with maximum sustained winds near 30 mph (48 kph), the weather service said. Its strength wasn't expected to change much in the next day or two.\n\nThe storm is forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flash flooding from the lower and mid-Mississippi Valley to the Great Lakes into Wednesday, the weather service said.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana and Michigan. A few tornadoes were possible in Missouri, Tennessee, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana and Ohio, forecasters said.\n\nBeryl came ashore in Texas as a Category 1 hurricane, far less powerful than the behemoth that tore a deadly path through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean. But its winds and rains still knocked down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in saturated earth and stranded dozens of cars on flooded roads.\n\nIt could take days to fully return power in Texas after Beryl toppled 10 transmission lines. Top priorities for power restoration include nursing homes and assisted living centres, said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting as governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country.\n\nPowerful storms in the area in May killed eight people, left nearly 1 million without power and flooded streets.
