{"uri": "8217491935", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "18:51:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T18:51:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T18:50:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.brandonsun.com/world/2024/07/09/beryl-leaves-hot-misery-in-the-houston-area-it-still-threatens-flooding-on-its-path-northward", "title": "Beryl leaves hot misery in the Houston area. It still threatens flooding on its path northward", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- Many of the millions left without power after Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas, killing several people and unleashing flooding, sweltered and fretted Tuesday as the storm deprived them of air conditioning, food and water in dangerous heat.\n\nA heat advisory took effect through Wednesday in the Houston area and beyond, with temperatures expected to soar into the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) and humidity that could make it feel as hot as 105 degrees (40.5 Celsius).\n\n\"We can handle it, but not the kids,\" said Walter Perez, 49, as he arrived early Tuesday at celebrity pastor Joel Osteen's megachurch in Houston, which served as a cooling center and distributed 40-bottle packs of water to cars that drove up.\n\nPerez said he, his wife, their 3-year-old son and 3-week-old daughter, and his father-in-law retreated from their apartment after a night he described as \"bad, bad, bad, bad.\"\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas -- and at least 11 in the Caribbean. At midday Tuesday, it was a post-tropical cyclone centered over Arkansas and was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flooding to a swath extending to the Great Lakes and Canada.\n\nMore than 2.1 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. For many, it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, said at a news conference with other officials that restoring power is the No. 1 priority. And in Washington, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said President Joe Biden approved a major disaster declaration. Emergency crews hope to have power restored to another 1 million people by the end of the day, she said.\n\nFood spoiled in listless refrigerators in neighborhoods that pined for air conditioning. Long lines of cars and people queued up at any fast food restaurant, food truck or gas station that had power and was open.\n\nDamonte Oliver, 32, visited Osteen's Lakewood Church with his girlfriend and her mother. Their apartment had lost power for days after the May storm.\n\n\"I know they are trying to do their best to get everything back on. It's just a waiting game on how long it's going to take,\" he said before walking to a convenience store to buy cigarettes.\n\n\"I've got to calm down a little bit myself,\" Oliver said.\n\nIt could take days to fully return power in Texas after Beryl toppled 10 transmission lines. Top priorities for power restoration include nursing homes and assisted living centers, said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting as governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country. Sixteen hospitals were running on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nBeryl's strength at midday Tuesday -- with sustained winds near 30 mph (48 kph) -- wasn't expected to change much in the next two days. It was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flash flooding from the lower and mid-Mississippi Valley to the Great Lakes into Wednesday, the National Weather Service said.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana and Michigan. A few tornadoes were possible in Missouri, Tennessee, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana and Ohio, forecasters said.\n\nWhen Beryl made landfall, it was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean. But its winds and rains still knocked down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in saturated earth and stranded dozens of cars on flooded roads.\n\nBeryl was the earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 in the Atlantic. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\n___\n\nContributing to this report were Associated Press journalists Jim Vertuno in Austin, Texas; Sara Cline in Baton Rouge, Louisiana; Jeff Martin in Atlanta; and Sarah Brumfield in Silver Spring, Maryland.", "source": {"uri": "2024-07-417497400", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:32:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:32:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T01:01:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2024/jul/10/houston-residents-sweltering-after-beryl-with-over/", "title": "Houston residents stew and swelter after storm Beryl leaves millions without power", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- The return of searing heat in the Houston area has deepened the misery for people still without power after Hurricane Beryl left residents in search of places to cool off and fuel up as the extended outages strained one of the nation's largest cities.\n\nMore than 1.7 million homes and businesses in Texas lacked electricity Wednesday morning, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. State officials faced questions over whether the power utility that covers much of the area had sufficiently prepared.\n\nTexas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick said that a sports and event complex would be used to temporarily hold up to 250 hospital patients who are awaiting discharge but cannot be released to homes with no power.\n\nBeryl, which made landfall in Texas early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas -- and at least 11 in the Caribbean. It weakened as it moved deeper into the U.S. and early Wednesday was a post-tropical cyclone centered over northeastern Indiana.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, New York, Vermont, New Hampshire and Maine. The storm spawned suspected tornadoes in parts of Indiana and Kentucky.\n\nIn the Houston area, Beryl compounded and repeated the misery of May, when storms killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power.\n\nHigh temperatures Tuesday climbed into the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) with humidity that made it feel even hotter. Similar heat and humidity were expected on Wednesday. The National Weather Service described the conditions as potentially dangerous, given the lack of power and air conditioning.\n\nPeople coped as best they could. Kyuta Allen took her family to a Houston community center to cool down and use the internet.\n\n\"During the day you can have the doors open, but at night you've got to board up and lock up -- lock yourself like into a sauna,\" she said.\n\nAn executive for CenterPoint Energy, which covers much of the Houston area, defended the utility's preparation and response.\n\n\"From my perspective, to have a storm pass at 3 p.m. in the afternoon, have those crews come in in the late evening, and have everything ready by 5 a.m. to go out and get out and start the workforce is rather impressive, because we're talking about thousands of crews,\" said Brad Tutunjian, vice president of regulatory policy.\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, stressed that restoring power was the top priority.\n\nPatrick, who is acting as governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is overseas, said nursing homes and assisted living centers were the highest priority. State officials faced questions over whether the power utility that covers much of the area had sufficiently prepared.Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick said that a sports and event complex would be used to temporarily hold up to 250 hospital patients who are awaiting discharge but cannot be released to homes with no power.Beryl, which made landfall in Texas early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas -- and at least 11 in the Caribbean. It weakened as it moved deeper into the U.S. and early Wednesday was a post-tropical cyclone centered over northeastern Indiana.A flood watch was in effect for parts of Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, New York, Vermont, New Hampshire and Maine. The storm spawned suspected tornadoes in parts of Indiana and Kentucky.In the Houston area, Beryl compounded and repeated the misery of May, when storms killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power.High temperatures Tuesday climbed into the 90s with humidity that made it feel even hotter. Similar heat and humidity were expected on Wednesday. The National Weather Service described the conditions as potentially dangerous, given the lack of power and air conditioning.People coped as best they could. Kyuta Allen took her family to a Houston community center to cool down and use the internet.\"During the day you can have the doors open, but at night you've got to board up and lock up -- lock yourself like into a sauna,\" she said.An executive for CenterPoint Energy, which covers much of the Houston area, defended the utility's preparation and response.\"From my perspective, to have a storm pass at 3 p.m. in the afternoon, have those crews come in in the late evening, and have everything ready by 5 a.m. to go out and get out and start the workforce is rather impressive because we're talking about thousands of crews,\" said Brad Tutunjian, vice president of regulatory policy.Nim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, stressed that restoring power was the top priority.Patrick, who is acting as governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is overseas, said nursing homes and assisted living centers were the highest priority. Sixteen hospitals ran on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nThe return of searing heat in the Houston area has deepened the misery for people still without power after Hurricane Beryl left residents in search of places to cool off and fuel up as the extended outages strained one of the nation's largest cities.\n\nMore than 1.7 million homes and businesses in Texas lacked electricity Wednesday morning, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. The storm spawned suspected tornadoes in parts of Indiana and Kentucky.\n\nIn the Houston area, Beryl compounded and repeated the misery of May, when storms killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power.\n\nHigh temperatures Tuesday climbed into the 90s with humidity that made it feel even hotter. Similar heat and humidity were expected on Wednesday. The National Weather Service described the conditions as potentially dangerous, given the lack of power and air conditioning.\n\nPeople coped as best they could. {"uri": "8217751885", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "23:28:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T23:28:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T23:27:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/news/nation-world/weather/frustrations-mount-in-the-houston-heat-after-beryl-moves-on-and-leaves-millions-without-power/article_2cbc24a0-d839-5d6d-99e9-0b1f324fcf7e.html", "title": "Frustrations mount in the Houston heat after Beryl moves on and leaves millions without power", "body": "HOUSTON -- Many of the millions left without power after Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas sweltered and grumbled Tuesday as the storm gutted access to air conditioning, food and water while smothering heat and humidity draped over the nation's fourth-largest city.\n\nFrustration mounted that Houston appeared to buckle under a storm not as powerful as previous ones. State officials were questioned whether utilities were prepared in advance, and at least one said they would withhold judgement until after the lights were turned back on.\n\nA heat advisory took effect through Wednesday in the Houston area and beyond, with temperatures expected to soar into the 90s and humidity that could make it feel as hot as 105 degrees. The National Weather Service described the conditions as potentially dangerous given the lack of power and air conditioning.\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths and at least 11 in the Caribbean. At midday Tuesday, it was a post-tropical cyclone centered over Arkansas and was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flooding to a swath extending to the Great Lakes and Canada.\n\nPeople are also reading... Man found dead behind the wheel of vehicle on Veterans Parkway, police say 8-year-old boy dies after Wednesday night crash on I-74 Body pulled from Illinois River identified as Bloomington teen Bloomington woman faces DUI in crash that killed her 8-year-old son Flick Fact: How many State Farm employees are college educated? LaSalle County man dies in illegal fireworks incident Pub II marking 50th anniversary with party in uptown Normal Bloomington man jailed on weapons, drug charges after traffic stop Flick Fact: The $800M ex-farm girl from Stanford and Olympia High? McLean County man detained on cocaine sales charges Man found unresponsive in Bloomington had suffered medical event, police said Aaron Rossi sentenced to 5 years in prison on federal fraud case Behind the Pritzker administration's quest to signal Illinois is 'open for business' Crystal Lake man identified in fatal crash near Downs Funerals pending for July 4\n\nMore than 2 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday, down from a peak of more than 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. For many, it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nFood spoiled in powerless refrigerators in neighborhoods that pined for air conditioning. Long lines of cars and people queued up at any fast food restaurant, food truck or gas station that had power and was open.\n\nPatrons lined up on one block to eat at KFC, Jack in the Box or Denny's -- or just to get a few minutes in some cooler air.\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, said at a news conference with other officials that restoring power is the No. 1 priority. In Washington, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said President Joe Biden approved a major disaster declaration.\n\nEmergency crews hoped to have power restored to an additional 1 million people by the end of the day, she said.\n\nIt could take days to fully return power in Texas after Beryl toppled 10 transmission lines. Top priorities for power restoration include nursing homes and assisted living centers, said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting as governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country. Sixteen hospitals were on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nPatrick said he would evaluate later whether utilities had taken proper steps before the storm to mount a swift response.\n\nCenterPoint Energy, which covers much of the Houston area, said it would bring in about 12,000 workers from around the region to help restore power. A company spokesperson said those workers weren't staged in the Houston area before the storm hit, noting that forecasts initially predicted it would go much further south.\n\nKyuta Allen brought her family to a Houston community center to cool down and use the internet for work and the night classes she takes online.\n\n\"You can't really get a lot of stuff done when you are hot,\" she said, adding it is also hard to sleep in the heat.\n\n\"During the day you can have the doors open but at night you've got to board up and lock up -- lock yourself like into a sauna,\" she said.\n\nLesley Briones, a Harris County commissioner, who visited a community center, said she's been told of people waiting hours to get gas.\n\n\"It's catastrophic when you lose everything in your fridge and you are living check to check,\" Briones said.\n\nBeryl's strength at midday Tuesday -- with sustained winds near 30 mph -- wasn't expected to change much in the next two days. It was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flash flooding from the lower and mid-Mississippi Valley to the Great Lakes into Wednesday, the National Weather Service said.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana and Michigan. A few tornadoes were possible in Missouri, Tennessee, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana and Ohio, forecasters said.\n\nLouisiana Gov. Jeff Landry issued a state of emergency Tuesday afternoon for part of that state after trees were knocked down, homes were damaged and thousands lost power.\n\nWhen Beryl made landfall, it was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean. But its winds and rains still knocked down hundreds of trees that already teetered in saturated earth and stranded dozens of cars on flooded roads.\n\nBeryl was the earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 in the Atlantic. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed more than $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nFrom the Caribbean to Texas, Hurricane Beryl leaves a trail of destruction Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nLocal Weather\n\nGet the daily forecast and severe weather alerts in your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.", "source": {"uri": "pantagraph.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "pantagraph.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": "juan_a_lozano@pantagraph.com", "name": "Juan A. {"uri": "2024-07-416523897", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "17:09:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T17:09:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T16:51:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/beryl-leaves-hot-misery-in-the-houston-area-it-still-threatens-flooding-on-its-path/article_3827e47c-07fe-561b-a512-333651a2f548.html", "title": "Beryl leaves hot misery in the Houston area. It still threatens flooding on its path northward", "body": "Kira Dehnel, center, walks with Samantha Ratra, right, and Noah Dehnel in the choppy surf on the beach as the remaining rain bands approach from Beryl Monday, July 8, 2024, in Galveston, Texas. Tropical Storm Beryl was unleashing heavy rains and powerful winds along the Texas coast, knocking out power to homes and businesses and flooding streets with fast-rising waters.\n\nHOUSTON (AP) -- Many of the millions left without power after Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas, killing several people and unleashing flooding, sweltered and fretted Tuesday as the storm deprived them of air conditioning, food and water in dangerous heat.\n\nA heat advisory took effect through Wednesday in the Houston area and beyond, with temperatures expected to soar into the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) and humidity that could make it feel as hot as 105 degrees (40.5 Celsius).\n\n\"We can handle it, but not the kids,\" said Walter Perez, 49, as he arrived early Tuesday at celebrity pastor Joel Osteen's megachurch in Houston, which served as a cooling center and distributed 40-bottle packs of water to cars that drove up.\n\nPerez said he, his wife, their 3-year-old son and 3-week-old daughter, and his father-in-law retreated from their apartment after a night he described as \"bad, bad, bad, bad.\"\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas, officials said. At midday Tuesday, it was a post-tropical cyclone centered over Arkansas and was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flooding to a swath extending to the Great Lakes and Canada.\n\nMore than 2.2 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. For many, it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nFood spoiled in listless refrigerators in neighborhoods that pined for air conditioning. Long lines of cars and people queued up at any fast food restaurant, food truck or gas station that had power and was open.\n\nDamonte Oliver, 32, visited Osteen's Lakewood Church with his girlfriend and her mother. Their apartment had lost power for days after the May storm.\n\n\"I know they are trying to do their best to get everything back on. It's just a waiting game on how long it's going to take,\" he said before walking to a convenience store to buy cigarettes.\n\n\"I've got to calm down a little bit myself,\" Oliver said.\n\nIt could take days to fully return power in Texas after Beryl toppled 10 transmission lines. Top priorities for power restoration include nursing homes and assisted living centers, said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting as governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country. Sixteen hospitals were running on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nBeryl's strength at midday Tuesday -- with sustained winds near 30 mph (48 kph) -- wasn't expected to change much in the next two days. It was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flash flooding from the lower and mid-Mississippi Valley to the Great Lakes into Wednesday, the National Weather Service said.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana and Michigan. A few tornadoes were possible in Missouri, Tennessee, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana and Ohio, forecasters said.\n\nWhen Beryl made landfall, it was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean. But its winds and rains still knocked down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in saturated earth and stranded dozens of cars on flooded roads.\n\nBeryl, the earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nContributing to this report were Associated Press journalists Jim Vertuno in Austin, Texas; Sara Cline in Baton Rouge, Louisiana; Jeff Martin in Atlanta; and Sarah Brumfield in Silver Spring, Maryland.", "source": {"uri": "register-herald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Beckley Register-Herald"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@register-herald.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "juan_a_lozano@register-herald.com", "name": "Juan A. {"uri": "2024-07-416960321", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "05:17:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T05:17:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T05:01:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/houston-residents-left-sweltering-after-beryl-with-over-1-7-million-still-lacking-power/article_892100e6-7878-5295-aab0-c048f09e1f93.html", "title": "Houston residents left sweltering after Beryl with over 1.7 million still lacking power", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- The return of searing heat in the Houston area has deepened the misery for people still without power after Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas and left residents in search of places to cool off and fuel up as the extended outages strained one of the nation's largest cities.\n\nMore than 1.7 million homes and businesses still lacked electricity Tuesday night, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. As frustration mounted, state officials faced questions over whether the power utility that covers much of the area had sufficiently prepared.\n\nNearly 36 hours after Beryl made landfall, Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick said that a sports and event complex would be used to temporarily hold up to 250 hospital patients who are awaiting discharge but cannot be released to homes with no power.\n\nPeople were coping as best they could.\n\n\"We can handle it, but not the kids,\" Walter Perez said as he arrived at celebrity pastor Joel Osteen's megachurch in Houston, which served as a cooling center and distributed 40-bottle packs of water.\n\nPerez said his wife, 3-year-old son, 3-week-old daughter and his father-in-law retreated from their apartment after a night he described as \"bad, bad, bad, bad.\"\n\nAn executive for CenterPoint Energy, which covers much of the Houston area, defended the utility's preparation and response.\n\n\"From my perspective to have a storm pass at 3 p.m. in the afternoon, have those crews come in in the late evening, and have everything ready by 5 a.m. to go out and get out and start the workforce is rather impressive because we're talking about thousands of crews,\" Brad Tutunjian, vice president of regulatory policy with CenterPoint Energy, said at a media briefing.\n\nHighs in the Houston area on Tuesday climbed back into the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) with humidity that made it feel even hotter. Similar heat and humidity was expected Wednesday. The National Weather Service described the conditions as potentially dangerous given the lack of power and air conditioning.\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas -- and at least 11 in the Caribbean.\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, emphasized that restoring power was the top priority.\n\nPatrick, who is serving as acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is overseas, said nursing homes and assisted living centers were the highest priority. Sixteen hospitals were running on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nFor many in the Houston area it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nPatrons on Tuesday lined up on one block to eat at KFC, Jack in the Box or Denny's. Dwight Yell took a disabled neighbor who did not have power to Denny's for some food.\n\nHe complained that city and state officials did not alert residents well enough to a storm initially projected to land much farther down the coast: \"They didn't give us enough warning, where maybe we could go get gas or prepare to go out of town if the lights go out.\"\n\nRobin Taylor, who got takeout from Denny's, has been living a hotel since her home was damaged by the storms in May. When Beryl hit, her hotel room flooded.\n\n\"No WiFi, no power, and it's hot outside,\" Taylor said. \"People will die in this heat in their homes.\"\n\nKyuta Allen brought her family to a Houston community center to cool down and use the internet.\n\n\"During the day you can have the doors open but at night you've got to board up and lock up -- lock yourself like into a sauna,\" she said.\n\nAssociated Press journalists Jim Vertuno in Austin, Texas; Sara Cline in Baton Rouge, Louisiana; Jeff Martin in Atlanta; and Sarah Brumfield in Silver Spring, Maryland, contributed.\n\nMore from this section\n\nInformative Research Adds Brandon Hall as New EVP of Operations\n\nDirect Mail Benchmark Report 2024 reveals 61% of marketers have increased direct mail investments in the last year\n\nProNotary Announces Exciting New Partner Program", "source": {"uri": "kulr8.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KULR-8 Local News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@kulr8.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "juan_a_lozano@kulr8.com", "name": "Juan A. {"uri": "8217500958", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "19:00:13", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T19:00:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T18:59:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.pbs.org/newshour/nation/beryl-leaves-hot-misery-along-texas-coast-and-brings-threat-of-flooding-to-the-north", "title": "Beryl leaves hot misery along Texas coast and brings threat of flooding to the north", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- Wide recovery efforts are underway after Hurricane Beryl left millions still without power as temperatures soar in Texas, officials said Tuesday.\n\nNim Kidd, the head of the state's division of emergency management, said at a news conference with other state officials that restoring power is the No. 1 priority.\n\nMore than 2.1 million customers in Texas were without power Tuesday afternoon, according to PowerOutage.us. That's down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday.\n\nA heat advisory took effect through Wednesday in the Houston area and beyond, with temperatures expected to soar into the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) and humidity that could make it feel as hot as 105 degrees (40.5 Celsius).\n\nREAD MORE: We're in literal hot water this hurricane season\n\n\"We can handle it, but not the kids,\" said Walter Perez, 49, as he arrived early Tuesday at celebrity pastor Joel Osteen's megachurch in Houston, which served as a cooling center and distributed 40-bottle packs of water to cars that drove up.\n\nPerez said he, his wife, their 3-year-old son and 3-week-old daughter, and his father-in-law retreated from their apartment after a night he described as \"bad, bad, bad, bad.\"\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas -- and at least 11 in the Caribbean. At midday Tuesday, it was a post-tropical cyclone centered over Arkansas and was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flooding to a swath extending to the Great Lakes and Canada.\n\nFor many, it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nFood spoiled in listless refrigerators in neighborhoods that pined for air conditioning. Long lines of cars and people queued up at any fast food restaurant, food truck or gas station that had power and was open.\n\nDamonte Oliver, 32, visited Osteen's Lakewood Church with his girlfriend and her mother. Their apartment had lost power for days after the May storm.\n\n\"I know they are trying to do their best to get everything back on. It's just a waiting game on how long it's going to take,\" he said before walking to a convenience store to buy cigarettes.\n\n\"I've got to calm down a little bit myself,\" Oliver said.\n\nIt could take days to fully return power in Texas after Beryl toppled 10 transmission lines. Top priorities for power restoration include nursing homes and assisted living centers, said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting as governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country. Sixteen hospitals were running on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nBeryl's strength at midday Tuesday -- with sustained winds near 30 mph (48 kph) -- wasn't expected to change much in the next two days. It was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flash flooding from the lower and mid-Mississippi Valley to the Great Lakes into Wednesday, the National Weather Service said.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana and Michigan. A few tornadoes were possible in Missouri, Tennessee, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana and Ohio, forecasters said.\n\nWhen Beryl made landfall, it was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean. But its winds and rains still knocked down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in saturated earth and stranded dozens of cars on flooded roads.\n\nBeryl was the earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 in the Atlantic. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\n___\n\nContributing to this report were Associated Press journalists Jim Vertuno in Austin, Texas; Sara Cline in Baton Rouge, Louisiana; Jeff Martin in Atlanta; and Sarah Brumfield in Silver Spring, Maryland.", "source": {"uri": "pbs.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "PBS.org"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@pbs.org", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": true}, {"uri": "juan_a_lozano@pbs.org", "name": "Juan A. {"uri": "2024-07-416948265", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "05:01:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T05:01:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T04:41:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://internewscast.com/news/houston-residents-suffer-in-heat-after-beryl-with-over-1-7-million-still-without-power/", "title": "Houston Residents Suffer in Heat After Beryl, with Over 1.7 Million Still Without Power - Internewscast Journal", "body": "The heat wave returning to Houston worsened the situation for those still without electricity following Hurricane Beryl's impact on Texas. Residents were left struggling to find ways to stay cool and access fuel as prolonged power outages put a strain on one of the nation's major cities.\n\nThere was growing frustration over Houston's response to a storm that was less severe than previous ones, prompting inquiries into whether the local power utility had adequately prepared for the situation.\n\nTexas officials faced scrutiny for the handling of the aftermath, with questions raised about the readiness of the utility company serving much of the affected area. Nearly two days after Beryl's landfall, the lieutenant governor announced plans to utilize a sports and event complex to accommodate around 250 hospital patients awaiting discharge but unable to return home due to power outages.\n\nPeople were coping as best they could.\n\n\"We can handle it, but not the kids,\" Walter Perez said as he arrived Tuesday at celebrity pastor Joel Osteen's megachurch in Houston, which served as a cooling center and distributed 40-bottle packs of water.\n\nPerez said his wife, 3-year-old son, 3-week-old daughter and his father-in-law retreated from their apartment after a night he described as \"bad, bad, bad, bad.\"\n\nHighs in the Houston area on Tuesday climbed back into the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) with humidity that made it feel even hotter. Similar heat and humidity was expected on Wednesday. The National Weather Service described the conditions as potentially dangerous given the lack of power and air conditioning.\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas -- and at least 11 in the Caribbean.\n\nMore than 1.7 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday night, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. For many, it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nPatrons on Tuesday lined up on one block to eat at KFC, Jack in the Box or Denny's. Dwight Yell took a disabled neighbor who did not have power to Denny's for some food.\n\nHe complained that city and state officials did not alert residents well enough to a storm initially projected to land much farther down the coast: \"They didn't give us enough warning, where maybe we could go get gas or prepare to go out of town if the lights go out.\"\n\nRobin Taylor, who got takeout from Denny's, has been living a hotel since her home was damaged by storms that hit the city in May. When Beryl hit, her hotel room flooded.\n\n\"No WiFi, no power, and it's hot outside,\" Taylor said. \"People will die in this heat in their homes.\"\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, emphasized that restoring power was the top priority. CenterPoint Energy in Houston has said it aims to restore power to 1 million customers by the end of Wednesday.\n\nTexas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is serving as acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is overseas, said nursing homes and assisted living centers were the highest priority. Sixteen hospitals were running on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nAn executive for CenterPoint Energy, which covers much of the Houston area, defended the utility's preparation and response.\n\n\"From my perspective to have a storm pass at 3 p.m. in the afternoon, have those crews come in in the late evening, and have everything ready by 5 a.m. to go out and get out and start the workforce is rather impressive because we're talking about thousands of crews,\" Brad Tutunjian, vice president of regulatory policy with CenterPoint Energy, said at a media briefing on Tuesday.\n\nKyuta Allen brought her family to a Houston community center to cool down and use the internet.\n\n\"During the day you can have the doors open but at night you've got to board up and lock up - lock yourself like into a sauna,\" she said.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press journalists Jim Vertuno in Austin, Texas; Sara Cline in Baton Rouge, Louisiana; Jeff Martin {"uri": "8217990906", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "04:29:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T04:29:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T04:26:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13618553/Houston-residents-left-sweltering-Beryl-1-7-million-lacking-power.html", "title": "Houston residents left sweltering after Beryl with over 1.7 million...", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) - The return of soaring heat in Houston has deepened the misery for people still without power after Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas and left residents in search of places to cool off and fuel up as the extended outages strained one of the nation\u00b4s largest cities.\n\nFrustration mounted that Houston appeared to buckle under a storm less powerful than previous ones and state officials faced questions over whether the power utility that covers much of the area had sufficiently prepared.\n\nNearly 36 hours after Beryl made landfall, Texas\u00b4 lieutenant governor said Tuesday that a sports and event complex would be used to temporarily hold up to 250 hospital patients who are awaiting discharge but cannot be released to homes with no power.\n\nPeople were coping as best they could.\n\n\"We can handle it, but not the kids,\" Walter Perez said as he arrived Tuesday at celebrity pastor Joel Osteen's megachurch in Houston, which served as a cooling center and distributed 40-bottle packs of water.\n\nPerez said his wife, 3-year-old son, 3-week-old daughter and his father-in-law retreated from their apartment after a night he described as \"bad, bad, bad, bad.\"\n\nPeople fill gas cans the day after Hurricane Beryl made landfall nearby Tuesday, July 9, 2024, in Freeport, Texas. (Jon Shapley/Houston Chronicle via AP)\n\nHighs in the Houston area on Tuesday climbed back into the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) with humidity that made it feel even hotter. Similar heat and humidity was expected on Wednesday. The National Weather Service described the conditions as potentially dangerous given the lack of power and air conditioning.\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths - one in Louisiana and six in Texas - and at least 11 in the Caribbean.\n\nMore than 1.7 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday night, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. For many, it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nPatrons on Tuesday lined up on one block to eat at KFC, Jack in the Box or Denny\u00b4s. Dwight Yell took a disabled neighbor who did not have power to Denny\u00b4s for some food.\n\nHe complained that city and state officials did not alert residents well enough to a storm initially projected to land much farther down the coast: \"They didn\u00b4t give us enough warning, where maybe we could go get gas or prepare to go out of town if the lights go out.\"\n\nRobin Taylor, who got takeout from Denny\u00b4s, has been living a hotel since her home was damaged by storms that hit the city in May. When Beryl hit, her hotel room flooded.\n\n\"No WiFi, no power, and it\u00b4s hot outside,\" Taylor said. \"People will die in this heat in their homes.\"\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state\u00b4s division of emergency management, emphasized that restoring power was the top priority. CenterPoint Energy in Houston has said it aims to restore power to 1 million customers by the end of Wednesday.\n\nTexas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is serving as acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is overseas, said nursing homes and assisted living centers were the highest priority. Sixteen hospitals were running on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nAn executive for CenterPoint Energy, which covers much of the Houston area, defended the utility's preparation and response.\n\n\"From my perspective to have a storm pass at 3 p.m. in the afternoon, have those crews come in in the late evening, and have everything ready by 5 a.m. to go out and get out and start the workforce is rather impressive because we\u00b4re talking about thousands of crews,\" Brad Tutunjian, vice president of regulatory policy with CenterPoint Energy, said at a media briefing on Tuesday.\n\nKyuta Allen brought her family to a Houston community center to cool down and use the internet.\n\n\"During the day you can have the doors open but at night you\u00b4ve got to board up and lock up - lock yourself like into a sauna,\" she said.\n\nAssociated Press journalists Jim Vertuno in Austin, Texas; Sara Cline in Baton Rouge, Louisiana; Jeff Martin in Atlanta; and Sarah Brumfield in Silver Spring, Maryland, congtributed.\n\nStaff at Lakewood Church hand out water and operate a cooling station in Houston, Tuesday, July 9, 2024. The effects of Hurricane Beryl left most in the area without power. (AP Photo/Eric Gay)\n\nStaff at Lakewood Church hand out water and operate a cooling station in Houston, Tuesday, July 9, 2024. The effects of Hurricane Beryl left most in the area without power. {"uri": "8216819552", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "11:17:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T11:17:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T11:17:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/galleries/article-13615533/Hurricane-Beryl-kills-eight-Killer-storm-leaves-3M-without-power.html", "title": "Hurricane Beryl kills eight: Killer storm leaves 3M without power", "body": "Several hospitals have been forced to close and cancel patients appointments after Hurricane Beryl ripped through southeast Texas, causing widespread power outages and leaving at least eight people dead. The super storm brought howling winds and torrential rain on Monday, flooding highways, closing oil ports, canceling more than 1,300 flights and knocking out power at more than 2.7 million houses and businesses. Some hospitals in the Houston suffered damage during the storm and have been forced to close their doors Tuesday to non-emergency appointments. At least one is operating on generator power.\n\nBeryl hit land as a Category 1 hurricane, strengthening from a tropical storm over the Gulf of Mexico. It later weakened into a tropical depression with maximum wind speeds of about 35mph. The storm, which was expected to rapidly weaken as it moved inland, swept a destructive path through Jamaica, Grenada, and St. Vincent and the Grenadines last week. It killed at least 11 in Mexico and the Caribbean and before reaching Texas. Beryl was blamed for killing several people in Texas on Monday and at least one person in Louisiana , officials said.\n\nAfter a peak Monday of more than 2.7million customers around Houston without power, the numbers improved to more than 2.4million homes and businesses lacking electricity by Monday night, according to PowerOutage.us. Several hospitals and health clinics throughout the Greater Houston area were forced to hunker down during the storm, impacting their services. Most hospitals have remained open and are providing emergency medical assistance, The Houston Business Journal reported.\n\nHowever, some have closed outpatient services, specialty facilities, health centers, and same-day clinics. Patients whose appointments have been canceled will be rescheduled. St. Luke's Health system's Brazosport Hospital, located in Lake Jackson, was among the facilities damaged during the storm. It is currently operating on generator power and accepted new emergency patients. Officials told the newspaper that no staff or patients were injured, however some people receiving treatment had to be relocated in the facility. MD Anderson Cancer Center has closed its facility for all appointments except for emergency procedures at its Texas Medical Center campus.\n\nState officials have yet to assess the economic damage as officials remained on a rescue footing while powerful winds continued to blow. Restoring power would take several days, said Thomas Gleeson, chair of the Texas Public Utility Commission. More than 2,500 first responders were deployed statewide, said Nim Kidd, chief of the Texas Division of Emergency Management. The lack of cooling to people's homes, downed power lines and non-functioning traffic lights has led officials to ask residents to stay home if possible.\n\n'Houstonians need to know we're working around the clock so you will be safe,' Houston Mayor John Whitmire said Monday at a media briefing, urging residents to also know the dangers of high water, to stay hydrated and to check on their neighbors. Power crews are working to restore service as quickly as possible, an urgent priority for homes also left without air conditioning in the middle of summer. Temperatures in the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) were expected Tuesday. The National Weather Service issued a heat advisory that said the area heat index could reach 105 F (40.5 C).\n\nThe state was opening cooling centers as well as food and water distribution centers, said Nim Kidd, chief of state emergency operations. A flood watch was in place Tuesday across multiple U.S. states as tropical depression Beryl lashes the country's south with heavy rain after killing at least four people in Texas. The National Hurricane Center (NHC) said Beryl could bring flash flooding 'from the lower and mid Mississippi Valley to the Great Lakes' through Wednesday as it sweeps across swathes of the United States. A tornado is also possible Tuesday across parts of the south, the NHC said in its latest advisory.\n\nDespite weakening to a tropical depression, Beryl still packed a punch on Monday, with the National Weather Service confirming that tornadoes had been spotted in northeastern Louisiana. Bossier Sheriff Julian Whittington said in a Facebook post that a woman was killed in the Benton area when a tree fell on her home. Dozens of tornado warnings were issued in Louisiana and Arkansas on Monday evening and they continued into the night.\n\nTexas state and local officials warned it could take several days to fully restore power after Beryl came ashore as a Category 1 hurricane and toppled 10 transmission lines and knocked down trees that took down power lines. Beryl on Tuesday was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean last weekend. But its winds and rains were still powerful enough to knock down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in water-saturated earth, and strand dozens of cars on flooded roadways. 'We're not past any difficult conditions,' said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country.\n\nWant more stories like this from the Daily Mail? At midday Tuesday, it was a post-tropical cyclone centered over Arkansas and was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flooding to a swath extending to the Great Lakes and Canada.\n\nMore than 2.2 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. For many, it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nFood spoiled in listless refrigerators in neighborhoods that pined for air conditioning. Long lines of cars and people queued up at any fast food restaurant, food truck or gas station that had power and was open.\n\nDamonte Oliver, 32, visited Osteen's Lakewood Church with his girlfriend and her mother. Their apartment had lost power for days after the May storm.\n\n\"I know they are trying to do their best to get everything back on. It's just a waiting game on how long it's going to take,\" he said before walking to a convenience store to buy cigarettes.\n\n\"I've got to calm down a little bit myself,\" Oliver said.\n\nIt could take days to fully return power in Texas after Beryl toppled 10 transmission lines. Top priorities for power restoration include nursing homes and assisted living centers, said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting as governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country. Sixteen hospitals were running on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nBeryl's strength at midday Tuesday -- with sustained winds near 30 mph (48 kph) -- wasn't expected to change much in the next two days. It was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flash flooding from the lower and mid-Mississippi Valley to the Great Lakes into Wednesday, the National Weather Service said.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana and Michigan. A few tornadoes were possible in Missouri, Tennessee, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana and Ohio, forecasters said.\n\nWhen Beryl made landfall, it was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean. But its winds and rains still knocked down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in saturated earth and stranded dozens of cars on flooded roads.\n\nBeryl was the earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 in the Atlantic. {"uri": "8217759369", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "23:39:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T23:39:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T23:38:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://qctimes.com/news/nation-world/weather/frustrations-mount-in-the-houston-heat-after-beryl-moves-on-and-leaves-millions-without-power/article_da1eb56b-4b0e-5e4c-ae5d-8896ec39c6f7.html", "title": "Frustrations mount in the Houston heat after Beryl moves on and leaves millions without power", "body": "HOUSTON -- Many of the millions left without power after Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas sweltered and grumbled Tuesday as the storm gutted access to air conditioning, food and water while smothering heat and humidity draped over the nation's fourth-largest city.\n\nFrustration mounted that Houston appeared to buckle under a storm not as powerful as previous ones. State officials were questioned whether utilities were prepared in advance, and at least one said they would withhold judgement until after the lights were turned back on.\n\nA heat advisory took effect through Wednesday in the Houston area and beyond, with temperatures expected to soar into the 90s and humidity that could make it feel as hot as 105 degrees. The National Weather Service described the conditions as potentially dangerous given the lack of power and air conditioning.\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths and at least 11 in the Caribbean. At midday Tuesday, it was a post-tropical cyclone centered over Arkansas and was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flooding to a swath extending to the Great Lakes and Canada.\n\nPeople are also reading... An early look at Davenport's plans for Main Street Landing Chicago company buys apartment buildings in Davenport, Moline Quad-Cities business openings, closings: Shelly's Sweet Sensations, Crawford Brew Works and more John Deere closes on land for 1.2 million-square-foot warehouse in Indiana Agriculture expert: Deere prepares for future losses due to declining ag economy Driver of vehicle in LeClaire crash identified Police identify woman killed by crash Monday afternoon northwest of Davenport Matt Moody managed the Village Theater and touched many lives Moline woman gave report of missing mail to postal worker accused of stealing mail Review: Lainey Wilson sings in the rain Sunday at the John Deere Classic Review: Counting Crows at the John Deere Classic 'Concerts on the Course' Sarah Goodwin says her husband's life was 'swirling out of control' before he was killed Clinton man pleads guilty to federal child porn charge Quad-Cities prepare for 18-foot Mississippi River flood Registered sex offender accused of inappropriately touching girl\n\nMore than 2 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday, down from a peak of more than 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. For many, it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nFood spoiled in powerless refrigerators in neighborhoods that pined for air conditioning. Long lines of cars and people queued up at any fast food restaurant, food truck or gas station that had power and was open.\n\nPatrons lined up on one block to eat at KFC, Jack in the Box or Denny's -- or just to get a few minutes in some cooler air.\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, said at a news conference with other officials that restoring power is the No. 1 priority. In Washington, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said President Joe Biden approved a major disaster declaration.\n\nEmergency crews hoped to have power restored to an additional 1 million people by the end of the day, she said.\n\nIt could take days to fully return power in Texas after Beryl toppled 10 transmission lines. Top priorities for power restoration include nursing homes and assisted living centers, said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting as governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country. Sixteen hospitals were on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nPatrick said he would evaluate later whether utilities had taken proper steps before the storm to mount a swift response.\n\nCenterPoint Energy, which covers much of the Houston area, said it would bring in about 12,000 workers from around the region to help restore power. A company spokesperson said those workers weren't staged in the Houston area before the storm hit, noting that forecasts initially predicted it would go much further south.\n\nKyuta Allen brought her family to a Houston community center to cool down and use the internet for work and the night classes she takes online.\n\n\"You can't really get a lot of stuff done when you are hot,\" she said, adding it is also hard to sleep in the heat.\n\n\"During the day you can have the doors open but at night you've got to board up and lock up -- lock yourself like into a sauna,\" she said.\n\nLesley Briones, a Harris County commissioner, who visited a community center, said she's been told of people waiting hours to get gas.\n\n\"It's catastrophic when you lose everything in your fridge and you are living check to check,\" Briones said.\n\nBeryl's strength at midday Tuesday -- with sustained winds near 30 mph -- wasn't expected to change much in the next two days. It was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flash flooding from the lower and mid-Mississippi Valley to the Great Lakes into Wednesday, the National Weather Service said.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana and Michigan. A few tornadoes were possible in Missouri, Tennessee, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana and Ohio, forecasters said.\n\nLouisiana Gov. Jeff Landry issued a state of emergency Tuesday afternoon for part of that state after trees were knocked down, homes were damaged and thousands lost power.\n\nWhen Beryl made landfall, it was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean. But its winds and rains still knocked down hundreds of trees that already teetered in saturated earth and stranded dozens of cars on flooded roads.\n\nBeryl was the earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 in the Atlantic. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed more than $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nFrom the Caribbean to Texas, Hurricane Beryl leaves a trail of destruction 0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nLocal Weather\n\nGet the daily forecast and severe weather alerts in your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.", "source": {"uri": "qctimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Quad-City Times"}, "authors": [{"uri": "juan_a_lozano@qctimes.com", "name": "Juan A. {"uri": "8217825238", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "01:09:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T01:09:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T01:08:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://jamaica-gleaner.com/article/world-news/20240709/frustrations-mount-houston-heat-after-beryl-moves-and-leaves-millions", "title": "Frustrations mount in the Houston heat after Beryl moves on and leaves millions without power", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- The return of soaring heat in Houston on Tuesday deepened the misery for millions of people still without power after Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas and left residents in search of places to cool off and fuel up as the extended outages strained one of the nation's largest cities.\n\nFrustration mounted that Houston appeared to buckle under a storm less powerful than previous ones.\n\nState officials faced questions over whether Houston's power utility had sufficiently prepared, including one who said he would withhold judgement until after the lights are back on.\n\nHospitals also started to feel the pinch: Nearly 36 hours after Beryl made landfall, Texas' lieutenant governor said a sports and event complex would be used to temporarily hold up to 250 patients who are awaiting discharge but cannot be released to homes with no power.\n\nPeople coped as best they could.\n\n\"We can handle it, but not the kids,\" said Walter Perez, 49, as he arrived early Tuesday at celebrity pastor Joel Osteen's megachurch in Houston, which served as a cooling centre and distributed 40-bottle packs of water.\n\nPerez said his family -- including his wife, a three-year-old son, a three-week-old daughter and his father-in-law -- retreated from their apartment after a night he described as \"bad, bad, bad, bad.\"\n\nHighs in the Houston on Tuesday climbed back into the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) and humidity that could make it feel even hotter. The National Weather Service described the conditions as potentially dangerous given the lack of power and air conditioning.\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category one hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven US deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas -- and at least 11 in the Caribbean.\n\nNearly two million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. For many, it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly one million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nFood spoilt in listless refrigerators in neighbourhoods that pined for air conditioning. Long lines of cars and people queued up at any fast food restaurant, food truck or gas station that had power and was open.\n\nPatrons lined up on one block to eat at KFC, Jack in the Box or Denny's -- or just to get a few minutes in some cooler air. Dwight Yell, 54, had power at his house but took a disabled neighbour, who did not, to Denny's for some food.\n\nHe complained that city and state officials did not alert residents well enough to a storm initially projected to land much farther down the coast: \"They didn't give us enough warning, where maybe we could go get gas or prepare to go out of town if the lights go out.\"\n\nRobin Taylor, who got takeout from Denny's, was getting tired of the same old struggle. She has been living in a hotel since her home was damaged by the storms in May. When Beryl hit, her hotel room flooded.\n\nShe was angry that Houston didn't appear prepared to handle the Category one storm after it had weathered much stronger ones in the past.\n\n\"No Wi-Fi, no power, and it's hot outside. That's dangerous for people. That's really the big issue,\" Taylor said. \"People will die in this heat in their homes.\"\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, emphasised that restoring power was the top priority. CenterPoint Energy in Houston has said it aims to restore power to one million customers by the end of Wednesday.\n\nBut for others, getting the lights back could take several more days or longer. Texas Lieutenant Governor Dan Patrick, who is serving as acting governor while Governor Greg Abbott is overseas, said nursing homes and assisted living centres were the highest priority. Sixteen hospitals were running on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nPatrick urged utilities to restore power quickly and said he would evaluate later whether they did enough before the storm.\n\nAn executive for CenterPoint Energy, which covers much of the Houston area, defended the utility's preparation and response.\n\n\"From my perspective to have a storm pass at 3 p.m. in the afternoon, have those crews come in in the late evening, and have everything ready by 5 a.m. to go out and get out and start the workforce is rather impressive {"uri": "8217997745", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "04:33:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T04:33:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T04:33:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/07/10/nation/houston-residents-left-sweltering-after-beryl-with-over-17-million-still-lacking-power/", "title": "Houston residents left sweltering after Beryl with over 1.7 million still lacking power - The Boston Globe", "body": "Nearly 36 hours after Beryl made landfall, Texas' lieutenant governor said Tuesday that a sports and event complex would be used to temporarily hold up to 250 hospital patients who are awaiting discharge but cannot be released to homes with no power.\n\n\"We can handle it, but not the kids,\" Walter Perez said as he arrived Tuesday at celebrity pastor Joel Osteen's megachurch in Houston, which served as a cooling center and distributed 40-bottle packs of water.\n\nPerez said his wife, 3-year-old son, 3-week-old daughter and his father-in-law retreated from their apartment after a night he described as \"bad, bad, bad, bad.\"\n\nHighs in the Houston area on Tuesday climbed back into the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) with humidity that made it feel even hotter. Similar heat and humidity was expected on Wednesday. The National Weather Service described the conditions as potentially dangerous given the lack of power and air conditioning.\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas -- and at least 11 in the Caribbean.\n\nMore than 1.7 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday night, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. For many, it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nPatrons on Tuesday lined up on one block to eat at KFC, Jack in the Box or Denny's. Dwight Yell took a disabled neighbor who did not have power to Denny's for some food.\n\nHe complained that city and state officials did not alert residents well enough to a storm initially projected to land much farther down the coast: \"They didn't give us enough warning, where maybe we could go get gas or prepare to go out of town if the lights go out.\"\n\nRobin Taylor, who got takeout from Denny's, has been living a hotel since her home was damaged by storms that hit the city in May. When Beryl hit, her hotel room flooded.\n\n\"No WiFi, no power, and it's hot outside,\" Taylor said. \"People will die in this heat in their homes.\"\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, emphasized that restoring power was the top priority. CenterPoint Energy in Houston has said it aims to restore power to 1 million customers by the end of Wednesday.\n\nTexas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is serving as acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is overseas, said nursing homes and assisted living centers were the highest priority. Sixteen hospitals were running on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nAn executive for CenterPoint Energy, which covers much of the Houston area, defended the utility's preparation and response.\n\n\"From my perspective to have a storm pass at 3 p.m. in the afternoon, have those crews come in in the late evening, and have everything ready by 5 a.m. to go out and get out and start the workforce is rather impressive because we're talking about thousands of crews,\" Brad Tutunjian, vice president of regulatory policy with CenterPoint Energy, said at a media briefing on Tuesday.\n\nKyuta Allen brought her family to a Houston community center to cool down and use the internet.\n\n\"During the day you can have the doors open but at night {"uri": "8218265566", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "08:04:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T08:04:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T08:04:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://english.elpais.com/climate/2024-07-10/after-beryl-tears-through-texas-residents-are-caught-between-persistent-flooding-and-rising-temperatures.html", "title": "After 'Beryl' tears through Texas, residents are caught between persistent flooding and rising temperatures", "body": "After the storm, the calm has yet to reach Texas. After Beryl tore through the state on Monday, leaving at least eight dead -- in the first of a hurricane season that is expected to be historic -- the risk of flooding persists as temperatures increase, driven by a heat wave that is affecting the entire country. State authorities estimate that returning power to the nearly three million homes and businesses that suffered outages from the Category 1 storm will take anywhere from a few days to two weeks.\n\nActing Governor Dan Patrick, who is filling in for Greg Abbott while the latter is out of the country, announced that energy company CenterPoint Energy will bring in thousands of additional workers to restore power. According to Patrick, the hurricane took down 10 transmission lines and many of the service outages were caused by downed trees. Fallen trees also caused several of the deaths attributed to Beryl, along with a house fire believed to have been caused by lightning, and drowning.\n\nWhen Beryl made landfall in Texas on Monday it was far from the Category 5 hurricane that had destroyed Caribbean islands and hit parts of Mexico a few days earlier; by then it had been downgraded to tropical storm, but it still unleashed heavy rains. In a short time the flooding had trapped dozens of cars on streets and highways, while the winds knocked down hundreds of trees, already fragile due to the saturated soil. In the coming days the storm is expected to affect several other states. According to the National Hurricane Center, dangerous winds and flash flooding will continue as the storm moves forward.\n\nAs the dark clouds of Beryl gave way to the harsh summer sun, the need to restore power became increasingly urgent as Texas grapples with a heat wave. In the Houston metropolitan area, the fourth most populated city in the country, more than two million homes and businesses suffered outages due to storms for the second time this year, while temperatures were forecast to climb into the mid-90s on Wednesday. The National Weather Service in Houston had a heat advisory in place for Wednesday, warning that \"with power outages continuing across South-East Texas, the lack of air conditioning will aggravate the risk for heat-related illnesses.\"\n\nIn the city of Galveston, south of Houston, authorities warned of difficulties still ahead. \"As efforts move full steam ahead, we want residents to be aware and prepare for a possible multi-day outage. The estimate is between 72 hours and two weeks in some areas.\"\n\nOn Monday afternoon in Houston, the sound of chainsaws echoed as citizens got to work clearing streets and sidewalks of trees and branches that were blocking the roads. But acting governor Patrick warned that flooding could return within the week if heavy rain fell on already highly saturated areas.\n\nThe situation has also affected the industrial engine of the state. This area of Texas has a large number of oil refineries and several companies announced that it has become necessary to activate flaring -- the burning of residual or preventive natural gas due to pressure changes in the plant -- because of changes in the electrical supply. It is not yet clear how much gas was burned, nor what impact on emissions this may have had.\n\nBeryl, the fastest storm to become a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean towards Texas. The storm ripped off doors, windows and roofs with devastating winds and tides fueled by record-breaking Atlantic heat. On three occasions in the past week, Beryl increased its wind speed by 35 miles per hour (56 km/h) in 24 hours or less, the official definition of rapid intensification.\n\nBeryl's explosive growth is due to warm water from the Atlantic and Caribbean and is just a prelude to what the Atlantic hurricane belt can expect for the rest of the season, experts have warned. In Jamaica, authorities said Monday that island residents will face food shortages after Beryl destroyed more than $6.4 million worth of crops and infrastructure.\n\nIn Louisiana, \"the risk will be for heavy rain and the potential for flash flooding,\" the National Weather Service said. State meteorologists are also watching out for \"fast-moving tornadoes,\" said Donald Jones, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Lake Charles, Louisiana. \"It's just a matter of exactly where it's going to be,\" Jones added. \"It is very difficult to predict it more than an hour in advance.\"\n\nBeryl is forecast to bring more rain and strong winds to other states in the coming days. One of them, Missouri, is already dealing with a wet summer. Heavy rains unrelated to the storm prompted several water rescues around the city of Columbia, where rivers and streams were already swollen before Beryl's arrival on Tuesday.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8217547519", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "19:45:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T19:45:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T19:44:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://theeagle.com/news/state-regional/weather/beryl-leaves-hot-misery-in-houston-area-still-threatens-flooding-on-its-path-northward/article_6a8446f0-3e28-11ef-b879-8b959ecee898.html", "title": "Beryl leaves hot misery in Houston area, still threatens flooding on its path northward", "body": "JUAN A. LOZANO Associated Press\n\nHOUSTON -- Many of the millions left without power after Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas, killing several people and unleashing flooding, sweltered and fretted Tuesday as the storm deprived them of air conditioning, food and water in dangerous heat.\n\nA heat advisory took effect through Wednesday in the Houston area and beyond, with temperatures expected to soar into the 90s and humidity that could make it feel as hot as 105 degrees.\n\n\"We can handle it, but not the kids,\" said Walter Perez, 49, as he arrived early Tuesday at celebrity pastor Joel Osteen's megachurch in Houston, which served as a cooling center and distributed 40-bottle packs of water to cars that drove up.\n\nPerez said he, his wife, their 3-year-old son and 3-week-old daughter, and his father-in-law retreated from their apartment after a night he described as \"bad, bad, bad, bad.\"\n\nPeople are also reading... Texas A&M baseball transfer Wyatt Henseler bookends standout college career at Blue Bell Park Potential RELLIS manufacturing facility could bring 1,800 jobs, $31.2M in city revenue Texas A&M AD Trev Alberts details days leading up to Jim Schlossnagle's departure Fargo's Pit BBQ in Bryan to close after 24 years Texas A&M infielder Kaeden Kent to return to Aggie baseball program Snook sunflower field has become a popular local photo spot 'This is my home': Jace LaViolette, Gavin Grahovac announce they will return to Texas A&M Power outages flare up across Brazos Valley after Tropical Storm Beryl crosses region Waco man arrested in Brazos County for alleged theft of a firearm Brenham man dies in fatal Washington County crash Watch: Jace LaViolette explains decision to stay at Texas A&M Police identify Lake Bryan drowning victim Bryan man arrested with over 600 grams of meth A pair of Texas A&M baseball players recommit to program A&M's Athletics Hall of Fame adds 8\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas -- and at least 11 in the Caribbean. At midday Tuesday, it was a post-tropical cyclone centered over Arkansas and was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flooding to a swath extending to the Great Lakes and Canada.\n\nMore than 2.1 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. For many, it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, said at a news conference with other officials that restoring power is the No. 1 priority. And in Washington, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said President Joe Biden approved a major disaster declaration. Emergency crews hope to have power restored to another 1 million people by the end of the day, she said.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nFood spoiled in listless refrigerators in neighborhoods that pined for air conditioning. Long lines of cars and people queued up at any fast food restaurant, food truck or gas station that had power and was open.\n\nDamonte Oliver, 32, visited Osteen's Lakewood Church with his girlfriend and her mother. Their apartment had lost power for days after the May storm.\n\n\"I know they are trying to do their best to get everything back on. It's just a waiting game on how long it's going to take,\" he said before walking to a convenience store to buy cigarettes. \"I've got to calm down a little bit myself.\"\n\nIt could take days to fully return power in Texas after Beryl toppled 10 transmission lines. Top priorities for power restoration include nursing homes and assisted living centers, said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting as governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country. Sixteen hospitals were running on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nBeryl's strength at midday Tuesday -- with sustained winds near 30 mph -- wasn't expected to change much in the next two days. It was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flash flooding from the lower and mid-Mississippi Valley to the Great Lakes into Wednesday, the National Weather Service said.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana and Michigan. A few tornadoes were possible in Missouri, Tennessee, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana and Ohio, forecasters said.\n\nWhen Beryl made landfall, it was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean. But its winds and rains still knocked down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in saturated earth and stranded dozens of cars on flooded roads.\n\nBeryl was the earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 in the Atlantic. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nLocal Weather\n\nGet
