The effects of Hurricane Beryl left most in the area without power. Eric Gay/Associated Press\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas, officials said. At midday Tuesday, it was a post-tropical cyclone centered over Arkansas and was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flooding to a swath extending to the Great Lakes and Canada.\n\nMore than 2.2 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. For many, it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nFood spoiled in listless refrigerators in neighborhoods that pined for air conditioning. Long lines of cars and people queued up at any fast food restaurant, food truck or gas station that had power and was open.\n\nDamonte Oliver, 32, visited Osteen's Lakewood Church with his girlfriend and her mother. Their apartment had lost power for days after the May storm.\n\n\"I know they are trying to do their best to get everything back on. It's just a waiting game on how long it's going to take,\" he said before walking to a convenience store to buy cigarettes.\n\n\"I've got to calm down a little bit myself,\" Oliver said.\n\nIt could take days to fully return power in Texas after Beryl toppled 10 transmission lines. Top priorities for power restoration include nursing homes and assisted living centers, said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting as governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country. Sixteen hospitals were running on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nBeryl's strength at midday Tuesday -- with sustained winds near 30 mph -- wasn't expected to change much in the next two days. It was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flash flooding from the lower and mid-Mississippi Valley to the Great Lakes into Wednesday, the National Weather Service said.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana and Michigan. A few tornadoes were possible in Missouri, Tennessee, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana and Ohio, forecasters said.\n\nWhen Beryl made landfall, it was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean. But its winds and rains still knocked down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in saturated earth and stranded dozens of cars on flooded roads.\n\nBeryl, the earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nContributing to this report were Associated Press journalists Jim Vertuno in Austin, Texas; Sara Cline in Baton Rouge, Louisiana; Jeff Martin in Atlanta; and Sarah Brumfield in Silver Spring, Maryland.\n\nCopy the Story {"uri": "2024-07-416547200", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "17:34:29", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T17:34:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T16:51:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/beryl-leaves-hot-misery-in-the-houston-area-it-still-threatens-flooding-on-its-path/article_1b1062d0-bf4d-57ff-bc86-ca5ed03adfed.html", "title": "Beryl leaves hot misery in the Houston area. It still threatens flooding on its path northward", "body": "Many of the millions left without power after Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas are sweltering and fretting as they face days without air conditioning in dangerous heat\n\nHOUSTON (AP) -- Many of the millions left without power after Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas, killing several people and unleashing flooding, sweltered and fretted Tuesday as the storm deprived them of air conditioning, food and water in dangerous heat.\n\nA heat advisory took effect through Wednesday in the Houston area and beyond, with temperatures expected to soar into the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) and humidity that could make it feel as hot as 105 degrees (40.5 Celsius).\n\n\"We can handle it, but not the kids,\" said Walter Perez, 49, as he arrived early Tuesday at celebrity pastor Joel Osteen's megachurch in Houston, which served as a cooling center and distributed 40-bottle packs of water to cars that drove up.\n\nPerez said he, his wife, their 3-year-old son and 3-week-old daughter, and his father-in-law retreated from their apartment after a night he described as \"bad, bad, bad, bad.\"\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas, officials said. At midday Tuesday, it was a post-tropical cyclone centered over Arkansas and was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flooding to a swath extending to the Great Lakes and Canada.\n\nMore than 2.2 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. For many, it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nFood spoiled in listless refrigerators in neighborhoods that pined for air conditioning. Long lines of cars and people queued up at any fast food restaurant, food truck or gas station that had power and was open.\n\nDamonte Oliver, 32, visited Osteen's Lakewood Church with his girlfriend and her mother. Their apartment had lost power for days after the May storm.\n\n\"I know they are trying to do their best to get everything back on. It's just a waiting game on how long it's going to take,\" he said before walking to a convenience store to buy cigarettes.\n\n\"I've got to calm down a little bit myself,\" Oliver said.\n\nIt could take days to fully return power in Texas after Beryl toppled 10 transmission lines. Top priorities for power restoration include nursing homes and assisted living centers, said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting as governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country. Sixteen hospitals were running on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nBeryl's strength at midday Tuesday -- with sustained winds near 30 mph (48 kph) -- wasn't expected to change much in the next two days. It was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flash flooding from the lower and mid-Mississippi Valley to the Great Lakes into Wednesday, the National Weather Service said.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana and Michigan. A few tornadoes were possible in Missouri, Tennessee, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana and Ohio, forecasters said.\n\nWhen Beryl made landfall, it was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean. But its winds and rains still knocked down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in saturated earth and stranded dozens of cars on flooded roads.\n\nBeryl, the earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nContributing to this report were Associated Press journalists Jim Vertuno in Austin, Texas; Sara Cline in Baton Rouge, Louisiana; Jeff Martin in Atlanta; and Sarah Brumfield in Silver Spring, Maryland.\n\nMore from this section\n\nNew Industrial Manufacturing Projects Third Month in a Row of Growth with 164 New Projects for June 2024\n\nDirect Mail Benchmark Report 2024 reveals 61% of marketers have increased direct mail investments in the last year\n\nEighteen homebuyer assistance programs offering up to $117,000 are available to help people with disabilities and family caregivers purchase or modify a home", "source": {"uri": "kulr8.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KULR-8 Local News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@kulr8.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "juan_a_lozano@kulr8.com", "name": "Juan A. {"uri": "2024-07-417511186", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:42:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:42:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T12:51:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/houston-residents-stew-and-swelter-after-storm-beryl-leaves-millions-without-power/article_892100e6-7878-5295-aab0-c048f09e1f93.html", "title": "Houston residents stew and swelter after storm Beryl leaves millions without power", "body": "The return of searing heat in the Houston area has deepened the misery for people still without power after Hurricane Beryl\n\nHOUSTON (AP) -- The return of searing heat in the Houston area has deepened the misery for people still without power after Hurricane Beryl left residents in search of places to cool off and fuel up as the extended outages strained one of the nation's largest cities.\n\nMore than 1.7 million homes and businesses in Texas lacked electricity Wednesday morning, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. State officials faced questions over whether the power utility that covers much of the area had sufficiently prepared.\n\nTexas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick said that a sports and event complex would be used to temporarily hold up to 250 hospital patients who are awaiting discharge but cannot be released to homes with no power.\n\nBeryl, which made landfall in Texas early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas -- and at least 11 in the Caribbean. It weakened as it moved deeper into the U.S. and early Wednesday was a post-tropical cyclone centered over northeastern Indiana.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, New York, Vermont, New Hampshire and Maine. The storm spawned suspected tornadoes in parts of Indiana and Kentucky.\n\nIn the Houston area, Beryl compounded and repeated the misery of May, when storms killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power.\n\nHigh temperatures Tuesday climbed into the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) with humidity that made it feel even hotter. Similar heat and humidity were expected Wednesday. The National Weather Service described the conditions as potentially dangerous, given the lack of power and air conditioning.\n\nPeople coped as best they could. Kyuta Allen took her family to a Houston community center to cool down and use the internet.\n\n\"During the day you can have the doors open, but at night you've got to board up and lock up -- lock yourself like into a sauna,\" she said.\n\nAn executive for CenterPoint Energy, which covers much of the Houston area, defended the utility's preparation and response.\n\n\"From my perspective, to have a storm pass at 3 p.m. in the afternoon, have those crews come in in the late evening, and have everything ready by 5 a.m. to go out and get out and start the workforce is rather impressive, because we're talking about thousands of crews,\" said Brad Tutunjian, vice president of regulatory policy.\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, stressed that restoring power was the top priority.\n\nPatrick, who is acting as governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is overseas, said nursing homes and assisted living centers were the highest priority. {"uri": "2024-07-416524660", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "17:10:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T17:10:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T04:04:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://www.trentonian.com/2024/07/09/beryl-leaves-hot-misery-in-the-houston-area-it-still-threatens-flooding-on-its-path-northward/", "title": "Beryl leaves hot misery in the Houston area. It still threatens flooding on its path northward", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- Many of the millions left without power after Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas, killing several people and unleashing flooding, sweltered and fretted Tuesday as the storm deprived them of air conditioning, food and water in dangerous heat.\n\nA heat advisory took effect through Wednesday in the Houston area and beyond, with temperatures expected to soar into the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) and humidity that could make it feel as hot as 105 degrees (40.5 Celsius).\n\n\"We can handle it, but not the kids,\" said Walter Perez, 49, as he arrived early Tuesday at celebrity pastor Joel Osteen's megachurch in Houston, which served as a cooling center and distributed 40-bottle packs of water to cars that drove up.\n\nPerez said he, his wife, their 3-year-old son and 3-week-old daughter, and his father-in-law retreated from their apartment after a night he described as \"bad, bad, bad, bad.\"\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas, officials said. At midday Tuesday, it was a post-tropical cyclone centered over Arkansas and was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flooding to a swath extending to the Great Lakes and Canada.\n\nMore than 2.2 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. For many, it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nFood spoiled in listless refrigerators in neighborhoods that pined for air conditioning. Long lines of cars and people queued up at any fast food restaurant, food truck or gas station that had power and was open.\n\nDamonte Oliver, 32, visited Osteen's Lakewood Church with his girlfriend and her mother. Their apartment had lost power for days after the May storm.\n\n\"I know they are trying to do their best to get everything back on. It's just a waiting game on how long it's going to take,\" he said before walking to a convenience store to buy cigarettes.\n\n\"I've got to calm down a little bit myself,\" Oliver said.\n\nIt could take days to fully return power in Texas after Beryl toppled 10 transmission lines. Top priorities for power restoration include nursing homes and assisted living centers, said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting as governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country. Sixteen hospitals were running on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nBeryl's strength at midday Tuesday -- with sustained winds near 30 mph (48 kph) -- wasn't expected to change much in the next two days. It was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flash flooding from the lower and mid-Mississippi Valley to the Great Lakes into Wednesday, the National Weather Service said.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana and Michigan. A few tornadoes were possible in Missouri, Tennessee, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana and Ohio, forecasters said.\n\nWhen Beryl made landfall, it was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean. But its winds and rains still knocked down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in saturated earth and stranded dozens of cars on flooded roads.\n\nBeryl, the earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 hurricane in the Atlantic, caused at least 11 deaths as it passed through the Caribbean on its way to Texas. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\n___\n\nContributing to this report were Associated Press journalists Jim Vertuno in Austin, Texas; Sara Cline in Baton Rouge, Louisiana; Jeff Martin in Atlanta; and Sarah Brumfield in Silver Spring, Maryland.", "source": {"uri": "8219284838", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "19:30:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T19:30:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T19:30:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.delcotimes.com/2024/07/10/frustration-builds-in-houston-as-utility-struggles-to-restore-power-cut-by-hurricane-beryl/", "title": "Frustration builds in Houston as utility struggles to restore power cut by Hurricane Beryl", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- Houston's biggest utility came under mounting pressure Wednesday over its response to Hurricane Beryl, as nearly 1.4 million area homes and businesses remained without power and residents searched for places to cool off, fuel up and find something to eat.\n\nCity Council member Abbie Kamin called the extended lack of power a \"life safety concern.\"\n\n\"We say 'everything we can do' to get the lights back on. In my opinion, respectfully, they should be on,\" Kamin told a CenterPoint Energy executive during a council meeting.\n\n\"This was a Category 1 (storm),\" Kamin said, referring to the weakest type of hurricane. \"We know that this severe weather, the extreme weather due to climate change, is real and we've known for some time.\"\n\nPower outages peaked at 2.7 million customers after the storm made landfall in Texas on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. Brad Tutunjian, vice president for regulatory policy for CenterPoint Energy, defended the company's response and told council members that more than 1 million customers had their power restored by Wednesday morning, although the company's online tracker put the figure at just under a million at the time.\n\n\"To me, I think that's a monumental number right there,\" he said.\n\nThe company has acknowledged that most of the 12,000 workers it brought in to help the recovery effort were not in the Houston area when the storm arrived. Initial forecasts had the storm blowing ashore much farther south along Gulf Coast, near the Texas-Mexico border, before heading toward Houston.\n\nThe company would not ask third-party workers from other companies and municipalities to pre-position and \"ride out\" the storm, \"because that is not safe,\" he said.\n\n\"We ask you to get as close as possible, so you can respond as efficiently as practical,\" he said of the instructions given to the workers.\n\nTutunjian noted how difficult it is to quickly restore power that was cut off by falling trees and branches.\n\n\"When we have storms such as this, with the tree completely coming down ... taking out our lines and our poles, that's where all the time comes in to do the restoration work,\" he said.\n\nCouncil members pressed Tutunjian about why the company, which has been the Houston area for about 100 years, hasn't lain more of its power lines underground. He replied that it has been laying all new lines underground in residential areas for decades.\n\nTwo council members said they received a text about a house that burned down after reporting a downed power line. The texts reported the fire department said it could not do anything, and the utility company did not respond.\n\nBeryl has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas -- and at least 11 in the Caribbean. It weakened as it moved deeper into the U.S. and early Wednesday was a post-tropical cyclone centered over northeastern Indiana.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, New York, Vermont, New Hampshire and Maine. The storm spawned suspected tornadoes in parts of Indiana and Kentucky.\n\nIn the Houston area, Beryl compounded and repeated the misery of May, when storms killed eight people and left nearly a million customers without power.\n\nHigh temperatures in Houston on Wednesday were expected to climb into the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius), with humidity making it feel even hotter.\n\nPeople coped as best they could. Kyuta Allen took her family to a Houston community center to cool down and use the internet.\n\n\"During the day, you can have the doors open. But at night, you've got to board up and lock up -- lock yourself like into a sauna,\" she said.\n\nRaquel Desimone, who sought relief in a cooling center, has lived in the Houston area since about 2000 and has been through multiple hurricanes and tropical storms. Still, was surprised and frustrated having to scrambled yet again for power and shelter from the heat.\n\n\"I went through Rita, Ike, Imelda and Harvey,\" Desimone said. \"That the infrastructure can't handle a basic storm, leaving for a Category 1, (it) is sort of crazy to me that I'm having to do this.\"\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, stressed that restoring power was the top priority.\n\nTexas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting as governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is overseas, said nursing homes and assisted living centers were the highest priority. Sixteen hospitals ran on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nState officials planned to use a sports and event complex to temporarily hold up to 250 hospital patients who are awaiting discharge but cannot be released to homes with no power.\n\nPatrick said Tuesday that he would wait until after the recovery effort to focus on CenterPoint's response and whether the company was poorly prepared.\n\n\"CenterPoint will have to answer for themselves, if they were prepared, if they were positions. Their company is responsible for that. The state was in position,\" he said. \"I'll tell you whether I'm satisfied or not when I have a full report of where their crews were when they were asked to come in.\"", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8217825194", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "01:10:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T01:10:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T01:08:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/ap/national/frustrations-mount-in-the-houston-heat-after-beryl-moves-on-and-leaves-millions-without-power/article_70fdf399-02cd-5a35-a49a-603776100241.html", "title": "Frustrations mount in the Houston heat after Beryl moves on and leaves millions without power", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- The return of soaring heat in Houston on Tuesday deepened the misery for millions of people still without power after Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas and left residents in search of places to cool off and fuel up as the extended outages strained one of the nation's largest cities.\n\nFrustration mounted that Houston appeared to buckle under a storm less powerful than previous ones. State officials faced questions over whether Houston's power utility had sufficiently prepared, including one who said he would withhold judgement until after the lights are back on.\n\nHospitals also started to feel the pinch: Nearly 36 hours after Beryl made landfall, Texas' lieutenant governor said a sports and event complex would be used to temporarily hold up to 250 patients who are awaiting discharge but cannot be released to homes with no power.\n\nPeople coped as best they could.\n\n\"We can handle it, but not the kids,\" said Walter Perez, 49, as he arrived early Tuesday at celebrity pastor Joel Osteen's megachurch in Houston, which served as a cooling center and distributed 40-bottle packs of water.\n\nPerez said his family -- including his wife, a 3-year-old son, a 3-week-old daughter and his father-in-law -- retreated from their apartment after a night he described as \"bad, bad, bad, bad.\"\n\nHighs in the Houston on Tuesday climbed back into the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) and humidity that could make it feel even hotter. The National Weather Service described the conditions as potentially dangerous given the lack of power and air conditioning.\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas -- and at least 11 in the Caribbean.\n\nNearly 2 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. For many, it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nFood spoiled in listless refrigerators in neighborhoods that pined for air conditioning. Long lines of cars and people queued up at any fast food restaurant, food truck or gas station that had power and was open.\n\nPatrons lined up on one block to eat at KFC, Jack in the Box or Denny's -- or just to get a few minutes in some cooler air. Dwight Yell, 54, had power at his house but took a disabled neighbor, who did not, to Denny's for some food.\n\nHe complained that city and state officials did not alert residents well enough to a storm initially projected to land much farther down the coast: \"They didn't give us enough warning, where maybe we could go get gas or prepare to go out of town if the lights go out.\"\n\nRobin Taylor, who got takeout from Denny's, was getting tired of the same old struggle. She has been living a hotel since her home was damaged by the storms in May. When Beryl hit, her hotel room flooded.\n\nShe was angry that Houston didn't appear prepared to handle the Category 1 storm after it had weathered much stronger ones in the past.\n\nToday's Top Headlines\n\nStory continues below\n\nSC restaurateurs charged with bilking federal pandemic loan programs out of $591K A good neighbor's bad decision. Summerville man dies after placing firework atop his head. 'Mamma Mia!' Another celebrity in Charleston, this time at a 'Southern Charm' star's shop Dick Harpootlian leading charge to have Group Therapy, Saloon's liquor licenses revoked What to know about Charleston's Emma Navarro, and how to watch her today at Wimbledon Ikea's parent is feeling sunny and energized about a rural SC county Bankrupt apparel maker spun out of SC textile mill owner sizes up its options Meet Florence's longest serving worker, who kept police cars running for 50 years Recruiting: Good news, bad news for South Carolina football What is SC's largest city? The answer is more complicated than you might think.\n\n\"No WiFi, no power, and it's hot outside. That's dangerous for people. That's really the big issue,\" Taylor said. \"People will die in this heat in their homes.\"\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, emphasized that restoring power was the top priority. CenterPoint Energy in Houston has said it aims to restore power to 1 million customers by the end of Wednesday.\n\nBut for others, getting the lights back could take several more days or longer. Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is serving as acting governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is oveseas, said nursing homes and assisted living centers were the highest priority. Sixteen hospitals were running on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nPatrick urged utilities to restore power quickly and said he would evaluate later whether they did enough before the storm.\n\nBrad Tutunjian, vice president of regulatory policy with CenterPoint Energy, said at a media briefing on Tuesday that the utility was fully prepared for the storm and that because the storm didn't move out of the area until Monday afternoon, it took until early Tuesday to get a large number of crews out and working.\n\nAn executive for CenterPoint Energy, which covers much of the Houston area, defended the utility's preparation and response.\n\n\"From my perspective to have a storm pass at 3 p.m. in the afternoon, have those crews come in in the late evening, and have everything ready by 5 a.m. to go out and get out and start the workforce is rather impressive because we're talking about thousands of crews,\" Brad Tutunjian, vice president of regulatory policy with CenterPoint Energy, said at a media briefing on Tuesday .\n\nKyuta Allen brought her family to a Houston community center to cool down and use the internet for work and the night classes she takes online.\n\n\"During the day you can have the doors open but at night you've got to board up and lock up - lock yourself like into a sauna,\" she said.\n\nLouisiana Gov. Jeff Landry issued a state of emergency Tuesday afternoon for part of that state after trees were knocked down, homes were damaged and thousands lost power.\n\nWhen Beryl made landfall, it was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean.\n\nBeryl was the earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 in the Atlantic. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nContributing to this {"uri": "8217496480", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "18:55:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T18:55:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T18:55:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://lethbridgenewsnow.com/2024/07/09/beryl-leaves-hot-misery-in-the-houston-area-it-still-threatens-flooding-on-its-path-northward/", "title": "Beryl leaves hot misery in the Houston area. It still threatens flooding on its path northward", "body": "Perez said he, his wife, their 3-year-old son and 3-week-old daughter, and his father-in-law retreated from their apartment after a night he described as \"bad, bad, bad, bad.\"\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas -- and at least 11 in the Caribbean. At midday Tuesday, it was a post-tropical cyclone centered over Arkansas and was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flooding to a swath extending to the Great Lakes and Canada.\n\nMore than 2.1 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. For many, it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, said at a news conference with other officials that restoring power is the No. 1 priority. And in Washington, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said President Joe Biden approved a major disaster declaration. Emergency crews hope to have power restored to another 1 million people by the end of the day, she said.\n\nFood spoiled in listless refrigerators in neighborhoods that pined for air conditioning. Long lines of cars and people queued up at any fast food restaurant, food truck or gas station that had power and was open.\n\nDamonte Oliver, 32, visited Osteen's Lakewood Church with his girlfriend and her mother. Their apartment had lost power for days after the May storm.\n\n\"I know they are trying to do their best to get everything back on. It's just a waiting game on how long it's going to take,\" he said before walking to a convenience store to buy cigarettes.\n\n\"I've got to calm down a little bit myself,\" Oliver said.\n\nIt could take days to fully return power in Texas after Beryl toppled 10 transmission lines. Top priorities for power restoration include nursing homes and assisted living centers, said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting as governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country. Sixteen hospitals were running on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nBeryl's strength at midday Tuesday -- with sustained winds near 30 mph (48 kph) -- wasn't expected to change much in the next two days. It was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flash flooding from the lower and mid-Mississippi Valley to the Great Lakes into Wednesday, the National Weather Service said.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana and Michigan. A few tornadoes were possible in Missouri, Tennessee, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana and Ohio, forecasters said.\n\nWhen Beryl made landfall, it was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean. But its winds and rains still knocked down hundreds of trees that had already been teetering in saturated earth and stranded dozens of cars on flooded roads.\n\nBeryl was the earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 in the Atlantic. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed over $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\n___\n\nContributing {"uri": "8217758052", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "23:38:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T23:38:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T23:36:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.stltoday.com/news/nation-world/weather/frustrations-mount-in-the-houston-heat-after-beryl-moves-on-and-leaves-millions-without-power/article_b02ddfb6-5aa9-5cc6-89cd-e08ffa895f7c.html", "title": "Frustrations mount in the Houston heat after Beryl moves on and leaves millions without power", "body": "HOUSTON -- Many of the millions left without power after Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas sweltered and grumbled Tuesday as the storm gutted access to air conditioning, food and water while smothering heat and humidity draped over the nation's fourth-largest city.\n\nFrustration mounted that Houston appeared to buckle under a storm not as powerful as previous ones. State officials were questioned whether utilities were prepared in advance, and at least one said they would withhold judgement until after the lights were turned back on.\n\nA heat advisory took effect through Wednesday in the Houston area and beyond, with temperatures expected to soar into the 90s and humidity that could make it feel as hot as 105 degrees. The National Weather Service described the conditions as potentially dangerous given the lack of power and air conditioning.\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths and at least 11 in the Caribbean. At midday Tuesday, it was a post-tropical cyclone centered over Arkansas and was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flooding to a swath extending to the Great Lakes and Canada.\n\nPi Pizzeria closing last remaining location, in St. Louis' Central West End McClellan: Downtown St. Louis is a casualty of the do-gooder war Hulk Hogan starts selling his new Real American Beer in Missouri, competing with Bud Light Tropical Storm Beryl could hit St. Louis area with 4 inches of rain or more BenFred: Why Jordan Walker's name will provide hot-stove fodder as Cardinals near trade deadline Wentzville schools investigated board members for alleged retaliation, ethics violations Parades, fireworks and parties: Your guide to July 4th in St. Louis Several St. Louis-area cities move fireworks shows to Friday. Others cancel events. Messenger: She sold her house to help support her baby. Missouri's AG wants the money. Two dead in North County, 7 injured in downtown St. Louis during Fourth of July shootings Youth hockey coach turned 'dreams into a nightmare' in St. Louis area, abuse victim says Tipsheet: Jordan Montgomery's season goes from bad to worse in Arizona Rains, hail, storms in St. Louis area expected on July 4th Extra! Extra! Read all about Cardinals' comeback from 5-run deficit to outlast Nats in 11th Messenger: Judge fines St. Louis attorney for hiding documents on police shootings\n\nMore than 2 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday, down from a peak of more than 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. For many, it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nFood spoiled in powerless refrigerators in neighborhoods that pined for air conditioning. Long lines of cars and people queued up at any fast food restaurant, food truck or gas station that had power and was open.\n\nPatrons lined up on one block to eat at KFC, Jack in the Box or Denny's -- or just to get a few minutes in some cooler air.\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, said at a news conference with other officials that restoring power is the No. 1 priority. In Washington, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said President Joe Biden approved a major disaster declaration.\n\nEmergency crews hoped to have power restored to an additional 1 million people by the end of the day, she said.\n\nIt could take days to fully return power in Texas after Beryl toppled 10 transmission lines. Top priorities for power restoration include nursing homes and assisted living centers, said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting as governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country. Sixteen hospitals were on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nPatrick said he would evaluate later whether utilities had taken proper steps before the storm to mount a swift response.\n\nCenterPoint Energy, which covers much of the Houston area, said it would bring in about 12,000 workers from around the region to help restore power. A company spokesperson said those workers weren't staged in the Houston area before the storm hit, noting that forecasts initially predicted it would go much further south.\n\nKyuta Allen brought her family to a Houston community center to cool down and use the internet for work and the night classes she takes online.\n\n\"You can't really get a lot of stuff done when you are hot,\" she said, adding it is also hard to sleep in the heat.\n\n\"During the day you can have the doors open but at night you've got to board up and lock up -- lock yourself like into a sauna,\" she said.\n\nLesley Briones, a Harris County commissioner, who visited a community center, said she's been told of people waiting hours to get gas.\n\n\"It's catastrophic when you lose everything in your fridge and you are living check to check,\" Briones said.\n\nBeryl's strength at midday Tuesday -- with sustained winds near 30 mph -- wasn't expected to change much in the next two days. It was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flash flooding from the lower and mid-Mississippi Valley to the Great Lakes into Wednesday, the National Weather Service said.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana and Michigan. A few tornadoes were possible in Missouri, Tennessee, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana and Ohio, forecasters said.\n\nLouisiana Gov. Jeff Landry issued a state of emergency Tuesday afternoon for part of that state after trees were knocked down, homes were damaged and thousands lost power.\n\nWhen Beryl made landfall, it was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean. But its winds and rains still knocked down hundreds of trees that already teetered in saturated earth and stranded dozens of cars on flooded roads.\n\nBeryl was the earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 in the Atlantic. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed more than $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\n0 Comments", "source": {"uri": "stltoday.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "St. Louis Post-Dispatch"}, "authors": [{"uri": "juan_a_lozano@stltoday.com", "name": "Juan A. re-classified to a tropical storm on Monday - knocked out 10 long-distance transmission lines and toppled hundreds of trees, some of which took down local power lines.\n\nAlmost two million of those affected are customers of CenterPoint Energy, Houston's main electricity provider, which has said it hopes to restore services to half of them by Thursday, according to NBC, Sky's US partner, quoting PowerOutage.us.\n\nTexas lieutenant governor Dan Patrick said the company was bringing in thousands of additional workers to restore power, and prioritising places such as nursing homes and assisted living centres.\n\nMr Patrick said: \"We're not past any difficult conditions,\" and predicted a \"multiple day process to get power restored\".\n\nDozens of vehicles were left stranded on flooded roads as heavy rains swamped parts of the state.\n\nHouston, the fourth-largest city in the US, suffered much of the damage as Beryl's rains pounded coastal areas, but there were no immediate reports of structural damage.\n\nVideo of the dramatic rescue of man who had climbed to the roof of his pickup truck after it got trapped in fast-flowing waters was broadcast by local TV stations.\n\nEmergency crews used an extension ladder from a fire truck to drop him a life jacket and a rope before moving him to dry land, one of at least 25 water rescues in the city, mostly for people with vehicles stuck in floodwaters.\n\nIn May, eight people died and nearly one million were left without power as a previous set of storms hit the city.\n\nHouston mayor John Whitmire said: \"First responders are putting their lives at risk. That's what they're trained for. It's working.\"\n\nDamaging winds and flash flooding would continue as Beryl pushes inland, forecasters said.\n\nWith parts of the area sweltering in a heatwave, restoring power is an urgent requirement, even though temperatures cooled slightly with the storm.\n\nBeryl weakened further into a tropical depression, the National Hurricane Centre said on Monday evening, before moving eastwards, putting several other states at risk.\n\nRead more:\n\n'We were all scared,' says Hurricane Beryl survivor\n\nLas Vegas hits all-time record high temperature\n\nAlec Baldwin film set shooting trial begins\n\nIt is forecast to weaken further to become a post-tropical cyclone on Tuesday.\n\nAs it moved inland, the storm threatened to create tornadoes and the US National Weather {"uri": "2024-07-417636215", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "15:31:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T15:31:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T15:10:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://www.fox13memphis.com/news/houston-residents-stew-and-swelter-after-storm-beryl-leaves-millions-without-power/article_9347d786-3ece-11ef-9543-3b7969aa781b.html", "title": "Houston residents stew and swelter after storm Beryl leaves millions without power", "body": "HOUSTON (AP) -- The return of searing heat in the Houston area has deepened the misery for people still without power after Hurricane Beryl left residents in search of places to cool off and fuel up as the extended outages strained one of the nation's largest cities.\n\nMore than 1.7 million homes and businesses in Texas lacked electricity Wednesday morning, down from a peak of over 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. State officials faced questions over whether the power utility that covers much of the area had sufficiently prepared.\n\nTexas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick said that a sports and event complex would be used to temporarily hold up to 250 hospital patients who are awaiting discharge but cannot be released to homes with no power.\n\nBeryl, which made landfall in Texas early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths -- one in Louisiana and six in Texas -- and at least 11 in the Caribbean. It weakened as it moved deeper into the U.S. and early Wednesday was a post-tropical cyclone centered over northeastern Indiana.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, New York, Vermont, New Hampshire and Maine. The storm spawned suspected tornadoes in parts of Indiana and Kentucky.\n\nIn the Houston area, Beryl compounded and repeated the misery of May, when storms killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power.\n\nHigh temperatures Tuesday climbed into the 90s (above 32.2 Celsius) with humidity that made it feel even hotter. Similar heat and humidity were expected Wednesday. The National Weather Service described the conditions as potentially dangerous, given the lack of power and air conditioning.\n\nPeople coped as best they could. Kyuta Allen took her family to a Houston community center to cool down and use the internet.\n\n\"During the day you can have the doors open, but at night you've got to board up and lock up -- lock yourself like into a sauna,\" she said.\n\nAn executive for CenterPoint Energy, which covers much of the Houston area, defended the utility's preparation and response.\n\n\"From my perspective, to have a storm pass at 3 p.m. in the afternoon, have those crews come in in the late evening, and have everything ready by 5 a.m. to go out and get out and start the workforce is rather impressive, because we're talking about thousands of crews,\" said Brad Tutunjian, vice president of regulatory policy.\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, stressed that restoring power was the top priority.\n\nPatrick, who is acting as governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is overseas, said nursing homes and assisted living centers were the highest priority. Sixteen hospitals ran on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nDownload the FOX13 Memphis app to receive alerts from breaking news in your {"uri": "8217746703", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "23:22:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T23:22:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T23:20:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://wcfcourier.com/news/nation-world/weather/frustrations-mount-in-the-houston-heat-after-beryl-moves-on-and-leaves-millions-without-power/article_7c79fa4f-a006-5cf1-b886-6ec7b87e8dfa.html", "title": "Frustrations mount in the Houston heat after Beryl moves on and leaves millions without power", "body": "HOUSTON -- Many of the millions left without power after Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas sweltered and grumbled Tuesday as the storm gutted access to air conditioning, food and water while smothering heat and humidity draped over the nation's fourth-largest city.\n\nFrustration mounted that Houston appeared to buckle under a storm not as powerful as previous ones. State officials were questioned whether utilities were prepared in advance, and at least one said they would withhold judgement until after the lights were turned back on.\n\nA heat advisory took effect through Wednesday in the Houston area and beyond, with temperatures expected to soar into the 90s and humidity that could make it feel as hot as 105 degrees. The National Weather Service described the conditions as potentially dangerous given the lack of power and air conditioning.\n\nPeople are also reading... John Deere closes on land for 1.2 million-square-foot Indiana warehouse Man shot outside bar in downtown Waterloo Ag expert: Deere prepares for future losses due to downturned ag economy Woman dead in single-vehicle accident Woman identified in fatal crash Waterloo man arrested after alleged assault at Sunnyside County Club Woman arrested for assaulting multiple people, punching officer, ramming property in Waterloo Restaurant inspection update: Grimy blenders, mouse droppings and bad sushi Firecracker Fourth of July celebrations planned throughout Cedar Valley Drivers urged to slow down or steer clear of construction zone John Eveland: Waterloo businessman makes lasting impact in Cedar Valley community Bond remains same in pre-teen sex sting in Evansdale Child shot while playing at Waterloo's Lafayette Park Sunday night Walnut Ridge Church to move to Tower Park Drive, future uncertain for private school space College Football: Cedar Falls OL, second Tiger commits to Northern Iowa football program\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths and at least 11 in the Caribbean. At midday Tuesday, it was a post-tropical cyclone centered over Arkansas and was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flooding to a swath extending to the Great Lakes and Canada.\n\nMore than 2 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday, down from a peak of more than 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. For many, it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nFood spoiled in powerless refrigerators in neighborhoods that pined for air conditioning. Long lines of cars and people queued up at any fast food restaurant, food truck or gas station that had power and was open.\n\nPatrons lined up on one block to eat at KFC, Jack in the Box or Denny's -- or just to get a few minutes in some cooler air.\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, said at a news conference with other officials that restoring power is the No. 1 priority. In Washington, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said President Joe Biden approved a major disaster declaration.\n\nEmergency crews hoped to have power restored to an additional 1 million people by the end of the day, she said.\n\nIt could take days to fully return power in Texas after Beryl toppled 10 transmission lines. Top priorities for power restoration include nursing homes and assisted living centers, said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting as governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country. Sixteen hospitals were on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nPatrick said he would evaluate later whether utilities had taken proper steps before the storm to mount a swift response.\n\nCenterPoint Energy, which covers much of the Houston area, said it would bring in about 12,000 workers from around the region to help restore power. A company spokesperson said those workers weren't staged in the Houston area before the storm hit, noting that forecasts initially predicted it would go much further south.\n\nKyuta Allen brought her family to a Houston community center to cool down and use the internet for work and the night classes she takes online.\n\n\"You can't really get a lot of stuff done when you are hot,\" she said, adding it is also hard to sleep in the heat.\n\n\"During the day you can have the doors open but at night you've got to board up and lock up -- lock yourself like into a sauna,\" she said.\n\nLesley Briones, a Harris County commissioner, who visited a community center, said she's been told of people waiting hours to get gas.\n\n\"It's catastrophic when you lose everything in your fridge and you are living check to check,\" Briones said.\n\nBeryl's strength at midday Tuesday -- with sustained winds near 30 mph -- wasn't expected to change much in the next two days. It was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flash flooding from the lower and mid-Mississippi Valley to the Great Lakes into Wednesday, the National Weather Service said.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana and Michigan. A few tornadoes were possible in Missouri, Tennessee, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana and Ohio, forecasters said.\n\nLouisiana Gov. Jeff Landry issued a state of emergency Tuesday afternoon for part of that state after trees were knocked down, homes were damaged and thousands lost power.\n\nWhen Beryl made landfall, it was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean. But its winds and rains still knocked down hundreds of trees that already teetered in saturated earth and stranded dozens of cars on flooded roads.\n\nBeryl was the earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 in the Atlantic. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed more than $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nFrom the Caribbean to Texas, Hurricane Beryl leaves a trail of destruction 0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nLocal Weather\n\nGet the daily forecast and severe weather alerts in your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.", "source": {"uri": "wcfcourier.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Waterloo Cedar Falls Courier"}, "authors": [{"uri": "juan_a_lozano@wcfcourier.com", "name": "Juan A. {"uri": "8217743024", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "23:16:29", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T23:16:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T23:15:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://mcdowellnews.com/news/nation-world/weather/frustrations-mount-in-the-houston-heat-after-beryl-moves-on-and-leaves-millions-without-power/article_702ea667-4077-59cb-9d78-9d49157c5d2c.html", "title": "Frustrations mount in the Houston heat after Beryl moves on and leaves millions without power", "body": "HOUSTON -- Many of the millions left without power after Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas sweltered and grumbled Tuesday as the storm gutted access to air conditioning, food and water while smothering heat and humidity draped over the nation's fourth-largest city.\n\nFrustration mounted that Houston appeared to buckle under a storm not as powerful as previous ones. State officials were questioned whether utilities were prepared in advance, and at least one said they would withhold judgement until after the lights were turned back on.\n\nA heat advisory took effect through Wednesday in the Houston area and beyond, with temperatures expected to soar into the 90s and humidity that could make it feel as hot as 105 degrees. The National Weather Service described the conditions as potentially dangerous given the lack of power and air conditioning.\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths and at least 11 in the Caribbean. At midday Tuesday, it was a post-tropical cyclone centered over Arkansas and was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flooding to a swath extending to the Great Lakes and Canada.\n\nPeople are also reading... 3 dead in plane crash near McDowell, Rutherford county line Plane crashes in McDowell; emergency crews ask people to avoid Brackett Town Road Marion man meets McDowell paramedic who saved his life 24 years ago Toddler killed by truck at Steel Creek campground north of Morganton Body found Sunday was Marion man; cause of death pending toxicology report Golden Hour Charcuterie opens in Marion's Depot District Nebo woman charged with break-in Man found dead near Lake James in McDowell County McDowell Little League crowns two champions; league to host a baseball state tournament Burkemont Mountain in Morganton ablaze with 30-acre wildfire When are the 4th of July fireworks, parades in McDowell County? Delta Apparel declares bankruptcy, closing four NC plants May storm in Marion declared disaster by governor McDowell calendar: Independence Day parades set for today Local high school athletes very busy during June live period\n\nMore than 2 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday, down from a peak of more than 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. For many, it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nFood spoiled in powerless refrigerators in neighborhoods that pined for air conditioning. Long lines of cars and people queued up at any fast food restaurant, food truck or gas station that had power and was open.\n\nPatrons lined up on one block to eat at KFC, Jack in the Box or Denny's -- or just to get a few minutes in some cooler air.\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, said at a news conference with other officials that restoring power is the No. 1 priority. In Washington, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said President Joe Biden approved a major disaster declaration.\n\nEmergency crews hoped to have power restored to an additional 1 million people by the end of the day, she said.\n\nIt could take days to fully return power in Texas after Beryl toppled 10 transmission lines. Top priorities for power restoration include nursing homes and assisted living centers, said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting as governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country. Sixteen hospitals were on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nPatrick said he would evaluate later whether utilities had taken proper steps before the storm to mount a swift response.\n\nCenterPoint Energy, which covers much of the Houston area, said it would bring in about 12,000 workers from around the region to help restore power. A company spokesperson said those workers weren't staged in the Houston area before the storm hit, noting that forecasts initially predicted it would go much further south.\n\nKyuta Allen brought her family to a Houston community center to cool down and use the internet for work and the night classes she takes online.\n\n\"You can't really get a lot of stuff done when you are hot,\" she said, adding it is also hard to sleep in the heat.\n\n\"During the day you can have the doors open but at night you've got to board up and lock up -- lock yourself like into a sauna,\" she said.\n\nLesley Briones, a Harris County commissioner, who visited a community center, said she's been told of people waiting hours to get gas.\n\n\"It's catastrophic when you lose everything in your fridge and you are living check to check,\" Briones said.\n\nBeryl's strength at midday Tuesday -- with sustained winds near 30 mph -- wasn't expected to change much in the next two days. It was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flash flooding from the lower and mid-Mississippi Valley to the Great Lakes into Wednesday, the National Weather Service said.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana and Michigan. A few tornadoes were possible in Missouri, Tennessee, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana and Ohio, forecasters said.\n\nLouisiana Gov. Jeff Landry issued a state of emergency Tuesday afternoon for part of that state after trees were knocked down, homes were damaged and thousands lost power.\n\nWhen Beryl made landfall, it was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean. But its winds and rains still knocked down hundreds of trees that already teetered in saturated earth and stranded dozens of cars on flooded roads.\n\nBeryl was the earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 in the Atlantic. In Jamaica, officials said Monday that island residents will have to contend with food shortages after Beryl destroyed more than $6.4 million in crops and supporting infrastructure.\n\nFrom the Caribbean to Texas, Hurricane Beryl leaves a trail of destruction Local Weather\n\nGet the daily forecast and severe weather alerts in your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.", "source": {"uri": "mcdowellnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "McDowellNews.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": "juan_a_lozano@mcdowellnews.com", "name": "Juan A. {"uri": "8217752442", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "23:29:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T23:29:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T23:28:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5647059082984924, "url": "https://journalstar.com/news/nation-world/weather/frustrations-mount-in-the-houston-heat-after-beryl-moves-on-and-leaves-millions-without-power/article_2d7a7b1a-8875-5e60-9bf1-b4469abf1da1.html", "title": "Frustrations mount in the Houston heat after Beryl moves on and leaves millions without power", "body": "HOUSTON -- Many of the millions left without power after Hurricane Beryl crashed into Texas sweltered and grumbled Tuesday as the storm gutted access to air conditioning, food and water while smothering heat and humidity draped over the nation's fourth-largest city.\n\nFrustration mounted that Houston appeared to buckle under a storm not as powerful as previous ones. State officials were questioned whether utilities were prepared in advance, and at least one said they would withhold judgement until after the lights were turned back on.\n\nA heat advisory took effect through Wednesday in the Houston area and beyond, with temperatures expected to soar into the 90s and humidity that could make it feel as hot as 105 degrees. The National Weather Service described the conditions as potentially dangerous given the lack of power and air conditioning.\n\nBeryl, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, has been blamed for at least seven U.S. deaths and at least 11 in the Caribbean. At midday Tuesday, it was a post-tropical cyclone centered over Arkansas and was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flooding to a swath extending to the Great Lakes and Canada.\n\nPeople are also reading... Crete, Nebraska: 7 shot in 'welcoming community' by neighbor who 'hated everybody' Lincoln-based Valentino's closes A Street pizza shop Matt Rhule's 'right-hand man' leaves Nebraska football's coaching staff Social media influencer Cam Wilder draws more than 1,000 to Lincoln park Big Chicken restaurant, founded by NBA star Shaquille O'Neal, is coming to Omaha Lincoln man shot and killed Friday night in business parking lot Soft-serve survivors: How Zesto endured in Nebraska after its ice-cream empire melted Lincoln police identify victim, provide details from Friday night shooting Body of missing 17-year-old who jumped into Platte River to save girl found, authorities say Nebraska lawmakers 'bewildered' as Gov. Pillen's 'high risk' special session nears Report: NFL coach emerges as Nebraska's potential replacement for Evan Cooper Lincoln's wind turbines blown up in northeast Lincoln South Dakota's No. 1 prospect commits to Nebraska football's 2025 class Downtown Lincoln facelift: Corridor enchantment plan prioritizes pedestrians 'Grateful and excited': Megan Conway finds a landing anchor chair at 10/11 in Lincoln\n\nMore than 2 million homes and businesses around Houston lacked electricity Tuesday, down from a peak of more than 2.7 million on Monday, according to PowerOutage.us. For many, it was a miserable repeat after storms in May killed eight people and left nearly 1 million without power amid flooded streets.\n\nFood spoiled in powerless refrigerators in neighborhoods that pined for air conditioning. Long lines of cars and people queued up at any fast food restaurant, food truck or gas station that had power and was open.\n\nPatrons lined up on one block to eat at KFC, Jack in the Box or Denny's -- or just to get a few minutes in some cooler air.\n\nNim Kidd, head of the state's division of emergency management, said at a news conference with other officials that restoring power is the No. 1 priority. In Washington, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said President Joe Biden approved a major disaster declaration.\n\nEmergency crews hoped to have power restored to an additional 1 million people by the end of the day, she said.\n\nIt could take days to fully return power in Texas after Beryl toppled 10 transmission lines. Top priorities for power restoration include nursing homes and assisted living centers, said Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting as governor while Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country. Sixteen hospitals were on generator power Tuesday morning, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nPatrick said he would evaluate later whether utilities had taken proper steps before the storm to mount a swift response.\n\nCenterPoint Energy, which covers much of the Houston area, said it would bring in about 12,000 workers from around the region to help restore power. A company spokesperson said those workers weren't staged in the Houston area before the storm hit, noting that forecasts initially predicted it would go much further south.\n\nKyuta Allen brought her family to a Houston community center to cool down and use the internet for work and the night classes she takes online.\n\n\"You can't really get a lot of stuff done when you are hot,\" she said, adding it is also hard to sleep in the heat.\n\n\"During the day you can have the doors open but at night you've got to board up and lock up -- lock yourself like into a sauna,\" she said.\n\nLesley Briones, a Harris County commissioner, who visited a community center, said she's been told of people waiting hours to get gas.\n\n\"It's catastrophic when you lose everything in your fridge and you are living check to check,\" Briones said.\n\nBeryl's strength at midday Tuesday -- with sustained winds near 30 mph -- wasn't expected to change much in the next two days. It was forecast to bring heavy rains and possible flash flooding from the lower and mid-Mississippi Valley to the Great Lakes into Wednesday, the National Weather Service said.\n\nA flood watch was in effect for parts of Oklahoma, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana and Michigan. A few tornadoes were possible in Missouri, Tennessee, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana and Ohio, forecasters said.\n\nLouisiana Gov. Jeff Landry issued a state of emergency Tuesday afternoon for part of that state after trees were knocked down, homes were damaged and thousands lost power.\n\nWhen Beryl made landfall, it was far less powerful than the Category 5 behemoth that tore a deadly path through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean. But its winds and rains still knocked down hundreds of trees that already teetered in saturated earth and stranded dozens of cars on flooded roads.\n\nBeryl was the earliest storm to develop into a Category 5 in the Atlantic. LOZANO\n\nAssociated Press\n\nSEVERE WEATHER\n\nMATAGORDA, Texas -- Tropical Storm Beryl unleashed heavy rains and powerful winds along the Texas coast Monday, knocking out power to more than 2 million homes and businesses and flooding streets with fast-rising waters as first responders raced to rescue stranded residents.\n\nBeryl already cut a deadly path through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean before making a turn, sweeping ashore as a Category 1 hurricane in Texas early Monday, then later weakening to a tropical storm. At least two people were killed. The National Hurricane Center said damaging winds and flash flooding will continue as Beryl continues pushing inland.\n\nMore than 2 million homes and businesses in the Houston area were without electricity, CenterPoint Energy officials said. Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is acting governor while Texas Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country, said crews cannot get out to restore it until the wind dies down.\n\nPeople are also reading... In flood-weary Houston, where previous storms already washed out neighborhoods, television stations on Monday broadcast the dramatic rescue of a man who climbed to the roof of his pickup truck after it got trapped in fast-flowing waters.\n\nEmergency crews used an extension ladder from a fire truck to drop him a life preserver and a tether before moving him to dry land.\n\nHouston officials said they performed at least 15 high-water rescues and more were ongoing.\n\nHouston was under a flashflood warning for most of the morning as heavy rain continued to soak the city. Flood warnings also were in effect across a wide stretch of the Texas coast, where a powerful storm surge pushed water ashore, and further inland as heavy rain continued to fall.\n\nVideo footage showed heavy street flooding in the barrier island city of Galveston.\n\nTwo people were killed after trees fell on their houses: a man in the Houston suburb of Humble and a woman in Harris County, authorities said.\n\nBeryl and the widespread power outages were just the latest weather blows for Houston, where nearly 1 million people lost power when deadly storms ripped through the area in May, {"uri": "2024-07-416866736", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "02:42:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T02:42:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T02:42:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.industriesnews.net/news/274448597/remnants-of-beryl-spread-inland-heat-causes-concern-in-texas", "title": "Remnants of Beryl spread inland; heat causes concern in Texas", "body": "The remnants of the storm that hit the southern United States as Hurricane Beryl spread heavy rains further inland Tuesday, after killing at least six people in Texas and one person in Louisiana. It has knocked out power to more than 3 million homes and businesses.\n\nThe U.S. National Hurricane Center forecast the center of the storm to move up to the Great Lakes in the coming days, spreading rain across Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois, Kentucky, Indiana, Tennessee, Ohio and Michigan.\n\nAuthorities in Texas warned it could take days to restore power. Houston, the fourth-largest city in the U.S., was among the areas hardest hit by the storm as it came ashore early Monday with maximum sustained winds of about 130 kilometers per hour (80 miles per hour).\n\nHouston residents now face dangerous heat with no electricity. A heat advisory was in effect through Wednesday in the area, with temperatures expected to surpass 32 degrees Celsius (90 Fahrenheit). The humidity would make the temperature feel like 40 degrees Celsius (104 Fahrenheit).\n\nAs of Tuesday morning, PowerOutage.us reported that over 2.3 million homes and businesses around Houston were without power. That number was over 2.7 million on Monday.\n\n\"Houstonians need to know we're working around the clock so you will be safe,\" said the city's mayor, John Whitmire.\n\nAn area of Houston, Texas, is flooded in the aftermath of Hurricane Beryl on July 8, 2024.\n\nThe White House said President Joe Biden expressed his condolences in a phone call late Monday with Whitmire and pledged support for the people of Texas in recovery efforts.\n\nAirlines canceled 1,300 flights, and oil companies pulled crews from rigs in the Gulf of Mexico.\n\nBefore hitting Texas, Beryl moved through the Caribbean, killing three people in Venezuela, three people in Grenada, three people in St. Vincent and the Grenadines and two people in Jamaica.\n\nBeryl also struck Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula before crossing the Gulf of Mexico and heading for Texas.\n\nThe storm set a record as the earliest to attain Category 5 strength during the Atlantic hurricane season, which runs from June to November.\n\nSome information for this story was provided by The Associated Press and Reuters.\n\nThe Voice of America provides news and information in more than 40 languages to an estimated weekly audience of over 326 million people. "https://cdn.bignewsnetwork.com/voa1720548319.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9716370", "eventUri": "eng-9716370", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": {"uri": "2024-07-415715989", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "04:11:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T04:11:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T04:09:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://www.bradenton.com/news/nation-world/national/article289868969.html", "title": "Beryl rips through Houston, killing 4 and knocking out power for millions", "body": "By J. David Goodman, Judson Jones and Shannon Sims NYT News Service/Syndicate Stories\n\nTropical Storm Beryl ripped a path of destruction through the heart of Houston on Monday, transforming roads into rivers, killing at least four people and knocking out power for more than 2 million customers across Texas.\n\nThe storm, which made landfall early Monday as a Category 1 hurricane, weakened as it passed over the city and continued its swirling march north.\n\nBut its relatively modest official strength undersold its power, local authorities said. As it churned through Houston, officials warned people to stay inside and away from windows, \"as though there was a tornado coming your way,\" Lina Hidalgo, the top official in Harris County, which includes Houston, cautioned residents.\n\nThe center passed just to the west of the city, meaning Houston received some of the worst of the storm as it spun counterclockwise.\n\nBy Monday afternoon, officials were beginning to assess the destruction as residents emerged to find a landscape of downed power lines, damaged homes, fallen trees and rippling water along the streets. The city's airports remained closed into the afternoon because of lingering strong winds.\n\nHoustonians have long been accustomed to power outages and strong weather. But Beryl, which began as an unusually powerful storm in the Caribbean, offered an ill omen, striking early in a hurricane season that has been predicted to be unusually active.\n\n\"The wind gusts were way stronger than I expected for a Cat 1,\" said Julie Kickham, who rode out the storm in the Montrose neighborhood of Houston. \"This makes me nervous for the rest of hurricane season.\"\n\nIt was the second time in less than two months that residents found their city battered by winds and plunged into darkness. Even before the hurricane season had started, an unexpectedly strong storm struck Houston and its surrounding suburbs in May, killing at least seven people and leaving hundreds of thousands without power for days.\n\nFar more were without power Monday: About 1 in 5 electricity customers in Texas had lost power by midday, with most of the more than 2.7 million outages at one utility, CenterPoint Energy, in the Houston area.\n\n\"I do not have power,\" Mayor John Whitmire said during a news conference. \"We're all in this together.\"\n\nOfficials warned that it could take days for many in the city to get their power and air conditioning back, with temperatures forecast to climb into the 90s on Tuesday. In areas where residents could afford them, the sounds of backup generators could be heard rumbling in the streets.\n\nTwo people were killed inside their homes, officials said, crushed under the weight of trees that had been knocked over in the winds. One was a man at home with his family in the Atascocita area north of Houston; the other, a 74-year-old woman, was killed in a northwestern neighborhood near Interstate 45, officials said.\n\nA third victim, a civilian employee of the Houston Police Department, drowned when his car became submerged in high water, Whitmire said. The employee had been exiting an interstate and went into a flooded underpass. Whitmire said the man had tried to call other members of the department for help, but they were not able to reach him in time.\n\nA fourth death, caused by a house fire on Monday morning, was also connected to the storm.\n\nIn Louisiana, a woman died when a tree fell on her home in Bossier Parish near the Texas border, the sheriff's office said in a Facebook post.\n\nNine others died after the storm hammered the Caribbean islands and Mexico's Yucat\u00e1n Peninsula last week.\n\nOn Monday night, Beryl fell to tropical depression status, according to the National Hurricane Center's 11 p.m. Eastern advisory. The storm was about 20 miles east-northeast of Tyler, Texas, with maximum sustained winds of 35 mph. It was moving north-northeast at 17 mph.\n\nAs with previous strong storms that have hit the city, Beryl transformed Houston's urban landscape.\n\nTrees blocked roadways. Toads, whose mating call is usually heard when the weather cools at night, sang in the daylight. Sections of highways filled with water that was whipped into white caps, looking like rough seas in the middle of the city.\n\nA rescue team using a crane pulled a man from a pickup truck that had become surrounded by rough and rising waters along Highway 288. At least eight people had been rescued from high water as of the middle of the day, said Thomas Hardin, an assistant police chief.\n\nSeveral of Houston's bayous, which help to drain water from the city during storms, were filled to their banks, or in some cases overtopped. The county's flood warning system showed several places where the bayous were over capacity, including one near downtown.\n\nThe fuel giant Marathon Petroleum said Monday that its Galveston Bay Refinery had briefly lost power during the storm, and that it was burning off excess gases as a safety measure.\n\nBut unlike during Hurricane Harvey in 2017, which stalled over the city and rained for days, Beryl moved through Houston relatively quickly, allowing the floodwaters to begin slowly receding by afternoon with no apparent large-scale industrial damage.\n\nBy later in the day, some coastal areas were beginning to emerge from the storm and return to their ordinary rhythms. In the city of Galveston, along the Gulf of Mexico, several people gathered in Robert's Lafitte bar, two blocks from the beach. The owner, Scott Butler, said the bar had no electricity but plenty to drink.\n\nThe National Weather Service Lake Charles confirmed a tornado near Jasper, Texas, at 11:11 a.m. local time with 30 to 40 homes damaged, according to Jasper County Judge Mark Allen. The tornado hit an apartment complex and nursing home facility.\n\nA tornado also touched down in the east Texas town of Timpson. And there were tornadoes near the Texas-Lousiana border.\n\nThe tornado risk will spread into southeast Missouri, northern Tennessee, Kentucky, southern Illinois, southern Indiana and Ohio on Tuesday.\n\nThe hurricane center said the fast-moving storm is expected to move into the Lower Mississippi Valley on Tuesday and then the Ohio Valley by Wednesday.\n\nHeavy rainfall of 3 to 5 inches, with locally higher amounts, is expected across portions of far southeastern Oklahoma, Arkansas and southern Missouri through Tuesday. Local flash and urban flooding are expected.", "source": {"uri": "bradenton.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Bradenton Herald"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri":
