{"uri": "2024-07-416944107", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "04:55:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T04:55:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T04:47:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://www.cnn.com/2024/07/10/weather/beryl-texas-power-outages-heat-wednesday/index.html", "title": "Miserable heat threatens millions of Texans who remain without power in the wake of storm Beryl", "body": "Staff at Lakewood Church hand out water and operate a cooling station in Houston, on July 9.\n\nLife-threatening heat is gripping southeast Texas, where nearly 2 million homes and businesses remain without power and air conditioning in the wake of storm Beryl's deadly and destructive landfall.\n\nRestoring electricity across the region is expected to take days - and in some cases weeks - after Beryl tore through the state Monday, flooding coastal communities, shredding homes and ripping down webs of power lines.\n\nHomes have become saunas and food languishes in warm refrigerators as about 1.7 million homes and businesses are still without power across southeast Texas, mainly from Galveston to north of Houston, according to PowerOutage.us. Phone and internet access has also been cut off in some communities, including Galveston.\n\n\"No WiFi, no power, and it's hot outside. That's dangerous for people. That's really the big issue,\" resident Robin Taylor told the AP. \"People will die in this heat in their homes.\"\n\nBeryl has been blamed for at least 10 deaths in Texas and Louisiana, mainly from fallen trees. However, two deaths in Houston's Harris County were the result of carbon monoxide poisoning, Texas emergency officials said, prompting warnings about the dangers using generators in areas where families are living and sleeping.\n\nCooling centers have opened across the region as temperatures creep into the 90s and heat indices reach 105 degrees in some areas. The heat index is a measurement of how the body feels under both heat and humidity.\n\nProlonged heat exposure poses significant health risks for people without adequate cooling and may be especially dangerous for Texans working outdoors to clear debris or damaged infrastructure. Heat also presents increased risks for the elderly, people with chronic medical conditions, homeless people and children.\n\nHospitals in Houston are at risk of overcrowding as they are unable to release patients to homes without power, prompting city officials to organize overflow beds in a sports stadium, Lt. Governor Dan Patrick said Tuesday.\n\nLong lines of cars and residents snaked out of fast food restaurants, food trucks and gas stations in the hopes of getting a few minutes of cool air or a bite to eat, according to the AP. Dwight Yell, 54, had power at his house but took a disabled neighbor, who did not, to Denny's for some food, the outlet reports.\n\nPatrick said he has stressed to CenterPoint Energy, the utility with the vast majority of outages in the area, the importance of restoring power as quickly as possible. The utility estimates about 80% of its customers in Houston are without power.\n\n\"It's tough to be in the heat. It's tough now to be able to refrigerate anything and tough not being able to go out and get food,\" Patrick said. \"I made sure that CenterPoint was aware of that and asked them to pull out all the stops to get power back as quickly as they could.\"\n\nBut CenterPoint officials say it could be several days before power is fully restored to its customers, though it hopes to restore service to 1 million customers by Wednesday night. As of Tuesday night, more than 1.3 million of its customers were still in the dark.\n\nPresident Joe Biden approved a federal emergency disaster declaration that will assist with some recovery costs, including clearing debris, Texas Governor Greg Abbott's office said.\n\nBut before long-term recovery efforts get underway, many frustrated residents are grappling with how to address their immediate needs.\n\n\"It's catastrophic when you lose everything in your fridge and you are living check to check,\" Harris County commissioner Lesley Briones told the AP.\n\nA home in Surfside Beach, Texas, was destroyed by Hurricane Beryl on July 8.\n\nMark Felix/AFP/Getty Images\n\nBeryl barrels into Northeast\n\nThough Beryl has substantially weakened since slamming into Texas as a Category 1 hurricane, its remnants still pose serious flood and tornado threats as they blow through the Ohio Valley and Northeast on Wednesday.\n\n\"On Wednesday, Beryl will continue northeastward through Ohio and into Ontario and rainfall will increase over northern areas of New York into New England,\" the National Weather Service said.\n\nMore than 2 million people are under flood watches across parts of the Midwest and Northeast. The watches will begin to expire for the Midwest by the end of the day Wednesday but will last in New England until Thursday morning.\n\nHeavy rainfall and winds could also churn up tornadoes, with the biggest threat spreading from northern Pennsylvania to southern New Hampshire and Vermont. That includes Syracuse and Albany, New York, and Scranton, Pennsylvania.\n\nBeryl whipped up more than a dozen tornadoes across Texas, Arkansas and Louisiana on Monday and two in Indiana and Kentucky on Tuesday. The National Weather Service in Shreveport, Louisiana, issued 67 tornado warnings on Monday, the most it has ever issued in a single day.\n\nCNN's Robert Shackelford, Joe Sutton, Sarah Dewberry and {"uri": "2024-07-416598369", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "18:38:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T18:38:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T18:13:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5254902243614197, "url": "https://ca.finance.yahoo.com/news/blacked-houston-feels-106f-gas-181309760.html", "title": "Blacked-Out Houston Feels Like 106F as Gas Lines Grow Post-Beryl", "body": "(Bloomberg) -- Houston is baking under a dangerous bout of heat as more than 2 million homes and businesses in the area remain without power after Hurricane Beryl and signs of fuel shortages begin to emerge.\n\nMost Read from Bloomberg\n\nThe region's heat index values -- a measure of how hot it feels when humidity is factored in -- are forecast to be as high as 106F (41C), the US National Weather Service said, warning of the possibility of illness under the extreme conditions. Actual temperatures will exceed 90F.\n\nWhile those temperatures aren't unusual for Houston at this time of year, scorching weather and humidity combined with the lack of power will make for brutal conditions, as people won't be able to turn on air conditioners for a break from the heat. The sweltering conditions and significant power outages are both expected to last for days.\n\nMore than 2.1 million homes and businesses are still without power in eastern Texas, mostly concentrated in the Houston area, according to PowerOutage.us. Over 75% of those are customers of CenterPoint Energy Inc., the Houston area's main electric utility. Mobile phone service was also beginning to falter in and around the city on Tuesday.\n\nActing Governor Dan Patrick said President Joe Biden has granted his request for a federal emergency disaster declaration, which will help cover some costs from the storm. At a press conference on Tuesday, Patrick said he's talked to CenterPoint several times and that the company is working to restore power safely and quickly.\n\nBased on current progress with damage assessment and initial restoration, CenterPoint expects to have power restored to 1 million impacted customers by the end of day on July 10, the company said in a statement late Monday.\n\nBeryl left the Houston metro area -- home to roughly 7 million -- a morass of flooded streets, downed trees, darkened traffic lights and power lines lying on the ground. At least three deaths were blamed on the storm. Beryl, a Category 1 hurricane when it struck Texas early Monday, already had killed 11 people in a week-long rampage across the Caribbean.\n\nDozens of cars were lined up at a west Houston Shell gasoline station Tuesday as frustrated residents sought fuel a day after Beryl made landfall.\n\nThey were lucky the station had power to pump the fuel -- some drivers had already been to multiple sites that were still closed. For Houston residents who've been through this before, the outages are becoming a regular, and infuriating, occurrence.\n\n\"I'm just tired of the power grid basically. We've been through too many storms for them not to know how to handle this,\" said Chrishique Harvey, 31. \"Every hard wind that blows, there's an outage.\"\n\nA spokesperson for grid operator Electric Reliability Council of Texas said the grid is running normally and any outages are local in nature. Ercot doesn't own power plants or transmission lines.\n\nKeion Logan, 24, a recent transplant from Chicago who was waiting in line for gas at the west Houston station, said he'd never been through a hurricane before -- and it was trying his resilience.\n\nThe \"electricity is off, running out of gas, my phone is dead,\" Logan said. \"I'm trying to survive, trying not to give in.\"\n\nThe Port of Houston closed Monday and will remain so Tuesday. Maersk, in a separate advisory, said some of its local trucking operations facilities are without power but it expects to resume operations once the Houston terminal gates open. BNSF Railway said its Pearland Intermodal Facility in Houston will be closed until it is safe to resume operations.\n\nBeryl, now a post-tropical cyclone, is sweeping across the South, with heavy rainfall expected in the Mississippi Valley. Tornadoes are possible across Missouri, Tennessee, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana and Ohio. Almost 30,000 homes and businesses are without power Tuesday in Louisiana, Tennessee and Arkansas.\n\nScorching weather is also set to bake western states this week, raising fire risks from Canada to Mexico. A million people are under an excessive heat warning in the US West, according to Bryan Jackson, a meteorologist at the Weather Prediction Center.\n\nLas Vegas on Sunday hit an all-time high temperature of 120F (49C). Palm Springs and Redding in California have also set records. The high in Sacramento may reach 110F on Thursday, while Furnace Creek -- the gateway to Death Valley -- is poised to hit 128F.\n\n--With assistance from Tope Alake, Millie Munshi, Naureen S. {"uri": "2024-07-416945886", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "04:57:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T04:57:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T04:47:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5215686559677124, "url": "https://keyt.com/news/weather-news/cnn-weather-environment/2024/07/09/miserable-heat-threatens-millions-of-texans-who-remain-without-power-in-the-wake-of-storm-beryl/", "title": "Miserable heat threatens millions of Texans who remain without power in the wake of storm Beryl", "body": "(CNN) -- Life-threatening heat is gripping southeast Texas, where nearly 2 million homes and businesses remain without power and air conditioning in the wake of storm Beryl's deadly and destructive landfall.\n\nRestoring electricity across the region is expected to take days - and in some cases weeks - after Beryl tore through the state Monday, flooding coastal communities, shredding homes and ripping down webs of power lines.\n\nHomes have become saunas and food languishes in warm refrigerators as about 1.7 million homes and businesses are still without power across southeast Texas, mainly from Galveston to north of Houston, according to PowerOutage.us. Phone and internet access has also been cut off in some communities, including Galveston.\n\n\"No WiFi, no power, and it's hot outside. That's dangerous for people. That's really the big issue,\" resident Robin Taylor told the AP. \"People will die in this heat in their homes.\"\n\nBeryl has been blamed for at least 10 deaths in Texas and Louisiana, mainly from fallen trees. However, two deaths in Houston's Harris County were the result of carbon monoxide poisoning, Texas emergency officials said, prompting warnings about the dangers using generators in areas where families are living and sleeping.\n\nCooling centers have opened across the region as temperatures creep into the 90s and heat indices reach 105 degrees in some areas. The heat index is a measurement of how the body feels under both heat and humidity.\n\nProlonged heat exposure poses significant health risks for people without adequate cooling and may be especially dangerous for Texans working outdoors to clear debris or damaged infrastructure. Heat also presents increased risks for the elderly, people with chronic medical conditions, homeless people and children.\n\nHospitals in Houston are at risk of overcrowding as they are unable to release patients to homes without power, prompting city officials to organize overflow beds in a sports stadium, Lt. Governor Dan Patrick said Tuesday.\n\nLong lines of cars and residents snaked out of fast food restaurants, food trucks and gas stations in the hopes of getting a few minutes of cool air or a bite to eat, according to the AP. Dwight Yell, 54, had power at his house but took a disabled neighbor, who did not, to Denny's for some food, the outlet reports.\n\nPatrick said he has stressed to CenterPoint Energy, the utility with the vast majority of outages in the area, the importance of restoring power as quickly as possible. The utility estimates about 80% of its customers in Houston are without power.\n\n\"It's tough to be in the heat. It's tough now to be able to refrigerate anything and tough not being able to go out and get food,\" Patrick said. \"I made sure that CenterPoint was aware of that and asked them to pull out all the stops to get power back as quickly as they could.\"\n\nBut CenterPoint officials say it could be several days before power is fully restored to its customers, though it hopes to restore service to 1 million customers by Wednesday night. As of Tuesday night, more than 1.3 million of its customers were still in the dark.\n\nPresident Joe Biden approved a federal emergency disaster declaration that will assist with some recovery costs, including clearing debris, Texas Governor Greg Abbott's office said.\n\nBut before long-term recovery efforts get underway, many frustrated residents are grappling with how to address their immediate needs.\n\n\"It's catastrophic when you lose everything in your fridge and you are living check to check,\" Harris County commissioner Lesley Briones told the AP.\n\nBeryl barrels into Northeast\n\nThough Beryl has substantially weakened since slamming into Texas as a Category 1 hurricane, its remnants still pose serious flood and tornado threats as they blow through the Ohio Valley and Northeast on Wednesday.\n\n\"On Wednesday, Beryl will continue northeastward through Ohio and into Ontario and rainfall will increase over northern areas of New York into New England,\" the National Weather Service said.\n\nMore than 2 million people are under flood watches across parts of the Midwest and Northeast. The watches will begin to expire for the Midwest by the end of the day Wednesday but will last in New England until Thursday morning.\n\nHeavy rainfall and winds could also churn up tornadoes, with the biggest threat spreading from northern Pennsylvania to southern New Hampshire and Vermont. That includes Syracuse and Albany, New York, and Scranton, Pennsylvania.\n\nBeryl whipped up more than a dozen tornadoes across Texas, Arkansas and Louisiana on Monday and two in Indiana and Kentucky on Tuesday. The National Weather Service in Shreveport, Louisiana, issued 67 tornado warnings on Monday, the most it has ever issued in a single day.\n\nCNN's Robert Shackelford, Joe Sutton, Sarah Dewberry and Fabiana Chaparro contributed to this report.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company. Gov. Dan Patrick (R-TX) announced that a sports and event complex would temporarily accommodate up to 250 hospital patients awaiting discharge, unable to be released to homes without power.\n\nPatrick, who is acting as governor while Gov. Greg Abbott (R-TX) is abroad, said nursing homes and assisted living centers were of utmost priority.\n\nAccording to the Federal Emergency Management Agency, 16 hospitals were operating on generator power Tuesday morning.\n\nBrad Tutunjian, vice president of regulatory policy at CenterPoint Energy, which serves a significant portion of the Houston area, supported the utility's readiness and response efforts.\n\n\"From my perspective to have a storm pass at 3 p.m. in the afternoon, have those crews come in in the late evening, and have everything ready by 5 a.m. to go out and get out and left without power as powerful tropical storm Beryl, which brought damaging winds and floods, slammed into Texas early on Monday.\n\nBeryl brought Schools, businesses, offices, and financial institutions to a halt soon after it made landfall near Matagorda as a category 1 hurricane, the National Hurricane Centre said on Monday evening.\n\nAlso Read | Hurricane Beryl Update: Storm Weakens to Tropical Depression After Slamming Into Texas As Category-1 Hurricane.\n\nFlooding, rains and tornadoes were possible across portions of eastern Texas, Western Louisiana and Arkansas, the centre said.\n\nTwo people were killed after trees fell on homes, and a civilian employee of the Houston Police Department was killed when he was trapped in flood waters.\n\nAlso Read | PM Modi Russia Visit: Prime Minister Narendra Modi, Russian President Vladimir Putin Hold Informal Meet at Novo-Ogaryovo Residence (See Pics and Video).\n\nOne more person was reported dead in a fire incident.\n\nOfficials asked residents to stay home on Monday night as floodwaters from Beryl began to recede, and crews started surveying the damage.\n\n\"Don't let the clear skies fool you,\" Mayor John Whitmire said at a news conference.\n\n\"There were no immediate reports of widespread structural damages,\" he said. \"We still have dangerous circumstances.\"\n\nHarris County Judge Lina Hidalgo offered a similar message: \"We're not out of the woods yet... Let's just wait until tomorrow. Doing a damage assessment on your own property is one thing, but driving around unnecessarily -- we really ask that you avoid it.\"\n\nLt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is leading the state while Texas Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country, said it will be a \"multiple-day process to get power restored\" to the about 2.7 million customers across Texas experiencing outages.\n\nPatrick said CenterPoint officials told him they were sending in 11,500 people to help with restoration efforts.\n\nThe workers are coming both from out of state and from unaffected counties in Texas, Patrick said during a late Monday afternoon storm briefing in Austin.\n\nHigh water, tree damage and other debris are expected to make roadways unsafe for the next several days, according to officials with TxDOT's Houston district.\n\nSeveral neighbourhoods in Fortbend County, worst affected, saw debris from huge trees on intersections and roads, besides power outages and rising flood waters.\n\nOther neighbourhoods, such as Katy, Cinco Ranch, Cross Creek and Fulshear, have been without power since early Monday morning.\n\nTraffic is off the roads or very sporadic, as very few traffic signals are operational, but all others are down.\n\nStorm damage has largely been limited to downed branches, broken fences and uprooted trees.\n\n\"There isn't much structural damage, just broken branches and stuff,\" said Texas Highway Patrol Officer Corey Robinson, who has been on duty since 6 a.m. on Monday.\n\n\"We've got more patrol officers coming in from other cities.\"\n\nSchool closures will stretch into Tuesday for many of southeast Texas' K-12 districts and higher education institutions. He went to check the generator and she went to find flashlights and candles. Minutes later, a large tree tore through their home in Wharton, Texas, about 60 miles southwest of Houston.\n\n\"When I got into the kitchen, [there was a] The big crash and the ceiling fell,\" he told NBC News. \"We were in the living room and we moved -- that's where all the spiky wood came down from the ceiling, so we could have been killed.\"\n\nAs of Tuesday afternoon, more than 2.1 million customers were without power PowerOutage.us, Including 1.7 million customers of Centerpoint Energy, a major supplier to the Houston area.\n\nThe company said that Over 800,000 were recovered It said it would restore connections in the past 24 hours and another million by the end of Wednesday, but its crews are battling high water to reach some areas after more than a foot of rain fell in the past 24 hours.\n\nDowned trees and downed power lines from strong winds across the greater Houston area, the company said, had a worse-than-expected impact due to a slight shift in the storm's course.\n\n\"We didn't really sleep,\" Eva Costancio said as she watched a large tree fall across power lines in her neighborhood in the Houston suburb of Rosenberg. {"uri": "2024-07-416123487", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "11:08:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T11:08:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T10:48:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4862745106220245, "url": "https://weather.com/storms/hurricane/news/2024-07-09-power-still-out-aftermath-beryl-wrecks-houston-texas-area-flood", "title": "Eight Dead After Beryl Wrecks Into Texas, Power Still Out", "body": "Beryl has moved on from Texas. However, the storm's impact is still being felt across the region. After making landfall as a Category 1 hurricane early Monday, Beryl left widespread destruction including power outages, tornadoes and severe flooding. At least eight people are dead including one person who is thought to have died from a lightning strike.\n\nPower Restoration\n\nOne of the most-felt impacts from Beryl in the U.S. was power outages. At one point, more than 2.5 million homes and businesses in Texas were without power. Efforts are ongoing to restore electricity. CenterPoint Energy, a provider in control of a major portion of the outages, says they expect to restore energy for a million homes and businesses by the end of Wednesday.\n\nTornadoes, Destruction and Fatalities\n\nAfter barreling through the Caribbean, Beryl caused a mess along the American Gulf of Mexico coast. Strong winds knocked down tree limbs, the cause of at least two deaths in Texas. In Houston, a First Tier Civilian employee with Houston Police Department found himself trapped in flooding on Houston Avenue and tragically died, according to official sources. One person is dead in Louisiana; a resident was killed by a falling tree from a possible tornado near the town of Benton. All said, at least eight people are dead; a toll that may rise as search and rescue efforts continue across the region.\n\nHouston Mayor John Whitmire urged residents to stay safe and check on their neighbors. \"Houstonians need to know we're working around the clock so you will be safe,\" Whitemire said at a Monday briefing according to the Associated Press. President Biden has pledged federal support for recovery efforts. Cooling centers and food distribution points have been opened across the state of Texas. Locals can find resources by searching the internet for their specific county. Residents can also search for \"Extreme Heat Cooling Centers\" via Texas 2-1-1.\n\nEnvironmental Impact\n\nIndustrial facilities said that, due to power disruptions, gas flaring was necessary with at least one plant calling it a, \"safe combustion of excess gasses.\" The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality requires companies to share emissions data within 24 hours of a flaring event like this.\n\nWhat Is Next For Beryl?\n\nBeryl's remnants are expected to bring more severe weather to additional states. Heavy rain and a few tornadoes can be expected in parts of the Midwest and Northeast through Wednesday. {"uri": "8216193946", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "03:44:19", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T03:44:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T03:43:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4745098054409027, "url": "https://www.newsdrum.in/international/hurricane-beryl-kills-four-plunges-three-million-into-darkness-in-texas-5551469", "title": "Hurricane Beryl kills four, plunges three million into darkness in Texas", "body": "Houston, Jul 9 (PTI) At least four people were killed, and nearly three million homes and businesses were left without power as powerful tropical storm Beryl, which brought damaging winds and floods, slammed into Texas early on Monday.\n\nBeryl brought Schools, businesses, offices, and financial institutions to a halt soon after it made landfall near Matagorda as a category 1 hurricane, the National Hurricane Centre said on Monday evening.\n\nFlooding, rains and tornadoes were possible across portions of eastern Texas, Western Louisiana and Arkansas, the centre said.\n\nTwo people were killed after trees fell on homes, and a civilian employee of the Houston Police Department was killed when he was trapped in flood waters.\n\nOne more person was reported dead in a fire incident.\n\nOfficials asked residents to stay home on Monday night as floodwaters from Beryl began to recede, and crews started surveying the damage.\n\n\"Don't let the clear skies fool you,\" Mayor John Whitmire said at a news conference.\n\n\"There were no immediate reports of widespread structural damages,\" he said. \"We still have dangerous circumstances.\" Harris County Judge Lina Hidalgo offered a similar message: \"We're not out of the woods yet... Let's just wait until tomorrow. Doing a damage assessment on your own property is one thing, but driving around unnecessarily -- we really ask that you avoid it.\" Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is leading the state while Texas Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country, said it will be a \"multiple-day process to get power restored\" to the about 2.7 million customers across Texas experiencing outages.\n\nPatrick said CenterPoint officials told him they were sending in 11,500 people to help with restoration efforts.\n\nThe workers are coming both from out of state and from unaffected counties in Texas, Patrick said during a late Monday afternoon storm briefing in Austin.\n\nHigh water, tree damage and other debris are expected to make roadways unsafe for the next several days, according to officials with TxDOT's Houston district.\n\nSeveral neighbourhoods in Fortbend County, worst affected, saw debris from huge trees on intersections and roads, besides power outages and rising flood waters.\n\nOther neighbourhoods, such as Katy, Cinco Ranch, Cross Creek and Fulshear, have been without power since early Monday morning.\n\nTraffic is off the roads or very sporadic, as very few traffic signals are operational, but all others are down.\n\nStorm damage has largely been limited to downed branches, broken fences and uprooted trees.\n\n\"There isn't much structural damage, just broken branches and stuff,\" said Texas Highway Patrol Officer Corey Robinson, who has been on duty since 6 a.m. on Monday.\n\n\"We've got more patrol officers coming in from other cities.\" School closures will stretch into Tuesday for many of southeast Texas' K-12 districts and higher education institutions. Though schools reported minimal damage no electricity following the storm is a matter of concern.\n\nBeryl, after weakening into a tropical storm, was far less powerful than the Category-5 behemoth that tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean last weekend. {"uri": "8217289468", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "16:08:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T16:08:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T16:07:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4705882370471954, "url": "https://www.insurancejournal.com/news/southcentral/2024/07/09/783027.htm", "title": "Houston Will Feel Like 106F as Millions Remain Without Power", "body": "Houston is set for a dangerous bout of heat as more than 2 million homes and businesses remain without power in the area around the nation's fourth-largest city after Hurricane Beryl's battering.\n\nThe region is under a heat advisory, with heat index values -- a measure of how hot it feels when humidity is factored in -- forecast as high as 106F (41C), the US National Weather Service said, warning of the possibility of illness under the extreme conditions. Actual temperatures will exceed 90F.\n\nWhile those temperatures aren't unusual for Houston at this time of year, scorching weather and humidity combined with the lack of power will make for brutal conditions, as people won't be able to turn on air conditioners for a break from the heat. The sweltering conditions and significant power outages are both expected to last for days.\n\n\"It can be pretty uncomfortable, especially without power,\" said Bob Oravec, lead forecaster at the US Weather Prediction Center. Real temperatures will likely be in the mid 90s for the next few days, which is typical for this time of year. \"It's average hot, but that's still pretty hot.\"\n\nAs of Tuesday morning, about 2.3 million homes and businesses were still without power in eastern Texas, concentrated in the Houston area, according to PowerOutage.us. More than 75% of those without power are customers of CenterPoint Energy Inc., the Houston area's main electric utility.\n\nRead More: Texas' Extreme Weather Pileups Point to World's Climate Future\n\nBeryl left the Houston metro area -- home to roughly 7 million -- a morass of flooded streets, downed trees, darkened traffic lights and power lines lying on the ground. At least three deaths were blamed on the storm. Beryl, a Category 1 hurricane when it struck Texas early Monday, already had killed 11 people in a week-long rampage across the Caribbean.\n\nBased on current progress with damage assessment and initial restoration, CenterPoint expects to have power restored to 1 million impacted customers by the end of day on July 10, the company said in a statement late Monday.\n\nThe storm, now a tropical depression, is sweeping across the South, with heavy rainfall expected in the Mississippi Valley. Tornadoes are possible across Missouri, Tennessee, Kentucky, Illinois, Indiana and Ohio. Almost 35,000 homes and businesses are without power Tuesday in Louisiana and Arkansas.\n\nScorching weather is also set to bake western states this week, raising fire risks from Canada to Mexico. A million people are under an excessive heat warning in the US West, according to Bryan Jackson, a meteorologist at the Weather Prediction Center.\n\nLas Vegas on Sunday hit an all-time high temperature of 120F (49C). Palm Springs and Redding in California have also set records. Let's just wait until tomorrow. Doing a damage assessment on your own property is one thing, but driving around unnecessarily -- we really ask that you avoid it.\" Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, who is leading the state while Texas Gov. Greg Abbott is out of the country, said it will be a \"multiple-day process to get power restored\" to the about 2.7 million customers across Texas experiencing outages.\n\nPatrick said CenterPoint officials told him they were sending in 11,500 people to help with restoration efforts.\n\nThe workers are coming both from out of state and from unaffected counties in Texas, Patrick said during a late Monday afternoon storm briefing in Austin.\n\nHigh water, tree damage and other debris are expected to make roadways unsafe for the next several days, according to officials with TxDOT's Houston district.\n\nSeveral neighbourhoods in Fortbend County, worst affected, saw debris from huge trees on intersections and roads, besides power outages and rising flood waters.\n\nOther neighbourhoods, such as Katy, Cinco Ranch, Cross Creek and Fulshear, have been without power since early Monday morning.\n\nTraffic is off the roads or very sporadic, as very few traffic signals are operational, but all others are down.\n\nStorm damage has largely been limited to downed branches, broken fences and uprooted trees.\n\n\"There isn't much structural damage, just broken branches and stuff,\" said Texas Highway Patrol Officer Corey Robinson, who has been on duty since 6 a.m. on Monday.\n\n\"We've got more patrol officers coming in from other cities.\" School closures will stretch into Tuesday for many of southeast Texas' K-12 districts and higher education institutions. Though schools reported minimal damage no electricity following the storm is a matter of concern.\n\nBeryl, after weakening into a tropical storm, was far less powerful than the Category-5 behemoth that tore a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean last weekend. {"uri": "8216715189", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-09", "time": "10:16:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-09T10:16:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-09T10:13:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4274509847164154, "url": "https://newsday.co.tt/2024/07/09/trinis-safe-in-texas-after-beryl/", "title": "Trinis safe in Texas after Beryl - Trinidad and Tobago Newsday", "body": "HURRICANE Beryl continued to wreak havoc, despite weakening to category one, as it hit Texas, US on Monday morning. It has since weakened to a tropical storm.\n\nInternational news outlet AP reported there being heavy rains and powerful winds along Texas's coast, leaving over two million people without electricity. Many streets were also badly flooded.\n\nAP added that at least two people were killed.\n\nSeveral parts of Texas were put under flash flood, storm surge, tornado and tropical storm warnings.\n\nCalishia Mendoza, a TT national who moved to Houston, Texas last year told Newsday her faith in God and constant praying helped her through the storm.\n\nShe said she knew God would \"cover (her) with his hands and keep (her) safe.\n\n\"I was a little terrified but, of course, my mom also kept me calm and prayed as well.\n\n\"It was the first time I experienced a hurricane...I served in the army and normally get to see and experience the aftermath when they sent us out to help the affected areas, but actually being in the middle of it was a new experience for me overall.\"\n\nShe said electricity fluctuated a lot but as of Monday afternoon, it was back for good.\n\n\"I'm truly blessed to have power right now because I know some areas are out of power,\" she added.\n\nShe said while her home was not flooded, she is yet to go outside as it is \"still a little windy.\n\n\"I was worried the whole time but I also kept my faith going and praying every chance I got.\n\n\"I'm grateful to be okay right now as I know so many were affected and didn't have the outcome I did, and I will continue to pray for Houston and everyone affected.\n\n\"Living here, I have notice how resilient these people are and I know they will get through this. I know we all will .\n\nA TT national who preferred not to be named told Newsday she was in Houston, Texas, but for vacation. On Saturday morning, she said, the weather was fine and sunny. She is staying at a hotel.\n\nHowever, around 2am on Monday, \"There was heavy rainfall, wind, lightning, thunder...It was a lot of wind too so the building was kind of shaking.\"\n\nShe said this was the first time she experienced a hurricane and it was really scary.\n\n\"I was really worried. And if this was a category one, then I don't want to ever experience a category two.\"\n\nShe said she remained in touch with her family and friends home, who were also worried about her and her safety. She said at no point did the hotel lose power or any parts of it flooded.\n\n\"There was no flooding or anything like that but when you looked outside, you would see No Parking signs blown to the side, trees bending...But inside, we were pretty safe.\"\n\nShe said hotel guests talked to each other about the experience in shared spaces. She is set to leave Texas on Tuesday.\n\nThe Texas Division of Emergency Management has urged all who experienced property damage to submit an online report via its website.\n\nIt also advised, through its social media platforms, that residents not drive through floodwaters, use flashlights instead of candles, be careful with portable generators and chainsaws, and to not push themselves too much during cleanup efforts.\n\nIn a press conference on Monday afternoon, Houston mayor John Whitmire said the city was experiencing \"the dirty side of a dirty hurricane.\n\n\"Shelter in place. It made landfall as a weakened hurricane with sustained winds of 80 mph (128 kpm) after having already torn a deadly path of destruction through parts of Mexico and the Caribbean.\n\nIn the Houston area, Beryl toppled transmission lines, uprooted trees and snapped branches that crashed onto power lines. By Wedesday afternoon -- nearly 60 hours after landfall -- about 1.3 million homes and businesses were still without power Wednesday, according to CenterPoint Energy. The utility said it had restored electricity to nearly 1 million customers who lost power during Beryl.\n\nTypically sweltering summer heat along the Texas coast has added to the urgency of restoring power.
